fullName: PHY-1080-1, OBSERVING THE COSMOS (LAB) DIPANKAR BHATTACHARYA
title: OBSERVING THE COSMOS (LAB) DIPANKAR BHATTACHARYA,
description:
Observing the Cosmos [PHY-1080/ AST-1080] [PHY-1080/ AST-1080-1]

Faculty Name
Dipankar Bhattacharya [dipankar.bhattacharya@ashoka.edu.in] ,Shwetha Prakash [shwetha.prakash_ug23@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Instructor: Dipankar Bhattacharya

This will be a hands-on laboratory course with both indoor and outdoor experiments.  Students will learn how to handle an optical telescope and a radio telescope, a theodolite, a sextant and other related equipment.  They will measure the temperature of the Sun and several other bright stars, learn how to measure distances using parallax and how to infer the latitude and longitude of a location from the position of stars.  Variable stars like Cepheids that are important distance indicators will be studied.  The experiments will include the measurement of Doppler effect and the detection of rotation of our galaxy using the Doppler shift of the spectral line of hydrogen at the radio frequency of 1.4 Gigahertz.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Recommended reading:

  1. Observational Astronomy, D. Scott Birney, G. Gonzalez and D. Oesper, Cambridge University Press
  2. A Practical Guide to Observational Astronomy, M. Shane Burns, CRC Press
Attendance Policy

Attendance is compulsory

title: PHYSICS OF THE UNIVERSE
description:
Physics of the Universe [PHY-2850/ AST-2850] [PHY-2850/ AST-2850-1]

Faculty Name
Kandaswamy Subramanian [kandaswamy.subramanian@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Instructor:  Kandaswamy Subramanian

This course will introduce the students to the contents of the universe and the physical processes that occur in them.  It will describe how, starting from the big bang, the universe expanded to its present size, what forces it experienced, the nature of dark matter and dark energy, how galaxies, stars and planets formed, the origin and properties of compact objects such as neutron stars and black holes and the predicted future course of evolution of the universe.  The prime role of General Theory of Relativity in many of these processes will be highlighted.

Syllabus:

(1) Contents of the Universe from Stars/Galaxies to largest scales
(2) The smooth expanding Universe: Hubble law-redshift-Newtonian cosmology-Dark matter, Dark energy
(3) The Hot Universe: Big bang-Thermal history-Nucleosynthesis-Atom formation-Cosmic Microwave Background Radiation-Puzzles in cosmology-inflation-seed fluctuations-sound waves
(4) Structuring the universe: gravitational instability-spherical collapse-galaxy formation-dark ages-21 cm line-reionization-lyman alpha clouds-galaxies
(5) Gas in galaxies-atomic and molecular probes-formation of stars and planets-stellar structure and

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Pre-requisite (desirable): Physical science at the std XI-XII level, FCs on QRMT and PoS

Recommended reading:

  1. The Physical Universe, Frank H. Shu, University Science Books
  2. Foundations of Astrophysics, Barbara M. Ryden and Bradley M. Peterson, Cambridge University Press
  3. An Introduction to Modern Astrophysics, B.W. Carroll and D.A. Ostlie, Cambridge University Press
  4. Astrophysical Concepts, M. Harwit, Springer
  5. IGNOU PHE-15 Study Material
Grading Rubric

There will:

3 assignments of 10 marks, 2 quizes of 10 marks, 1 mid term of 20 marks and end exam of 30 marks

Attendance Policy

Attendance of 90% os classes is strongly recommended

title: THE VIOLENT UNIVERSE
description:
The Violent Universe [PHY-3860/ AST-3860] [PHY-3860/ AST-3860-1]

Faculty Name
Dipankar Bhattacharya [dipankar.bhattacharya@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Instructor: Dipankar Bhattacharya

Violent phenomena like energetic explosions, jet-like ejection of matter or sudden collapse of stars are very common in the Universe.  These phenomena play a key role in controlling the energetics of gas in galaxies and the synthesis and dispersal of heavy elements.   Of late, major emphasis has been placed globally on the study of such events and new information is emerging rapidly.  This course will acquaint the student with the physical processes associated with these violent events and the wealth of information that can be gleaned from them about the evolution of the universe.

Syllabus:

  1. Introduction to violent phenomena - explosions, implosions, ejections, jets - Big Bang, Novae, Supernovae, Gamma Ray Bursts, Solar Flares, Pulsars, Magnetars, Fast Radio Bursts, Accreting compact objects, Active Galactic Nuclei.
  2. Loss of Hydrostatic Equilibrium - Gravitational energy - Explosions and Implosions - Thermodynamic and Thermonuclear instability - Magnetospheric phenomena -  relevant time scales
  3. Collisions of planets, stars, galaxies and clusters; supernova remnants, Gamma Ray Burst afterglows; Radio Galaxies and Quasars
  4. Generation of Electromagnetic radiation, Gravitational Waves and Explosive Nucleosynthesis in violent events.
  5. Cosmological impact of violent events
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Pre-requisites (desirable): Physical science at the std XI-XII level, FCs on QRMT and PoS

Recommended reading:

  1. High Energy Astrophysics, M. Longair, Cambridge University Press
  2. Violent Phenomena in the Universe, J.V. Narlikar, Dover
Attendance Policy

Attendance requirement: 80%

title: ASTROPHYSICAL AND GEOPHYSICAL FLUID DYNAMICS
description:
Astrophysical and Geophysical Fluid Dynamics [PHY-4870/ AST-4870/ PHY-6870] [PHY-4870/ AST-4870/ PHY-6870-1]

Faculty Name
Kandaswamy Subramanian [kandaswamy.subramanian@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Instructor: Kandaswamy Subramanian

Fluid dynamics is at the heart of most  Astrophysical phenomena, and many of these processes have close parallels in Geophysics.  In this course the fluid dynamical principles will be introduced with specific applications to Astrophysical and Geophysical problems.  The topics covered will include hydrostatic equilibrium, accretion flows, shock waves, radiative gas dynamics and magnetohydrodynamics.

Syllabus:

Continuity, Euler and Navier-Stokes equations, Compressible and Incompressible fluids; Potential flows; Effect of rotation - cyclones and climate systems; Gasdynamics in gravitational field - Hydrostatic Equilibrium, Virial Theorem, Accretion flows; Shock Waves, Radiative Hydrodynamics; Induction equation and introduction to MHD - Terrestrial and Astrophysical Dynamos.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Pre-requisites: Classical Mechanics, Electromagnetism in the Light of Relativity

Recommended reading:

  1. The Physics of Fluids and Plasmas - An introduction for Astrophysicists, Arnab Rai Choudhuri, Cambridge University Press
  2. An introduction to Astrophysical Fluid Dynamics, M.J. Thompson, World Scientific
  3. Astrophysical Magnetic Fields, A. Shukurov and K. Subramanian, Cambridge University Press
  4. Fundamentals of Geophysical Fluid Dynamics, J.C. McWilliams, Cambridge University Press

 

Grading Rubric

There will be 3 assignments of 10 marks each, 2 quizzes of 10 marks, mid-term of 20 marks, end exam of 30 marks

Attendance Policy

Attendance of 75 percent of classes is strongly recommended

title: EVOLUTIONARY COGNITION
description:
Evolutionary Cognition [PSY-3012/ BIO-3204/ BIO-6204] [PSY-3012/ BIO-3204/ BIO-6204-1]

Faculty Name
Bittu R [bittu@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The goal of this course is to delve into the complicated question of how cognition has been shaped by Evolution. This question has been addressed by various disciplines, including the fields of “Evolutionary Psychology”, “Sociobiology” and “Physical Anthropology”. The common problem with the construction of the framework of these fields is the chain of untested assumptions underlying the historical ideas in the field, and the development of ideas unmoored to the physiological basis of either evolution or cognition. We will break down each model used to teach Evolutionary Psychology to critically examine each system, and each system feeds into a larger understanding of what is involved in the evolution of cognitive abilities. This course looks at the question of whether there are aspects of behaviour and cognition that do and do not seem to have evolved in particular evolutionary contexts.

The first step in our critical examination is to understand what evolution does and does not mean in a Darwinian framework; as well as whether and how cognition can be defined and accurately assessed. We look at what aspects of behaviour are hardwired, and what is plastic. We understand that evolution pertains to genetic changes, and get a quick understanding of what genetics constitutes. We then learn about epigenetics, gene expression, how the framework of genes and their expression drives physiological development of an embryo, how the brain develops as a subset of the body from a genetic framework, and about the relative ridigity and plasticity of parts of the brain during development and in adulthood. We then visit various questions in evolutionary cognition, focussing on the historical debates between the people who began extending the framework of evolution to understand behaviour and cognition.

 

Learning Outcomes

The learning goals for this class are to primarily learn how to distinguish an evidence-based understanding of evolutionary cognition from what have been called “just-so” stories, which clog the public and even scientific realm.

 

Classes will be structured with lectures interspersed with discussions and student presentations. Students will take responsibility for presenting specific papers and sections of books to the rest of the class. This will be a reading and discussion-heavy course.

 

The main expectation of students is that they pay full attention in class, alerting the TF or me, through class discussions or by posting on discussion fora if there is anything they do not understand. Piazza posts are encouraged to be public, so that other students can benefit from reading responses to questions asked, although they can certainly be anonymous.

Grading Rubric

This class will have one assignment and one presentation per student in class, where you can chose a topic to research and critically analyse the literature on the issue and develop your thinking on the question. Students can choose between a presentation and assignment format for their third submission. Each submission, whether assignment or presentation, will count for 30% each of your final grade.

 

Your participation in class or even by email will count towards the remaining 10%. This means that attendance is in some sense graded. Also note that your participation during presentations carry more weight than participation in other classes. The breakdown of this 10% is: 2% sharing of all presentations and assignments on piazza, 2% attentive listening, 4% attendance, 2% general participation in class or outside class during the semester (note that participation is calculated relative to the maximum participation score).

Attendance Policy

Attendance: will be marked as a component of the participation grade. Missing class is a student’s loss and will have a marginal impact on the class participation grades. For students who miss class for unavoidable reasons, they can come to me during office hours for help.

title: INTRODUCTION TO BIOLOGY I: GENETICS & EVOLUTION
description:
Introduction to Biology I: Genetics and Evolution [BIO-1200] [BIO-1200-1]

Faculty Name
Imroze Khan [imroze.khan@ashoka.edu.in] ,Test Faculty 1 [testfaculty1@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

For a biologist, the alternative to thinking in evolutionary terms is not to think at all.
— Peter B. Medawar (Nobel Laureate, 1960)

This is a basic introductory course for students who want to learn how modern biology started its journey in the mid-19th century and continues to mature till date. I will begin by discussing the grandeur of evolution, arguably the greatest show of the living world, and how it is irreversibly intertwined with genetics. Using historical contexts, I will introduce key debates in Genetics and Evolution that shrugged the initial days of Modern Biological Synthesis and then gradually move into advanced concepts of Evolutionary theory and Mendelian Genetics that will lay the foundation of the Biology curriculum at Ashoka. 

TENTATIVE COURSE STRUCTURE

Note:

- Subject to changes based on class room dynamics

- There might be additional make-up classes, if needed

- Tentative reading source is mentioned, but it is unlikely that only one source will be used. Hence, I haven’t specified the chapters. This information will be shared during the class

Topics to be covered

- Breaking the Ice: Intertwined strands of Genetics and Evolution in the era of Climate change and Infectious Disease

- Rise of Evolutionary Thoughts and Mendelism: Defying the Great Expectations

- Evidence for Evolution (Text: Mark Ridley/ Herron & Freeman)

- An Introduction to Natural Selection and Variation (Text: Mark Ridley)

- Mendel meets Darwin : Introduction to Genetical Theory of Natural Selection (Mark Ridley)

- Transmission Genetics I: The Dance of Genes (Griffith)

- Transmission Genetics II: Laws of probability, Crosses and the Genius of Mendel (Biology: A global approach by Campbell)

- Brief Introduction to Sexual Life-Cycles and Meiosis (Biology: A global approach by Campbell)

- Analysing Pedigrees (Benjamin Pierce)

- Extension of Mendelism: Dominance relationships; Multiple allelism; Lethal alleles; Pleiotropy; Epistasis; Penetrance and expressivity; Phenocopy; Polygenic inheritance (Benjamin Pierce)

- Introduction to Population Genetics I: Selection and Drift (Mark Ridley)

- Introduction to Population Genetics II: Migration, Non-random Mating and Inbreeding (Herron and Freeman)

- What is Adaptive Evolution? What is not? (Mark Ridley)

- Sexual selection I: "Love is the Ring of Fire" (Herron and Freeman)

- Sexual selection II: Why sex evolved? (Herron and Freeman)

- Eusociality: Evolution of social living (Herron and Freeman)

- Evolution of Life-history Traits (Herron and Freeman)

- Speciation and Seeding Concepts of Biogeography (Herron and Freeman (Ch.16)

- Linkage and chromosome I: The Fly Room; Chromosomal Basis of Sex; Sex Chromosome Systems (Griffith)

- Linkage, Chromosome and Evolution: Sex-linkage; Linkage map, Introduction to Multi-locus Population Genetics (Griffith)

- Life-history Evolution 

- Sexual conflict 

- Microbial Genetics I: A brief introduction to Bacterial genetics (Griffith)

- Microbial genetics II: Extending into phage genetics (Griffith)

- The Rise of Double Helix: Nucleic Acid and Inheritance I (Benjamin Pierce)

- Nucleic Acid and Inheritance II: Seeding the realms of Molecular Genetics (Benjamin Pierce)

- Gene editing

- Concluding lecture: So, how far did intertwining Genetics and Evolution make sense? Revisiting the awes of 21st century: Antibiotic resistance, Climate Change and Infectious Disease

 

Learning Outcomes

LEARNING OUTCOMES

This course primarily aims to strengthen the philosophy of studying Biology where understanding concepts and the ability to synthesize ideas are more important than mere acquisition of mundane information. At the end of the course, students will not only be familiar with the key concepts of Evolutionary Processes and genetics, but also understand how they can collectively contribute to the development of almost other areas of modern biology, including our current research efforts on climate change, antibiotic-drug resistance and emerging infectious diseases such as SARS, MERS and COVID-19.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

MATERIALS AND RESOURCES:

The recommended textbooks for this course are

- Evolution by Mark Ridley (3rd edition)

- Evolutionary Analysis by Herron and Freeman (4th or 5th edition)

- Biology: A Global Approach by Campbell, Urry, Cain, Wasserman, Minorsky and Reece (11th edition).

- Genetics: A conceptual approach by Benjamin Pierce

- An Introduction to Genetic Analysis by Anthony Griffiths (8th edition).

Few copies of these books are already available in the library. All the books are available in Amazon

Grading Rubric

TBA

Attendance Policy

Attendance is mandatory

fullName: BIO-3423 / BIO-6423, PHYSIOLOGY, SOUGATA ROY, KASTURI PAL
title: PHYSIOLOGY,
description:
Physiology [BIO-3423/ BIO-6423] [BIO-3423/ BIO-6423-1]

Faculty Name
Kasturi Pal [kasturi.pal@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sougata Roy [sougata.roy@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course consists of two parts cellular and animal physiology

Cellular Physiology

This course will mainly focus on cellular physiology and provide some basic knowledge of how cell functions. The theory Course is designed keeping in mind that the students have already acquired a detailed overview of genetics, cell and molecular biology, microbiology and biochemistry. Through these courses you have been introduced to discreet modules of biological phenomena. However, these are all part of one continuum. A cell is an organized state of chemical reactions with well-defined boundary conditions, which facilitate balance between energy vs entropy. The viscosity of the cellular fluid and rate of diffusion/movement of various components in and out cells maintain relative concentrations of biomolecules in time and space. Cellular Physiology deals with such fine balance between various states of biological reactions/events.

Human Physiology

The overall learning objective of this course will be to understand the concepts regulating tissue/organ functions necessary for achieving homeostasis in living organisms. The students will learn how basic concepts in cell biology, biochemistry and biophysics work in conjunction to regulate organ functions. The lecture topics will cover nerve-muscle physiology, sense organs, cardiac cycle, blood coagulation, digestion, endocrinology and excretion of nitrogenous waste.

Learning Outcomes

Cellular Physiology

This course will delve deep into Introduction to Cellular Physiology, How cells generate energy?,  How cells make their own food? How some cells maintain their water balance? How cells fix the atmospheric Nitrogen, How cells migrate?- Phototaxis and Chemotaxis, How cells emit light?, How cells sense time? 

Human Physiology

The students should be able understand how various tissues and organs work synergystically to maintain homeostasis

 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Cellular Physiology

Genetics and evolution, cell and molecular biology and biochemistry.

Materials will be provided during the class

Human physiology

Guyton & Hall Text book of Medical Physiology
Berne & Levy Physiology

Further reading materials in the form of recently published manuscripts will be provided during lecture and discussion

 

Grading Rubric

Cellular Physiology

a) Class Participation (5 marks).   b) One best score out of 2 exams will be considered. Each exam will be of 20 marks. The written exam will consist of short answer, problems and/or multiple choice questions. (25 marks, 25*1=25). The option for the other exam is to provide an opportunitunity to appear for the exam if you have missed the first exam or to better the score of the first exam. That means you have to attend at least one of the two exams.  c) Class assignments (20 Marks).

Animal Physiology

Quiz=10

Assignment=10

Final exam=30

Final score from both the section will be added and then graded on a curve

Attendance Policy

Cellular Physiology

1) Plagiarism or academic dishonesty (cheating on exams) will not be tolerated and will be dealt with utmost seriousness.

2) Attendance at theory and examinations are mandatory. There will be two theory exams and you have to attend atleast one of them. However, I encourage all to attend both for a better grasp of whatever you learnt in class and readings. If you miss any theory class, you must find out what you missed and make sure you understand it. If you need help regarding the course please request for appointment by dropping emails to Pooja Vaid (pooja.vaid_phd19@ashoka.edu.in).  3) It is expected that you will keep up to date notebooks for theory course. 4) I strongly advise not to use cell phones during the class.  Please silence your cell phones during the class. Laptops and tablets are allowed but strictly for note taking purpose. Cell phones or laptops are not allowed during exams unless advised otherwise.

Animal Physiology

70% attendance is mandatory to appear for final exam 

Any form of academic dishonesty is unacceptable

title: DECODING GENETICALLY MODIFIED CROPS: THE GLOBAL POLITICS OF AGRICULTURE AND BIOTECHNOLOGY
description:
Decoding Genetically Modified Crops: The Global Politics of Agriculture and Biotechnology [ES-3411/ SOA-3502/ POL-3061/ BIO-3411] [ES-3411/ SOA-3502/ POL-3061/ BIO-3411-1]

Faculty Name
Aniket Pankaj Aga [aniket.aga@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Decoding genetically modified (GM) crops: The global politics of agriculture and biotechnology
Spring 2023
Tue/Thu - 8:30 am - 10:00 am

AC 01 LR 103

Course description

Genetically modified (GM) are the subject of fierce global controversies. Nearly every aspect about them is disputed – from their role in “feeding the world” and their impacts with respect to yield and environment to regulatory policies and peoples’ notions of choice and ethics. This course examines the GM debate by looking at the transformations of agriculture and agricultural sciences in the 20th century. It analyzes how private industry has sought profits from agriculture, and the consequent impacts on farming communities. This will help us grasp deeper issues that are often lost in heated anti/pro-GM arguments. Surveying controversies in India, the USA and other parts of the world, the course will demonstrate how the GM debate is shaped by the inter-related shifts in law, politics, and science. By way of examining the case of Bt cotton, Golden Rice, Bt brinjal among others, the course ultimately invites the question: Where do GM crops fit in the landscape of the burning issues faced by the average farmer, if at all?

More broadly, the questions we will consider in this class are, in fact, relevant to most technologies incident upon agriculture, and on the relationship between technology and society, in general. Our learnings from this course will carry over to a larger set of issues than GM crops alone.

This is a seminar course i.e. it is a discussion-oriented course that relies on close reading of research. This course will involve a good amount of reading. 

Learning Outcomes

Students will…

1. Study the relationship between agricultural sciences and GM crops.

2. Study the questions of public interest in different classes of GM crops, particularly insect-resistant crops, herbicide tolerant crops, and Golden Rice.

3. Engage with the complexities of regulatory design.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Pre-requisites: None

title: ECOLOGY
description:
Ecology [BIO-3020/ BIO-6020/ ES-2101/ PHY-3020] [BIO-3020/ BIO-6020/ ES-2101/ PHY-3020-1]

Faculty Name
Shivani [shivani.krishna@ashoka.edu.in ] ;
Overview

The course will cover a range of topics from individuals to ecosystems with an emphasis on theoretical foundations and recent developments in the field. We will begin with how ecological understanding is achieved, how conditions and resources influence individual species and then move to processes at higher levels of organization and end with rethinking some of the big questions in ecology. The topics covered will include physiological ecology, population ecology, species interactions, community ecology, succession and disturbance; ecosystem ecology, and biogeochemistry. Topics introduced in the lectures will be followed by in class-activities (and simulations) and discussions. For discussion sessions, I will suggest classic and recent research papers and students will lead discussions based on those. The course will allow reflecting on uncertainty and variation in natural processes from individual behavior to ecosystem services. It is recommended strongly to take Genetics and Evolution course prior to this since this course will build on some of the modules covered in that course.

Learning Outcomes

Towards the end of this course, students will be able to (a) understand how ecologists empirically study processes occurring at various scales and apply evolutionary thinking to these processes (b) integrate proximate and ultimate factors to understand natural processes (c) quantitatively synthesize ecological research (d) explore applications of ecological concepts such as conservation, landscape management.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Begon, M., Harper, J. L., & Townsend, C. R. Ecology. Individuals, populations and communities. Blackwell scientific publications.

Scott, G. (2009). Essential animal behavior. John Wiley & Sons.

Davies, N. B., Krebs, J. R., & West, S. A. (2012). An Introduction to behavioural ecology. John Wiley & Sons.

Grading Rubric

Grading scheme for undergraduate students:

Absolute grading system will be followed for the course

Assignments - 40% (2 assignments of 20 marks each)

Paper discussions and presentations- 10%

Midterm (in class)- 20%

Final (in class)- 20%

Class participation and attendance- 10%

There will be two take-home assignments (20 marks each) and two examinations (midterm and final). A list of research papers will be circulated towards the second week of the course for discussions and presentations.

For graduate students:

Paper discussions and presentations- 10%; Assignments - 20% (2 assignments of 20 marks each); Reaction paper/critique paper- 30% (2 papers of 15 marks each); Midterm- 20%; Final- 20%

Graduate students are required to submit two written papers: 1500-word critique papers briefly summarizing and critically evaluating published research work, presenting personal viewpoints along with evidence backed by constructive criticism on a specific concept or research article.

Attendance Policy

No more than three unexcused absences will be allowed.

Attachment
Ecology course_Spring 2023.pdf

title: ADVANCED NEUROSCIENCE
description:
Advanced Neuroscience [PSY-3011/ BIO-3114/ BIO-4114/ BIO-6114] [PSY-3011/ BIO-3114/ BIO-4114/ BIO-6114-1]

Faculty Name
Bittu R [bittu@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

In this class, we will put together a series of topics in neuroscience for further study. A rough set of topics is provided in the syllabus, but we can explore really any other system that people are interested in. Every week, one class will involve teaching, and the other will involve discussion and presentations. In the second class, students take turns contributing to the collective understanding of the field by presenting individually selected readings, based on your own interest.  Then we will collectively discuss advances in each field, relying on looking up fresh primary research papers together.

Learning Outcomes

The goal of this class is for students to explore various topics in neuroscience that give one a sense of the possible framework of computation through electrical signaling by wet, messy, living systems. The introduction to neuroscience course should have already given you all a sense of how single neurons perform basic computations of addition and subtraction and how elementary circuits might perform more complicated computations. We will explore how these multi neuron circuits work in this course not through textbook material or conventional teaching, but rather through reading primary scientific material.

Grading Rubric

Grading is equally divided between assignments and presentation - one assignment, one presentation, and one choice between an assignment and a presentation. 

 

Your participation in class or even by email will count towards the remaining 10%. In terms of class participation, questions in class will be counted, as will engaging  by email, etc. Your attendance is a part of your participation grade.

Attendance Policy

Attendance: will be tracked for class participation, but not as a barrier to doing exams, etc. Missing class is a student’s loss and through the participation grade, there are built-in rewards for attending.

fullName: BIO-2202-1, CELL BIOLOGY AND GENETICS LAB, KASTURI PAL, ANUP PADMANABHAN, RAMA AKONDY, LASSYA SAMHITA
title: CELL BIOLOGY AND GENETICS LAB,
description:
Cell Biology and Genetics Lab [BIO-2202] [BIO-2202-1]

Faculty Name

title: FORCE AND MOTION IN BIOLOGY
description:
Force and Motion in Biology [BIO-3454/ BIO-4454/ PHY-4454] [BIO-3454/ BIO-4454/ PHY-4454-1]

Faculty Name
Anup Padmanabhan [anup.padmanabhan@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Modern biology is changing rapidly, and it has become unimaginable to teach biology in silos without discussing the underlying physical and chemical processes. One of the main precepts behind this course is to discuss and analyze the physical concepts underlying biological phenomena. This elective course is aimed at students who wish to understand how physical principles governing molecular interactions come together during biological processes. 

Learning Outcomes

The course will begin with simple order-of-magnitude estimates in biology. We will then move on to the basic quantifiable physical properties of biomolecules. We will then discuss the application of principles of physics to complex biological systems.

The course will intend to discuss the following topics,

0) Scales and orders of magnitude estimates 

What are the units and dimensions involved / relevant in cells/biosystems

  - Types of cells, organelles, Cellular Organization, and functions

  - Brief idea of developmental processes

  - Time-scales and length scales of relevance

  - Description of Cellular Forces

 

1) The basic physics of the cell

- Self-assembly Lipid Membrane - GUV/tether drawing discussion

- Self-assembly - Physics

- Osmotic pressure, surface tension, curvature, polymerization, etc.

 

2) Diffusion and transport 

   - Diffusion in Biology - bacterial cell size control / Organism Body Patterning /  - promoter scanning/receptor binding - microrheology examples in the nucleus ( shiva’s work)

   - FCS ; FRAP etc

   - How do cells move material within them?

   - The Random Walk

   - The Diffusion equation

 

3) The fluid milieu 

- How bacteria swim  (in medium and inside a cell- pathogen)

- Varieties of motility - cilia ; ciliopathies ; sperm motility etc

   - The idea of viscosity

   - The Navier-Stokes equation

  

4) The fluid cell membrane 

   - The basic units of membranes - introduce cell cortex/blebs

   - Introduce exocytosis/endocytosis/proteins that bind and bend membranes - BAR / I- BAR/ F-BAR

   - Active deformations during Membrane mediated processes; exo/endo-cytosis, tether formation, etc. - Curvature due to protein interactions)

 

5) Biological polymers 

DNA / RNA / nucleotide -protein interactions

MT/ Actin - structural differences - Dynamic instability/treadmilling

   - What is a polymer?

   - Flexible and semiflexible polymers

   - DNA mechanics and force-extension relations

DNA / RNA Polymerases exerting force on DNA - effect on replication and transcription

 

6) Understanding molecular motors 

   - Biology of tracks and motors

Actin – Myosin

Force generation due to polymerization/contractility

Regulation of contractility -  Actomyosin regulatory proteins

Active Force generation during Cell Division and Cell Death

Microtubules – Dyneins and Kinesins

How do cells sense and respond to forces

Measuring Forces

Microscopy - Measuring response to Perturbation

AFM

Displacement - beads and micro-pillars

   - Physics out of equilibrium

   - Active matter ideas

   - Single-molecule experiments and information from them

                   

7) Emergent Properties in Biological Systems

We discuss cell migration as a collective cellular behaviour in the context of

Microbial systems - MinCDE /

Morphogenesis (Patterns - Turing patterns)

Wound Healing

Chemotaxis - Fruiting body formation (Disctyostelium discoideum)

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Course content is derived from multiple sources. Information regarding reading materials and textbooks will be shared with participants during the class.

Grading Rubric

Grading Rubric

Tutorials to be scheduled beyond the class hours

 

Assessment

1 or 2 quizzes

1 presentation of a published paper

Grading will be as per Ashoka's grading rubric. More information will be shared during the course.

 

 

Attendance Policy

Attendance is not mandatory but recommended.

fullName: BIO-3434 / BIO-4434 / BIO-6434, DISEASE BIOLOGY, ALOK BHATTACHARYA, L.S. SHASHIDHARA, SHRADDHA KARVE, ANURAG AGARWAL
description:
Disease Biology [BIO-3434/ BIO-4434/ BIO-6434] [BIO-3434/ BIO-4434/ BIO-6434-1]

Faculty Name
Alok Bhattacharya [alok.bhattacharya@ashoka.edu.in] ,Anurag Agrawal [anurag.agrawal@ashoka.edu.in] ,L S Shashidhara [ls.shashidhara@ashoka.edu.in] ,Shraddha Karve [shraddha.karve@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The aim of this course is to provide a bird’s eye view of human diseases.  The major emphasis will be to understand the complexity and diversity of different pathogenic mechanisms, the role played by genetic and environmental factors and the impact of all these diseases on the well-being of the population. The virulence mechanisms that different pathogens use to employ for survival and host invasion will be explored using a few key examples. Pathobiological processes that participate in tumour formation and progression will be discussed. We will also discuss the biological basis of the observed diversity of phenotypes in genetic disorders. Finally, we will introduce different approaches for the prevention and treatment of these diseases.   

There is no prerequisite, however, a background in cell and molecular biology and immunology will be helpful.

Lecture details

General introduction, infectious and non-infectious diseases   (1)

Microbial (viral, bacterial & protist) pathogens:

Viral pathogens: 

General aspects, what are viruses, classification and principle of virus structure (1)

Viral life cycle - entry, replication, exit (This could be 2 lectures depending upon the details) (1)

Viral control of host pathways (this would also include examples of why some viruses cause cancers) (1)

Immunity, viral evasion mechanisms and vaccines (1)

Bacterial pathogens:  

Structure, classification and nomenclature of bacterial pathogens (1)

Chemotaxis, Flagella, Protein Secretion, Pili & Adhesins (1)

Toxins and other virulence molecules (1)

Invasion, Intracellular Growth & immune escape (1)

Eukaryotic pathogens: 

Structure and life cycle of unicellular and multicellular eukaryotic pathogens (1)

Host invasion by different pathogens (1)

Pathogen response to host defence systems (1)

Drugs, vaccines and resistance (1)

Cancer: 

Mechanism of tumour formation  (2)

Tumour progression (2)

Current approaches to cancer treatment (2)

Genetic disorder: 

Basic concepts and epidemiology (1)

Diagnosis and pathology of genetic disorders of a few selected diseases (1)

Current approaches to treatment of genetic disorders (1)

Public health and human diseases (2) 

Learning Outcomes

Understanding of the biology of common viral, bacterial and parasitic pathogens

Understanding of the mechanisms by which these pathogens cause disease

Understanding about and cancer and their treatment

Understanding about genetic disorders, their epidemiology and treatment.

Grading Rubric

Mid semester examination:  50 marks

End semester examination:  50 marks

Relative grading

The marking system will be explained after each examination and the answer sheet will be shown at a pre-announced time. There will not be any further discussion on grading.

Attendance Policy

70% or more for the award of final grades

fullName: BIO-4029 / BIO-6029, RHYTHMS OF LIFE AND SLEEP, SOUGATA ROY, KRISHNA M
title: RHYTHMS OF LIFE AND SLEEP,
description:
Rhythms of Life and Sleep [BIO-4029/ BIO-6029/ PSY-3013] [BIO-4029/ BIO-6029/ PSY-3013-1]

Faculty Name
Krishna Venkata Melnattur [krishna.melnattur@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sougata Roy [sougata.roy@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview


Rhythms of Life

Rhythms ranging from milliseconds to a year are observed across all kingdom of life. We will learn about all rhythms with special emphasis on the 24 hour circadian rhythms. Living organisms adapt to the surrounding environment by coordinating different biological tasks with the 24 h rotation of the earth with the help of a cell-based clock, termed as the circadian clock. Circadian clock generates self-sustaining endogenous rhythms in physiology, behaviour and metabolism that have wide implications in eukaryotes and prokaryotes. This course will give a brief overview of how circadian clocks generate temporal rhythms and their significance in survival and adaptability of the organisms.

Sleep

Sleep is a brain state we enter into and exit from daily. Further, it is not just us humans who sleep - sleep is near ubiquitous among animals. Yet, sleep remains enigmatic. In this section, we will introduce the neuroscience of sleep. We will begin with a description of sleep phenomenology, go on to discuss the circuits and transmitters that regulate sleep,  talk about sleep disorders, and finally consider some ideas about the functions of sleep. We will draw on sleep literature in humans, small mammals, and crucially very many invertebrates that are known to sleep.
 

Learning Outcomes

Rhythms of Life

Understanding the fundamentals and mechanism of temporal rhytms of behaviour, physiology, biochemistry and metabolism from a single celled to multicellular organisms

Sleep

Understanding the mechanisms that regulate sleep as well as the functional consequences of sleep for brain and body function.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

This course is for UG who have completed Introduction to biology 2 or Introduction to biology 3 OR Biology M.Sc. OR PhD students.

Some printed material will be provided in the class. 

Some electronic reading materials will be provided in the class.

a) Class Participation (5 marks).   b) One  exam of (20 marks).  c) Class assignments (15 Marks). d) Presentation (10 Marks). The grading rubric will be different for M.Sc. and PhD students and will be discussed during the class.

Faculty Name

title: ADVANCED TECHNIQUES: STRUCTURAL BIOLOGY
description:
Advanced Techniques : Structural Biology [BIO-4705/ BIO-6705] [BIO-4705/ BIO-6705-1]

Faculty Name
Dilip Kumar [dilip.kumar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The three-dimensional structures of biological macromolecules have helped us to understand the atomic details of biological reactions and their implications. We have exploited these structural information for understanding molecular mechanisms of disease biology and help driving drug discovery efforts. While the experimental methods (such as X-ray crystallography, NMR, and cryogenic electron microscopy) remain the methods of choice to understand macromolecular structures, the recent advancements in the field of protein structure prediction tools (such as AlphaFold and RoseTTAFold) have brought about an exciting phase in structural bioinformatics. Advanced methodologies course in structural biology course aims to equip the students with the recent developments in the field of structural biology. In this session, we will be covering topics related to protein structure determination, structure prediction, macromolecular modeling, searching for structural homologs, structural alignment, and visualizing protein structures to extract maximum information from the structures.

The course would be mostly in computational and theoretical study mode. We will be attempting some crystallization trials for easily crystallizable proteins such as lysozyme. We may also plan a day trip to visit high-end instruments (X-ray diffraction, cryo-EM) available at Central Research Facility IIT Sonipat/Delhi.

Learning Outcomes

The students will learn cutting-edge technologies for macromolecular structural determination. We will also be using in silico prediction methods and learning how we can use them to design our scientific research projects. This program will prepare the students to use structural biology-related methods to tackle their scientific pursuits.  

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The reading materials and research articles will be shared during the classes

Grading Rubric

Relative grading methods will be used

Class attendance and participation: 25 marks

Assignments: 75 (three assignments of 25 marks each)

Attendance Policy

Minimum of 75% attendance is required (relaxation only in case of medical urgencies).

title: STUDY DESIGN AND STATISTICAL MODELS: AN ESSENTIAL TOOLBOX FOR A RESEARCHER
description:
Study Design and Statistical Models: An Essential Toolbox for a Researcher [ES-3305/ BIO-3305/ BIO-6305] [ES-3305/ BIO-3305/ BIO-6305-1]

Faculty Name
Manvi Sharma [manvi.sharma@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Research problems often present themselves in the form of broken pieces of information. A modern biologist can use multiple tools to make sense of data and uncover signals that help describe how the world works. This course is aimed at providing a toolkit to help research students design field and laboratory studies and link data to models (a description of how the world works). The discussion topics include replication and pseudoreplication, randomisation, sample size and degrees of freedom, orthogonal design, and non-orthogonal observational data. The topics on statistical modelling include parameter estimation, model prediction, overfitting, collinearity, missing data, approaches to choosing models, and model simplification. This course will be taught through lectures and worksheets using the R programming language. The example datasets used in the worksheets will be from ecological, biomedical, and social sciences.

Statistical modelling is as much art as it is a craft. Students will be encouraged to think about creative ways to model seemingly disparate datasets. For example, modelling the occupancy of snow leopards in the Himalayan landscapes might be very similar to modelling the occupancy patterns of tuberculosis in Delhi.

Course cap: 25

Learning Outcomes

Appreciate that similar statistical tools can be used creatively to solve different problems

Ability to design an effective research study in the laboratory or field

Learning to visualise and manage data

Understanding principles of inference, avoiding overinterpretation of data

Understanding principles of good design, avoiding pseudoreplication, perils of p-hacking, and phantom degrees of freedom

Ability to run statistical techniques and tests

Grading Rubric

Assignments 25%

Paper presentation 25%

Final project 50%

Attendance Policy

The minimum attendance required to pass the course is 80%

Faculty Name

Overview

Climate change has played a critical role in shaping the biological diversity in our planet. This course aims to introduce participants to the effects of climate change to biotic diversity, biogeography and human evolution focusing specifically on:

a. evolution and diversity in the last few million years, and

b. the contribution of genetics and genomics in understanding the evolution of natural populations during this period.

A significant portion is devoted towards introducing participants to the concepts and methods of population genetics, phylogenetics, molecular ecology, archaeogenetics/genomics etc. including elements of ancient DNA genomics and its application in understanding biotic evolution under climate change.

The course aims to equip students with conceptual and methodological knowhow of related evolutionary research and both case studies and hands-on exercises will be frequently used in this regard.

title: TEN EUREKAS! A HISTORY OF SCIENCE THROUGH TEN DISCOVERIES
description:
Ten Eurekas! A History of Science through Ten Discoveries [HIS-3532/ BIO-3532] [HIS-3532/ BIO-3532-1]

Faculty Name
Projit Bihari Mukharji [projit.mukharji@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

What is the relationship between science and society? How do social contexts, institutions, and histories shape science? In turn, how does science transform societies and individuals? These are the main questions we will explore in this course.

Though the course is organized around a series of roughly chronological discoveries, rather than presenting any single narrative of scientific progress they will be treated as iconic case studies. Instead of simply seeing these discoveries as constituting a decontextualized global series, we will place each discovery back in their respective thick historical contexts with a view to teasing out what spurred them, how they were imagined by those involved and how they transformed the societies in which they happened.

We will take a rather broad view of a “discovery” covering a range of entities from natural forces, facts, and processes like gravity, vacuum, and evolution, as well as the fabrication of procedures, concepts, and objects such as Pasteurization, the Periodic Table and Insulin. Starting with Sir Isaac Newton in the 17th century we will travel up to the middle of the 20th century. Along the way we will meet such scientific luminaries as Sir Robert Boyle, Charles Darwin, James Joule, Louis Pasteur, Dmitri Mendeleev, Theodosius Dobzhansky, James Watson, Francis Crick and others.

Alongside roughly two articles on each case, we will also read brief extracts from original scientific works each week. The textbooks will be entirely optional and I do not expect any student to be disadvantaged by not reading the textbooks. Neither will students be disadvantaged if they lack any background in science.

fullName: ES-2106/ BIO-2106, 'SCIENCE, SOCIETY AND SUSTAINABILITY, GHAZALA SHAHABUDDIN
title: 'SCIENCE, SOCIETY AND SUSTAINABILITY,
description:
Science, Society and Sustainability [ES-2106/ BIO-2106] [ES-2106/ BIO-2106-1]

Faculty Name
Ghazala Shahabuddin [ghazala.shahabuddin@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Description

This course explores the concept of environmental sustainability in the Anthropocene, based on key ecological concepts such as biodiversity, ecosystems, population growth, food-webs and nutrient cycling. This course will be useful for students who wish to understand the scientific underpinnings of the sustainability concept in contemporary times, and the ways that they are deployed in current social-ecological contexts. The course is designed primarily as an introduction to ecological thinking for students from both natural and social sciences, based on analysis of complex environmental debates such as climate change mitigation, sustainable harvest and urban planning.

Pedagogy

Theory lectures will be interspersed with class discussions on related environmental concerns. Articles and books will be prescribed as background reading for each topic. There will be a field trip within Delhi NCR which will form a significant component of learning in this course.

Learning Outcomes

Students will learn to apply ecological principles to current environmental challenges and analyse the concept of sustainability in complex social-ecological situations.  They will be able to write critical papers on contemporary environmental problems using a holistic perspective.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

List of Modules with Readings

Module 1: Sustainability in the Anthropocene

The students will be introduced to the varying notions of social and ecological sustainability, using a historical perspective on the Anthropocene. Discussion will be invited on the relevance and application of science in addressing environmental concerns and sustainability.

Readings

Corlett, R. 2015.The Anthropocene concept in ecology and conservation. Trends in Ecology and Evolution 30(1):36-41.

Module 2,3:

Ecosystem Concept: Structure and Energy Flows

We will explore ecosystems and their different components. Concepts of energy flow, primary productivity, foodchains and foodwebs will be covered in addition to basic tenets of ecology.  

Readings:

Krebs, C.J. 2009. Chapter 22: Ecosystem Metabolism I: Primary Production (Pgs 451-473); Ecosystem Metabolism II: Secondary Production (Pgs 475-495). In Ecology: The Experimental Analysis of Distribution and Abundance. Benjamin Cummings Publications.

Module 4: Soil, Water and Nutrients

This module focusses on soils, and nutrient cycling, with the aim to introduce the students to ecosystem-level thinking about process. We study the underlying principles of flow of matter through ecosystems and the earth’s biogeochemical cycles, taking nitrogen, carbon and phosphorus as examples.

Reading:

Krebs, C.J. 2009. Chapter 22: Ecosystem Metabolism III: Nutrient Cycles (Pgs 497-519). In Ecology: The Experimental Analysis of Distribution and Abundance. Benjamin Cummings Publications.

Module 5: Sustainable Agriculture

The application of nutrient cycles for ecological health will be discussed, using the example of organic farming. Two short movies on organic farming will be used in this module, along with popular reading, to discuss sustainability in agriculture.

Readings

Pollan, M. 2006. Chapter 2: Farm, pp. 32-56. In: The Omnivore’s Dilemma. Penguin Books, USA.

Renard, D. and Tilman, D. 2021. Cultivate biodiversity to harvest food security and sustainability. Current Biology 31, R1141–R1224,

Movies:

Organic Farming in Auroville

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5iOTq6kb4qM

Rice diversity and cultivation

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C08FAa-Vlj0

Module 6: Understanding Pollution

In this module, students will read the environmental classic by Barry Commoner. They will then be involved in a classroom modelling exercise to apply ecological principles to a discussion question on pollution in Delhi NCR.

Readings:

Commoner, B. 1971. The Closing Circle, Nature, Man, Technology. Chapter 2: The Ecosphere (Pgs 14-48); Chapter 4: Los Angeles Air (Pgs 66-80). Alfred P. Knopf, New York, USA.

Module 7: World Climates

World climates provide the template on which ecosystems are developed and perpetuated. In this module, the geographic factors underlying climatic regimes across the world, will be studied. The climatic factors that are key to formation of a range of natural habitats and ecosystems will be elaborated. Students will be introduced to the features that characterize and distinguish the earth’s biomes, particularly climatic factors and topography.

Readings:

Ricklefs, R.E. & G. Miller. 2000. Ecology (Fourth Edition). Chapter 8: Climate, Topography and the Diversity of the Natural World (Pgs.138-161). W.H. Freeman & Co., New York.

Module 8:  Ecosystems of the World

This session will provide an introduction to the distribution and classification of terrestrial and aquatic biomes across the world. Students will also be introduced to the classification of vegetation types in India as laid out in Champion & Seth (1968). They will study the desert ecosystem in detail with respect to the major limiting factors, anthropogenic imprint and biodiversity.

Reading:

Ricklefs, R.E. & G. Miller. 2000. Ecology (Fourth Edition). Chapter 8: Climate, Topography and the Diversity of the Natural World (Pgs.138-161). W.H. Freeman & Co., New York.

Nabhan, G.P. 1997. Chapter V: Hornworm’s Home Ground (Pgs 249-259) In:Cultures of Habitat: On Nature, Culture and Story. Counterpoint, Washington D.C.

Module 9, 10. Science of Climate Change

This module goes into the scientific evidence for climate change and global warming. The visible impacts on climate systems, biodiversity and economies will be discussed using the case study of Sunderbans, one of the areas hard-hit by climate change.

                                    

Readings:

Climate Change and the Indian Ocean by Down to Earth

https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCIB_MLJZL0T_s5OUuqhmbVA

Kolbert, E. 2014. Chapter 8: The Forest and the Trees (Pgs.148-172) In: The Sixth Extinction, An Unnatural History. Bloomsbury, London.

Ghosh, A. 2019. Disastrous delta: Daily struggles against nature in the Sunderbans. Pp. 29-36 In. Ghosh, A. (Ed.). The Tides of Life: Surviving Between the Margins. Indira Gandhi National Centre for the Arts, India.

Module 11. Technological vs. Nature-Based Solutions to Global Warming

Fleischman, F. et al. 2020. Pitfalls of Tree Planting Show Why we Need People-centered Natural Climate Solutions. Bioscience 70(11):947-950.

Dyke, J.G., W. Knorr and R. Watson. 2021. Why Net Zero Policies Do More Harm than Good. Pgs 39-52 in Bohm, S. and S. Sullivan (Eds) Negotiating Climate Change in Crisis. Open Book Publishers, Cambridge, UK.

Chazdon, R. and P. Brancalion. 2019. Restoring forests as a means to many ends. Science. 364, 24– 10 25.

Module 12: Population Growth and Regulation

Concepts of populations, population structure, different parameters associated with populations, growth curves and population age structure will be covered. Mechanisms of population regulation will also be discussed.

Readings:

Kormondy, E.J. 1969. Concepts of Ecology (4th Edition). Chapter 10: Population growth and structure (Pgs 194-224). Prentice Hall, New Jersey.

Module 13:  Big Cats in Human Landscapes

Applications of key concepts in population ecology to the real-life challenge of Bengal tiger conservation will be discussed, based on articles and news.

Sinha, N. 2021. Chapter 6: The Mother of Men and Tigers, The Tiger (Panthera tigris) (Pgs 113-142) In: In Wild and Wilful; Tales of 15 Iconic Indian Species. Harper Collins India, U.P.

Chundawat, R. 2018. Chapter 5: Tiger Society: Solitary Existence but Social Living (Pgs 75-122). In: The Rise and Fall of the Emerald Tigers, Ten Years of Research in Panna National Park. Speaking Tiger Publications, New Delhi.

Kaushik, N. 2018. Was it necessary to kill tigress Avni? Scroll, November 20, 2018

https://scroll.in/article/902693/was-it-necessary-to-kill-tigress-avni

Module 14. Crocodiles for Sale: Sustainable Harvest

Students will apply theories of population growth and regulation to sustainable harvest of wild species, including saltwater crocodiles. They will compare the socio-political and scientific contexts of sustainable harvest between two countries: Australia and India.

Quammen, D. 2003. Monster of God, The Man-eating Predator in the Jungles of History and the Mind. Chapter 4: Leviathan with a Hook (Pgs 127-207). WW Norton & Co., New York, USA.

Module 15, 16: Biodiversity: Pattern and Process

This module will introduce students to the concept of biodiversity. They will learn how to characterise communities through commonly used metrics such as species richness, abundance, evenness, diversity indices and similarity. The ideas of ecological niche and resource partitioning  will be introduced. Global patterns of biodiversity and their underlying drivers will also be discussed. These concepts will be applied to understanding biodiversity impacts of monocultures at local and landscape scales.

Reading:

Krebs, C.J. 2009. Chapter 19: Community structure in Space: Biodiversity (Pgs 377-400). In Ecology: The Experimental Analysis of Distribution and Abundance. Benjamin Cummings Publications.

Mandal, J. and T.R. Shankar Raman. 2016. Shifting agriculture supports more tropical forest birds than oil palm or teak plantations in Mizoram, northeast India. The Condor 118: 345-359.

Modules 17,18: Ecological Interactions

In the first part of this module, various interspecific interactions such as predator-prey relations,  competition and plant-animal relations will be covered. Historic lab and field experiments in community ecology will be discussed. The second part of this module deals with food web theory, as a way to describe and understand the complexity in the ecological world.  The attributes of food webs that explain community persistence will be examined. The notion of ‘keystone species’ will be discussed.

Background Reading:

Krebs, C.J. 2009. Chapter 20: Community Dynamics I: Predation and Competition in Equilibrial Communities (Pgs 401-424). In Ecology: The Experimental Analysis of Distribution and Abundance. Benjamin Cummings Publications.

Module 19,20: Invasive Species

Invasive species present a useful system to understand basic ecological processes such as competition and population regulation. At the same time, invasive ecology has immense implications for socio-economic stability and ecosystem services, and requires detailed study. In this module, students will apply the basics of community ecology to understanding invasives and their socio-economic impacts.

Simberloff, D. et al. 2013. Impacts of biological invasions: what’s what and the way forward. Trends in Ecology and Evolution 28(1): 58-66.

Ricciardi, A., M.E. Palmer and N.D.Yan. Should Biological Invasions be Managed as Natural Disasters? BioScience 61: 312-317.

Module 21: Reintroduction of Carnivores

Reintroduction of carnivores to areas where they occurred earlier, a form of ‘rewilding’, has become widespread in the 20th century. The key rationale employed here is that the reinstatement of the top-down forces of predation prevents ‘ecosystem collapse’. In this module we examine one of the most celebrated cases of reintroduction- that of gray wolves to the Greater Yellowstone ecosystem in North America- in relation to debates on bottom-up and top-down trophic forces. The cheetah reintroduction in India will also be examined from the sustainability perspective.

Readings:

Ripple, W.J., T.P. Rooney and R.L. Beschta. 2010. Large Predators, Deer and Trophic Cascades in Boreal and Temperate Ecosystems. Pp. 141-162 In Terborgh, J. And J. Estes (Eds.) Trophic Cascades: Predators, Prey and the Changing Dynamics of Nature. Island Press, Washington, USA.

Terborgh, J. 1988. The Big things that Run the World, A Sequel to E.O. Wilson. Conservation Biology 2: 402-403.

Randall, C. 2020. A Rewilding Triumph: Wolves help to Reverse Yellowstone degradation, Guardian, January 25, 2020.

https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2020/jan/25/yellowstone-wolf-project-25th-anniversary

Peterson, C. 2020. 25 years after returning to Yellowstone, wolves have helped stabilize the ecosystem. National Geographic, July 10, 2020.

https://www.nationalgeographic.com/animals/article/yellowstone-wolves-reintroduction-helped-stabilize-ecosystem

Module 22: Ecological Succession

Description:

Many of the spatial patterns in plant communities that we observe today reflect historical and ongoing ecological processes. The plant and animal communities are likely to be very different from those that  existed a few decades ago and bear the imprint of both ongoing ecological processes and human activities. We will explore the successional patterns in plant communities and how these patterns manifest in variations in communities of animals and plants that depend on them.

Background Reading:

Krebs, C.J. 2009. Chapter 18: Community Structure in Time: Succession (Pgs 352-376). Ecology (6th Edition). In Ecology: The Experimental Analysis of Distribution and Abundance.  Benjamin Cummings Publishing, USA.

Module 23: Restoring Forests

Restoring forests on degraded land so as to recreate productive ecosystems is now being taken up on a large scale across the world. Effective restoration requires not just sound ecological knowledge of species and their interactions, but also recognition of the socio-economic matrix within which it is undertaken. Discussion will take place around three short videos on forest restoration from different parts of the world.

Movies:

Restoring forests in New Zealand:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3VZSJKbzyMc

Restoring Forests in Annamalai

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=biazSyLYsEY

Restoring forests in Australia

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=g9yiclBCxMo

Module 24, 25: Sustainability and the City

Urban ecology has come to the forefront in recent decades given the rapid expansion of urbanization into the countryside, rural-to-urban migration of people and numerous environmental problems that exist. The city is a place where social churning is visible, yet history constrains positive change in many ways. This module aims to introduce the students to the social-ecological complexity of the city through a comparative approach. Students will attempt to discover temporal trends across two metropolitan cities- Delhi and Bengaluru-and analyze the role of science in urban management.

Readings:

Agarwal, R. 2018. ‘Natural’ no More? Delhi’s Yamuna River. Pp.185-209 In in G. Cederlof and M. Rangarajan (Eds.) At Nature’s Edge, The Global Present and Long-Term History. Oxford University Press, Delhi, India.

Agarwal, R. 2014. The Fight for an Urban Forest: The Delhi Ridge. Pp. 107-130 In Rangarajan, M., M.D. Madhusudan and G. Shahabuddin (Eds.) Nature Without Borders. Orient Blackswan, India.

Nagendra, H. 2016. Nature in the City, Bengaluru in the Past, Present and Future. Chapter 3: Resilient City (Pp38-60); Chapter 9: Blue Nature (Pp.163-185). Oxford University Press, India.

Module 26: Field Trip (Urban Ecology)

Students will be taken on a day-long field trip to explore first-hand various aspects of urban ecology. They will then work on their term paper that will aim to apply the course learnings to the given topic.

Grading Rubric

Course evaluation will be based on a combination of one in-class test, a mid-term essay and a final term paper (based on the field trip). In addition, students will be graded on the quality of their participation in class discussions. 

Weightage of Assessments:

Attendance: 10%

Participation in class discussions: 25%

In-class Test: 20%

Mid-term Essay: 20%

Term paper: 25%

 

Attendance Policy

Attendance will be graded; students are expected to attend at least 85% of classes.

Attachment
SciSustain-Full Syllabus.docx

title: GROUP THEORY ON QUANTUM MECHANICS
description:

Faculty Name
Sourav Pal [sourav.pal@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

A. Basic Quantum Mechanics: Postulates of quantum mechanics; Concept of stationary and nonstationary states; Ehrenfest Theorem and its consequences; Commutation of Operators and its significance in measurement; Some exactly solvable systems as examples of stationary states of energy

B: Introduction to group theory, Properties of a group, Subgroup and Class, Symmetry operators and their relevance to stationary states in quantum mechanics; Concepts of groups in symmetry; Matrix representation of groups, Operators and basis functions; Symmetry of Hamiltonian Operator; Unitary and Similarity transformation; Reducible and Irreducible
representations; Schur's Lemma, Great Orthogonality Theorem and its consequences; Character tables, Wavefunctions as bases for irreducible representation, Direct product and significance; Symmetry adapted basis and the consequence in the solution of energy eigenfunctions
C: Applications to Spectroscopy : Einstein A and B coefficients; dipolar interaction between light and matter;  time-dependent perturbation approach;  Weak and strong field interaction; Transition probability and
Transition moment integral, Fermi's golden rule; Vibrational spectroscopy; Normal coordinates, normal modes and their symmetry; Selection rules for fundamental vibrational transitions

Learning Outcomes

Outcome: Symmetry in quantum mechanics, its application in electronic stricture and spectroscopy

title: WEALTH & INEQUALITY IN CHINA (1500 TO THE PRESENT)
description:
Wealth and Inequality in China (1500 to the Present) [CHI-3002/ HIS-3511] [CHI-3002/ HIS-3511-1]

Faculty Name
Eloise Wright [eloise.wright@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Among the most vivid images of China’s modern history have been the extremes of decadent imperial courts and starving peasants. China’s sixteenth-century commercial revolution, in the context of the growing international trade in silver, transformed social and cultural life in every corner of society. Since then, arguments about the distribution of resources and the proper remedy for inequality have been central to political and social movements, especially during the twentieth century. In this course we will examine the economic bases of income inequality in Chinese history, investigate strategies Chinese governments and individuals have used to mitigate rural and urban poverty, and come to appreciate how these economic realities affected people at all levels of Chinese society. Wealth and poverty were experienced differently according to factors including (but not limited to) gender, age, level of education, disability, sexuality, ethnicity, and location. We will read primary sources which illuminate a wide range of perspectives and consider, in conversation with the secondary literature, how to synthesise these materials. The written assessment for this class will build towards developing expertise on a single Chinese region or locality.

fullName: CHI-3003, CONFUCIANISM, FAMILY LINEAGE, AND LOCAL SOCIETY, DANIEL MURRAY
title: CONFUCIANISM, AND LOCAL SOCIETY,
description:
Confucianism, Family Lineage, and Local Society [CHI-3003/ SOA-3100/ HIS-3814] [CHI-3003/ SOA-3100/ HIS-3814-1]

Faculty Name
Daniel Murray [daniel.murray@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Course Overview

This course approaches Confucianism as a lived tradition in Chinese local society with an emphasis on the role of family lineages. Family lineages developed to be one of the pivotal institutions in organizing local society in late imperial China. These institutions were an important factor in state-society relations, property ownership, infrastructure projects, personal relations, and ritual practice. This course overviews major studies of the historical development of family lineages, its geographic diversity, and their continued existence today as well as their relation to issues of gender, ethnicity, religion, and kinship.

The first section gives a general overview of Confucian thought with an emphasis on its understanding of kinship and ritual. Section two moves onto historical anthropological studies of the development of family lineages, their related institutional structures (lineage halls) and rituals (ancestor veneration), and their connection to broader social, political, and economic life. Finally, we end the course with ethnographic studies of family lineages in the modern world to consider the impact of the nation-state, urbanization, changes in family dynamics, and transnational communication have had on the lineage.

Section 1: Kinship and Ritual in Confucian Thought and Imperial Power
This section of the course focuses on Confucian theories of kinship and ritual followed by an overview of the role of these ideas in the structuring of the state and society. The purpose of these theories was different than modern academic works as the aim was to influence how people acted rather than explain what they already were doing. However, they also present an indigenous understanding of these concepts and how the literati elite used them to analyze social issues.

Section 2: Historical Anthropology, Family Lineage, and Local Society
Historical anthropology emerged in China in response to largely ahistorical orientalist ethnographies of Chinese societies that saw the lineage structure as a monolith and largely drew on existing theories of lineage from European colonies in Africa as well as nationalist histories that presented a unified Chinese culture. In contrast to such studies, historical anthropologists combine fieldwork and local historical documents to analyze the diverse ways that family lineage developed throughout China. Historical anthropology emerged in China in response to largely ahistorical orientalist ethnographies of Chinese societies that saw the lineage structure as a monolith and largely drew on existing theories of lineage from European colonies in Africa as well as nationalist histories that presented a unified Chinese culture. In contrast to such studies, historical anthropologists combine fieldwork and local historical documents to analyze the diverse ways that family lineage developed throughout China.

Section 3: Ethnography, Lineage, and Modernity
The twentieth century saw the end of dynastic China and with it the bureaucracy staffed by scholar-officials trained in the Confucian tradition. Despite the numerous attacks on traditional culture and the land reform movement that stripped lineages of their land holdings in this period, many lineages throughout China continue to this day. This section focuses on ethnographic studies of how the family lineage has responded to many of the changing social, political, and geographic issues in this period.

title: AN INTERPRETIVE HISTORY OF MAO ZEDONG AND THE CHINESE COMMUNIST REVOLUTION
description:
An Interpretive History of Mao Zedong and the Chinese Communist Revolution [CHI-4001/ HIS-4802/ POL-3090/ IR-3027] [CHI-4001/ HIS-4802/ POL-3090/ IR-3027-1]

Faculty Name
Sayantani Mukherjee [sayantani.mukherjee@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course introduces the historical relationship between Mao Zedong’s philosophy of history and revolution, and the global context of Chinese Revolution in the twentieth century. We will examine Mao’s theories and practice of revolution through a thematic lens: not as biographical artifacts but as thought produced by and constitutive of the revolutionary circumstances in the twentieth-century world at large and China in particular.  Our aim will be to investigate how three modal terms—Chinese, Revolutionary, Marxist—reflect on each other as open questions when Mao Zedong is studied in contextually-embedded and philosophically complex manner.

Situating the world in an intimate dialogic relationship to China, we will ask the questions; was Mao a Marxist? How was Mao’s Marxism inflected by his positionality of being Chinese in a revolutionary twentieth-century world? How was Mao’s Chineseness influenced by his being a revolutionary in the twentieth-century world? How was Marxism impacted by Mao’s articulation of revolution in the twentieth-century world? The readings for this class will mostly be drawn from Mao’s own writings, and students will be expected to read these texts intensively, with an open mind. While this course does not require any previous knowledge of China, as an advanced level class, a familiarity with general twentieth-century world history and/or a background in the history of Marxism will be helpful. Students with prior background in neither will be expected to learn on a very steep curve.

Learning Outcomes

Read intertextually and understand literary productions as artefacts of historical and social construction.

Summarize academic monographs in East Asian studies and introduce salient points in notes and in speech.

Be able to draw connections between works to gain an overview of scholarly and historiographical debates.

Be able to trace theoretical or methodological trends across multiple empirical contexts.

Learn the skills of co-writing and co-presenting to gain a sense of how cooperative work can integrate intellectual property as well as collective clarity.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

You are not required to purchase any materials for this course. All readings will be provided in PDF via email.

Grading Rubric

Requirements and Expectations:        

Assessment & Assignments:

30% - Regular participation in class discussions

70% - Writing Portfolio (summarized below):

10% - Progress meetings (minimum 2)

40% - Report

20% - Op-ed

Attendance, Participation and Discussion Étiquette:

One third of your grade in this class depends on learning how to read written productions “against the grain”. That is to say, scrutinizing the beliefs and attitudes that typically go unexamined in a text, drawing attention to the gaps, silences, contradictions, and unspoken impetus that animate written words, but also reading that text through the various registers of its production and circulation—as an artefact of literary, historical and social conditions that may or may not alter its imagined “original” context. We are reading Mao, but we will never take him for his word.

I will not take attendance in each class meeting, however, participation in weekly class discussions is a mandatory part of your grade and is necessary for succeeding in the course. If you have circumstances that might affect attendance at a specific class meeting, please let me know ahead of time whenever possible. Flexibility is especially important since Covid is still with us. To protect your privacy, please do not describe any medical situations to me; just inform me that the situation exists and be prepared to provide a doctor’s note if requested.

Participation is part of your grade, and should be based on attentive reading, listening, and preparation. Always keep an open mind and be respectful of your classmates and your instructor regardless of what you wish to say, or whether you agree with what has already been said. Being respectful also means that (1) if you have not completed a particular reading, please refrain from commenting on it (2) in the normal course of discussion, if you have just spoken, you should refrain from speaking again until others who wish to contribute have done so (3) contributions to discussion should be based on the readings, lectures, and discussion questions, and should aim to improve our collective understanding of them. In general, please avoid unstructured/unsupported reflections as well as topics that are beyond the scope of the course.

Writing Portfolio

Two-thirds of your final grade for this class will depend on two written pieces that will be thematically related and proceed from each other. The purpose of these pieces is to help you further navigate the landscape of political writing, by interrogating how the processes of (narrative) writing engage with the conveying of “information” in the quest for coherence, conviction, and accessibility.

The first of these pieces will be a Report on an Investigation of the  < > Movement, approx. 5000-6000 words, modeled on Mao’s famous Report on the Hunan Peasant Movement. For this first piece, you may choose between reporting on the working conditions of a) campus workers at Ashoka or b) teaching fellows at Ashoka.

The second text is an opinion piece (no longer than 1,000 words) that condenses your longer report into a piece that should function as a call to action. Unlike the first piece, where your stated purpose is an “investigation”, your purpose in this second piece is to craft an appeal.

Please note that you have the option of writing both the Report and the op-ed as a team project, but that the requirements will change accordingly.

For both pieces, you may choose to conduct interviews in person, speak to campus “experts”, read theoretical texts or works providing historical background. The methodology is entirely up to you, but you are encouraged discuss your thinking and writing process with me through a series of progress meetings. These meetings will count for ten percent of your final grade.

Attachment
An Interpretive History of Mao Zedong and the Chinese Communist Revolution.docx
