title: BORDERLANDS: TOWARDS A SPATIAL HISTORY OF EMPIRE
description:
Borderlands: Towards a Spatial History of Empire [HIS-3516/ SOA-3514/ CHI-3203/ IR-3028] [HIS-3516/ SOA-3514/ CHI-3203/ IR-3028-1]

Faculty Name
Sayantani Mukherjee [sayantani.mukherjee@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

What is the violence of a line drawn upon a map? Or on a terrain? How are people produced by such mapping? What anxieties drive the imperial cartographic impulse? What pressures does terra nullis exert in situ? What do the bodies produced in mapped territories look like? What bodies exist in unmapped terrains? What is the relationship between wonder/amazement, and control/annihilation? Where do we locate ourselves as scholars reading these maps? What maps are visible when we visit the landscape? How are narratives produced against maps? How are histories made visible in terrain?

These questions will guide us as we traverse a theoretical terrain of writings on space and territory, and situate ourselves in specific historical moments of imperial mastery over space. We will cover a lot of ground temporally but our geographic focus will be South and East Asia. In this class we will develop skills in reading and understanding the genre of the academic monograph; in understanding how they relate to each other; and in analyzing the theoretical and methodological bases and trends of these works.

Learning Outcomes

Summarize academic monographs in South and East Asian studies and introduce salient points in notes and in speech.

Be able to draw connections between works to gain an overview of scholarly and historiographical debates.

Be able to trace theoretical or methodological trends across multiple empirical contexts.

Analyze and present in writing your interpretation of the role of space and place in a geographical region relevant to your work or interest.

Learn the skills of co-writing and co-presenting to gain a sense of how cooperative work can integrate intellectual property as well as collective clarity.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

You are not required to purchase any materials for this course. All readings will be provided in PDF via email.

Grading Rubric

Assessment & Assignments:

40% - Leading weekly discussion in class and participating in class discussions

60% - Carto-Paper (Optional Team Project)

Attendance, Participation and Discussion Etiquette :

I will not take attendance in each class meeting, however, participation in weekly class discussions is a mandatory part of your grade and is necessary for succeeding in the course. If you have circumstances that might affect attendance at a specific class meeting, please let me know ahead of time whenever possible. Flexibility is especially important since Covid is still with us. To protect your privacy, please do not describe any medical situations to me; just inform me that the situation exists and be prepared to provide a doctor’s note if requested.

 

Participation is part of your grade, and should be based on attentive reading, listening, and preparation. Participation can take many forms. Always keep an open mind and be respectful of your classmates and your instructor regardless of what you wish to say, or whether you agree with what has already been said. Being respectful also means that (1) if you have not completed a particular reading, please refrain from commenting on it (2) in the normal course of discussion, if you have just spoken, you should refrain from speaking again until others who wish to contribute have done so (3) contributions to discussion should be based on the readings, lectures, and discussion questions, and should aim to improve our collective understanding of them. In general, please avoid unstructured/unsupported reflections as well as topics that are beyond the scope of the course.

 

Class lead:

One student per week (both Tuesday and Thursday) will introduce the assigned readings for that week (~10 mins) and facilitate discussion for the rest of the class. Try to keep your presentation to under ten minutes, and use the time to provide a short summary of one or two of the assigned texts, and present to the class your own questions and ideas about the theme through the readings. This exercise will help you condense the readings to their core argument and thereby facilitate review before assignments are due. For this reason, it makes sense to approach every set of readings with a few basic questions: who is the author? What is his or her background? What kind of audience are they addressing? And what is the aim of the text? Is it a purely technical piece of writing or does it raise (or hide?) important political questions? These questions are very basic, but they will help you to structure your contribution to the class. If you would like to additionally discuss reading material or resources not on the reading list in your presentation, please feel free to discuss your ideas for the presentation with me beforehand. Following the week’s discussion, the class lead will collate all the notes for the assigned readings, to structure them into an annotated entry for each text we have read.

Carto-paper:

This assignment will be a 5500-6000 word (Times New Roman 12 pt. font, double-spaced, not including footnotes and bibliography) investigation of a single primary source relevant to the field of cartography, broadly construed: this can be a specific map, a surveyor’s field diary, an object history of a technical instrument, etc. Feel free to discuss your ideas or adjustments, if you prefer, for this project with me beforehand. You may also turn this into a collaborative project if you wish. Your carto-paper is due 11.59 pm May 14, by email to me. We will be discussing two drafts of your paper as a class. These two drafts are due on Monday 11.59 pm February 20 and April 3, by email. Following your submissions, we will intensively workshop everyone’s paper as a group. In these group discussions, you will be expected to have read your peers’ work (as you would when you will attend conferences, workshops, and panel discussions), and offer constructive feedback to help your peers make progress on their projects. Your participation in these discussions will count towards your final grade for the carto-paper.

These essays are an important way to develop your writing skills—particularly the formation of a clear and logical argument, the mobilization of evidence, and the quality of prose. Your essays are intended to help you build the specific skill of making a historical argument, and to that end they should be erudite, specific, supportable and argumentative—not an unstructured reflection, opinion, or summary. They must refer, when needed, to the readings with citations.

 

Late submissions will not be accepted. If you anticipate that for any reason you will be unable to make these deadlines, please email me at least 48 hours in advance for an extension.

 

Your essays must aim to illuminate the texts you have chosen to discuss, rather than simply critique them or identify the gaps in the knowledge of the authors. The effectiveness of your arguments will rest on your plausible articulation of positions and paradigms of thinking that you may be unfamiliar or even disagree with. Thus, both your essays and the feedback you offer your peers should attempt to first reconstruct the carefully considered and rigorously formulated thoughts and arguments of the authors you are reading, before seeking to push that comprehension in a new direction.

Attachment
Borderlands 2023 syllabus and weekly schedule.docx

fullName: CHI-3204, STONE, PAPER, BAMBOO, SILK: SINOPHONE TEXTUAL CULTURES, ELOISE WRIGHT
title: STONE, PAPER, BAMBOO, SILK: SINOPHONE TEXTUAL CULTURES,
description:
Stone, Paper, Bamboo, Silk: Sinophone Textual Cultures [HIS-3513/ CHI-3204/ VA-3027/ ENG-3413] [HIS-3513/ CHI-3204/ VA-3027/ ENG-3413-1]

Faculty Name
Eloise Wright [eloise.wright@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Today, when so much of our daily communication occurs via text or email, it can be difficult to imagine a world in which writing was the preserve of a tiny minority. Chinese characters are frequently cited as the oldest continuous written tradition, beginning over three thousand years ago, but in that time the physical form of the characters and the materials they were written on have transformed over and over again. We will consider what questions these problems raise for historians' use of textual sources by looking at writing as a social, material, and political act. What were the symbolic meanings attributed to writings that most people could not understand? What practical uses could writing serve? How did access to writing intersect with other social hierarchies, like gender and class? Beginning with the invention of writing in the Yellow River region, we will discuss problems such as: the relationship between speech and writing; changes in writing materials; writing for display and writing for use; censorship; Chinese characters in non-Chinese societies; and debates over script reform.

The written assessment for this class will build towards a final research paper on a topic of the students' choice.

title: LINGUISTIC MULTIPLICITIES OF ASSAM
description:
Linguistic Multiplicities of Assam [CLA-0031] [CLA-0031-1]

Faculty Name
Jyotirmoy Talukdar [jyotirmoy.talukdar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Taught by Jyotirmoy Talukdar

The course will introduce the students to different languages and linguistic cultures found in the state of Assam including, but not limited to, Assamese. Along with standard Assamese, the course will also lay emphasis on understanding and appreciating other variants of the language and the cultural and literary results generated by them. In addition to being introduced to the wide array of tribal languages in Assam like Bodo, Mising, Karbi and Tiwa, the students will also be made aware of how these languages are - both linguistically and politically - influenced by and coexist with Assamese, the official and commonly-used language of the state. Cultural and literary forms like folktales, songs and films would be used to demonstrate how, in this story of influence and coexistence, linguistic communities have loaned words, proverbs, tunes and even phones (speech sounds) from one another. The course would be an attempt to give the students a tour and a feel of a heterogeneous, multiethnic and polyphonic Assam living on the edge in India’s Northeast.

fullName: CLA-0029, BHOJPURI IN A POSTMODERN AGE: TEXTS, IMAGES & SOUNDS, GAUTAM CHOUBEY
title: BHOJPURI IN A POSTMODERN AGE: TEXTS, IMAGES & SOUNDS,
description:
Bhojpuri in a Postmodern Age: Texts, Images & Sounds [CLA-0029] [CLA-0029-1]

Faculty Name
Gautam Choubey [gautam.choubey@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Taught by Gautam Choubey

The emergent technologies of mass communication have a significant bearing on the newfound visibility of Bhojpuri. Thanks to the cassette revolution of the late 80s, single-screen theatres, and, of late, a YouTube-steered resurgence of the vernacular, Bhojpuri appears stronger than ever. Yet, beyond the stereotypes, little is known about the culture. This course proposes to introduce the fascinating world of Bhojpuri through an assortment of cultural specimens—literary, folk, cinemati and ethnomusicological. Inter alia, it seeks to engage with Bhojpuri’s history, its relationship with other dominant languages, a popular-yet-divisive movement for its official recognition, and the questions of visibility and obscenity that have long plagued its prospects.

title: BUILDING MODELS: HOW LANGUAGES MET AND MERGED IN INDIA
description:
Building Models: How Languages met and merged in India [CLA-0041] [CLA-0041-1]

Faculty Name
Mary Margaret Christina Mohan [peggy.mohan@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Taught by Peggy Mohan

This is a course on Indian languages that aims to build a model of mixture, taking off from the present day situation, which we can see before us, and going backward in time to study situations in the past, where our model will have to serve as our compass. Over the last year the process of language spread in this region has become clearer, more consistent with what we know of the Indian languages that have left their traces in the literary record. This course aims to turn previous findings on their head, in a way that will allow students to see with their own instincts how change seems to have happened. Best of all, it falls in line with a new kind of thinking that raises questions about language change in other places, outside India, with the Indian experience getting a chance to shape linguistic theory. This will be a chance to re-think—and revise—ideas that came up when we first looked at Indian languages as mixed, and to see how, far from new languages emerging in moments of ‘chaos’, the actual process was more orderly than that, and with a different timeline from what we first imagined.

Bharatanatyam is one of India's most well-known dance forms.  Perhaps because of its widespread nature, it can be divided into sometimes startling different stylistic schools. Nevertheless, there are a number of common key elements which give bharatanatyam its identity.  These elements- mostly practical, but also including some fragments of bharatanatyam's multiple histories- will form the basis of the classroom work.

Known for its physical geometry and cerebral complexity, the style's main components will be approached in the light of moulding the body comfortably to the movement vocabulary as well as attuning the student dancer to the art of gesture and expression. 

This course is not for those who have previous experience in bharatanatyam.

title: DASTANGOI: THE REDISCOVERED ART OF STORYTELLING
description:
Dastangoi: The Rediscovered Art of Storytelling [CPA-0059] [CPA-0059-1]

Faculty Name
Nusrat Ansari [nusrat.ansari@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Taught by Nusrat Ansari   

The word Dastangoi refers to the art of storytelling. Dastans were epics, often oral in nature, which were recited or read aloud and in essence were like medieval romances everywhere. Dastangoi died out with its last traditional proponent Mir Baqar Ali in 1928. Over the last 15 years it has seen a major revival thanks to the scholarship of the late S. R. Faruqi and the efforts of his nephew Mahmood Farooqui, who has trained dozens in this modern art form. We will analyse and compare traditional and modern Dastangoi performances using practical examples and lecture demonstrations. We will also simultaneously work on performative aspects of dastangoi- voice modulation, poetry recitation, pronunciation, expression. Towards the end, the students will have the opportunity to participate in the staging of one of the traditional dastans.

title: ODISSI AND THE ART OF MOVEMENT
description:
Odissi and the art of movement [CPA-0077] [CPA-0077-1]

Faculty Name
Supriya Nayak [supriya.nayak@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Taught by Supriya Nayak                          

This course has three broad objectives. One, it seeks to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of the distinctive elements that form the bedrock of Odissi dance as we see it being performed. This will entail a historical exploration of the formative decades of Odissi in the mid-twentieth century, when multiple practitioners and scholars came to define its core principles based on the interpretation of texts, and visual and performing cultures, together with a practical focus on learning a range of stances, movements and rhythms.

The course also aims to instill an embodied and studied understanding of movement through an engagement with certain concepts associated with the Alexander Technique, which has been foundational for artists across a range of disciplines.

Finally, this course aims to cultivate a critical regard of ‘classical’ dance history in India through the case of Odissi. While focusing on specific elements made visible in the presentation of Odissi, we will attempt to uncover what was left out in the creation and propagation of a standardised, ‘classical’ style of dance, and how the dance’s growing popularity since its foundation has aided and hindered its practitioners.

Students who take this course will gain a familiarity with and basic literacy in Odissi, which is a culturally and historically specific vocabulary of movement, along with the tools that can help them better engage with the performing arts more broadly, as practitioners and as students of the humanities.

The course focuses on understanding the basic concepts of SEA, which involves Public Art, Participatory Art, Site-specific Art, Relational Art, Community Art, and Art & activism through practice. It also explores how these concepts bridge the theory and practice concerning SEA practices deploying diverse methodologies and approaches. What is the need for multi-disciplinarity in SEA practice, and how do these art practices engage people/communities through art in response to the critical context?

The course is practice-based in SEA and confirms the generation of intermediate, experimental, innovative, interactive forms that contextualize and expand symbolic expression in daily life. Subhashis Banerjee [suban@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Concept of an algorithm; principle of mathematical induction; correctness of algorithms; efficiency of algorithms - time and space measures; algorithms to programs; specification, top-down development and step-wise refinement; the notion of state and finite state machine; imperative programs; correctness and loop invariants; basic algorithm design techniques; encapsulation, abstractions and modularity; basics of object-oriented programming; basic logic, soundness and completeness, example of a propositional resolution; an example of concurrency; an intro to numerical computation.

The course will be programming language independent, and will involve programming in multiple programming languages, in both functional and imperative styles.

The course will expect familiarity with class 12 level mathematics, but not necessarily with programming.

Learning Outcomes

The course will address the following issues:

  1. Problem formulation in a precise and concise fashion and independent of language considerations.
  2. The design of simple algorithms from the problem specification -- their correctness and analysis of  efficiency.
  3. The intermediate steps in the design of a program from an algorithm through a process of step-wise refinement. Language dependent considerations may be used in this process, but not elsewhere.

The emphasis throughout the course will be on the analysis required while designing correct and efficient algorithms. The course is intended to teach a student a systematic process of design - beginning with problem formulation from an informal specification, through convincing arguments to algorithms, the analysis of their correctness and efficiency, and finally arriving at programs through a process of step-wise refinement. A programming language bias will be avoided and programs will be developed in both imperative and functional styles. 

The first part of the course will introduce the basics of the functional and imperative models of computation, recursive and iterative processes, and the basics of programming using higher-order functions. 

The second part of the course will  introduce data-directed programming. It will emphasize on programming with records, lists, trees, arrays and developing abstract data types. 

The third part of the course will address the issues in design and analysis of simple algorithms. Examples will be taken from Divide and conquer, Backtracking, Logical resolution, Numerical algorithms, Randomized algorithms and Geometric algorithms.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Reading material: Mostly class notes and  examples worked out in the class.

Grading Rubric

 Assignments: 45%, Quizes: 25%, Midterm: 15%, Final exam: 15%. There will be a quiz every week.

Attendance Policy

100% attendance is required, though attendance will not be recorded or monitored.

title: LINEAR ALGEBRA
description:
Linear Algebra [MAT-1001/ CS-2210/ PHY-1001] [MAT-1001/ CS-2210/ PHY-1001-2]

Faculty Name
Gaurav Bhatnagar [gaurav.bhatnagar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Linear algebra is one of the most important parts of mathematics, perhaps as important or more than the Calculus. Peter Lax (NYU) has remarked: "If you can reduce a mathematical problem to linear algebra, you can most likely solve it". The introductory concepts (that we will study in this course) are easy to understand, but are powerful and apply in many contexts. 

The applications to various fields are too numerous to mention. Lets  just say that the modern world would not be so modern without the application of linear algebra,  nor would our understanding of the universe would be where it is now. And neither would mathematics be as developed if all kinds of mathematical objects are not studied using linear algebra.  

However, the course is mostly mathematical. Applications will be to understand some mathematical objects.The subject unfolds slowly over the semester. As you work through the semester, you learn how to extend your intuition of two and three dimensions to work in an n-dimensional space. At the same time, as the title of the main textbook reflects,  this course may be regarded as an introduction to abstract mathematics. So you learn how to apply logical arguments to prove statements.

Its a busy course requiring a lot of effort and enthusiasm. You have to be young and energetic and want to learn a lot very quickly. But why am I saying this? You are Ashoka students. Of course you are young and energetic and want to learn a lot very quickly!

Learning Outcomes

The syllabus in the course handbook is as follows.

Syllabus: Real vector spaces, subspaces, spanning sets, basis sets, dimension of a vector space.  Solution of a system of linear equations. Row space and column space of a matrix, rank of a matrix, elementary row and column operations of a matrix. Inversion of square matrices, rank factorization of a matrix. Properties of determinants. Linear transformations, range and null space of a linear transformation, rank-nullity theorem. Matrix representation of a linear transformation. Inner product spaces, normed linear spaces, examples of different normed linear spaces, orthonormal basis sets. Eigenvalues, eigenvectors, characteristic polynomials. Spectral theorem for real symmetric matrices. Singular value decompositions.

We are likely to do all the above for vector spaces over Complex numbers. The proof of the Spectral theorem is a little easier for this. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Text book:

Isaiah Lankham, Bruno Nachtergaele and Anne Schilling, Linear Algebra - As an Introduction to Abstract Mathematics, Free online text available from: 

https://www.math.ucdavis.edu/~anne/linear_algebra/

We will cover most of the book including Appendix A.

The course material is roughly from this book, but I may deviate considerably. 

Additional References.

You may find the following books helpful as supplementary reading in case something is not clear from the textbook.

1. S. H. Friedberg, A. J. Insel and L. E. Spence, Linear algebra, Pearson, 2015. (Good book for extensive explanations, lots of problems for you to make sure you have understood the topics.)

2. P. Bogacki, Linear Algebra, Concepts and Applications, AMS/MAA Textbooks, Vol 47, 2019. (Good for matrix examples.)

3. Gilbert Strang, Linear Algebra and its Applications, (4th or 5th edition). (The classic textbook. Covers a lot. At some point in your career, you should become familiar with it. Lectures are also available for these.)

4. T. Shifrin and M. R. Adams, Linear Algebra: A Geometric Approach, WH Freeman (2nd edition). (Nice book with a geometric flavor. Great for gaining intuition.)

5. Wikipedia is great for mathematics. 

6. I will hand out a problem set which includes (most of) Professor Bhatia's problems from a few years ago. 

Computer algebra system.

We will make extensive use of the computer algebra system SAGE. In the real world, Linear Algebra is done using many different numerical packages. However, we use a symbolic algebra package. SAGE is available at:

www.sagemath.org

Please install it before coming to class. Write to me in case of difficulties. There is a possibility of using it online too, but that has become very slow and irritating. It has to be used as a last resort.

Grading Rubric

There will be 10 quizzes (in lecture) (on occasion replaced by Assignments) (33.33% of grade),  2 midterms (in lecture) (33.33%) and a take home final (33.33%).  Midterms 1 and 2 are  in-class exams. More details will be provided on the first day of class. A max of 2 missed quiz scores can be replaced by average of rest.  

Attendance Policy

While there is no formal requirement to attend lectures and DS sessions, it may be a good idea to do so because we may deviate or add to the material in the textbook which may show up on quizzes and tests. In general, its easier to read the book when you know whats going on in the lectures. Further, there will be no makeup exams (Quizzes or midterms) and these will happen during class times. Usually for math courses expect to spend a minimum of 4-5 hours outside of class every week to keep up.

title: SYMBOLIC LOGIC
description:
Symbolic Logic [PHI-1060/ CS-2160] [PHI-1060/ CS-2160-1]

Faculty Name
Eric Paul Snyder [eric.snyder@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This is an introductory course to symbolic logic. Generally speaking, logic is the study of correct reasoning. Informal logic studies correct patterns of inference, in a relatively informal way. Formal logic, on the
other hand, studies correct patterns of inference, in a relatively formal way.  By “formal”, we just mean the way a mathematician might do it. Symbolic logic is formal logic, where correct patterns of inference are symbolized into an artificial language. This class will cover both informal and formal logic, and so will contain a mixture of symbolic and non-symbolic representations of arguments. The aim is to introduce students to basic logical concepts, different logical systems, various paradoxes and other conundrums central to the development of formal logic, and perhaps most importantly, to learn how to reason better, primarily through learning how to diagram and evaluate arguments, not only those found “in the wild”, but also one’s own arguments. Topics will include: logical notations, diagramming arguments, quantification, formal proofs, paradox, classical logic, modal logic, various non-classical logics, inductive logic, computer logic, metalogic, and some (light) set theory.

title: SYMBOLIC LOGIC
description:
Symbolic Logic [PHI-1060/ CS-2160] [PHI-1060/ CS-2160-2]

Faculty Name
Tammo Lossau [tammo.lossau@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Suppose that all Germans like Sauerkraut. Then, you may use the fact that I am a German to infer that I like Sauerkraut. However, you should not use the fact that Sarah likes Sauerkraut to infer that Sarah is German. Formal logic studies cases like this and provides us with a notion of deductive validity that can explain why the first inference is better than the second. In this course, we will develop this notion, along with a few others, by studying two formal languages called "propositional logic" and "first-order logic". These languages will allow us to precisely define validity and to check whether a given argument is valid in these languages. Understanding these languages will also be helpful for analyzing spoken languages, and it gives us an insight into computer processing and programming languages as well.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

No prerequisites or required readings. The course will be formally consistent with Volker Halbach's book The Logic Manual, but buying this book will not be necessary.

Grading Rubric

Weekly sets of homeworks plus two exams

Attendance Policy

Attendance mandatory

title: AI ETHICS
description:
AI Ethics [PHI-2678/ CS-3260/ POL-2097] [PHI-2678/ CS-3260/ POL-2097-1]

Faculty Name
Daniel Benjamin Weltman [danny.weltman@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This is a course examining the ethics of artificial intelligence. AI is having an increasingly large effect throughout the world and its use raises many ethical questions, both practical and theoretical. We will begin with some introductory topics. After that, the remaining topics will be chosen by class vote. If you have suggestions for topics, please let me know.

Learning Outcomes

Investigate some of the main issues in the intersection of AI and ethics

Improve your writing skills with a focus on concise summary and argumentation

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Jan 25: Shevlin, Vold, Crosby, and Halina, “The limits of machine intelligence”

Jan 27: Cave, Nyrup, Vold, and Weller, “Motivations and Risks of Machine Ethics”

Feb 1: Bostrom, “The Superintelligent Will: Motivation and Instrumental Rationality in Advanced Artificial Agents”

Feb 3: Schulz, “Machine Grading and Moral Learning”

Feb 8: Christiano, “Algorithms, Manipulation, and Democracy”

Feb 10: Hull, “Successful failure: what Foucault can teach us about privacy self-management in a world of Facebook and big data”

Feb 15: Benn and Lazar, “What’s Wrong with Automated Influence”

Feb 17: Talbot, Jenkins, Purves, “When Robots Should Do the Wrong Thing”

The rest of the schedule will be determined via voting on topics.

Possible topics include AI agency and responsibility, AI governance, AI moral patients, algorithm bias, algorithm fairness, autonomous vehicles, black boxes, human responsibility for AI, criminal law, killer robots, medical AI, moral robots, trust, and value alignment.

Attendance Policy

If you do not foresee being able to attend this class you should not enroll in this class.

title: THE PHILOSOPHY OF COMPUTABILITY
description:
The Philosophy of Computability [PHI-3250/ CS-3360] [PHI-3250/ CS-3360-1]

Faculty Name
Ernst Love Eric Johannesson [ernst.johannesson@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course provides an introduction to the technical notion of computability and to some of the philosophical issues surrounding it. More specifically, it will address questions such as:

  • What is a computable function?
  • What is a decidable problem?
  • What is a hard problem?
  • What is the relation between computability and formal reasoning?
  • What is the connection between the existence of undecidable problems and Gödel’s first incompleteness theorem?
  • What is the essential difference between a proof and a valid argument?
  • Does the existence of undecidable problems imply that the universe is inherently unpredictable?
  • What is it for a concrete physical system to implement an abstract computable function?
  • What is a machine learning algorithm, essentially?

Link to full course description: https://www.dropbox.com/s/fi58nwunppqg7sl/philosophy_of_computability.pdf?dl=0

title: INTRODUCTION TO CREATIVE WRITING
description:
Introduction to Creative Writing [CW-1001] [CW-1001-1]

Faculty Name
Janice Erica Pariat [janice.pariat@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Course description: In this course, students will experiment with two creative genres—poetry and fiction—as a means of developing different imaginative approaches to experience. The emphasis will be on generating substantial amounts of raw material, and advancing a body of this toward completion. Each craft lecture will be tied to a set of readings that will be discussed in class. At the end of the course, students will learn how to look at literature from the point of view of a practitioner and apply writing techniques to a variety of rhetorical situations. Anyone who wants to earn this minor or take creative writing courses, must successfully complete this course. There are no prerequisites for this course.

Grading Rubric

30% = Class participation: I want you to be attentive, be present and engaged. Remaining absent during workshop days will bring your down your grade significantly.

20% = Writing Exercises:​ We will do a writing prompt in almost every class. At the end of the semester, you will submit THREE writing prompts along with your final portfolio.

50% = Short Story (Between 1500-3000 words) and a Set of Poems (maximum six pages): You will write, workshop these and revise during the exam week. This will be a part of your final portfolio.

Attendance Policy

You are allowed up to TWO absences in the semester. Further absences will incur a .5

grade cut per absence.

description:

Faculty Name
Janice Erica Pariat [janice.pariat@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Course description:

This course functions as a “laboratory” for working writers of fiction. It will follow a studio format where each student takes turns to submit a piece of fiction that the class will workshop when they meet. Each submission is limited to 1,500-3,000 words. We will also be reading a series of short novellas through the semester to instigate class discussion on craft and literary technique.

Grading Rubric

30% = Class participation + Peer Feedback: I want you to be attentive, present and engaged. Remaining absent during workshop days for your peers will bring your down your grade significantly.

50% = Final portfolio comprising a fiction piece (maximum 8,000 words)

20% = Workshop Critique Packs: You will submit a critique (minimum one page) for TWO stories at the end of semester. I will review these to give you a grade. Your critiques will be written for the penultimate round of workshops conducted after midterm break.

title: READING FOR WRITING
description:
Reading for Writing [CW-1005] [CW-1005-1]

Faculty Name
Jatindra Kumar Nayak [jatindra.nayak@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Why do people write autobiographies or personal narratives? Why do readers find them interesting, even absorbing? Can autobiographies be read as history or can narratives chronicling an individual’s life illuminate aspects of larger historical processes? How does someone writing her/his autobiography construct out of private memories a coherent narrative? How does she/he negotiate identity? Does an autobiography provide a privileged access to the mode of consciousness of another person? Can autobiographical narratives, supposed to be based on verifiable facts relating to someone’s personal journey through life, be regarded as a form of creative writing? What challenges does one meet when one attempts to tell the story of one’s life?

The course aims at inviting students to address such questions. The rich tradition of writing autobiographies in India will provide a reference point and the larger context for discussion. Selected texts will be discussed with the students. They will be encouraged to reflect critically upon a genre that until recently was treated warily by historians and literary critics alike, but has now emerged as a vibrant field of study.

It involves reading 10 novellas and novels (tentative reading list below), participating in discussions, writing short papers, and making a presnetation. title: IS THERE A MODERN LITERATURE?
description:
Is There A Modern Indian Literature? [ENG-4405/ CW-4405] [ENG-4405/ CW-4405-1]

Faculty Name
Amit Prakash Chaudhuri [amit.chaudhuri@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

For ‘Is There a Modern Indian Literature?’, I will use the Picador Book of Modern Indian Literature and a few other texts, and some cinema and music. I also plan to bring in some material from outside India – the stories of Junichiro Tanizaki, for instance.  The question in the course title is one I asked myself as I began putting together the anthology I mention above in the late 1990s. How was one to conceive of a tradition called 'Indian literature'? Was it the total of thevarious literatures of India? Or was there another way of exploring this category? It was a time when the Indian novel in English and the idea of 'postcolonial literature' had begun to dominate. How did the modernist and avant garde trajectories of literatures in the Indian languages fit into these relatively recent categorisations? One of my own reasons for rethinking and enlarging the frame had to do with my affinities with modernism as a reader and writer, affinities that seemed out of place post-Midnight's Children, but not so out of place within the experimental histories of
modern Indian literatures themselves. The use of the word 'modern' was, and is, deliberate, to point to developments that the term 'postcolonial' doesn't address. The texts we'll read here would follow, without too much narrow systematising, ‘Indian literature’ and the way its emergence from the late nineteenth century in various languages embodied the trajectory of modernity, modernism, the avant garde, and formal preoccupations in India. The course means to question the largely theme-driven, Anglophone parameters of the ‘postcolonial’ that have been with us for some decades now.

'As in 2022, this will be a hybrid course, co-hosted by The Oxford Research Centre of the Humanities. Participants will join in from all over the world, but the core class will comprise Ashoka University students, who will take the course in person and will be required to write two essays of 1500 words each over the course of the semester.' 

Learning Outcomes

Students from Oxford and other universities will be sitting in on the class, and will participate in discussions. However, only Ashoka students will be writing essays, for which they'll be graded.

Grading Rubric

Grades will be given on the basis of two short essays to be written by each student over the term, plus class contributions. Essays should be shared with the tutor and other students at least four days prior to each class.

Attendance Policy

TBA

title: STORYTELLING IN THE DIGITAL AGE
description:
Storytelling in the Digital Age [MS-3051/ CW-2051/ VA-2015] [MS-3051/ CW-2051/ VA-2015-1]

Faculty Name
Natasha Badhwar [natasha.badhwar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course will focus on the creative process of using digital technology as a medium and a tool of narrating personal histories. We will create podcasts and videos using apps and software, but more importantly our own talent and skill with scripting, drawing, interview, monologue, multimedia visualization, videography, design and editing. 


AIM: The aim of this course is two-fold. Students will experiment with form using multimedia tools to combine audio, images, and video clips to tell a story. They will learn to create digital stories that explain a concept, make an argument, reflect on a personal experience and retell a family or community history. 
Through workshops and targeted assignments, each student will be encouraged to craft personal narratives that delve into conflicts of identity and privilege and lead to a deeper understanding of one’s own location in the intersecting grid of socio-economic, cultural as well as political hierarchies that dominate the times we live in. 

 

 

 

Learning Outcomes

Through practical exercises, writing and collective brainstorming, students will get familiar with both form and content of digital storytelling. They will acquire multimedia skills as well as engage in critical thinking and analysis as they complete their final projects for this course.

title: INTRODUCTION TO CRITICAL THINKING
description:
Introduction to Critical Thinking [CT-0001] [CT-0001-5]

Faculty Name
Arpita Das [arpita.das@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

In this course, you will develop and rehearse the habits that are essential to the development of a critical mind: reading, writing, speaking, listening and - of course - thinking. You will engage with a variety of source materials and understand how to ask questions that extend and enrich your understanding -- of situations, texts, institutions and people. You will explore the distinctness of academic research and writing, and participate in an active knowledge community constituted by your peers. By the close of the course, you will have a clearer understanding of what it means to be a scholar in an academic setting, and a keener sense of your own processes of learning, thinking and writing.

The theme this semester is Environmentalism Desi-Style where we read writings by Vandana Shiva, Ram Guha, Amita Baviskar, Mahesh Rangarajan, Nagaraj Adve, Arpitha Kodiveri and others to examine how environmentalism might mean different things for different people in South Asia, and how it has different ramifications in our part of the world than it does in the West. 

Most importantly, our classroom will be a safe space for discussion, debate and constructive disagreements. 

I like my classes to be as interactive and discussive as possible. 

If you feel unsure or diffident about speaking up in class, please do not worry; there will be many ways in which I can continue to get a sense of how you feel about various things under discussion, via the weekly blog, other written submissions, and our chats during office hours.

Learning Outcomes

Reading:

1. Breaking down texts into identifiable parts.

2. Making patterns and connections across texts

3. Building reading stamina and the ability to select texts

4. Understanding textual context, genre and source material and documenting these via strategic note-making.

Writing 

1. Developing the craft of outlining, revising, editing

2. Applying form, voice, style, tone to affect writing

3. Developing logical, coherent, structured writing

4. Using explanatory, narrative and justificatory writing

Thinking

1. Practising converting thoughts into words

2. Narrowing down a curiosity or thought into a question

3. Constructing and developing a reasoned argument

4. Engaging meaningfully with multiple perspectives

Speaking-Listening

1. Aiming for confidence, clarity, coherence 

2. Practising and harnessing audience engagement 

3. Developing active and respectful listening to others 

4. Engaging meaningfully with ongoing discussions

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

You can expect to do regular reading (of academic texts and wider materials) in this course. These will be specified on a weekly basis on the schedule at the end of this outline. In addition, you can expect to write consistently, participate in giving and taking feedback, and work on medium-term projects both individually and in collaboration with your course mates.

Grading Rubric

The ICT will be graded on a rubric. The weightage of the elements, their exact definition, and the decision to add new elements, will be equally divided between the following parameters:

 

1. Participation (in classes, office hours’ meetings, and the weekly blog)

2. Research paper (a longform argumentative paper with citations, written in academic style)

3. Small summative written assignments (including a written quiz at mid-term) 

4. Presentations in class (including a group-based semester-end Debate)

Attendance Policy

For this course, you are allowed three unexcused absences (for which you do not need permission from the instructor) and two excused absences (for which you do need permission from the instructor). The penalty for any absence beyond these five will be decided by the ICT instructor on a case-by-case basis. Please note that a consistent pattern of non-attendance may include discretionary penalties such as grade cuts.

title: MATHEMATICS FOR ECONOMICS
description:
Mathematics for Economists [ECO-1010] [ECO-1010-1]

Faculty Name
Suraj Shekhar [suraj.shekhar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course is compulsory for all Economics Majors, PPE as well as Economics Minors. The course
introduces students to the mathematical techniques necessary for the study of economics at the
undergraduate level. Amongst other topics, the course will cover univariate and multivariate calculus,
optimization and linear algebra.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Any one of the following textbooks would provide useful guidance to you. However, I will mostly rely on my
notes/slides for teaching.


a) Essential Mathematics for Economic Analysis by Sydsaeter, Hammond and Strom (4th or newer
edition)
b) Mathematics for Economic Analysis by Sydsaeter and Hammond

title: MATHEMATICS FOR ECONOMICS
description:
Mathematics for Economists [ECO-1010] [ECO-1010-3]

Faculty Name
Mihir Bhattacharya [mihir.bhattacharya@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course is compulsory for all Economics Majors, PPE as well as Economics Minor. This course introduces students to all the mathematical tools necessary for the study of economics at the undergraduate level. We start with preliminary topics like logic and reasoning. First few topics include set theory, linear equations and their solutions. We will learn to apply these concepts to some applications from economics. We will then cover univariate and multivariate calculus, and rules of differentiation. Some of the material will be proof-based and technical. Once basic calculus is covered, we will study optimization techniques and linear algebra. We will apply theorems from these topics to different optimization problems in Economics like the consumer's utility maximization problem.

Learning Outcomes

 By the end of the course students should be adept at calculating derivatives, slopes of different graphs, concavity and convexity, single variable and multivariable optimization, Lagrange method.

Students are expected to learn proof techniques like the method of contradiction, direct proof, contrapositive, and mathematical induction. This will enable them to learn more advanced topics in Economics.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Main textbooks:  

1. Sydsæter and Hammond's, Mathematics for Economic Analysis, 2002, Pearson Education.

2. Chiang and Wainwright’s Fundamental Methods of Mathematical Economics, 4th Edition,  McGraw Hill Education 

Others: 

1. Chiang, Alpha C. “Fundamental Methods of Mathematical Economics.”  

2. Hoy, Livernois, McKenna, Rees, Stengos, “Mathematics for Economics”, MIT Press.  3. Simon and Blume's “Mathematics for Economists”, Norton Press.

Grading Rubric

Grading weights: 15% for class participation, 20% for Assignments/Quizzes and tests, 30% for midterms and 35% for finals.  Bonus points for exceptional class participation.

Relative grading but conditional on thresholds being cleared. For example, if a student has top rank but has scored below 85% of the total, that student may not qualify for the highest grade. This does not mean that anyone above 85% will get the highest grade. Similar thresholds will exist for other grades as well. 

 

Attendance Policy

Since there is 15% weightage on class participation, attendance is compulsory. Students who consistently respond in class and offer interesting comments get points throughout the semester.

Use of laptops and mobile phones are not allowed. All handwriting-based ipads, tablets and notepads are allowed.

title: ECONOMETRICS
description:
Econometrics [ECO-2400] [ECO-2400-3]

Faculty Name
Anisha Sharma [anisha.sharma@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This is a standard introductory econometrics course for undergraduates pursuing a major or an interdisciplinary major in economics. Through this course, we will understand how to infer economic relationships from data. We will learn a number of tools economists use to analyse data, and apply these tools to datasets using Stata.

Students must have a basic understanding of statistics and mathematical tools for economists. As such, students should have completed the Mathematics and Statistics courses offered by the Economics department.

Attachment

title: ECONOMETRICS
description:
Econometrics [ECO-2400] [ECO-2400-6]

Faculty Name
Kanika Mahajan [kanika.mahajan@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This will be an introductory course in econometrics. It will build on the concepts of statistical inference with the aim to apply them to data and enable understanding of economic relationships. The course will have both a theoretical and an application-based part. The theory will involve understanding the method of least squares estimation and the application part will involve data visualization and analyses using STATA computing software.

Learning Outcomes

The crux of econometrics is to be able to test hypothesis about a population using a sample. We begin by building on our understanding of a population and a sample and the basics of hypothesis testing. The course then moves onto the methods of estimation to understand causal relationships between variables. These methods are not just restricted to economics but are also relevant to the study of political science, sociology and public policy in general. The emphasis will be on inferring causality throughout the course. By the end of this course you should be able to understand and apply the taught econometric methods to test a relevant hypothesis of interest using data, interpret the results and draw appropriate conclusions. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Textbooks and Articles

SJeffrey M. Wooldridge [JMW], Introductory Econometrics: A Modern Approach, 4th or 5th edition

Cameron, A.C. and Trivedi, P.K [CT]. Microeconometrics using Stata, 2nd ed., Stata Press, 2010

 

Course Outline

Chapter 1-7 of JMW will form the core of this course. Below is topic wise course outline.

 

1. Review of Statistics: Random variables, Joint distribution, Probability Distributions, Sampling, Estimation, Hypothesis Testing

Appendix A, B and C [JMW]

 

2. Nature of Econometrics:

Chapter 1 [JMW] and Chapter 1 [Mastering Metrics by Joshua Angrist and Jörn Steffen Pischke, this will be circulated]

 

3. Simple Regression Model: Estimation, Inference

Chapter 1 and 2 [JMW]

 

4. Multiple Regression Model: Estimation, Inference

Chapter 3 (exclude appendix 3A), 4, and 6(exclude prediction interval and prediction error, Appendix 6A) [JMW]

 

5. Dummy Variables in a Regression Model

Chapter 7 (exclude testing for difference in Regression functions across Groups and section 7.5) [JMW]

Grading Rubric

Home-assignments:  20%

Class quizzes: 20%

Mid-term:  30%

Final:  30%

 

Homework problems will generally be assigned from Wooldridge. Homework assessments will be submitted individually. Group discussions are allowed but plagiarism will be dealt with a fail grade on the assessment. For STATA based assessments, printouts of output should be accompanied with proper explanations and do/log file must be emailed. Assignments must be submitted in time. Late submission will not be graded. The quizzes will not be announced and no make-up will be allowed for missed quizzes.

 

Tutorials will be held by the Teaching Assistant for one hour per week from week 2. The time and location will be announced later.

Attendance Policy

Attendance will not be used as an eligibility to sit for exams and will not count towards any assessment but is highly encouraged. Class participation is also recommended. This course forms the basis for electives that follow in the coming semesters and conceptual gaps that remain will snowball later.

title: PUBLIC ECONOMICS
description:
Public Economics [ECO-3630] [ECO-3630-1]

Faculty Name
Bhanu Gupta [bhanu.gupta@ashoka.edu.in] ,Satyam Kumar Rai [satyamkumarrai_phd20@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course will cover the role of government in modern economies. We will dig deep into the study of various instruments used to generate government revenue and analyze efficient ways to spend government monies. You will also be exposed to microeconomic models that are used to study the reaction of agents to government policies.  This course will serve as a comprehensive introduction to various empirical tools used in modern public economics. Government expenditure, externalities, public goods, taxation, social security programs,  are some of the topics that will be covered in this course. Abstract concepts will be mapped to real-world examples to develop your public economics intuition.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The main course material will be papers assigned during the course. In case you haven’t studied public economics during undergraduate studies, please refer to the following textbook:

Gruber, J., Public Finance & Public Policy (I am using the 5th edition).

A list of topics that will be discussed in the course are given below. Please note that subject to time constraints, topics may be added or deleted from this list. List of topics are: Introduction to Public Economics; Defining and Measuring Inequality; Theoretical and Emprical Tools for Public Economics; Tax Incidence and Efficiency costs of Taxation; Optimal Labor Income Taxation; Taxes and Labor Supply; Externalities; Public Goods; Taxes on Capital and Savings; Behavioral Public Finance; Political Economy; Social and Health Insurance; Education and Discrimination. 

Grading Rubric

Homeworks: 20% 

Exams (Mid-term and Final): 30% 

Class presentation: 10% 

Term paper: 40%

Attendance Policy

None.

title: ECONOMETRICS I
description:
Econometrics 1 [ECO-5401] [ECO-5401-1]

Faculty Name
Kanika Mahajan [kanika.mahajan@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

In today’s world analyzing any problem at hand using data is an important skill. This course is designed to equip students to learn the statistical tools for analyzing real life data, related to economics in particular and social sciences in general. This course will focus on both theoretical knowledge as well as implementation of theory through software applications like STATA and real datasets.

Learning Outcomes

The main thrust of the course will be data analysis using multivariate regression technique, followed by specific econometric tools for cross-sectional and program evaluation. An important objective of this course is to acquaint students with the language of advanced econometrics so that they can later pick-up higher order courses in this area.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Prerequisites

Statistics

 

Textbooks and Articles

Jeffrey M. Wooldridge, Introductory Econometrics: A Modern Approach, 4th or 5th edition (JMW)

Wooldridge, J. Econometric Analysis of Cross Section and Panel Data, 2nd ed., MIT Press, 2010. (CSPD)

Cameron, A.C. and Trivedi, P.K. Microeconometrics using Stata, 2nd ed., Stata Press, 2010

Angrist, J.D and Pischke, J.-S. Mostly Harmless Econometrics, Princeton University Press, 2008. (MHE)

Mathematical Statistics with Applications, John E. Freund, Irwin Miller and Marylees Miller, 8th editions (Freund)

Greene, W.H., Econometric Analysis, (7th edition), Pearson, 2012 (Optional)

 

Grading Rubric

Evaluation

Homeworks:  35%

Mid-term:  25%

Final:  40%

Homework problems will generally be based on data. Homework assessments will be submitted individually. Group discussions are allowed but plagiarism will be dealt with a fail grade on the assessment. For STATA based assessments, printouts of output should be accompanied with proper outputs and explanations. Assignments must be submitted in time. Late submission will not be graded. Cheating during exams will be dealt with by a fail grade on the course.

Attendance Policy

Attendance will not affect your grades. But past data shows high positive correlation between the two. You can choose!

title: INTRODUCTION TO ECONOMICS
description:
Introduction to Economics [ECO-1001] [ECO-1001-1]

Faculty Name
Sneha Bakshi [sneha.bakshi@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course will be an introduction into the economic way of thinking about the world and of analyzing questions and figuring out answers. It will cover both Microeconomics and Macroeconomics and lay the foundation for the methodology and practices in both.

Learning Outcomes

This course will aim to equip students with basic comprehension of demand, supply, markets, the economic basis for trade, national income accounting, prices and inflation, real and nominal measures of GDP, and help students understand externalities and welfare, the choices in the labor market and its resulting level of employment, and the role of government in markets and the economy. Additional topics in Micro & Macro economics might be covered depending on the pace of the course.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Course material will use recommended textbooks and excerpts from journal articles, news and other media, and other sources. The recommended textbooks are:

The Economy, by The CORE project/team: https://www.core-econ.org/project/core-the-economy/

The Economy: A South Asian Perspective, by The CORE project/team: https://www.core-econ.org/project/the-economy-a-south-asian-perspective/

Grading Rubric

25% of course grade on class participation; 35% on quizzes/assignments spaced out through the semester; and 40% on final exams.

Attendance Policy

Attendance is important for this course. There will be short quizzes in class without any pre-announcement. Students will be graded on their responses in these quizzes, either individually or in groups, as well as on attendance taken randomly in class. Together these will be considered as the students’ performance on ‘class participation’.

Course material will use recommended textbooks and excerpts from journal articles, news and other media, and other sources. The recommended textbooks are:

The Economy, by The CORE project/team: https://www.core-econ.org/project/core-the-economy/

The Economy: A South Asian Perspective, by The CORE project/team: https://www.core-econ.org/project/the-economy-a-south-asian-perspective/

Grading Rubric

25% of course grade on class participation; 35% on quizzes/assignments spaced out through the semester; and 40% on final exams.

Attendance Policy

Attendance is important for this course. There will be short quizzes in class without any pre-announcement. Students will be graded on their responses in these quizzes, either individually or in groups, as well as on attendance taken randomly in class. Together these will be considered as the students’ performance on ‘class participation’.

title: MICROECONOMICS 2
description:
Microeconomics 2 [ECO-5102] [ECO-5102-1]

Faculty Name
Ratul Lahkar [ratul.lahkar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This is an advanced course on game theory and applications. We will study the four fundamental types of games. They are (1) static games of complete information, (2) dynamic games of incomplete information, (3) static games of incomplete information and (4) dynamic games of incomplete information. In each of these topics, we will study the fundamental game theoretic solutions and important economic applications. 

Learning Outcomes

1. Static games of complete information: Dominant strategies, rationalizability, Nash equilibrium and applications like oligopoly and externalities. 

2. Dynamic games of complete information: Backward induction, subgame perfection and applications like limit pricing, bargaining and repeated games. 

3. Static games of incomplete information: Bayesian Nash equilibrium and applications like auctions and mechanism design.

4. Dynamic games of incomplete information: Perfect Bayesian equilibrium and applications like adverse selection and moral hazard.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

1. "Microeconomic Theory" by Mas-Colell, Whinston and Green,

2. "Game Theory-An Introduction" by Steven Tadelis. 

Grading Rubric

Homework: 20%; Midterm: 40%; Final: 40%.

Attendance Policy

No attendance requirement. But attendance is higly recommended in order to keep up with the class.

title: MICROECONOMICS 2
description:
Macroeconomics 2 [ECO-5202] [ECO-5202-1]

Faculty Name
Ronit Mukherji [ronit.mukherji@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course is compulsory for all students in MA Economics and Ph.D. students.
This course is the second course in the macroeconomics sequence for first-year MA and Ph.D. students. Having been exposed to ideas and models of macroeconomic growth in Macroeconomics I, this course introduces students to modern macroeconomic theories that seek to explain short-run fluctuations.
How do macroeconomists explain short-run macroeconomic fluctuations? And how does this inform macroeconomic policy? This course will provide an in-depth introduction to modern macroeconomic models of business cycles. We will start with some topics on real business cycles. Then the course will then cover the extensions of the model to deal with the shortcomings with respect to labour markets and real dynamics. These extensions will cover various leading macroeconomic theories of labour markets, investment, and consumption. Finally, we will study topics from New Keynesian Economics. The policy implications of these models will be studied throughout.

Learning Outcomes

By the end of the course, students should have a firm grasp of:
• Real Business Cycle Models
• Real Dynamics - Search Models of Labour Markets, Adjustment Cost Models of Investment and Capital Formation, and Consumption.
• New Keynesian Models

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

• Romer, D., Advanced Macroeconomics (4th Edition or later)
• Gali, J., Monetary Policy, Inflation and the Business Cycle - An Introduction to the New Keynesian Framework, Princeton University Press
Students should have a copy of the textbooks, henceforth referred to as Romer, and Gali respectively. The prescribed readings will be taken from Romer (4th Edition) and Gali (1st Edition). Students with later editions of the textbooks will need to cross-check readings with the earlier editions.
In addition to the prescribed textbooks, other textbooks (wherever relevant), and lecture readings from Journal articles will also be provided. Students will be expected to complete these readings as well as those from the textbooks to get a complete grasp of each of the topics.
A detailed reading list, including textbook references, will be available in the separate Reading List document.

Grading Rubric

Student grades have the following components:

Exams(2*30%=60%),

Assignments (2*15% = 30%)

Class Attendance and Participation (10%).

Attendance Policy

No strict attendance policy but students are expected to attend all classes. Exams are compulsory and must be taken on the day specified with no exceptions.

title: FINANCIAL MARKET AND ASSET PRICING
description:
Financial Markets and Asset Pricing [FIN-3001/ ECO-3203] [FIN-3001/ ECO-3203-1]

Faculty Name
Arghya Bhattacharya [arghya.bhattacharya@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course focuses on the pricing of financial assets. We will talk mostly about the equity market, but later we will also discuss options (puts & calls). The course revolves around different models or methods, that *might* help us identify mispriced financial assets which in turn could help us design a reasonably good portfolio. These methods and models have some kind of economic or accounting rationale behind them and some of them are based on groundbreaking papers published in the last century. Despite all that, a student in this course would eventually come to realize that no one model/ method is enough to help us understand the true value of a financial asset. In fact, it is extremely hard to explain why a given object has a particular value and whether that object is overpriced or underpriced. Renowned statistician, George Box once said - "all models are wrong, but some are useful". That is what we will try to do in this course - study some models that have been useful in the context of asset pricing. To be specific, we will study Markowitz portfolio selection, index models, capital asset pricing model (CAPM), and its variants, arbitrage pricing theory, Fama-French three-factor model, efficient market hypothesis, equity valuation models, and later we will study options, put-call parity, Black-Scholes' options pricing.

Attendance Policy

If you are not in the habit of attending lectures regularly and in a timely fashion (not arriving late/ leaving early), then do not sign up for my courses be it the Monetary Economics or the Financial Markets & Asset Pricing course. The penalty for lack of participation (attendance being a chief component) will be announced shortly. Watch this space for more details.

title: MACROECONOMIC THEORY 2
description:
Macroeconomic Theory II [ECO-2202] [ECO-2202-1]

Faculty Name
Pubali Chakraborty [pubali.chakraborty@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This is the second course in the Macroeconomics sequence at the undergraduate level. The focus of this course is studying economic outcomes in the long run. We will primarily be learning about theoretical models pertaining to economic growth and current empirical patterns associated with it. We will discuss the different sources of growth: technological change, accumulation of physical and human capital, population growth, geography and government. Students are expected to be well versed with concepts of functions, derivatives, integrals, ordinary differential equations.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The following textbooks are required for this course. You must obtain a hard or a soft copy of the books.

  • Introduction to Economic Growth, by Charles I. Jones and Dietrich Vollrath. Third Edition
  • Economic Growth, by David N Weil. Third Edition
Grading Rubric

Tentative.

  • Quizzes: 15%
  • Assignments: 30%
  • Midterm Exam: 20%
  • Final Exam (cumulative): 35%
Attendance Policy

None.

title: MACROECONOMIC THEORY 2
description:
Macroeconomic Theory II [ECO-2202] [ECO-2202-5]

Faculty Name
Anuradha Saha [anuradha.saha@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The process of economic growth and differences in patterns of growth within and across economies are some of the most interesting areas in economics. This course provides an introduction to the study of economic growth. The first two units of the course will be a theoretical exploration on the different sources of growth – population growth, technological change, accumulation of physical and human capital, geography, government and structural change. The analysis of these economic models will set the stage for the last unit where we will look at empirical studies on current patterns of growth. Students must be mathematically comfortable with concepts of functions, derivatives, integrals, ordinary differential equations. Some basic knowledge on regression analysis is also required.

Learning Outcomes

See the Course Schedule

Grading Rubric

title: MACROECONOMIC THEORY 2
description:
Macroeconomic Theory II [ECO-2202] [ECO-2202-6]

Faculty Name
Nishant Chadha [nishant.chadha@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This is a course in Economic Growth Theory. 

One of the most enduring questions in economics is about the differences in incomes, and more generally living standards, of people across countries, across states and provinces or indeed over time. An average Indian today is 22 times richer than they were in 1960. And yet an average American today is 30 times richer than an average Indian. These differences in the standard of living are even more stark if we expand the set of countries. So to paraphrase the economic historian David Landes: “Why are they so rich and we so poor?”.  

This course will introduce the students to the basics of modern economic growth theory. We will begin the course by formalising the measure of 'standard of living'. The discussion of growth theories will start with the seminal model of economic growth, the Solow model. We will then cover topics in endogenous growth theory, the economics of ideas, and technology transfer. This part will highlight the role of  R&D and innovation in economic growth. The second part of the course will study some fundamental causes of economic growth such as the role of institutions. Given their ubiquitous nature in the modern world, we will also spend some time trying to understand the relationship between emerging technologies such as Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML), and economic growth. We will end by looking at the relationship between economic growth and exhasutible natural resources.

Students must be comfortable with functions, derivatives, and optimisation, integrals, simple differential equations. Some basic knowledge of regression analysis is also required. So please ensure to brush up these topics before the course.

Learning Outcomes

What is economic growth? How do economists measure economic growth?

What are the proximate and ultimate causes of economic growth?

Basic knowledge of various economic growth models

How can poorer economies catch up with the richer ones? How does one apply the knowledge obtained through the economic models.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The course will rely on the following as its primary text. I will follow the chapters in this book closely.

Introduction to Economics Growth, Jones and Vollrath, 3 Ed

Another useful reference is the following book

Economic Growth, David Weil, 2 Ed

In addition I will use some journal articles and data sources that I will discuss and covey during classes. 

Grading Rubric

25% assignments (total five in number)

20% mid-term exam,

40% end-term exam, and

15% class participation

Assignments and exams will be returned to students within two weeks of the submission date. The grading policy is not open to change.

Attendance Policy

I like my classes to be lively! Therefore we will work with the following attendance policy.

The course has a 15% class participation component out of which 5% will be awarded on the basis of attendance in class. Grades for attendance will not be linear. You will lose 0.5% of the grade for every class you miss for the first five classes. Absence beyond that will mean you lose the entire grade for attendance.

The rest of the 10% class participation grade will be based on regular participation in class as well as special in-class discussion sessions (15 - 20 mins each) that we will have about 3 - 4 times during the semester.

title: MICROECONOMIC THEORY 2
description:
Microeconomic Theory II [ECO-2102] [ECO-2102-1]

Faculty Name
Dhritiman Gupta [dhritiman.gupta@ashoka.edu.in] ,Swagata Bhattacharjee [swagata.bhattacharjee@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The course, the second one in the Microeconomics sequence, is an introduction to strategic reasoning. While Microeconomics I focused on single agent decision making, in this course we will explore strategic interactions when multiple economic actors make decisions and each one's action affects the others. Economists use the mathematical toolkit of Game Theory to study strategic interactions. The course will, therefore, equip you with the toolkit of game theory. We will cover complete information games and its applications in different contexts like firm competitions, auctions, public good provision, etc. Time permitted, we will also discuss the games of incomplete information and Bayesian learning.

Learning Outcomes

The course will teach you one of the most widely used tool in modern microeconomics: game theory. You should be able to model real life situations using game theoretic reasoning and apply the logic.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

    Textbook:

  ∙  Strategy: An Introduction to Game Theory by Joel Watson (ISBN: 9788130915999)
  ∙  A Course in Game Theory by Osborne and Rubinstein (ISBN: 9788120351868)
  ∙  The main reference will be the lecture slides outlining the material, which will be uploaded weekly on Moodle.

Grading Rubric


Assignments    15%
Class Participation    15%
Midterms    20%+20%
Final    30%
 

Attendance Policy

Attendance in lectures and active class participation is highly recommended. The in-class quizzes will not be announced beforehand and missed quizzes can not be taken at any other time.

title: MICROECONOMIC THEORY 2
description:
Microeconomic Theory II [ECO-2102] [ECO-2102-3]

Faculty Name
Abhinash Borah [abhinash.borah@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The course introduces strategic reasoning and its consequences for outcomes in markets and other economic, social, and political institutions. The formal toolkit economists use to study strategic reasoning is game theory. The course will, therefore, equip you with a thorough understanding of game theory and its two building blocks: normal and extensive form games. Along with this, the course will also demonstrate the power of this tool kit by showing how it can be used to answer substantive questions in the economic and socio-political domains. A portion of the course will be devoted to understanding strategic problems involving asymmetric information. For this, we will develop the language of Bayesian games. We will study the consequences of asymmetric information on the operation of markets and why it can result in inefficiencies and market failures. In other words, we will demonstrate why the message and scope of the First Welfare Theorem that you learned in Micro 1 may be severely constrained in the presence of asymmetric information (and, indeed, when any of the implicit and explicit assumptions of the competitive framework like the presence of complete markets or the absence of externalities are violated). Two leading themes in asymmetric information are moral hazard and adverse selection, and we will discuss both. 

The broad philosophy with which I will approach these topics is to demonstrate the methodology and aesthetics of Economics and the powerful tools that economists have developed to systematically study what, at first pass, may appear to be analytically intractable problems. Overall, our investigation into these matters will be as analytical as it will be methodological and, at times, philosophical and historical. 

Learning Outcomes

An appreciation of the methodology of economics and an understanding of the primary language economists use to study social interactions. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Please see the attached syllabus.

Grading Rubric

Please see the attached syllabus.

Attendance Policy

Please see the attached syllabus.

Attachment
Syllabus-ECO 2102.pdf

title: MICROECONOMIC THEORY 2
description:
Microeconomic Theory II [ECO-2102] [ECO-2102-6]

Faculty Name
Dhritiman Gupta [dhritiman.gupta@ashoka.edu.in] ;

title: ECONOMICS OF DISCRIMINATION
description:
Economics of Discrimination [ECO-6670] [ECO-6670-1]

Faculty Name
Ashwini Deshpande [ashwini.deshpande@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course familiarizes students with theories and empirical tools to understand and measure economic discrimination based on social group identities, such as caste, race, gender, tribal status, ethnicity and so on. The course will focus on evidence related to caste and sex in India. 

The first part of the course will take students through theories of discrimination such as statistical discrimination and taste for discrimination, based on the work of Kenneth Arrow, Gary Becker and George Akerlof.  This will lead to a discussion of the overlap between economics of discrimination and related sub-disciplines that are relatively new but are rapidly expanding, viz., “Identity Economics”, pioneered by George Akerlof and Rachel Kranton, “Feminist Economics”, and “Stratification Economics”. 

The second section will introduce students to concepts in social psychology such as stereotype threat and implicit bias that produce discriminatory outcomes. 

The third part of the course introduces students to some of the key methods of empirically gauging discrimination in market settings. This section would familiarize students with decomposition analyses applied to the labour market (what part of the wage gap between two groups is due to differences in abilities, and what part is due to discrimination), using standard techniques from Labour Economics. We would also discuss experimental methods – both field-based as well as lab-based experiments to gauge discrimination outside the labour market (e.g. housing market), or in the field of charitable giving, or even in labour markets but during the job search process (before applicants find jobs).  

Students will be familiarized with literature that applies these methods in the Indian context, particularly to the study of caste and gender discrimination. 

The final part of the course will deal with policy options to deal with group-based disparities and discrimination, with a focus on affirmative action policies. This section will outline the various types of affirmative action, including quotas or reservation, and discuss debates around affirmative action, focusing on evidence-based research gauging its impact.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Note: This reading list could see minor changes during the semester which will be announced well ahead of time. 

I.               How does social identity shape economic outcomes? 

 

Akerlof, George. 1984. “The economics of caste and of the rat race and other woeful tales”, in An Economic Theorist’s Book of Tales, Cambridge University Press, 1984, models of statistical discrimination and the caste economy. 

Becker, Gary. 1957. The Economics of Discrimination, Chs. 1, 2 and 10

 Akerlof, George A. and Rachel Kranton. 2010. Identity Economics: how our identities shape our work, wages and well-being, Princeton University Press, Chs. 1-4

title: ECONOMICS OF AGRICULTURAL TRANSFORMATION
description:
Economics of Agricultural Transformation [ECO-6690] [ECO-6690-1]

Faculty Name
Bharat Ramaswami [bharat.ramaswami@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course looks at economic development through the lens of food and agriculture.  As we shall see, such a view can offer a powerful framework for understanding economic development outcomes.  It is also productive in suggesting new lines of enquiry. 

The main theoretical framework is drawn from models of structural transformation.  While these are macro models, the empirical analysis uses the techniques of micro-econometrics.  

The course is heavily based on research papers - mostly published in recent years.  

Learning Outcomes

By the end of this course, you will understand the processes of structural transformation and how they are modelled and tested.  You will also gain an understanding of the economics of the major challenges within agriculture.  These will supply you a framework for thinking of developmental issues relating to structural transformation and agriculture.  A second goal of the course is for you to get comfortable with reading, analyzing and presenting research papers.  

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The detailed course outline will soon be distributed.  For now, I am enclosing the course outline from 2021.  There will be some changes but the broad structure will remain the same.
