title: INTERNATIONAL FINANCE
description:
International Finance [FIN-3030/ ECO-3303] [FIN-3030/ ECO-3303-1]

Faculty Name
Biswajit Banerjee [biswajit.banerjee@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The objective of this course is to provide a framework for making corporate financial decisions in an international context. Managing an international business or one exposed to global competition requires an understanding of international financial instruments, markets, and institutions. This course seeks to provide a working knowledge of these issues. The stress will be on an understanding of the intuition behind the theories, not on mathematical proofs or on replicating empirical results from the literature. The course will not shy away from complex ideas but will try to make the ideas as accessible as possible. Solving mathematical financial problems is an important part of the course.

The course will address the following main topics: national income accounting and balance of payments; global economic developments and outlook; growth and slowdown of globalization; international financial systems; foreign exchange market and exchange rate determination; foreign currency derivative instruments; arbitrage and international parity conditions; risks in global finance (e.g., foreign exchange risk and country risk), and the management of foreign exchange risk with forwards and options

Learning Outcomes

Students will develop a strong foundation to follow economic developments across countries and recognize their interlinkages and spillovers.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

There will be no single required text book for the course. Recommended books include:

International Finance: Theory and Policy by Paul R. Krugman, Maurice Obstfeld, and Marc Melitz, Pearson.

International Financial Management, by Cheol Eun and Bruce Resnick, McGraw-Hill- Irwin. 

International Finance: Theory into Practice by Piet Sercu, Princeton University Press

The Globalization Paradox, by Dani Rodrik, Norton & Co.

Financial Times; Wall Street Journal; The Economist

 

Grading Rubric

There will be six quizzes during the semester and one mid-term exam. There will be no make-up quizzes or make-up exam for any reason.  

The overall grade for the course will be the aggregate scores of the six quizzes (60% of the grade) and mid-term exam (40% of the grade). If a student misses any quiz or exam, she/he will be marked a zero score for that particular quiz/exam. If you miss any quiz or exam for valid medical reasons, you must provide a certificate from a registered medical practitioner or hospital.

The final letter-grading will be on a curve. The distribution of final grades will be such that no more than 15% will receive an "A" grade, no more than 15% will receive an "A minus grade" and no more than 20% of the class will receive a "B+" grade

Attendance Policy

Attendance is not compulsory. However, students are encouraged to attend classes regularly to get the most benefits from the course.

title: COMPUTER PROGRAMMING AND APPLICATIONS
description:
Computer Programming and Applications [ECO-6800] [ECO-6800-1]

Faculty Name
Kush Khurana [kush.khurana@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This hands-on course intends to equip students with the necessary computational tools to apply grad-level economics & statistics to real world problems. While establishing solid foundations in computer programming & data science, the course will focus on applications that not only bring about a deeper appreciation for concepts being taught in other courses but also inspire the students to apply computational techniques to venture confidently into new areas. The intended audience for this course is First Year MA economics students.

Learning Outcomes

By the end of the course, students will be able to:

  1. Write python code at least as comfortably as they are able to write math in their notebooks, if not more.
  2. Set up their own Virtual-Lab (using Jupyter); Extract, Transform, Analyse data quickly. Build visualizations & communicate results lucidly.
  3. Naturally incorporate computation (as a technology) in their learning & research workflows to:
    1. Enhance understanding (deeper appreciation of abstract math/stats concepts and insights into economic models),
    2. Build richer applications, and
    3. Attack problems which cannot be solved on paper or otherwise.
  4. Translate mathematical concepts into actionable code, especially in the areas of Linear Algebra, Optimization & Statistics that are relevant to economics.
  5. Venture on their own into picking up advanced computational technologies after the course ends, owing to the strong foundations established in their course.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

- To truly deliver the learning outcomes of this course, it is recommended that each student has a laptop and brings it to the class. Pen and paper can-be distractions in fact – as the core vision of the course is to empower you to transform what you are thinking into something actionable, by harnessing the computational power of machines.

- For students with zero or limited exposure to basic computer science concepts, here is a fun and accessible intro (free Harvard Course): CS50's Introduction to Computer Science | edX . This will also serve as a refresher in case you have not studied programming after school.

Grading Rubric

The grading process is focused on bringing the best out of each student and therefore encourages continuously practicing and iterating to get better:

  1. Weekly Programming Assignments, where the students are encouraged to Collaborate to make the learning process quicker, richer & fun (40%).
  2. Class Interaction: In-class programming tasks, error-spotting, Q&As to encourage Attentiveness (20%) *
  3. Keystone Project: Towards the end of course, students will be asked to form groups of 3 – each group will build an application of their choice and present it to the class. This is to encourage Innovation and Independent thinking (40%).
Attendance Policy

Note that there is an Attentiveness bit in grading (20% weightage). Attendance though, is a necessary, but not a sufficient condition for Attentiveness 😊.

title: ECONOMIC FORECASTING AND ANALYSIS
description:
Economic Forecasting and Analysis [ECO-3402] [ECO-3402-1]

Faculty Name
Kavita Sardana [kavita.sardana@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

There are several ways that time series data is different from cross-sectional data. When using time series data for forecasting, the Ordinary Least Square Method is often incorrect due to violations of the Gauss-Markov assumptions. The nature of these violations is described in this course, to introduce methods for rectification. To ensure that the standard asymptotic analysis is accurate, we address constraints that limit the temporal correlation in a time series as we can no longer assume random sampling. Most macroeconomic models are multivariate, which permits feedback between the models' variables. Therefore, in this course, the study of univariate and multivariate processes for forecasting is given equal weight. This course gives emphasis on solving computer exercises. 

Empirical exercises will involve applications from the fields of macroeconomics and financial derivatives. All computer exercises will be solved using statistical software STATA.

Learning Outcomes

After completing this course, the students will be able to

1. Distinguish problems in econometrics relating to cross-section and time series

2. To theoretically and empirically formulate problems that can be resolved using time series analysis

3. Proficiency in use of statistical package

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

ECO 2400 (Econometrics)

Grading Rubric

Mid-term and final exam with 50% weightage each. Both exams will have a theory and a practical component. 

Attendance Policy

Attendance is mandatory.

title: GAME THEORY AND APPLICATIONS
description:
Game Theory and Applications [ECO-3100] [ECO-3100-1]

Faculty Name
Bhaskar Dutta [bhaskar.dutta@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Please see uploaded file. 

Learning Outcomes

The main purpose of the course is to introduce  students to the wide range of areas in which standard tools of game theory have been applied.

title: ASYMMETRIC INFORMATION MODELS
description:
Asymmetric Information Models [ECO-6101] [ECO-6101-1]

Faculty Name
Suraj Shekhar [suraj.shekhar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This is an advanced course in microeconomics. Knowledge of basic game theory will be assumed. The objective of this course is to equip the students with the tools to build and analyse models of strategic behaviour in environments with asymmetric information. We will then take these tools and apply them to study real-life problems. Specific topics include Bayesian equilibrium, models of moral hazard and adverse selection, and applications to microfinance, insurance, herd behaviour and advertising.

title: FIRM AND SECTORAL DYNAMICS
description:
Firm and Sectoral Dynamics [ECO-6300] [ECO-6300-1]

Faculty Name
Anuradha Saha [anuradha.saha@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course discusses growth in a disaggregated economy. We look at multi-sector growth models to understand how preferences, productivity differences and factor intensity differences contribute to structural change. We also discuss how firms innovate and imitate in an economy. While a major part of the course would be applied and based on current affairs, we would draw motivation for our discussion from the existing empirical literature. Expertise in calculus (especially differential equations) is a prerequisite.

title: INTERNATIONAL TRADE
description:
International Trade [ECO-3301] [ECO-3301-1]

Faculty Name
Abhishek Rai [abhishek.rai@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Why do countries trade? Who gains and who loses from international trade? How have the global trade patterns evolved in the last three decades? What is the relation between international trade and Economic growth? We will study these questions both empirically and theoretically. In particular, we will cover the Ricardian theory of comparative advantage, the Heckscher-Ohlin Model of factor endowments, and trade driven by Economies of scale. Next, we will study the welfare consequences of trade, including empirical literature from the last decade and the role of trade policy. We will briefly cover different exchange rate regimes and the nature of trade imbalances. Finally, we will study the relationship between trade and economic development.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

International trade : Theory and Policy by Krugman, Obstfeld and Melitz 10th edition (required)

Lecture notes/Lecture slides

I will try the following approach when teaching the questions/topics mentioned in course overview:

a) use real world data to motivate a particular question,

b) develop a theoretical model which inccorporates main mechanisms relavent to the specific question, 

c) contrast and compare the model predictions against empirical evidence. 

Since we will continously oscillate between theory and empirics, knowledge of Micro- I (ECO 2101)  and Econometrics (ECO 2400) is (almost) essential for this course. In exceptional cases, a waiver may be considered.

Grading Rubric

The grading will consist of following elements:

1) 2 homeworks worth 5 percent each,

2) 2 in-class exams worth 30 percent each,

3) 1 emprical project/write-up (with possible presentation) worth 30 percent

 

Attendance Policy

None

title: ECONOMICS OF TECHNOLOGY
description:
Economics of Technology [ECO-3710] [ECO-3710-1]

Faculty Name
Abhinit Anand [abhinit.anand_asp23@ashoka.edu.in] ,Nishant Chadha [nishant.chadha@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This is a course on the Economics of (Emerging) Technology

We are living in a time of amazing technological advances. Effects of these emerging technologies are everywhere. From the Google search that you do as your gateway to informtion on the internet, to the things you buy on Amazon or Flipkart to the recommended shows that you watch on your favourite over-the-top (OTT) platform. Even in Grammarly's editorial suggestions as I type this description up!

What will the impact of Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Learning (ML) on our economy and society be? Technology giants like Amazon, today have hundreds of economists working for them. What is it that these economists do? These are some of the questions that this course will try to answer.

We will begin the course by understanding what technology and innovation mean to an economist and why are they important. We will discuss how digital technologies reduce transaction and search costs and bring about significant changes in business organisation. Then the students will be given basic knowledge of platform economics. Platforms form the basis of industrial organisation in the digital economy. Next we sill study the economics of automation and technologies such as Artificial Intelligence (AI). In doing so we will also focus on aspects of the data and digital economy including privacy and data protection. This understanding will then be used to study the effect of such technologies on a range of topics such as employment and the future of jobs, economic growth, organisation of businesses, etc. 

The students should have completed courses in microeconomics, game theory, and growth theory. Knowledge of differential calculus and the basics of integration will also be required. Some knowledge of regression analysis will be useful. The course will be very participatory in nature.

Learning Outcomes

How does technology increase productivity?

What are platforms? What is the basic economics of platforms?

How does the data economy work?

How does automation impact work? 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

There is no textbook for this course. I will circulate the slides that I use to teach after each lecture. There will also be readings taken from both academic papers and popular articles that I will share from time to time.

The following books may be useful references for the course. 

›“Prediction machines: The Simple Economics of Artificial Intelligence”
By Ajay Agarwal, Joshua Gans and Avi Goldfrab
(https://www.predictionmachines.ai/)

“The Second Machine Age – Work, Progress, and Prosperity in a Time of Brilliant Technologies”
By Erik Brynjolfsson  and Andrew Mcafee

Grading Rubric

20% assignments (total four in number)

 25% mid-term exam,

40% for a term paper, and

15% for class participation

Assignments and exams will be returned to the students within two weeks of submission.

Attendance Policy

The course has a 15% class participation component out of which 7% will be awarded on the basis of attendance in class. Grades for attendance will not be linear. You will lose 0.5% of the grade for every class you miss for the first six classes that you miss. Absence beyond that will mean you lose the entire grade for attendance. As is clear I would prefer you not miss classes! I like a lively discussion in class and for that we need you there.

title: MONETARY THEORY
description:
Monetary Theory [ECO-3200] [ECO-3200-1]

Faculty Name
Arghya Bhattacharya [arghya.bhattacharya@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

What exactly is "money"? Is it simply something that is needed for trades? If so, then in our simplistic view of the world, money would be a constraint - a thing without which trades can't happen. What about alternative trading arrangements like barter or credit? Why does barter, credit, or a system that keeps track of transfers fails? This course starts with a micro-founded approach to money using an overlapping generations model and discusses why money is not a constraint but an instrument that arises endogenously leading to welfare gains for the economy. This course further discusses why money is welfare improving vis-a-vis barter or credit, why fiat money is Pareto superior to commodity money, and what causes inflation. Then we go on to study the relationship between money and other institutions that issue/ use money - financial intermediation & banks, a model of bank risk and bank panic (Diamond-Dybvig model). Time permitting we will cover other interesting topics.

Attendance Policy

If you are not in the habit of attending lectures regularly and in a timely fashion (not arriving late/ leaving early), then do not sign up for my courses be it the Monetary Economics or the Financial Markets & Asset Pricing course. The penalty for lack of participation (attendance being a chief component) will be announced shortly. Watch this space for more details.

title: MACROECONOMIC THEORY
description:
Macroeconomic Policy [ECO-3206] [ECO-3206-1]

Faculty Name
Ronit Mukherji [ronit.mukherji@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This is an elective course in advanced macroeconomics. This course will study macroeconomic policy by understanding crucial components of the macroeconomy – monetary policy and fiscal policy. In the first half of the course, we will look at consumption, investment, and risk-sharing in basic life cycle models, budget deficits, government debt dynamics, and fiscal policy. We will then focus on banks, their role in the monetary system, and how they interact with the central monetary institutions. We will develop a deeper understanding of the monetary transmission mechanism and how banks impact inflation beyond the central bank's control.

Learning Outcomes

By the end of the course, students should have a firm understanding of:

• Consumption and Investment Models

• Macroeconomic Models of Fiscal Policy and Government Debt Dynamics

• Monetary Policy Making with and without Financial Frictions

• Policy Making to Promote Growth

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The course consists of both required course materials and some suggested readings. I will provide lecture notes on the different topics we cover in the class, which will be usually uploaded before the relevant class. Students should acquire a soft copy of these textbooks or use the library resources:

a) Mankiw, G., Macroeconomics (5th edition or later)- Required.

b) Jones, C., Macroeconomics (3rd Edition)

c) Froyen, R.T., Macroeconomics Theories, and Policies (7th Edition or later)

e) Dornbusch, R., Fischer, S., Startz, R., Macroeconomics (9th Edition or later)

f) Handa, J., Monetary Economics (2nd Edition)

Grading Rubric

The course will have absolute grading.

The total grades from the course will be distributed among Assignments (2 x 20% = 40%), class tests (3 x 15% = 45%), and class participation and discussion (15%).

Each class assignment and test will consist of a series of problem questions and essay(s).

Problem Questions – Students should show all working and provide economic intuition for their answers and use graphs whenever necessary.

Essay(s) – The essay will be based on providing clear economic intuitions and the ability to research topics independently.

Attendance Policy

There is no attendance policy but students are expected to attend all classes and submit their assignments on time. There is no exception to missing class tests, which are compulsory.

title: MACHINE LEARNING FOR ECONOMICS
description:
Machine Learning for Economics [ECO-3404] [ECO-3404-1]

Faculty Name
Amit Kumar Goyal [amit.goyal@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

In this course, we'll start with Introduction to Python Programming - Variables, Lists, Tuples, Dictionaries, Functions, and Loops. Then we'll look at the relevant Python libraries such as Numpy, Matplotlib, Pandas, Scikit-learn and Scipy and explore these for data analysis, manipulation and data visualization. After this we'll do a refresher on mathematics needed for Machine Learning and cover key concepts of linear algebra, and multivariable calculus using Python and then use it to perform optimization tasks in Python. We'll then review some probability concepts and see how to use simulation in learning economics. Finally, we'll use all of the above to perform machine learning tasks such as: (i) Supervised learning (linear regression, logistic regression, neural networks). (ii) Unsupervised learning (clustering).

Learning Outcomes
  • You'll learn how to program in Python.
  • Use Python to solve interesting Linear Algebra, Calculus, and Optimization problems.
  • Visualising probability distributions that are widely used in statistics and data science.
  • How to make good predictions and think conditionally.
  • Problem solving strategies.
  • Using Python to run simulations and solve probability problems.
  • You'll learn how to perform Machine Learning tasks such as Linear and Logistic Regression, and Clustering.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

References for the lectures:

  • Basics of Python: https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLUJGfL_499TLpqYmNQQGCUPckMqoOLmdC
  • Machine Learning: https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLLssT5z_DsK-h9vYZkQkYNWcItqhlRJLN

Your course score will be determined as the following weighted average:

title: DEVELOPMENT ECONOMICS
description:
Development Economics [ECO-6500] [ECO-6500-1]

Faculty Name
Swati Sharma [swati.sharma@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The objective of this course is to familiarize students with a wide range of issues that hold key to the economic development in the contemporary world. This course will follow critical investigation of a set of recent relevant research papers with an emphasis on possible policies and remedies to overcome poverty and inequality. We will begin with a quick re-cap of macro growth theories and transition into micro issues related to development. The focus will be on the relationship between development and institutions, education, gender, social capital and culture. The underlying objective of this course is to familiarize students with the use of econometric techniques and tools to explore the relationship between theory and practice. At the end of the course, students should be able to critically conduct econometric analysis and use statistical software to carry out evidence backed research crucial for economic development. The prerequisite for this course is the understanding of basic econometrics.

Learning Outcomes

1. Familiarity with issues inhibiting nations from development

2. Understanding of causal concepts

3. Put theory/concepts to practice using STATA

4. Identification of literature gaps for future research in development economics

5. A working knowledge of writing a reserach paper

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

There is no particular book. I will share relevant book chapters for the concepts and applied research papers as we move along the topics.

Grading Rubric

Class participation                                        20%

Paper presentation*                                      10%

Take home assignment (STATA based)        10%

Short research proposal/paper#                     20%

Final written exam                                         40%

*Probably a group task (depends on class size). Each group will be assigned an applied research paper from the reading list for presentation/discussion for 30 minutes. 

#Probably a group task (depends on class size). Each group will come up with a novel research idea from the list of topics covered in the class. Groups are required to discuss the idea in the class towards the end of the semester and submit a formal written research propasal incorporating feedback from the class discussions.

Attendance Policy

title: ECONOMICS OF DISCRIMINATION
description:
Economics of Discrimination [ECO-3671] [ECO-3671-1]

Faculty Name
Ashwini Deshpande [ashwini.deshpande@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course familiarizes students with theories and empirical tools to understand and measure economic discrimination based on social group identities, such as caste, race, gender, tribal status, ethnicity and so on. The course will focus on evidence related to caste and sex in India. 

The first part of the course will take students through theories of discrimination such as statistical discrimination and taste for discrimination, based on the work of Kenneth Arrow, Gary Becker and George Akerlof.  This will lead to a discussion of the overlap between economics of discrimination and related sub-disciplines that are relatively new but are rapidly expanding, viz., “Identity Economics”, pioneered by George Akerlof and Rachel Kranton, “Feminist Economics”, and “Stratification Economics”. 

The second section will introduce students to concepts in social psychology such as stereotype threat and implicit bias that produce discriminatory outcomes. 

The third part of the course introduces students to some of the key methods of empirically gauging discrimination in market settings. This section would familiarize students with decomposition analyses applied to the labour market (what part of the wage gap between two groups is due to differences in abilities, and what part is due to discrimination), using standard techniques from Labour Economics. We would also discuss experimental methods – both field-based as well as lab-based experiments to gauge discrimination outside the labour market (e.g. housing market), or in the field of charitable giving, or even in labour markets but during the job search process (before applicants find jobs).  

Students will be familiarized with literature that applies these methods in the Indian context, particularly to the study of caste and gender discrimination. 

The final part of the course will deal with policy options to deal with group-based disparities and discrimination, with a focus on affirmative action policies. This section will outline the various types of affirmative action, including quotas or reservation, and discuss debates around affirmative action, focusing on evidence-based research gauging its impact.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Course Outline and Reading List 

Note: This reading list could see minor changes during the semester which will be announced well ahead of time. 

I.               How does social identity shape economic outcomes? 

 

Akerlof, George. 1984. “The economics of caste and of the rat race and other woeful tales”, in An Economic Theorist’s Book of Tales, Cambridge University Press, 1984, models of statistical discrimination and the caste economy. 

Becker, Gary. 1957. The Economics of Discrimination, Chs. 1, 2 and 10

Darity, William Jr., Darrick Hamilton, Patrick Mason et al 2017: “Stratification Economics: A general theory of Intergroup Inequality”, in Hidden Rules of Race(https://www.researchgate.net/publication/320335744_Stratification_Economics_A_General_Theory_of_Intergroup_Inequality)

II. Stereotype Threat and Implicit Bias

Steele, C. M., & Aronson, J. (1995). Stereotype threat and the intellectual test performance of African-Americans. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 69, 797-811.

Nosek, B.A., Banaji, M.R. and Greenwald, A.G. 2002. “Math=male, me=female, therefore math me.” Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 83(1), 44-59. 

III The caste system in India and contemporary caste disparities

Mosse, David. 2018. Contemporary Perspectives on a structure of discrimination and disadvantage, World Development, 110 (2018), 422-436

Deshpande, Ashwini. “The Grammar of Caste: Economic Discrimination in Contemporary India”, Oxford University Press, 2017 paperback edition

Deshpande, Ashwini and Rajesh Ramachandran. 2019. Traditional Hierarchies and Affirmative Action in a Globalising Economy: Evidence from India. World Development, 118 (2019) 63-78

 

IV.   Decomposition analyses

 

Banerjee, Biswajit and Knight, J.B. 1985: “Caste discrimination in the Indian urban labour market”, Journal of Development Economics, Vol 17, pp 277-307.

 

Cotton, J. 1988: “On the decomposition of wage differentials”, Review of Economics and Statistics, Vol. 70, No.2

 

 Deshpande, Ashwini and Smriti Sharma. 2016. “Disadvantage and discrimination in self-employment: caste gaps in earnings in Indian small businesses”, Small Business Economics: An entrepreneurship journal, 46(2):325-346, February 2016

 

V. Experimental methods to investigate labour market discrimination 

 

Bertrand, M. and Mullainathan, S. 2004. “Are Emily and Greg more employable than Lakisha and Jamal? A field experiment on labour market discrimination”, American Economic Review, 94 (4): 991-1013

 

Thorat, Sukhadeo and Paul Attewell. 2007. “The legacy of social exclusion: A correspondence study of job discrimination in India”, Economic and Political Weekly, Vol. XLII, No. 41, October 13.

Optional: Pager, Devah and Bruce Western. 2005. “Race at Work: realities of race and criminal record in the NYC job market”, Report for NY City Human Rights Commission, 50th Anniversary conference.

 

 

Deshpande, Ashwini and Katherine Newman. 2007. “Where the path leads: role of caste in post university employment expectations”, Economic and Political Weekly, Vol. XLII, No. 41, October 13, 2007, pp. 4133-4140.

 

Jodhka, Surinder and Katherine Newman. 2007. “Meritocracy, Productivity and the Hidden language of Caste”, Economic and Political Weekly, Vol. XLII, No. 41, October 13, 2007.

 

 

 VI. Beyond the labour market

 

Hoff, Karla and Priyanka Pandey. 2006.  “Discrimination, Social Identity and Durable Inequalities”, American Economic Review, Vol. 96, No.2, May, pp. 206-211

 

Deshpande, Ashwini and Dean Spears. 2016. “Who is the Identifiable Victim?: Caste and Charitable Giving in Modern India”, Economic Development and Cultural Change, Vol. 64, No. 2, pp. 299-321, January

 

 

 

VII. Remedies for inter group disparity: affirmative action and compensation issues

 

 

Loury, Glenn C., Roland G. Fryer. 2005. "Affirmative Action and its Mythology," Journal of Economic Perspectives, Vol. 19, No. 3 (Summer 2005).

 

 

Deshpande, Ashwini and Thomas E. Weisskopf. 2014.“Does Affirmative Action Reduce Productivity? A Case Study of the Indian Railways”, World Development, Vol. 64 (December 2014), pp. 169-180.

 

Bertrand, Marianne, Rema Hanna and Sendhil Mullainathan. 2010. “Affirmative Action in Education: evidence from engineering college admissions in India”, Journal of Public Economics, Elsevier, vol. 94(1-2), pages 16-29.

VIII. Gender discrimination and the gender caste overlap

 

Deshpande, Ashwini. 2007. “Overlapping identities under liberalisation: gender and caste in India”, Economic Development and Cultural Change, 55 (4), July 2007, pp.735-760 

 

Elson, Diane. 1999. “Labour markets as gendered institutions: equality, efficiency and empowerment issues”, World Development, Vol. 27, No. 3, pp. 611-627.

 

Blog: Tim Harford, 24 February 2022.  Hard Truths about the Gender Pay Gap

 

Extra-curricular resources

Podcast on linguistic Discrimination: https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/w3ct3hgt

Films:

 

Masaan (Hindi); Geeli Pucchi (Hindi); Sairat (Marathi); Court (Marathi); Jai Bhim (Tamil)

India Untouched (Documentary)

Grading Rubric

Grading Rubric

 The final grade will be a weighted average of three components, with the weights defined as follows: 

I. Mid-term Test: 20%

II. Project: 30%. 

III. Final Examination: 50%

Attendance Policy

You can miss up to 6 classes through the semester. These six absences are supposed to cover illnesses (your own and family members’), weddings, other family commitments. Remember that illness typically arrives unannounced and unexpectedly. If you have already missed 6 classes for non-essential reasons, you will NOT get extra classes off for illnesses, even with medical certificates. Late entry (entering class 5 minutes later than the start time), early exit (any time before the class ends), and repeated entry-exit are not allowed, unless there is a serious medical emergency. Mobile phone usage is not allowed. 

If you miss 7-9 classes, you get one grade downgrade. If you miss 10 or more, you get an F.

title: SPATIAL ECONOMICS
description:
Spatial Economics [ECO-6605] [ECO-6605-1]

Faculty Name
Abhishek Rai [abhishek.rai@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Why per capita output is significantly higher in Banglore and Mumbai relative to any district in Bihar? Why people from Eastern UP migrate to Delhi and Mumbai and not vice versa? Why coastal regions are relatively more prosperous relative to inland regions? 

Economic activity is unequally distributed across space. Why do some locations attract many people, have higher per capita income, and grow at a faster rate relative to other locations? How do the movement of goods (trade) and people (migration) between locations affect wages, prices, and welfare in those locations? How the spatial distribution of economic activity and population evolves with economic development? Is there a role for place-based public policy to help economically less developed regions? 

In this course, we will study these questions using the quantitative models of trade and migration developed in the last two decades. We will also aim :

(i) to learn the structural method used in international trade and economic geography and,

(ii) to develop general equilibrium intuition in the spatial context.

This course is hard since we will have to work with theory (develop and solve general equlibrium model), empirics (confront model predictions against empirical evidence) and coding (easiest way to solve a GE model is to code it in matlab or python). 

Grading Rubric

3 Take home assignments each worth 15 percent,

1 Presentation worth 20 percent,

1 Research Project/proposal worth 30 percent

class participation worth 5 percent

Attendance Policy

Attendance is not mandatory but strongly encouraged.

title: FINANCE AND VOLATILITY
description:
Finance and Volatility [ECO-6555] [ECO-6555-1]

Faculty Name
Gurbachan Singh [gurbachan.singh@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Finance and Volatility
Elective course in the 4th semester of the MA Economics programme by Gurbachan Singh
About the syllabus
The objective is to understand why we often see volatility or instability in the financial sector. This is primarily a course on theory to explain the real world. We keep an eye on broad stylized facts (and occasionally an empirical study). We will consider policy issues. The course is useful for students aspiring to be academics, policy makers, and practitioners (in alphabetical order). The syllabus includes some behavioural finance. It also includes a bit on economics of homes as an asset. Since the financial system is usually classified into two parts viz., financial markets and financial intermediaries, the syllabus is, broadly speaking, in two parts (though these are not always mutually exclusive).
1. Asset markets, and possible excess volatility
Formal CAPM model and evidence, stochastic discount factor, efficient markets theory and behavioural finance, limits to arbitrage, stabilizing speculation and destabilizing speculation, asset price bubbles - rational and irrational, debt and asset prices, leverage cycle, balance sheet recession, dynamic hedging, risk aversion and risk appetite, neglected risks, diagnostic expectations (and adaptive and rational expectations), and agency cost (including the dual agency cost perspective).
2. Financial intermediaries, and instability
Rationale for demand deposits, liquidity (many different meanings), banking crises (different from currency crisis, fiscal crisis, and asset price crashes), bank runs (sunspots and fundamentals-based, inefficient and efficient, partial and complete), non-performing loans, ‘sudden stop’ and banks, fluctuations in interest rates, ‘peculiar’ case of stable and efficient Canadian banking, deposit insurance, lender of last resort, credit lines, capital adequacy.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Readings, in alphabetical order
• Allen, Franklin, and Douglas Gale (ed.), 2008, Financial Crises, An Elgar Reference Col- lection, Chapter 20.
• Campbell, John Y., 2018, Financial decisions and Markets - A course in Asset Pricing, Princeton University Press, New Jersey (sections 4.1.1 - 4.1.4, and section 5.2).
• Diamond, Douglas W., and Raghuram G. Rajan, 2001, Banks and liquidity, American Economic Review Papers and Proceedings, 91(2), 422- 425.
• Eichberger, Jurgen, and Ian R. Harper, 1997, Financial Economics, Oxford University Press, New York (section 2.2.2).

Geanakoplos, John, 2010, The leverage cycle, Cowles Foundation Discussion Paper No. 1304.
• Gennaioli, Nichola, and Andrei Shleifer, 2018, A Crisis of Beliefs - Investor Psychology and Financial Fragility, Princeton University Press, chapter 4, and chapter 5 (p. 137-156).
• Genaioli, Nichola, Andrei Shleifer, and R.W. Vishny, 2012, Neglected risks, financial inno- vation, and financial fragility, Journal of Financial Economics, 104, 452-468 (p. 452-461 for the course).
• Glaeser, Edward L., Gyourko, Joseph, and Saiz, Albert, 2008, Housing supply and housing bubbles, Journal of Urban Economics, 64(2), pages 198-217 (the first part of the paper on rational bubbles).
• Koo, Richard, 2013, Central banks in balance sheet recessions: A search for correct re- sponse, Institute for New Economic Thinking (INET), April.
• Shin, Hyun Song, 2010, Risk and Liquidity, Clarendon Lectures, Oxford University Press (chapters 1-5).
• Shleifer, Andrei. 2000. Inefficient Markets - An Introduction to Behavioural Finance, Oxford University Press, New York, chapters 1, 2, 4, and 6 (first part).
• Shleifer, Andrei, and R.W. Vishny, 2010, Unstable banking, Journal of Financial Economics 97, 306-318.
• Tirole, Jean, 2006, The Theory of Corporate Finance, Princeton University Press, chapter 3.
 

Grading Rubric

Grading weights (tentative):
• Mid-semester exam 25%,
• end-semester exam 50%,
• presentations (and participation in classes) 15%, and • home assignment(s) 10%.

title: EMPIRICAL MONETARY POLICY AND FINANCE
description:
Empirical Monetary Policy and Finance [FIN-3031/ ECO-3304] [FIN-3031/ ECO-3304-1]

Faculty Name
Varun Khandelwal [varun.khandelwal@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

We will analyse role of monetary policy during the key macro events of the last century - the Great Depression, stagflation in the 1970s and early 1980s, the East Asian crisis, Dot Com bust and finally the GFC 2008. The lessons learned will then be applied to the economic events and policy actions from 2008-2022. We will attempt to correlate the impact of monetary and fiscal policy with movements in relative interest rates, forex rates and asset prices. Finally, we use the lessons learned from the past and apply them to present day monetary policy and financial market conditions across major economies.

Learning Outcomes

The primary objective of this course is to develop the ability to apply the theoretical concepts learnt in the undergraduate program thus far. There will be a focus throughout the course on the impact of economics policies on financial asset markets and the real economy.

By the end of the course, students should be able to understand the causes and consequences of the great depression, the change in the monetary policy regime since the 1980s, the causes and consequences of the subprime housing bubble and the financial crisis of 2008.

Students will learn to apply these to understand the financial and political implications of the major economic events of the last 15 years including the eurozone debt crisis, taper tantrum, demonetisation, and the post covid monetary policy regime.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The course assumes a strong understanding of the macroeconomics and courses taken in the last two years.

Please note that there is no textbook for this course. Students will need to do a substantial amount of reading across a variety of material ranging from academic papers, news articles, industry research, etc. These will be shared as the course progresses.

Grading Rubric

50pc      – two individual assignments

25pc      – end of term group research and presentation

15pc      – class participation

10pc      – attendance (see attendance policy below)

Assignments – these are expected to be between 1000 – 2500 words each. The first will be due at the end of the mid term break and the second one at the end of term.

Group presentation – the class will be divided into groups of 3 students. Groups will be asked to research a question, jointly author a 1000 - 2500 words paper and present it to their peers. Each group’s presentation will be followed by a short Q&A.

Class participation – regular participation in classes by students will enliven the class and enhance the learning experience for the entire cohort. We will not be covering new theoretical material and the emphasis will be on well documented economic events over the last century. Materials relevant to each lecture will be shared a fortnight before the lecture starts and students are expected to read up in advance to make the class more meaningful.  

Attendance Policy

Since this is an applied course with no specific course text, it is critical that students participate in lectures and discussions therein. The 10pc allocated to attendance is yours to lose!

The loss rate will be 2.5pc per lecture missed. Please bear in mind that missing lectures also means that you will not be able to participate in those classes and this may further adversely affect the ‘class participation’ evaluation component.

title: DATA SCIENCE FOR SOCIAL SCIENCE RESEARCH
description:
Data Science For Social Science Research [POL-2094/ ECO-3406] [POL-2094/ ECO-3406-1]

Faculty Name
Anustubh Agnihotri [anustubh.agnihotri@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Course Draft Syllabus (Click for Latest Version) 

Data science techniques are now central to quantitative research in social sciences. From academics to public policy practitioners, to non-profit organizations all increasingly rely on data science techniques for cleaning and gathering data, conducting data analysis, and presenting the results. For example, multiple datasets often need to be transformed, aggregated, and merged before a more comprehensive analysis can be carried out.  Researchers might need to create datasets from scratch by converting a large number of PDFs into machine-readable texts or scraping data from a website or interacting with an API. These tasks require knowing, among other things – basic data wrangling concepts, concepts for cleaning messy datasets, and familiarity with programming concepts for creating a data flow that can be replicated and shared with multiple collaborators. This course will provide students with the skills necessary for successfully carrying out quantitative social science research, by deploying data science techniques. 

The research questions students will engage with will be related to the political economy of development. For example, we will try to understand the relationship between the level of socio-economic development and political outcomes like incumbency and competition, examine the determinants of differences in quality of public service delivery and local institutions, or explore how the background of individual bureaucrats shapes their career trajectories. These broad sets of relationships will be examined from different perspectives throughout the course. We will begin by basic descriptive statistics, then visualize the data in different ways. To achieve this the course will rely on the R statistical software (open source) using a predefined set of freely available datasets (more details below). Students will learn how to gather, aggregate, analyze, and interpret datasets as well as presenting findings. 

The course can be divided into two broad parts that have substantial overlap. The first part of the course will focus on the basics of data science – data wrangling, visualization, and analysis. These skills will teach students how to aggregate, transform, and merge datasets for a richer analysis. The second part will focus on data gathering and cleaning. In this section, the students will be creating new datasets by gathering data from websites and APIs and then cleaning and processing the data. The aim here is to expose students to the challenges of creating new datasets. 

Learning Outcomes

By the end of the course, students should be able to

  • Understand basic programming terminologies, structures, and conventions
  • Write, execute, and debug R code for data analysis, and visualization
  • Be familiar with regular expressions and basic data cleaning techniques 
  • Be familiar with the basics of web scraping and APIs
  • Be able to gather, analyze, visualize large scale datasets 
  • Be able to use understand and communicate relationship between variables 
  • Do preliminary geospatial analysis 
  • Overall goal of the course is to enabled students with the ability to gather new sets of data and pursue new research ideas 
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Requirements

Students are not required to have prior programming experience or a background in computer science to take this course. The course will enable students to become proficient with programming in the R software over the course of the semester. Thus, students should be willing to spend time learning how to code. 

Students should have taken an introductory course on quantitative social science research methodology (This requirement can be waived for final year and ASP students)

Grading Rubric
  • Completion of assigned homework (individual) (3) (40%) 
  • Participation - attendance, engagement, and lightning presentations in front of peers (20%)
  • Final project presentation (Proposal + Final Presentation) (20%)
  • Final project report (20%)
Attachment
Course_Spring_2023_Draft.pdf

title: DATA SCIENCE FOR SOCIAL SCIENCE RESEARCH
description:
Data Science For Social Science Research [POL-2094/ ECO-3406] [POL-2094/ ECO-3406-2]

Faculty Name
Anustubh Agnihotri [anustubh.agnihotri@ashoka.edu.in] ;

title: FORMS OF LITERATURE
description:
Forms of Literature [ENG-1001] [ENG-1001-1]

Faculty Name
Jonathan Gil Harris [jgharris@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course is the gateway course to the English major and minor at Ashoka University.  It introduces English students to literary history as articulated through different genres: the epic, the tale, the novel, the lyric, the drama, and the short story.  Rather than regarding literary forms as fixed categories with specific rules, we will instead examine them as dynamically shaped by, and in conversation with, their social and historical contexts.  We will consider how these forms have meant different things at different times, both to understand the transformations of literature and the changing meanings of genre itself.  We will look at epic and how its world view has transformed from Gilgamesh to John Milton’s Paradise Lost; tales and how their preoccupations have changed from Geoffrey Chaucer’s Canterbury Tales and Kalyana Malla’s Suleiman Charitra to T.S. Eliot’s Waste Land; novels and how their social function and meaning vary from Joseph Conrad’s Heart of Darkness to Amruta Patil’s Kari; lyric poetry and how its modes of intimacy have transformed from Sappho’s fragments, Amir Khusro’s ghazals, and William Shakespeare’s Sonnets to Audre Lorde’s poetry; drama and how its representation of gender has morphed from Kalidasa’s Shakuntala to Caryl Churchill’s Top Girls; and short stories and how their uncanny imaginative scope has been reconfigured from E. T. A. Hoffman to Saadat Hasan Manto and Ismat Chughtai.  We will also read some theories of literature and literary transformation, including essays by Karl Marx, Mikhail Bakhtin, T. S. Eliot, Bertolt Brecht, and Sigmund Freud.

Grading Rubric

A-F

Attendance Policy

3 free absences total from all lectures and discussion sections; grade penalty after that

title: FORMS OF LITERATURE
description:
Forms of Literature [ENG-1001] [ENG-1001-2]

Faculty Name
Mandakini Dubey [mandakini.dubey@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course introduces English majors and minors to literary history as articulated through different genres: drama, poetry, prose, and newer forms. Rather than fixed categories or lists of unvarying characteristics, we will examine literary forms as dynamically shaped by their social and historical contexts. We will examine how these forms have signified differently at various points, both to understand the changing narratives of history and the changing meanings of the genre itself.

title: ENGLISH GRADUATE PROSEMINAR: THESIS WRITING
description:
English Graduate Proseminar: Thesis Writing [ENG-4002] [ENG-4002-1]

Faculty Name
Alexandra Cassatt Verini [alexandra.verini@ashoka.edu.in] ,Tanvi Chowdhary [tanvi.chowdhary_phd21@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The Pro-Seminar is required for all ASP and MLS students doing a thesis in English, Creative Writing, Performing Arts, and/or Media Studies. It is intended to initiate participants into the world of research and critical writing at the graduate level.

 

The Graduate Pro-Seminar this spring will be in a different format from last semester. This term, instead of listening to others speak about their writing processes, you will be presenting your own ideas. The bulk of our Tuesday meetings— aside from a few talks on writing from outside speakers including our very own GAs—will be devoted to group presentations in which you will present your ideas on a given topic in conversation with several of your classmates. Weekly discussion sections led by graduate assistants will allow you to workshop your thesis as you complete your first draft and write the final version.

 

The written outcomes for this course will be 1.) Your thesis draft and 2.) Your final thesis (due at the end of the term).

title: INTRODUCTION TO CHILDREN’S LITERATURE
description:
Introduction to Children’s Literature [ENG-2330] [ENG-2330-1]

Faculty Name
Geetanjali Chanda [geetanjali.chanda@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

What we read as children forms who we become and provides our first world view. This course provides an opportunity to critically assess the stories that shaped our own understanding of morals, culture, and values, as well as those we will impart to future generations. In this discussion-oriented interactive course, we will read and review children’s books, examine the purposes of visual literacy, and write reviews on specific authors and illustrators.

This course aims to examine how the books children read – from Aesop’s Fables to Amar Chitra Katha comics and the Harry Potter series – shape their outlook and emotional development. We will study the historical, creative, nurturing, emotional, and educational aspects of these forms of literature and their impact on us later in life. We will also consider why a study of children’s literature is important, and how it impacts pedagogies for children across borders.

            We will also examine the views of multiple theoretical thinkers and texts in conjunction with actual children's literature. We will ask the important but often overlooked questions about this particular genre, mainly focusing on Indian and American children’s literature. The purpose is not so much to compare these two cultural offerings, but to give us a taste of both. 

            We shall also consider popular books for children up to 12 years old, including Harry Potter & The Philosopher’s Stone, Amar Chitra Katha, Matilda, The Little Prince, and Alladin. At the same time, we will also study theoretical thinkers such as Jack Zipes, Seth Lerer, Paulo Freire, and Bruno Bettelheim to help us navigate the complex field of children’s literature in relation to issues of culture, religion, difference, gender, and sexuality.

We will also explore the didactic intent as well as the pleasure principle that might have prompted the writers. Authorial intent is, however, only one part of our study; the other part is to see how children and parents receive these stories. Children’s literature creates moral as well as national frameworks that help acculturate young people. In examining the genre of children’s literature, we will consider various sub-genres such as picture books, fairy tales, fables, and chapter books. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Rushdie, Salman. Haroun and the Sea of Stories  London: Penguin (1990). 

de Saint Exupery, Antoine. The Little Prince [Translated by Richard Howard] (2000).

Rowling, J.K. - Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (1997).

Dahl, Roald. Matilda (1988). University of Chicago Press (2009).

Chandra, Nandini. The Classic Popular: Amar Chitra Katha (1967-2007), Yoda Press (2008).

Lal, Ranjit. The Battle for No.19, Penguin India (2007).

Grading Rubric

Attendance + Class Participation : 10%

In-class writing                                : 10%

Class Presentations                         : 10%

Visual Literacy project                    : 5%

Disney Blog (in-class)                     : 5%

Mid-term paper                                : 25%

Final paper                                        : 35%

Attendance Policy

Attendance + Class Participation (15%): Attendance is mandatory and will impact your final grade. You may miss 3 classes during the semester without penalty.  After three absences, a letter from your final grade will be deducted for each missed class. If you have 3 unexcused absences, I will reserve the right to fail you for the course.  Coming more than 5 minutes late to class will count as an absence. Participation in-class discussions are an essential requirement. This means listening as well as responding and reacting to the ongoing discussions about the readings. Your ability to raise issues and questions that occurred to you while you read the texts demonstrates your attention to the readings. You must complete the assigned readings by the day before so you come prepared to discuss in class.

title: INTRODUCTION TO PERFORMANCE STUDIES
description:
Introduction to Performance Studies [ENG-2610/ PA-2610/ ENG-4610] [ENG-2610/ PA-2610/ ENG-4610-1]

Faculty Name
Vivek Venkitaraman Narayan [v.v.narayan@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Is everyday life a performance? Are our social interactions forms of playacting? How about the ways in which we present ourselves—as gendered bodies, as students, as friends, as professors, and as so many other less nameable identities—are these too performances? What would it tell us if we were to think of everyday social interaction and self-presentation as performance? Does this mean our interactions are shallow, our relationships fake, and our personalities mere pretense? Or will it reveal aspects of everyday life that otherwise remain hidden in plain view?   

These are some questions that inspire this course to explore the social phenomenon of performance and its theoretical value to the humanities. We will investigate the ways in which our everyday behaviours and the stories we tell shape our identities and our experience of the world. We will see how thinking of, with, and through performance can help us investigate social behaviour, individual and collective identity, and embodied knowledge. 

We will do so by focusing on three recurring themes: first, the relationship between representation and performance, which will help us understand social behaviour; second, the paradigm of performativity, which is significant to theorizing identity; and third, the debate between whether performance is an ephemeral or enduring phenomenon, which is central to conceptualizing embodied knowledges. We will see, in short, how performance—as object, method, and analytic—can help us understand societies and cultures by focusing on acts of doing, ways of being, and modes of knowing. We will read Judith Butler, JL Austin, Diana Taylor, Richard Schechner, Susan Sontag, Harry Elam, Victor Turner, Bishnupriya Dutt, Erving Goffman, Clifford Geertz, Aparna Dharwadker, Ngugi wa Thiong’o, and Paulla Ebron. We will also engage with Dharamvir Bharati’s Andha Yug, Maya Rao’s Walk, and the real-life cases of Rachel Dolezal and Jessica Krug. 

(Undergrads may sign up for ENG-2610 or PA-2610, while grads are welcome to sign up for ENG-4610.)

title: WRITING THE SELF
description:
Critical Thinking Seminar: Writing the Self [ENG-2331] [ENG-2331-1]

Faculty Name
Geetanjali Chanda [geetanjali.chanda@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course seeks to examine the autobiography or memoir as a literary genre, an historical archive, and an individual/community narrative.

We will also consider how graphic novels, poems and blogs can be seen as constructions of a specific kind of persona.

As the definition of autobiography has expanded over time, different kinds of memoirs and autobiographies have liberated Identity as a singular noun to self-consciously manage our plural or even desired identities and playfully experiment with different notions of selfhood.

 

In this course, we will examine the idea of “truth telling” that is often associated with autobiographies. We also consider how the study of international autobiographies allows us a view of the local in the context of the global.

Learning Outcomes

Learn about the genre of autobiography.

See the historical development and change in the form and content of  autobiography.

Explore the diverse cultural contexts in which autobiographies are produced.

Question why autobiographies are written.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Primary Texts: You must have.

Anne Frank: The Diary of a Young Girl. (1952)

Marjane Satrapi :Persepolis (2000)  (Graphic Novel)

Azadeh Moaveni: Lipstick Jihad: A Memoir of Growing Up Iranian in America and American in Iran. (2005)

bell hooks. Bone Black (1996)

A. Revathi: The Truth About Me: A Hijra Life Story. (2017)

Riverbend. Baghdad Burning (2005) Excerpts

Jerry Pinto. Em and the Big Hoom (2012)

Yashica Dutt. Coming Out As Dalit: A Memoir. (2019)

Your ability to raise issues and questions that occurred to you while you read the texts demonstrates your attention to the readings. title: LITERATURE IN THE AGE OF EMPIRE
description:
Literature and the Age of Empire [ENG-2002] [ENG-2002-1]

Faculty Name
Mandakini Dubey [mandakini.dubey@ashoka.edu.in] ;

title: LITERATURE IN THE AGE OF EMPIRE
description:
Literature and the Age of Empire [ENG-2002] [ENG-2002-2]

Faculty Name
Huzaifa Omair Siddiqi [huzaifa.siddiqi@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

In this survey course we will read a selection of texts written by British poets, novelists, painters and philosophers from the late 17th to the 19th century in order to examine how they participated in the creation and construction of Empire. We will read texts ranging from Aphra Behn’s Oronooko and Alexander Pope’s The Rape of the Lock to William Wordsworth’s Lyrical Ballads and Adam Smith’s Wealth of Nations, Mary Shelley’s Frankenstein, Emily Bronte’s Wuthering Heights, the Sherlock Holmes novels as well as a few colonial subjects who write back to Empire (mostly from the Urdu literary tradition) such as Ghalib, Sir Syed Ahmed Khan, and Altaf Hussain Hali.

title: FILM THEORY
description:
Film Theory [ENG-3801/ MS-3481] [ENG-3801/ MS-3481-1]

Faculty Name
Abir Bashir Bazaz [abir.bazaz@ashoka.edu.in] ,Madhura Kar [madhura.kar_ma23@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

What is cinema? This classic question posed by early film theory will guide our survey of theoretical approaches to the study of film from its beginnings in the 1910s to the present. We will study major film theories such as the realist film theory, formalist film theory, auteur theory, feminist film theory, apparatus theory, semiotic and psychoanalytic film theory but also turn to film-philosophical approaches to cinema. We will be discussing the debates and arguments that have shaped film studies and situate film theory in the context of larger intellectual movements such as Phenomenology, Russian Formalism, Marxism, Existentialism and Poststructuralism. We will discuss major film theories in relation to different film genres, film movements and national cinemas. Film theorists studied will include Hugo Munsterberg, Béla Balázs, Walter Benjamin, Rudolph Arnheim, Sergei Eisenstein, Siegfried Kracauer, Andre Bazin, Jean-Louis Baudry, Christian Metz, Laura Mulvey and Gilles Deleuze. Film screenings will include the works of Sergei Eisenstein, Chris Marker, Terrence Malick, Max Ophuls, Abbas Kiarostami, Paul Thomas Anderson, Agnes Varda, Ang Lee and Chang-dong Lee. Students who opt for this course must be familiar with basic terms and concepts in film studies (such as montage, mise-en-scène, continuity editing) or have taken an introductory course in film studies.

title: MA PROSEMINAR
description:
MA Proseminar II: Thesis Writing [ENG-5004] [ENG-5004-1]

Faculty Name
Alexander Robert Phillips [alexander.phillips@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This semester’s Graduate Proseminar is all about writing. The Monsoon Proseminar was meant to give you a sense of how academic writing looks and works, as you read, dismantled, and analyzed the components of guest academics’ essays. This semester, you will put that knowledge to use in building up your own writing. The Proseminar is meant to help you advance through the stages of planning and composing your dissertation; it is also meant to provide a collegial environment in which you can analyze and improve your writing as you produce it. Writing, rewriting, and editing are all parts of the writing process that we will undertake together.

title: GRADUATE RESEARCH WRITING AND METHODS
description:
Graduate Research Writing and Methods [ENG-5002] [ENG-5002-1]

Faculty Name
Subhasree Chakravarty [subhasree.chakravarty@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

For MA and PhD students only (required of first-year MA and PhD students)

 

Writing a dissertation, as you will soon realize, is an intimate and personal process. Some even go as far as calling it akin to childbirth, but I will spare you the gendered imagery. Yet, I will say it is indeed intimate, private, personal and momentous. At the same time, graduate students often feel that writing within an academic institution does not bear much relevance to their lives outside of academia. To dispel such myths and make more happy ones for ourselves, in this course we will ask; How should we begin to think about writing? How is it possible to learn to write? Is writing purely a technical craft? What is criticism and how do we write critically about literature?

 While we discuss and dissent on the answers to these questions, we will also learn about all the delicate ways in which a hypothesis can be formulated, how to fashionably synthesize materials from written sources, organize ideas in almost perfect forms and develop marvelously captivating arguments.

title: INDIAN LITERATURE
description:
Indian Literatures [ENG-2003] [ENG-2003-1]

Faculty Name
Rita Kothari [rita.kothari@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

What would be the origins, scope, and variety of literature produced in India? Was there always an “India”? This course begins with these questions and takes students through milestone moments of literature-making. Traversing different genres and languages from ancient times to the present day, the scope of this course is vast, for it has the provision of including a Buddhist nun’s verses from the sixth century BCE to Khalid Jawed’s The Paradise of Food (translated from Urdu by Baran Farooqi; awarded the JCB Prize in 2022). Clearly, it is not possible to expose the students to this entire range. However, the course aims to kindle profound interest in the intersections of languages and themes, the forms and genres that characterise the loosely named body called “Indian literature/s.” We will go from the ancient to medieval, colonial to modern and postcolonial body of writing—sometimes in detail, sometimes not. It would be difficult to say what gives unity, if any, to this body and whether this “body” is discursively formed through its users who read literature from Indian languages in English. The course examines the politics around such archives and the interrelationship between English and the bhashas. While the politics of language and translation underpin the instructor’s theoretical approach, the course is committed to understanding the questions of history, region, community, caste, and region-making politics in India.  

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Ajay Navaria, Unclaimed Terrain (Translated from Hindi by Laura Brueck) 

Anungla Zoe Longkumer (ed.), The Many That I am: Writings from Nagaland

Dharamvir Bharati, Andha Yug (Translated from Hindi by Alok Bhalla)

Salman Rushdie, Midnight's Children 

Susie Tharu and K. Lalita (eds.), Women Writing in India: 600 B.C to the Present

title: LOCATING THE FEMININE
description:
Locating the Feminine [ENG-4503] [ENG-4503-1]

Faculty Name
S Satish Kumar [s.kumar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course aims at charting a critical historiography and archaeology of the feminine subject within the beginnings of decolonisation in the literatures and cultures of Africa and South Asia. How are the discourses of colonisation, postcolonialism, nation building, and decolonisation inscribed on feminine subjecthoods? Alternatively, how is feminine agency both exercised and circumscribed within such contexts that despite being plurally constituted are still systemically determined by an overarching cis-heteronormative patriarchal logic?

 

Towards unpacking such a historical problematique, we will be reading a selection of texts that represent and narrativise the experiences of feminine subjects within the transitions of coloniality, postcoloniality and decolonisation. Focusing especially on women writers who “came of age” in nascently formed postcolonial African and South Asian nations, this course seeks to provide both a historical and narrative context for theoretical frames such as “the Global South” and “Postcolonial Feminisms”.

fullName: ENG-4224, SUFISM, SEXUALITY, SHAKESPEARE, MADAVI MENON
title: SUFISM, SEXUALITY, SHAKESPEARE,
description:
Sufism, Sexuality, Shakespeare [ENG-4224] [ENG-4224-1]

Faculty Name
Madhavi Menon [menon@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The conclusion of Amir Khusrau’s Poem # 35 could serve well as an epigraph to Richard II: “Poetry became my plague. / Alas, that Khusrau never said, ‘Silence,’ / and I did not stop talking.” This class will have the pleasurable task of putting in conversation texts and ideas that have not often been thought of together. Routine Eurocentric readings of Shakespeare assume that Christianity is the only religious influence on Shakespeare’s work. And that Europe derived its poetic traditions autochthonously. But both these assumptions point to a paucity of the imagination rather than being an actual statement of fact. A play like Romeo and Juliet, for instance, owes a lot to Persian tales like Laila-Majnun and Shirin-Farhad. And a play like Richard II shares an investment in the poetic exploration of desire with the entire corpus of Sufi poetry. In the belief that it is time to present these Persianate links as avenues for exploration, this class will foreground the theoretical question of queer desire. The aesthetics of power, the impossibility of fulfilled desire, an enchantment with rhetorical dexterity, a depth of tumultuous affect, are some of the ideas with which we will engage in our twin exploration of Sufi and Shakespearean poetry and desire.

title: THE TWILIGHT OF MODERNITY
description:
The Twilight of Modernity [ENG-4323] [ENG-4323-1]

Faculty Name
Vivek Venkitaraman Narayan [v.v.narayan@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

What is modernity? Or, perhaps more to the point, when was modernity? What is its provenance? And where lies its scope? Is modernity a global or a local phenomenon? If it is global, does this mean that modernity in the Global South is necessarily derivative of (Western) colonial modernity? And if it is local, can we think of modernities as alternative, multiple, and heterogeneous, but always connected and entangled phenomena? What, if anything, can we learn by comparing the situated histories of modernities at the end of the long nineteenth-century and the beginning of the twenty-first century?   

The Twilight of Modernity will investigate, as the title suggests, what a hopeful dawn looks like from the vantage point of an anxious dusk. The course will compare the histories of modernities at the turn of the twentieth- and twenty-first centuries by focussing on three themes: first, experiences of time and space; second, conceptions of the nation and the social; and third, discourses of rights and practices of discipline. All these themes are enmeshed, we will see, in the ongoing social and intellectual project of modernity.

Course material may include films and writing by Franz Kafka, George Orwell, the Wachowskis, Jeff Orlowski, Martin Scorsese, Gogu Shyamala, Charles Dickens, EM Forster, JG Ballard, Charlie Chaplin, Claudia Rankine, Georg Büchner, BR Ambedkar, Hannah Arendt, Byung-Chul Han, Benedict Anderson, Wendy Brown, Uday Singh Mehta, Shoshana Zuboff, Andrew Sartori, Jürgen Habermas, Nancy Fraser, Angela Davis, Charles Taylor, Keeanga-Yamahtta Taylor, Michel Foucault, EP Thompson, Zygmunt Bauman, Susan Buck-Morss, Georg Simmel, Eric Hobsbawm, Chris Bayly, Jürgen Osterhammel, WEB Du Bois, Paul Gilroy, and Karl Marx.       

(A clarifying note: This is a course about the social and intellectual project of modernity, which articulates political claims-making in the language of newness. The Twilight of Modernity does not focus on the associated aesthetic phenomena of various artistic movements assembled under the umbrella term of modernism.)

title: READING PSYCHOANALYTIC WRITING
description:
Reading Psychoanalytic Writing [ENG-4812] [ENG-4812-1]

Faculty Name
Amrita Narayanan [amrita.narayanan@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

What makes psychoanalytic writing psychoanalytic?  With equally hovering attention on language, form, and theoretical content, this class will grapple with the work of psychoanalytic writers from a few different schools, geographies, and time periods writing on diverse topics such as the body, art, violence, mourning and the clinic. Amongst others, we will read: Sigmund Freud, D.W. Winnicott, Masud Khan, Osaumu Kitayama, Melanie Klein, Nancy Riviere, Otto Rank, Andre Greene, Octave Mannoni, Haydée Faimberg and Maria Torok. As we read, we will discuss how and to what extent the concepts we read about translate from the language of psychoanalysis into the language of literary English, and from the clinic into other human experiences.

title: THE NATURE OF REALISM
description:
The Nature of Realism [ENG-4313] [ENG-4313-1]

Faculty Name
Alexander Robert Phillips [alexander.phillips@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

From post-Romanticism to global warming politics today, appeals to nature and appeals to realism often go hand in hand. This is hardly surprising, because the world as it (supposedly) is would seem to give lie to any number of fantasies, abstractions, and ideologies. But there is danger here, for while reality may bite, appeals to both “nature” and “realism” are often wielded as cudgels against the speculative, the utopian, the ideal, and the non-normative. But realism and nature have a much closer relation, for we see in the same history a pattern of nature somehow raising the stakes on realism itself. This course will thus investigate the representation of nature and theories of realism more broadly. From key thinkers of realism such as Georg Lukács, Erich Auerbach, and Roland Barthes we will consider the representation of the non-human as theorized in works by Herman Melville, Adalbert Stifter, Aldo Leopold, Edward Abbey, Annie Dillard, Amitav Ghosh, and more recent ecocritical debates on realism. Of course, “realism” is hardly the sole repository of the literary environmental imagination, so we will contrast these texts with works by authors such as Ursula LeGuin and Kim Stanley Robinson. In doing so we may find that even such speculative genres as science fiction are “realist” in their own right!

title: NEW DIRECTIONS IN POSTCOLONIAL STUDIES
description:
New Directions in Postcolonial Studies [ENG-4412] [ENG-4412-1]

Faculty Name
Rajeswari Sunder Rajan [rajeswari.rajan@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Postcolonial studies emerged as an influential sub-field in English departments in the metropolitan academy in the last decades of the twentieth century. This course is an attempt to identify and map the new directions that postcolonial studies appears to be moving into, a few decades on. Some of these shifts are clearly signalled, while others might be less perceptible. Even as it engages with new and urgent issues, adopts methods opened up by new technologies, and identifies fresh objects of study that promise greater relevance and staying power, postcolonial studies is also encountering challenges to its historical focus and its method as critique. We will focus on six key developments in the field:

  • a turn towards the anthropocene/environment, as an extension of the ‘postcolonial’ towards ‘planetary’ concerns and consciousness; 
  • different histories and alternative geographies (decoloniality; settler colonialism; indigenous studies; reconfigured regionalisms; Cold War and decolonization; globalization)
  • renewed or different emphasis on the politics of language (i.e. English, Anglophony/Francophony, and the ‘vernaculars’), and the politics of translation.
  • research in colonial and postcolonial print cultures and book history; 
  • the emergence of 'world literature' as rival paradigm; 
  • the critique of ‘critique' (the impact on postcolonial studies of the turn away from ‘critique’ in literary studies)

Academic Integrity: 

Any form of academic dishonesty, including multiple submissions, cheating, and plagiarism, will be reported to the OAA and will result in failure of the plagiarized assignment. If you have any questions about what constitutes plagiarism in the context of this course, please consult me.

 Accommodations and Accessibility: 

If you require accommodations, please contact the Office of Learning Support at ols@ashoka.edu.in. Doing so will allow you to maintain your privacy and allow me to meet the needs of all students in the course. 

Learning Outcomes

Schedule of Classes

II.Different histories and alternative geographies

The histories of colonialism are diverse and heterogeneous. ‘Decolonial' studies takes into account a longer history of New World settler colonialism in the Americas. Consequently, it regards the politics of indigenous peoples as a legitimate concern of the discipline. The histories of decolonization and the Cold War that have shaped the contemporary world order signal another major historical investment of the ‘new’ postcolonial studies. In addition, alternative geographies produced by globalization and new configurations of regionalisms (such as Indian Ocean studies, or the Black Atlantic) offer a turn away from the exclusive earlier focus on the colonized regions of Africa, the Caribbean and Asia.

III.The Politics of language and translation

Why does English (or the languages of European colonialism more generally) remain the dominant language of postcolonial writing? What is the nature of literatures in the languages of the global South (the ‘vernaculars', so-called: Arabic, Urdu, Hindi, Bahasa Indonesian, Yoruba, Swahili etc)? What role does translation play in the study and dissemination of postcolonial, comparative, and world literatures?

IV.Colonial and postcolonial print cultures and book history

The study of print cultures and histories of publication has opened up new areas of research into popular culture, print production (newspapers, periodicals, pamphlets, pulp fiction, ephemera, text-books etc), anti-colonial writing, colonial censorship, readerships, circulation, and networks in South Asia, Africa and the Caribbean, with significant implications for postcolonial literary studies and its relationship to English and comparative literature.

V.World Literature

‘World Literature‘ is in vigorous contestation with ‘postcolonial studies‘ in course offerings and job hires in English departments in the metropolitan academy. The politics and processes of such rivalry and substitution repay scrutiny. In what ways are the definitions, agendas, historical contexts and canons of postcolonial literature and world literature overlapping and related, and in what ways are they distinct or even antagonistic? We will pay particular attention to recent arguments originating in the critique of knowledge-production in the west that question the framing of world literature within a primarily European comparatist framework, and seek to restore its overlooked colonial genealogy as reflected in the histories of philology and, more broadly, orientalism.

VI.The Critique of ‘Critique‘

Like the emergence of ‘world literature‘ as a rival paradigm, the newly influential demand for ‘postcritical‘ reading seeks to restrict the perceived dominance of critical (read oppositional) forms of interpretation, of which postcolonialism as theoretical critique has arguably been the most effective. How do we understand the politics of this challenge from the academic establishment, and its likely implications?
