Grading Rubric

Assessment will be based on a variety of different assignments spread out over the course of the semester, as follows:

  • Attendance and class participation: 10%
  • Weekly responses: 20%
  • Mid-term short paper (1000 words, due March 13): 20% 
  • Group presentation: 10%
  • Final term paper (2500 words, due May 3): 40%

Explanation:

Weekly responses to readings (20%): Responses are to be posted, one a week, every week from weeks 2 to 13. You will be graded on your ten best posts. For this assignment you will be expected to comment on any one or more of the readings for the week. Your responses should be not less than 100 words long (about 10 lines). They can take the form of an interpretation, an opinion, a question, a comparison, an exposition, a close reading, an endorsement, a disagreement. . . Please feel free to write informally, but make your point clearly and coherently. The purpose of this exercise is to show that you have read the assigned texts and that you have given thought to the topic.

Please post your responses by midnight of the day before class. That will give me and everyone else time to read them before class. I would like to use them as the starting point of our subsequent class discussion.   

Mid-term paper (20%): The mid-term paper is due on March 13. Your paper should be approximately 1000 words long (about 4 pages, double-spaced). This paper should be a little more ambitious than the weekly post—cover more than one of the texts, find a common thread among them, and be more analytical. It should be formatted as a proper scholarly paper.

Final term paper (40%): The final paper will be due one week after the last class. We’ll set up consultations in person and via email to discuss your choice of a topic, your first draft and any stage of the process before or after. The final paper should be not less than 2500 words long (about 10 pages, double-spaced).

title: DAZZLING DARKNESS: VARIETIES OF MEDIEVAL MYSTICISM
description:
Dazzling Darkness: Varieties of Medieval Mysticism [ENG-4111] [ENG-4111-1]

Faculty Name
Alexandra Cassatt Verini [alexandra.verini@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Mystics and visionaries claim to have encounters with the divine that transcend ordinary human experience. The pursuit of this encounter is common across religious traditions and, during the period known as the Middle Ages, became an increasingly popular form of religious expression around the world. In this course, we ask, how can we make sense of spiritual experiences that exceed a post-enlightenment sense of the real? How can we read textual and visual representations of the inexpressible? Without homogenizing or simplifying how might we read mysticism comparatively across religious traditions?

 

With these questions in mind, this course offers a comparative introduction to medieval mysticism from Christian, Jewish, Islamic, and Hindu traditions. Examining writings by and of a wide variety of mystics—from Hildegard von Bingen to Kabir to Rabia of Basra—we will historically situate medieval visionaries while also considering points of intersection. From a literary studies perspective, we will explore the tensions between individual experience and communal or institutional religion; the kinds of authority and challenges to authority that these experiences created; the relationship between experiences of the spirit and practices of the body; the ways in which mysticism reflects and challenges pre-modern notions of gender and sexuality; and the problem of expressing the inexpressible. In the process, we will investigate the interpretative questions that mystical visions raise for historians and scholars of religion and examine the theories that scholars have used to study these types of religious experiences.

 

Please note: this course has two mandatory Saturday or Sunday (depending on student availability) visits that count as part of our course hours.

title: POPULAR FICTION: POLITICS AND PLEASURES
description:
Popular Fiction: Politics and Pleasures [ENG-3351] [ENG-3351-1]

Faculty Name
Rituparna Sengupta [rituparna.sengupta@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

How can we go beyond blanket dismissals or eulogization of the ‘popular’ and take up ‘popular fiction’ as a formal object of academic study? Are there specific tools of analysis that can be used to study the popular and its circuits of production, circulation, and consumption? How can studying popular fiction equip us for widening and deepening our modes of literary analysis? How does popular fiction both reflect and shape the cultures that produce and consume it? How can we reconcile the politics and pleasures of the popular?

In this course, we will draw upon concepts from Culture Studies and discuss a selection of scholarship from around the world that has taken up for analysis different genres and forms of popular fiction, in their specific social and cultural contexts. These include analyses of utopias in fantasy fiction, the sexual economies of romance novels, the workings of imperialism in Donald Duck cartoons, nationalism and masculinities in Amar Chitra Katha comics, among others. Our aim would be to study the popular as a dynamic interplay of dominant, residual, and emergent cultures, à la Raymond Williams.

title: THE ANGLOPHONE INDIAN NOVEL
description:
The Anglophone Indian Novel [ENG-3412] [ENG-3412-1]

Faculty Name
Rajeswari Sunder Rajan [rajeswari.rajan@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The production of English language fiction in India in the last two decades of the twentieth century has been described as a ‘boom’ comparable to a similar phenomenon in the South American continent in the 1960s. What supported the diagnosis was most immediately prolificity—what had earlier been a thin trickle of such works became a steady flow. The new fiction came to be seen moreover as a marked break from the kind of writing that went before, in terms of both its themes as well as the literary experimentation it attempted. Above all, there was the fact of the publication and recognition of the new writers in the west, which meant large international readerships.

 

It is widely acknowledged that the single factor responsible for these changes is the publication of Salman Rushdie’s Midnight’s Children in 1981. Midnight’s Children is informed by the ambition of narrating the nation, signalled by Rushdie’s device of twinning the destiny of its protagonist Saleem Sinai with that of the new Indian nation, both born at midnight on August 15,

1947. The Anglophone novel in India in following him is therefore regarded as a project in writing the nation. It is the nation—or more accurately, India-- as optic, invention and

investment that was perceived as driving the ‘new’ Indian novel in English.

 

At the same time, Rushdie’s influence has been challenged, and the thematic of the nation has been side-stepped, by several writers. We will therefore be open to the counter-thesis that other influences than Rushdie (notably, V.S. Naipaul), and other preoccupations than the nation inform (some of) the writing of this period.

 

Students will be required to read one novel every week, alongside one or two related critical essays. So prior familiarity with some of the novels of the period (and at least one of Naipaul’s novels) would be an asset.

Academic Integrity:  There is zero tolerance in this course for any form of academic dishonesty, including multiple submissions, cheating, and plagiarism. Any of these offenses will be reported to the OAA and will result in failure of the plagiarized assignment. If you have any questions about what constitutes plagiarism in the context of this course, please reach out to me.

 Accommodations and Accessibility: If you require accommodations, please contact the Office of Learning Support at ols@ashoka.edu.in. Doing so will allow you to maintain your privacy and allow me to meet the needs of all students in the course.

title: THE RECONSTRUCTION OF THOUGHT: MUHAMMAD IQBAL AND FRIEDRICH NIETZSCHE
description:
The Reconstruction of Thought: Muhammad Iqbal and Friedrich Nietzsche [ENG-3331] [ENG-3331-1]

Faculty Name
Huzaifa Omair Siddiqi [huzaifa.siddiqi@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Friedrich Nietzsche’s philosophy seems to have had two dominant effects in the theoretical currents that sought to recover his thought from Fascist appropriation in the 20th century: a suspicious and cautious deconstruction of given metaphysical systems or the speculative and playful construction of concepts. The question of what is noble, which is perhaps Nietzsche’s most interesting question, is what is repressed in this project (and as such returns to vitiate its egalitarian claims in various ways). In this course we will see how one of South Asia’s first readers of Nietzsche, the Urdu and Persian poet Muhammad Iqbal, gave a centrality to this problem in both his poetry and his philosophical prose. In this course we will read both Nietzsche’s works as well as Iqbal’s poems (in translation) and prose along with some other thinkers of that period like Henri Bergson and A.N. Whitehead. The objective of this course is to come to an understanding of what Iqbal meant by reconstruction and what that entails for our understanding of a political and philosophical position that takes the question of nobility seriously.

title: FOLKTALE AND THE WORLD
description:
Folktale and the World [CT-2422] [CT-2422-1]

Faculty Name
Malay Bera [malay.bera_ga@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

We all have grown up with folktales in the form of fables, ghost stories, fairy tales and/or Disney movies. These folktales shape our perception of the world, and in turn, are reshaped each time they are retold. How do we study these everyday narratives critically? Why do some tales stay with us while others fade from memory? What purpose do they serve in the world? How do social issues inform folk narratives? And how do folk narratives change the world in turn, for better or worse? Our aim is not to arrive at overarching theories but to regard folktales in their local and historical contexts as stories that are sometimes subversive and at others, reactionary.

The course will begin by situating fairy tales at the intersection between folklore and literature, and go on to explore other sub-genres of the folktale including urban legends, rumours, jokes and conspiracy theories. We will read selections from wide-ranging contexts from texts like the Grimm brothers’ fairy tales, The Panchatantra, The Arabian Nights, Thakurmar Jhuli etc. Along with oral and written narratives, we will look into their audio-visual variants in the culture industry as well. Our readings will be informed by theoretical works by Jack Zipes, Sadhana Naithani, Maria Tatar, Sigmund Freud and others. The aim is to approach the genre of the folktale from different theoretical vantage points including the ethnographic and the performative, but also feminist and postcolonial ones. We will simultaneously work on the fundamental aspects of academic writing such as structuring a coherent piece, developing a persuasive argument, dialoguing with existing research etc.

title: AT THE MARGINS OF CARE AND LOVE
description:
At the Margins of Care and Love [ENG-3341] [ENG-3341-1]

Faculty Name
S Satish Kumar [s.kumar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course seeks to reflect on care and love both conceptually and experientially. What does it mean to care for and love oneself and others? What allows us to love and care? What prevents us from loving and caring for ourselves and others? What forces—personal, interpersonal, or collective and communal—regulate, prescribe and even prohibit experiences and expressions of love. To paraphrase the narrator of The God of Small Things, this course attempts reflections on the “Love Laws” that determine who can be loved, how and how much.

 

The texts chosen for our study have been selected from literature, cinema, and television. In their own unique ways, each text deals with such themes through representations of experiences from subject positions that lie outside of “traditional” and “normative” structures within which love and care are usually understood and experienced. The primary objective of the course then is to develop a critical language towards understanding and addressing care and love as the basis for a relationship with oneself and between oneself and others.

title: INTRODUCTION TO GRAPHIC NARRATIVES
description:
Introduction to Graphic Narratives [ENG-2351] [ENG-2351-1]

Faculty Name
Rituparna Sengupta [rituparna.sengupta@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

What is the difference between ‘comics’, ‘graphic novels’, and ‘graphic narratives’? Are ‘graphic narratives’ the same as ‘picture books’, or is there something more specific about the combination of word and image in this form? Are graphic narratives meant for children, young adults, or adults? Is it a ‘western’ form that has been imported and adapted by the ‘east’, or can it be traced to deeper, more diverse roots? Historically, what has been the relationship of comics and censorship, and how did the term ‘graphic novel’ emerge out of the debates and discussions around the seductions of this form? 

In this course, we will look at a selection of comics, graphic novels, and graphic non-fiction from around the world, to understand the range and flexibility of this form across different genres, as both art and literature. We will begin by acquainting ourselves with comics vocabulary and grammar (panel transitions, gutter space, word-image relations) and then learn to apply them to understand why and how we consume/are consumed by this medium. We will pay special attention to why this medium has of late been used for the portrayal of narratives of trauma and acts of witnessing conflict and violence.

title: SEMINAR IN ADVANCED THEORY:READING THEORY
description:
Seminar in Advanced Theory: Reading Theory [ENG-3005] [ENG-3005-1]

Faculty Name
Madhavi Menon [menon@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The practice of reading, as Paolo and Francesca find out to their peril, can be fatal. Reading can inspire passion and theory, poetry and protest, deviance and death. This class will follow the literary trajectory of some passionate theories, and will try and stay alive while charting that perilous course. We will read the literary texts through which theorists have formulated their theories. And equally, we will read the theory as it engages with the literature that has nominally occasioned it. Thinking about “reading” in the most capacious sense, this course will engage with the multiple layers of textuality that make up the world in which we live. What is the relation between literature and theory? How do we get ideas? And how do these ideas allow us to engage the worlds in which we live?

title: IS THERE A MODERN LITERATURE?
description:
Is There A Modern Indian Literature? [ENG-4405/ CW-4405] [ENG-4405/ CW-4405-1]

Faculty Name
Amit Prakash Chaudhuri [amit.chaudhuri@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

For ‘Is There a Modern Indian Literature?’, I will use the Picador Book of Modern Indian Literature and a few other texts, and some cinema and music. I also plan to bring in some material from outside India – the stories of Junichiro Tanizaki, for instance.  The question in the course title is one I asked myself as I began putting together the anthology I mention above in the late 1990s. How was one to conceive of a tradition called 'Indian literature'? Was it the total of thevarious literatures of India? Or was there another way of exploring this category? It was a time when the Indian novel in English and the idea of 'postcolonial literature' had begun to dominate. How did the modernist and avant garde trajectories of literatures in the Indian languages fit into these relatively recent categorisations? One of my own reasons for rethinking and enlarging the frame had to do with my affinities with modernism as a reader and writer, affinities that seemed out of place post-Midnight's Children, but not so out of place within the experimental histories of
modern Indian literatures themselves. The use of the word 'modern' was, and is, deliberate, to point to developments that the term 'postcolonial' doesn't address. The texts we'll read here would follow, without too much narrow systematising, ‘Indian literature’ and the way its emergence from the late nineteenth century in various languages embodied the trajectory of modernity, modernism, the avant garde, and formal preoccupations in India. The course means to question the largely theme-driven, Anglophone parameters of the ‘postcolonial’ that have been with us for some decades now.

'As in 2022, this will be a hybrid course, co-hosted by The Oxford Research Centre of the Humanities. Participants will join in from all over the world, but the core class will comprise Ashoka University students, who will take the course in person and will be required to write two essays of 1500 words each over the course of the semester.' 

Learning Outcomes

Students from Oxford and other universities will be sitting in on the class, and will participate in discussions. However, only Ashoka students will be writing essays, for which they'll be graded.

Grading Rubric

Grades will be given on the basis of two short essays to be written by each student over the term, plus class contributions. Essays should be shared with the tutor and other students at least four days prior to each class.

Attendance Policy

TBA

fullName: CHI-3204, STONE, PAPER, BAMBOO, SILK: SINOPHONE TEXTUAL CULTURES, ELOISE WRIGHT
title: STONE, PAPER, BAMBOO, SILK: SINOPHONE TEXTUAL CULTURES,
description:
Stone, Paper, Bamboo, Silk: Sinophone Textual Cultures [HIS-3513/ CHI-3204/ VA-3027/ ENG-3413] [HIS-3513/ CHI-3204/ VA-3027/ ENG-3413-1]

Faculty Name
Eloise Wright [eloise.wright@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Today, when so much of our daily communication occurs via text or email, it can be difficult to imagine a world in which writing was the preserve of a tiny minority. Chinese characters are frequently cited as the oldest continuous written tradition, beginning over three thousand years ago, but in that time the physical form of the characters and the materials they were written on have transformed over and over again. We will consider what questions these problems raise for historians' use of textual sources by looking at writing as a social, material, and political act. What were the symbolic meanings attributed to writings that most people could not understand? What practical uses could writing serve? How did access to writing intersect with other social hierarchies, like gender and class? Beginning with the invention of writing in the Yellow River region, we will discuss problems such as: the relationship between speech and writing; changes in writing materials; writing for display and writing for use; censorship; Chinese characters in non-Chinese societies; and debates over script reform.

The written assessment for this class will build towards a final research paper on a topic of the students' choice.

title: READING HISTORY
description:
Reading History [HIS-3001/ SOA-3513/ ENG-3231] [HIS-3001/ SOA-3513/ ENG-3231-1]

Faculty Name
Neeladri Bhattacharya [neeladri.bhattacharya@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

READING HISTORY: FROM POSITIVISM TO CRITICAL THEORY

Neeladri Bhattacharya

Object of the course:

The course will explore how history as a modern discipline comes into being in the nineteenth century, and how it changes over time. It will focus on some of the dominant traditions of historical writing, and the internal dialogues within the traditions. It will move from positivism to critical theory, from Marxism to the Annales, from the French historical tradition to English social history, from Foucault’s discursive turn to Michel de Certeau’s focus on everyday practice. Through this journey, we will reflect on some of the binaries that often shape historical thinking –– the questions of history and myth, certainty and ambiguity, objectivity and prejudice, truth and falsehood –– and see how these notions are questioned and rethought over time.

If historians in the nineteenth century established some of the founding premises of the historian’s craft, the ‘critical turn’ from the 1970s has powerfully questioned many of these assumptions, underlining the complex nature of historical practice. It has persuaded historians to ask: what does it mean to enter the archive and mine the traces of the past, to read the record, to see and represent, to narrate, and to write a story based on evidence? This course will explore what this critical turn has meant to the writing of history, how it has forced historians to question earlier frames, and opened up new worlds of research.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

THEMES AND LECTURES:

Introduction: On Reading History

I: MODERNITY AND HISTORICAL KNOWEDGE

 

1) Ranke, Acton and the Shaping of the Historical Discipline

     Readings:

G. G. Iggers and K. von Moltke (eds), The Theory and Practice of History: Leopold von Ranke, Indianapolis, 1973, Introduction.

John Warren, ‘The Rankean Tradition in British Historiography, 1850-1950’, in Stephen Berger et al., eds., Writing History: Theory and Practice, Hodder Arnold, 2003.

Leonard Krieger, Ranke: The Meaning of History, (Read: Ch. 1: The Dubious Legacy, Ch. 2: The Unscientific Counterpoint, Ch. 3: The Limits of Theory), pp. 1-34.

Acton, A Lecture on the Study of History, Macmillan 1911.

 

2) Ethnocentrism, Teleology and the Idea of Progress:

      

     Readings:  

H. Butterfield, The Whig Interpretation of History. Norton Library, 1965. Chs. 1-3.

Collingwood, The Idea of History, Introduction and Part V, Epilegomena.

Peter Winch, ‘Understanding Primitive Society’, in Bryan Wilson ed. Rationality, Oxford, Basil Blackwell 1970.

Charles Taylor, ‘Understanding and Ethnocentricity’, in Social Theory as Practice (OUP, New Delhi, 1983)

 

3) History and the Narrative Turn

Readings:

Louis O.  Mink, ‘Narrative form as Cognitive Instrument’ in Louis O.  Mink, Historical Understanding, Cornell University Press, 1987.

Hayden White, ‘The Historical Text as a Literary Artifact’, in Hayden White, Tropics of Discourse, John Hopkins University Press, 1978.

Hayden White, ‘The Value of Narrativity in the Representation of Reality’, in White, The Content of the Form, The John Hopkins University Press, 1987.

Paul Ricoeur, ‘On Narrative Time’, Critical Inquiry, Vol. 7, No. 1, Special Issue on Narrative (Autumn, 1980), pp. 169-190.

David Carr, ‘Getting the Story Straight: Narrative and Historical Knowledge’, in Geoffrey Roberts Ed., The History and Narrative Reader, Routledge, 2001, pp. 197-208.

 

II: ANNALES AND THE FRENCH HISTORICAL TRADITION

 

4) The Vision of Total History:

   Readings:

Marc Bloch, The Historian’s Craft, New York 1953.

Lucien Febvre, ‘A New Kind of History’, in Burke, Peter ed., A New Kind of History: From the Writings of Lucien Febvre, Routledge, 1973, pp. 27-43.

Lucien Febvre, ‘Sensibility and History: How to Constitute the Emotional Life of the Past’, in Burke, ed., A New Kind of History: From the Writings of Lucien Febvre, pp. 12-26.

 

5) Braudel and Historical Time

   Readings:

Fernand Braudel, ‘History and the Social Sciences: The Longue Dureé’, Annales E.S.C., No 4, 1958, reproduced in Braudel, On History, The University of Chicago Press, 1980, pp. 25-54.

Peter Burke, ‘The History of the Event and the Revival of the Narrative’, in Peter Burke ed., New Perspectives on Historical Writing, Cambridge: Polity Press, 2001, pp. 283-300.

E. Le Roy Ladurie, The ‘Event and the Long Term in Social History: The Case of Chouan Uprising’, in Ladurie, The Territory of the Historian, The Harvester Press, 1979.

Aron Gurevich, ‘What is Time’, in Aron Gurevich, Categories of Medieval Culture, Routledge, 1985, pp. 152-93.

    

6) Febvre, Le Goff and the History of Mentalite

    Readings:

Jacques Le Goff,  ‘Merchant’s Time and Church’s Time in the Middle Ages’, Time Work and Culture in the Middle Ages, The University of Chicago Press, 1982, pp. 29-42.

Le Goff, ‘Dreams in the Culture and Collective Psychology of the Middle Ages’, Time Work and Culture in the Middle Ages, The University of Chicago Press, 1982, 201-204.

Robert Muchembled, Smells: A Cultural History of Odours in Early Modern Times, Polity, 2020, Chs 1-4.

LaCapra, Dominick., ‘Is Everyone a Mentalite Case?’ in LaCapra, Dominick, History and Criticism, Cornell University Press, 1985.

Peter Burke, ‘Strengths and Weaknesses of a History of Mentalities’, in Burke, Varieties of Cultural Histories, Cornell University Press, 1997 pp. 162-82.

 

III: MARXISM AND HISTORICAL WRITING

 

7) The Beginnings: Karl Marx, Marxism and History

           Readings:

Karl Marx, 18th Brumaire of Louis Bonaparte. 1852.

Marx, ‘Theses on Feuerbach’, 1845.

Eric Hobsbawm, ‘Karl Marx’s Contribution to Historiography’, in Ideology and Social Sciences, Suffolk 1962.

Joseph Stalin, Historical and Dialectical Materialism, 1938.

 

8) Althusser and the Structuralist Vision

     Readings:

Althusser, For Marx, Harmondsworth, 1969.Ch. 1.

Thompson, E.P., ‘Poverty of Theory: or an Orrery of Errors’, in The Poverty of Theory, Merlin, London, 1978, Ch.

Maurice Godelier, ‘The Ideal in the Real’, in Raphael Samuel and Stedman Jones eds., Culture, Ideology and Politics, Routledge, 1982.

 

9) History from Below and New Social History: E. P. Thompson and Beyond

    Readings:

E. Thompson, ‘The Moral Economy Of the English Crowd’, Past & Present, No. 50 (Feb. 1971), pp. 76-136.

Thompson, ‘Rough Music’, in Thompson, Customs in Common, Penguin, 1991, pp. 467-534.

Elizabeth Fox Genovese, “The Many Faces of Moral Economy: A Contribution to the Debate’, Past & Present , Feb., 1973, No. 58 (Feb., 1973), pp. 161-168.

Chris Wickham, ‘Gossip and Resistance among the Medieval Peasantry’, Past & Present, 160 (1998).

R.W. Scribner, ‘Sorcery, Superstition and the Society: The Witch of Urach’, in Scribner, Popular Culture and Popular Movements in Reformation Germany, 1529, The Hambledon Press, 1987, pp. 257-76.

Shahid Amin, ‘Gandhi as Mahatma’, in Ranajit Guha ed., Subaltern Studies III, OUP, 1984.

 

10) Gendering History (student led discussion)

      Readings:

Joan Wallach Scott, ‘Women in the Making of the English Working Class’, in Scott, Gender and the Politics of History, Columbia University Press, 1999, pp. 68-92

Carolyn Steedman, ‘The Price of Experience, Women and the Making of the English Working Class’, Radical History Review, 59, 1994, pp 108-119.

Judith Butler, ‘Speaking Up, Talking Back: Joan Scott’s Critical Feminism’, in Butler and Elizabeth Weed eds., The Question of Gender: Joan Scott’s Critical Feminism, Indiana University Press, 2011, pp. 11-30.

Saidiya Hartman, ‘A Venus in Two Acts’, Small Axe, 12: 26: 2, June 2008, pp 1-14

 

IV: HISTORY AND CRITICAL THEORY

 

11)  Foucault and Histories of Power:

Readings:

Michel Foucault, ‘The Body of the Condemned’, & ‘Docile Bodies’, in Discipline and Punish, Vintage Books, Part I, Ch 1&  Part  III, Ch. 2.

Michel Foucault, ‘Body Power”, & ‘Truth and Power’, in Power/Knowledge, The Harvester Press 1980, pp. 55-62, 109-33.

Foucault, ‘The Subject of Power’, Herbert Dreyfus and Paul Rabinow, Michel Foucault: Beyond Structuralism and Hermeneutics, University of Chicago Press, 1982, pp. 208-28.

 

12) Semiotics and the History of Meanings and Symbols

    Readings:

Robert Darnton, ‘The Great Cat Massacre’, in Darnton, The Great Cat Massacre and Other Episodes in French Cultural History, New York, Basic Books, 1984.

Roger Chartier, ‘Texts, Symbols and Frenchness’, in Chartier, Cultural History:  Between Practices and Representations, Polity Press, Cambridge, 1988.

Dominick La Capra, ‘Chartier, Darnton and the Great Symbol Massacre’, in La Capra, Soundings in Critical Theory, Cornell University Press, Ithaca, London, 1989.

Raphael Samuel, ‘Reading the Signs’, History Workshop, No. 32, 1991, pp. 88-109.

 

13) Michel de Certeau and the Practice of Everyday Life

      Readings:

Michel de Certeau, ‘Walking the City’, in de Certeau, The Practice of Everyday Life, University of California Press, 1988.

Michel de Certeau, ‘Making do: Uses and Tactics’, 115-30, in de Certeau, The Practice of Everyday Life, pp., 29-42.

Chartier, Cultural History:  Between Practices and Representations, Polity Press, Cambridge, 1988, Ch. 1

 

14) Looking at the Small and the Anecdotal: Microhistory and New Historicism

      Readings:

Microhistory: (student discussion)

Carlo Ginzburg, ‘Micro history: Two or Three Things that I Know about it’, Critical Inquiry, No. 1, 1993; reproduced in Threads and Traces, pp., 193-214.

Carlo Ginzburg, The Cheese and the Worms: The Cosmos of a Sixteenth-century Miller, John Hopkins University, 1980, pp. 1-35.

Giovanni Levi, ‘On Microhistory’, in: Peter Burke ed., New Perspectives on Historical Writing (Cambridge: Polity Press, 2001), p. 93-113.

Ranajit Guha, ‘Chandra’s death’, Subaltern Studies, V, OUP, 1987, 135-65.

Tanika Sarkar, ‘Talking about Scandals: Religion, Law and Love in Nineteenth Century Calcutta’, Studies in History, 13: 1 1997, pp. 63-95.

 

  New Historicism:

Stephen Greenblatt, ‘The Poetics of Culture’, Michael Payne ed., The Greenblatt Reader, Blackwell Publishing, 2005, pp. 30-49.

Catharine Gallagher and Stephen Greenblatt, Practicing New Historicism, University of Chicago Press, 1997. Introduction, pp. 1-19

         

Gallagher and Stephen Greenblatt, ‘Counter History and the Anecdote’, in Practicing New Historicism, University of Chicago Press, 1997pp. 49-74.

Gallagher, ‘The Potato in Materialist Imagination’, Practicing New Historicism, University of Chicago Press, 1997, pp.110-35.

 

15) Post Modernism, Post Colonialism and the Writing of History

      Readings

Dipesh Chakrabarty, ‘Postcoloniality and the Artifice of History: Who Speaks for "Indian" Pasts?’, Representations, No. 37 (Winter, 1992), pp. 1-26.

Gabrielle Spiegel, ‘History, Historicism and the Social Logic of the Text in the Middle Ages’, Speculum, lxv, 1990, pp. 59-86.

 Patrick Joyce and Catriona Kelly, ‘History and Post-Modernism’, Past & Present, No. 133 (Nov., 1991), pp. 204-213.

Hayden White, ‘Historical Emplotment and the Problem of Truth’, in Saul Friedlander, Probing the Limits of Representation, Harvard University Press, 1992, pp. 37-54.

Dominick LaCapra, ‘Representing the Holocaust: Reflections on the Historians’ Debate’, Saul Friedlander, Probing the Limits of Representation, Harvard University Press, 1992, pp. 108-127.

Braun, Robert, ‘The Holocaust and the Problems of Representation’, History and Theory, 34, 1, 1995.

Grading Rubric

Assessment:

There are no exams for this course. The structure of assessment will be as follows: (i) 8 short response papers/presentations on readings = 40 per cent of total credits (5% x 8 = 40) and (2) an end semester essay of 2500-3500 words = 60 percent of total credits.

The course has 4 parts. Students will have to write two response papers for each part. You can choose any two readings from those suggested for each part and write notes of about 400 words each, capturing the arguments in the essay and stating your responses to it. These will be discussed in the class on scheduled dates.

The end semester essay will be on a theme selected by the student in consultation with me, and the draft will be discussed in separate discussion groups, each with 5-6 students.

Attendance Policy

There is no compulsory attendance for the lectures, but all students are expected to be there for the scheduled discussions.  Participation in the discussions and student led presentations will be taken into account in grading.

title: SOCIAL ENTREPRENEURSHIP AND IMPACT
description:
Social Entrepreneurship and Impact [ENT-2002] [ENT-2002-1]

Faculty Name
Ankur Sarin [ankur.sarin@ashoka.edu.in] ,Ekanto Ghosh [ekanto.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in] ,Priyank Narayan [priyank.narayan@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Living in India, one does not need facts and figures to understand the monumental challenges
faced in the process of development and the need for social change. The state carries much of
the responsibility for social change in liberal conceptions of social order. While the
third-sector housing non-profit organisations have seen to be complementing this role, the
idea of “Social Entrepreneurship” today captures much of the innovative thinking that has
emerged over recent years to overcome these challenges.

By seeking to merge the creation of societal value with more market like pursuits, it seeks to
engage individuals who are interested in contributing to society but are either wary of or
intimidated by the traditional actors in the social space. However, the increased attention to
the sector has also lead to recognition of its limitations.

In this course, we will try to understand private actions that engender social change and
sources of resistance and threats to it.

The specific objectives of the course are to help participants:
● Engage with the complexities and paradoxes of social change
● Understand the need, role and functioning of social entrepreneurs in society

● Understanding models of social entrepreneurship
● Engage with evaluation frameworks for social enterprises

fullName: HIS-3214, TRADERS, MERCHANTS, AND CAPITALISTS: BUSINESS HISTORY OF INDIA 1600-PRESENT, GAURAV GARG
title: TRADERS, MERCHANTS, AND CAPITALISTS: BUSINESS HISTORY OF INDIA 1600-PRESENT,
description:
Traders, Merchants, and Capitalists: Business History of India 1600-Present [HIS-3214/ ENT-3015] [HIS-3214/ ENT-3015-1]

Faculty Name
Gaurav Churiwala Garg [gaurav.garg@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Course Overview

When India became independent, it was one of the few countries of the global South with a robust business class and a sizeable private sector. Did this class emerge because of colonialism or despite it? What has been role of businesses in India’s capitalist development and politics? Why are Indian businesspeople from certain communities that hail from the arid parts of South Asia? And what has been the relationship between entrepreneurship, caste, class, community, and gender in India? With these questions in mind, this course will introduce students to the main themes and issues in Indian business history from 1600 to the present. This course will equip students with a firm understanding of the long- term patterns of changes and continuity in Indian business landscape; enable them to make better sense of what is new and what is not about Indian private sector today; and help them critically analyze the discourse on and by businesses in modern India.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Course Structure and Reading:

The course is organized chronologically into 4 modules— 1600-1800; 1800-1914; 1914-1947; 1947 to Present. Each session will incorporate seminar style discussion and lectures.

Basic Texts:

Dwijendra Tripathi and Jyoti Jumanji The Concise Oxford History of Indian Business (OUP 2006).

Medha Kudaisya (ed). The Oxford India Anthology of Business History (OUP 2011).

Tirthankar Roy A Business History of India: Enterprise and the Emergence of Capitalism from 1600 (CUP 2018).

Selected Topical Readings (excerpts will be specified).

1600-1800

Prasannan Parthasarthi Why Europe Grew Rich and India did not? (Cambridge 2011).

Sven Beckert Empires of Cotton (Alfred Knopf 2014).

Sanjay Subrahmayam and Christopher Bayly “Portfolio Capitalists and the Political Economy of Modern India” IESHR 25:4

Stephen Dale Indian Merchants and Eurasian Trade (Cambridge 2009).

Ashin Dasgupta Indian Merchants and the Decline of Surat (South Asia 1994).

Lakshmi Subramanian Indigenous Capital and Imperial Expansion (OUP 1996).

Cristopher Bayly Rulers, Townsmen and Bazaars (Cambridge 1982).

Tirthankar Roy The East India Company (Penguin 2016).

Chhaya Goswami Globalization Before its Time: The Gujrati merchants from Kachh (Penguin 2016).

1800-1914

David Rudner Caste and Capitalism in Colonial India: The Nattukottai Chettiars (Berkely 1994).

Blair B. Kling Partners in Empire: Dwarkanath Tagore and the Age of Enterprise in Eastern India (KLM 1981).

Clause Markovitz The Global World of Indian Merchants, 1750-1947: Traders of Sind from Bukhara to Panama (Cambridge 2000).

Thomas Timberg Marwaris: From Traders to Industrialists (Vikas 1979).

Maria Misra Business, Race and Politics in British India 1850- 1960 (Oxford 1999).

Douglas Haynes Rhetoric and Ritual (Oxford 1992).

Douglas Haynes Small Town Capitalism in Western India (Cambridge 2012).

Rajat Ray “Asian Capital in the Age of European Domination, 1800-1914,” MAS, 29:3 (1995).

Rajat Ray “The Bazaar: Changing Structural Characteristics of Indigenous Section of the Indian economy,” IESHR 25:3, 1988.

Anand Yang Bazaar India (Berkeley 1998).

Joseph Sassoon The Sassoons: The Great Global Merchants and the Making of an Empire (Pantheon 2022).

1914-1947

Amiya Bagchi Private Investment in India 1900-1939 (CUP 1972).

Mircea Rainau Tata: The Global Corporation that Built India (HUP 2021).

Medha Kudaisya The Life and Times of G.D. Birla (OUP 2002).

Rajat Ray Entrepreneurship and Industry in India 1800-1947 (OUP 1994).

Ritu Birla Stages of Capital: Law, Culture and Market Governance in Late Colonial India (Duke 2009).

Akshaya Mukul Gita Press and the Making of Hindu India (Harper Collins 2015)

1947-Present

Vivek Chibber Locked in Place (Princeton 2003).

Nasir Tyabji Forging Capitalism in Nehru’s India (OUP 2015).

Harish Damodaran India’s New Capitalists: Caste, Business and Industry (Palgrave 2008).

Sharad Chari Fraternal Capital (Stanford 2004).

Josy Joseph A Feast of Vultures: The Hidden Business of Democracy in India (Harper Collins 2016).

Aseem Prakash Dalit Capital: State, Markets and Civil Society in Urban India (Routledge 2015).

Grading Rubric

Grading:

In class assessment 50 per cent: There will be a small in-class assessment at the end of every module. Of the four assessments the best two will be graded. This will carry 50 per cent of the grade.

Term-end Paper 35 per cent: Students will write one term-end paper (approx 2000 words) in which they will have to reflect on one of the following questions in the course:

What has been the relationship between businesses and colonialism in India?

What has been role of businesses in India’s capitalist development and politics?

Why are Indian businesspeople from certain communities that hail the arid parts of South Asia? How have these business communities changed over time?

What has been the relationship between entrepreneurship, caste, class, community, and gender in India?

Annotated Bibliography 15 percent: Students will have to work on an annotated bibliography focusing on the issues they choose to address in their term-end paper.

Attendance Policy

Not Compulsory. Details to be decided.

title: DECODING GENETICALLY MODIFIED CROPS: THE GLOBAL POLITICS OF AGRICULTURE AND BIOTECHNOLOGY
description:
Decoding Genetically Modified Crops: The Global Politics of Agriculture and Biotechnology [ES-3411/ SOA-3502/ POL-3061/ BIO-3411] [ES-3411/ SOA-3502/ POL-3061/ BIO-3411-1]

Faculty Name
Aniket Pankaj Aga [aniket.aga@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Decoding genetically modified (GM) crops: The global politics of agriculture and biotechnology
Spring 2023
Tue/Thu - 8:30 am - 10:00 am

AC 01 LR 103

Course description

Genetically modified (GM) are the subject of fierce global controversies. Nearly every aspect about them is disputed – from their role in “feeding the world” and their impacts with respect to yield and environment to regulatory policies and peoples’ notions of choice and ethics. This course examines the GM debate by looking at the transformations of agriculture and agricultural sciences in the 20th century. It analyzes how private industry has sought profits from agriculture, and the consequent impacts on farming communities. This will help us grasp deeper issues that are often lost in heated anti/pro-GM arguments. Surveying controversies in India, the USA and other parts of the world, the course will demonstrate how the GM debate is shaped by the inter-related shifts in law, politics, and science. By way of examining the case of Bt cotton, Golden Rice, Bt brinjal among others, the course ultimately invites the question: Where do GM crops fit in the landscape of the burning issues faced by the average farmer, if at all?

More broadly, the questions we will consider in this class are, in fact, relevant to most technologies incident upon agriculture, and on the relationship between technology and society, in general. Our learnings from this course will carry over to a larger set of issues than GM crops alone.

This is a seminar course i.e. it is a discussion-oriented course that relies on close reading of research. This course will involve a good amount of reading. 

Learning Outcomes

Students will…

1. Study the relationship between agricultural sciences and GM crops.

2. Study the questions of public interest in different classes of GM crops, particularly insect-resistant crops, herbicide tolerant crops, and Golden Rice.

3. Engage with the complexities of regulatory design.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Pre-requisites: None

title: ECOLOGY
description:
Ecology [BIO-3020/ BIO-6020/ ES-2101/ PHY-3020] [BIO-3020/ BIO-6020/ ES-2101/ PHY-3020-1]

Faculty Name
Shivani [shivani.krishna@ashoka.edu.in ] ;
Overview

The course will cover a range of topics from individuals to ecosystems with an emphasis on theoretical foundations and recent developments in the field. We will begin with how ecological understanding is achieved, how conditions and resources influence individual species and then move to processes at higher levels of organization and end with rethinking some of the big questions in ecology. The topics covered will include physiological ecology, population ecology, species interactions, community ecology, succession and disturbance; ecosystem ecology, and biogeochemistry. Topics introduced in the lectures will be followed by in class-activities (and simulations) and discussions. For discussion sessions, I will suggest classic and recent research papers and students will lead discussions based on those. The course will allow reflecting on uncertainty and variation in natural processes from individual behavior to ecosystem services. It is recommended strongly to take Genetics and Evolution course prior to this since this course will build on some of the modules covered in that course.

Learning Outcomes

Towards the end of this course, students will be able to (a) understand how ecologists empirically study processes occurring at various scales and apply evolutionary thinking to these processes (b) integrate proximate and ultimate factors to understand natural processes (c) quantitatively synthesize ecological research (d) explore applications of ecological concepts such as conservation, landscape management.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Begon, M., Harper, J. L., & Townsend, C. R. Ecology. Individuals, populations and communities. Blackwell scientific publications.

Scott, G. (2009). Essential animal behavior. John Wiley & Sons.

Davies, N. B., Krebs, J. R., & West, S. A. (2012). An Introduction to behavioural ecology. John Wiley & Sons.

Grading Rubric

Grading scheme for undergraduate students:

Absolute grading system will be followed for the course

Assignments - 40% (2 assignments of 20 marks each)

Paper discussions and presentations- 10%

Midterm (in class)- 20%

Final (in class)- 20%

Class participation and attendance- 10%

There will be two take-home assignments (20 marks each) and two examinations (midterm and final). A list of research papers will be circulated towards the second week of the course for discussions and presentations.

For graduate students:

Paper discussions and presentations- 10%; Assignments - 20% (2 assignments of 20 marks each); Reaction paper/critique paper- 30% (2 papers of 15 marks each); Midterm- 20%; Final- 20%

Graduate students are required to submit two written papers: 1500-word critique papers briefly summarizing and critically evaluating published research work, presenting personal viewpoints along with evidence backed by constructive criticism on a specific concept or research article.

Attendance Policy

No more than three unexcused absences will be allowed.

Attachment
Ecology course_Spring 2023.pdf

title: ENVIRONMENT AND SOCIAL EXCLUSION
description:
Environment and Social Exclusion [ES-3435/ POL-3049] [ES-3435/ POL-3049-1]

Faculty Name
Mukul Sharma [mukul.sharma@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This elective course focusses on questions of social exclusion and social justice in environment, with a particular emphasis on race, caste and class. The concept of social exclusion as an analytical framework has become increasingly relevant for an understanding of the notions of environmental inequality, conflicts, rights and justice. The course will capture the social exclusion structures and processes which restrict the access of certain social groups to environmental resources and entitlements. It will explain the different forms of social disadvantage – in village and community, in land and water, in space and commons, in wilderness and conservation – that persist, in multiple variants and with different intensity, across societies and nations. It will locate the agency to groups that either guard their domain of privilege or challenge the system of social inequalities and segmentation. Thus, understanding social exclusion as a condition/outcome as well as a dynamic process, the course will also examine some environmental justice movements. The course will also be contextually and temporally embedded. In the north, for example, along with African-Americans, Latino and indigenous people, the focus has been the changing nature of social exclusion in environment. Accordingly, the relevant focus groups are the new social groups, including the immigrants and ethnic groups. By contrast, in the Indian context, the problem is one of the persistent, multiple exclusion of certain social groups like Dalit affecting their basic environmental access and rights.

Learning Outcomes

The course is organized around weekly lectures and discussions based on the readings. Students will be asked to write an essay on one of the topics of the course, with footnotes and bibliography, and further readings will be given to them on their chosen topic, so that they can go in much more depth on a particular topic.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Unit 1: (Week 1): Social Exclusion and Environmental Justice: An Introduction to Conceptual Issues

Unit 2: (Week 2-3): Race, Caste, Class and Environment: Patterns and Processes

Class written assignment

Unit 3: (Week 4-6): Revisiting Village, Community, Water, Commons: Sites of Social Exclusion

Class written assignment

Unit 4: (Week 7-9): Social Exclusion and Environmental Change: Insights in the literature of Jotirao Phule, E. V. Ramasamy Periyar, B. R. Ambedkar, Dalit/anti-caste writers and Dalit autobiographies

Book Readings & Discussion

Unit 5: (Week 10-11): Environmental Justice Movements: A Global and Indian Outlook

Unit 6: (Week 12): Environmental Politics and Policy against Social Exclusion

Class written assignment

Essential Readings:

Unit 1: (Week 1): This unit will examine concepts around the social exclusion, inclusion and environmental justice.

David Harvey (1996), Justice, Nature & the Geography of Difference, USA: Blackwell.

Gerry Rodgers (1995), ‘What is special about a “social exclusion” approach?’ in Gerry Rodgers, Charles Gore, Jose B. Figueiredo (eds), Social Exclusion: Rhetoric, Reality, Responses, Geneva: International Institute for Labour Studies. pp. 43-55.

Angus Stewart (2000), ‘Social Inclusion: An Introduction’ in Peter Askonas and Angus Stewart (eds.), Social Inclusion: Possibilities and Tensions, London: Macmillan. pp. 1-16.

Ramachandra Guha (1994), ‘Introduction’ in Ramachandra Guha (ed.), Social Ecology, Delhi: Oxford University Press. pp. 1-18.

Joan Martinez-Alier (2004), ‘Environmental Justice in the United States and South Africa’ in Joan Martinez-Alier, The Environmentalism of the Poor: A Study of Ecological Conflicts and Valuation, New Delhi: Oxford University Press. pp. 168-194.  

Unit 2 (Week 2-3): This unit will study the inter-relationship between environment, race, caste and class, and its expressions in environmentalism.

Dorceta E. Taylor (2002), Race, Class, Gender, and American Environmentalism, Portland: Pacific Northwest Research Station, pp. 1-51.

Dianne D. Glove (2010), Rooted in the Earth: Reclaiming the African American Environmental Heritage, Chicago: Lawrence Hill Books.

Mukul Sharma (2017), ‘Brahmanical Activism as Eco-Casteism: Reading the Life Narratives of Bindeshwar Pathak, Sulabh International, and “Liberated” Dalits’, Biography: An Interdisciplinary Quarterly, Special Issue on Caste and Life Narratives, 40, 1, pp. 199-243.

Mukul Sharma (2012), ‘Dalits and Indian Environmental Politics’, Economic and Political Weekly (henceforth EPW), XLVII, 23, 9 June, pp. 46-52.

Ramachandra Guha & Juan Martinez – Alier (1997), ‘The Environmentalism of the Poor’ in Ramachandra Guha & Juan Martinez – Alier, Varieties of Environmentalism: Essays North and South. Oxford: Oxford University Press, pp. 3-21.

Unit 3 (Week 4-7): This unit will understand how village, community, land, water, forest, and commons are sites of social exclusion, based on poverty, inequality, caste and hierarchy.

Mukul Sharma (2017), Caste and Nature: Dalits and Indian Environmental Politics, New Delhi: Oxford University Press.

Noel Castree (2001), ‘Socializing Nature: Theory, Practice, and Politics’ in Noel Castree and Bruce Braun (eds.), Social Nature: Theory, Practice, and Politics, Oxford: Blackwell Publishers), pp.1-21.

Surinder S. Jodhka (2012), ‘Introduction’ in Surinder S. Jodhka (ed.), Village Society, Hyderabad: Orient Blackswan, pp. 1-20.

Esha Shah (2008), ‘Telling Otherwise: A Historical Anthropology of Tank Irrigation Technology in South India’, Technology and Culture 49, no. 3, pp. 652-74.

Suhas Paranjape, Raju Adagale, and Ravi Pomane (2008), ‘Mahad to Mangaon: Eighty Years of Caste Discrimination, What Caste Is Water? In K. J. Joy et al, Water Conflicts in India: A Million Revolts in the Making, New Delhi: Routledge, pp. 110-14.

N. S. Jodha (1986), ‘Common Property Resources and Rural Poor in Dry Regions of India’, Economic and Political Weekly 21, no. 27, pp.1167-81.  

Unit 4 (Week 8-9): This unit will focus on the environmental perspectives of Dalit thinkers and writers, raising the issues of social exclusion and social justice in environmental sphere.

G. P. Deshpande (2002), ‘Of Hope and Melancholy: Reading Jotirao Phule in Our Times’ in G. P. Deshpande (ed.), Selected Writings of Jotirao Phule, Delhi: LeftWord, pp. 1-21.

V. Geetha and S. V. Rajadurai (2008), ‘Samadharma’ in V. Geetha and S. V. Rajadurai, Towards a Non-Brahmin Millennium: From Iyothee Thass to Periyar, Kolkata: Samya, pp. 402-41.

Mukul Sharma (2017), ‘Ambedkar and Environmental Thought’ in Mukul Sharma, Caste and Nature, New Delhi: Oxford University Press, pp. 114-60.

Unit 5 (Week 10-11): This unit will examine the contours of environmental justice movements in south and north, challenging social exclusion.

Richard Peet and Michael Watts (1996), ‘Liberation Ecology: Development, Sustainability, and Environment in an age of Market Triumphalism’ in Richard Peet and Michael Watts (eds.), Liberation Ecologies: Environment, Development, Social Movements, Banerjee, London: Routledge, pp. 1-45.

Alf Gunvald Nilsen (2013), ‘The river and the rage: Introducing the Narmada Valley Conflict’ in Alf Gunvald Nilsen, Dispossession and Resistance in India: The River and the Rage, Delhi: Aakar Books, pp. 1-17.

Tania Murray Li (2008), ‘Situating Resource Struggles: Concepts for Empirical Analysis’ in Amita Baviskar (ed), Contested Grounds: Essays on Nature, Culture, and Power, New Delhi: Oxford University Press, pp. 193-216.

Subir Sinha (2003), ‘Development Counter-Narratives: Taking Social Movements Seriously’ in K. Sivaramakrishnan, Arun Agrawal (eds.), Regional Modernities: The Cultural Politics of Development in India, New Delhi: Oxford University Press, pp. 286-312.

Unit 6 (Week 12): This unit will map the ways social institutions, economic processes, environmental policies and politics can address the issues of social exclusion and social justice.

Wolfgang Sachs (1999), ‘Social Justice and Environmental Sustainability in the Post-Development Era’ in Mohamed Suliman (ed.), Ecology, Politics & Violent Conflict, London: Zed Books, pp. 59-75.

Eileen M. Mcgurty (2006), ‘Identity Politics and Multiracial Coalitions in the Environmental Justice Movement’ in Dianne D. Glave and Mark Stoll (eds), To Love the Wind and the Rain: African Americans and Environmental History, Pittsburgh: University of Pittsburg Press, pp. 133-149.

Mukul Sharma (2005), ‘Social Inclusion or Social Justice’ in Defining Dignity, New Delhi: World Dignity Forum, pp. 188-192.

Prakash Kashwan (2017), ‘Democracy in the Woods: Environmental Conservation in India, Tanzania, and Mexico,’ New Delhi: Oxford University Press.

Grading Rubric

Assessments: 1) There will be internal assessment exams held after every four weeks. This will be out of 50 marks. 2) Students will also be asked to submit a written essay of 2500 words with footnotes and bibliography, which will be out of 50 marks.

Attendance Policy

As per university policy.

title: CONSERVATION POLICY IN THE DEVELOPING WORLD
description:
Conservation Policy in the Developing World [ES-2002/ POL-2069] [ES-2002/ POL-2069-1]

Faculty Name
Ghazala Shahabuddin [ghazala.shahabuddin@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course delves into the policies relating to biodiversity conservation in developing countries with a reference to its ecological, historical and socio-political contexts.  Students will learn to integrate biodiversity concerns with sustainable development and social concerns. The course will begin with giving an understanding of the processes underlying the  loss of biodiversity and ecosystem degradation as well as its consequences for society. The historical and political dimensions of species loss will also be discussed. The essentials of conservation planning and design as currently practiced based on ecological principles, in the context of socio-political realities, will be studied. The course will then turn to critically exploring past and prevalent paradigms and strategies in biodiversity conservation such as strict nature protection, Integrated Conservation and Development (ICDP), community-based conservation, Payment for Ecosystem Services (PES) and ecotourism,  with the aid of key case studies. In addition, current debates on wildlife laws and policies in India will be discussed, based on current developments in Forest Conservation Act and Forest Rights Act. The aim of this course is to use perspectives from a variety of disciplines, including ecology, history, political science, economics and sociology, to develop a holistic view of today’s biodiversity crisis and its solutions.

 

Learning Outcomes

 

The students will learn to integrate knowledge from different disciplinary areas to understand biodiversity conservation in terms of policy and practice. They will learn about biodiversity conservaiton policies from both a historical and contemporary perspective.

 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Course Topics:

 

1    Causes of Biodiversity Loss

23    Economic Incentives for Conservation
24    Economic Incentives for Conservation

26    Case Study on Snow Leopard(Book Discussion)

Shahabuddin, G. 2019. Rewilding with the Asiatic Cheetah: Policy and Politics of Wildlife Reintroduction in India. In Shahabuddin, G. and K. Sivaramakrishnan (Eds.). Nature Conservation in the New Economy: People, Wildlife and the Law in India. Orient Blackswan, Delhi.

Grading Rubric

The successful completion of this course will depend on intensive reading, presentations in class and participation in discussions. title: STUDY DESIGN AND STATISTICAL MODELS: AN ESSENTIAL TOOLBOX FOR A RESEARCHER
description:
Study Design and Statistical Models: An Essential Toolbox for a Researcher [ES-3305/ BIO-3305/ BIO-6305] [ES-3305/ BIO-3305/ BIO-6305-1]

Faculty Name
Manvi Sharma [manvi.sharma@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Research problems often present themselves in the form of broken pieces of information. A modern biologist can use multiple tools to make sense of data and uncover signals that help describe how the world works. This course is aimed at providing a toolkit to help research students design field and laboratory studies and link data to models (a description of how the world works). The discussion topics include replication and pseudoreplication, randomisation, sample size and degrees of freedom, orthogonal design, and non-orthogonal observational data. The topics on statistical modelling include parameter estimation, model prediction, overfitting, collinearity, missing data, approaches to choosing models, and model simplification. This course will be taught through lectures and worksheets using the R programming language. The example datasets used in the worksheets will be from ecological, biomedical, and social sciences.

Statistical modelling is as much art as it is a craft. Students will be encouraged to think about creative ways to model seemingly disparate datasets. For example, modelling the occupancy of snow leopards in the Himalayan landscapes might be very similar to modelling the occupancy patterns of tuberculosis in Delhi.

Course cap: 25

Learning Outcomes

Appreciate that similar statistical tools can be used creatively to solve different problems

Ability to design an effective research study in the laboratory or field

Learning to visualise and manage data

Understanding principles of inference, avoiding overinterpretation of data

Understanding principles of good design, avoiding pseudoreplication, perils of p-hacking, and phantom degrees of freedom

Ability to run statistical techniques and tests

Grading Rubric

Assignments 25%

Paper presentation 25%

Final project 50%

Attendance Policy

The minimum attendance required to pass the course is 80%

title: ANTHROPOLOGY OF DISASTER AND VULNERABILITY
description:
Anthropology of Disaster and Vulnerability [SOA-2222/ ES-2439] [SOA-2222/ ES-2439-1]

Faculty Name
Mitul Baruah [mitul.baruah@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Neil Smith famously said – “there’s no such thing as a natural disaster.” He was echoing a generation of environmental geographers and anthropologists. Over the past few decades, critical scholarship on disaster and vulnerability has grown significantly, drawing on, among others, frameworks of political economy and political ecology. At the same time, hazards and disasters have also become increasingly frequent and destructive across the planet. From mega events such as tsunamis, hurricanes, earthquakes, nuclear accidents and oil spills to slow-onset disasters like air pollution, desertification, epidemics, soil erosion and sea level rise, disaster has come to define the times that we live in. Climate change has made matters worse. The impact of a disaster is uneven, however; some people are much more vulnerable than others.

This course is aimed at providing students critical perspectives on disaster and vulnerability. We will begin with an overview of concepts such as risk, hazards, disaster, vulnerability, and resilience. Drawing on case studies from around the world, the course will then expose students to a variety of political and cultural questions concerning disaster and vulnerability. The students will learn about, among others, the role of the state and capital in the production of disaster and hazardscape; how vulnerability is a social calculus; ideas of climate coloniality and climate justice; how various societies in different historical moments have responded to calamity, offering insight into the complex relationships between societies and their natural environments; and how disaster management efforts can promote widespread resilience or increase the vulnerability of some populations, thereby further deepening societal inequities.

fullName: HIS-3524, LANDSCAPES, SPORTS, AND MODERNITY: A GLOBAL HISTORY OF MOUNTAINS AND MOUNTAINEERING, GAURAV GARG
title: LANDSCAPES, SPORTS, AND MODERNITY: A GLOBAL HISTORY OF MOUNTAINS AND MOUNTAINEERING,
description:
Landscapes, Sports, and Modernity: A Global History of Mountains and Mountaineering [HIS-3524/ ES-3224/ SOA-3105] [HIS-3524/ ES-3224/ SOA-3105-1]

Faculty Name
Gaurav Churiwala Garg [gaurav.garg@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Most people today find mountains to be beautiful, majestic, and, serene. In contemporary imaginations, mountains are essential for the planet’s survival and indeed our own physical and mental health. But this was not always the case. In pre-modern Europe, for example, mountains were either ignored or depicted in literature as ugly deformities that scarred the Earth’s surface. Why did Europeans think of mountains as ugly? How, when, and why did their aesthetic imaginations change to a point where someone like the celebrated polymath John Ruskin could write that “mountains are the beginning and the end of all scenery”? How did European perceptions of mountains differ from that of the peoples and traditions of South Asia and elsewhere? And what role has South Asian history played in shaping modern human relationships with the mountains?

This course will take students on a journey from early Asia and pre- modern Europe, to the eighteenth-century when the Alps emerged as objects of adventure, veneration, and scientific experimentation, which in turn, kickstarted two new modern practices— mountain tourism and the world’s most literary sport, mountaineering. This course will then explore how these practices were deeply imbricated with colonialism, nationalism, fascism, and masculinity in the nineteenth and the twentieth centuries. The course will end in the late twentieth century where it will focus on commercialization of mountaineering and on issues pertaining to non-European modernity. In other words, this course will take students on a journey from a stage in human history where mountains were at best the abode of gods and spirits, and, at worst, ugly deformities, to a stage where there are now “traffic jams” on Mount Everest.

Focused on the Alps and the Himalaya, this interdisciplinary course will offer a new and exciting vantage point for learning about several fundamental issues and concepts in history and the humanities. Students will learn how scholars in the humanities have rehabilitated mountains as a key terrain where modernity is performed, its limits are exposed, and occasionally transcended. They will also learn about the extent to which our knowledge of the world is framed from the perspective of those who live in the “lowlands.” Overall, this course will motivate students to think of the history of human interactions with mountains as vital for making sense of what it means to be modern, and, for understanding how we got there.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Tenative Course Syllabus

 

Module I: A Cultural History of Mountains

Week 1: Mountains in Pre-Modern European Imagination and World History

Marjorie Hope Nicholson Mountain Gloom and Mountain Glory: The Development of the Aesthetics of the Infinite, pp. 34-71.

Week 3: Scared Mountain in Early to Middle China

Week 4: Environment and Aesthetics in Modern Europe

Week 5: Three interpretations of Change in European Attitudes towards the Mountains

Week 6: Mountains and Science

Week 7: European Mountaineering in the 19th Century

[The reading will be divided among students. Each student will read about 1-2 chapter. They will teach the assigned chapter in class].

Week 9: Mountains in 19th century Asian Imagination

Week 10: Mountains and the British Raj

Week 9: Mountaineering and Fascism

Week 10: Cinema and Mountains in the interwar years

Week 11: Gender and Mountaineering

Week 14: Mountains and Modernity
