fullName: CHI-3003, CONFUCIANISM, FAMILY LINEAGE, AND LOCAL SOCIETY, DANIEL MURRAY
title: CONFUCIANISM, AND LOCAL SOCIETY,
description:
Confucianism, Family Lineage, and Local Society [CHI-3003/ SOA-3100/ HIS-3814] [CHI-3003/ SOA-3100/ HIS-3814-1]

Faculty Name
Daniel Murray [daniel.murray@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Course Overview

This course approaches Confucianism as a lived tradition in Chinese local society with an emphasis on the role of family lineages. Family lineages developed to be one of the pivotal institutions in organizing local society in late imperial China. These institutions were an important factor in state-society relations, property ownership, infrastructure projects, personal relations, and ritual practice. This course overviews major studies of the historical development of family lineages, its geographic diversity, and their continued existence today as well as their relation to issues of gender, ethnicity, religion, and kinship.

The first section gives a general overview of Confucian thought with an emphasis on its understanding of kinship and ritual. Section two moves onto historical anthropological studies of the development of family lineages, their related institutional structures (lineage halls) and rituals (ancestor veneration), and their connection to broader social, political, and economic life. Finally, we end the course with ethnographic studies of family lineages in the modern world to consider the impact of the nation-state, urbanization, changes in family dynamics, and transnational communication have had on the lineage.

Section 1: Kinship and Ritual in Confucian Thought and Imperial Power
This section of the course focuses on Confucian theories of kinship and ritual followed by an overview of the role of these ideas in the structuring of the state and society. The purpose of these theories was different than modern academic works as the aim was to influence how people acted rather than explain what they already were doing. However, they also present an indigenous understanding of these concepts and how the literati elite used them to analyze social issues.

Section 2: Historical Anthropology, Family Lineage, and Local Society
Historical anthropology emerged in China in response to largely ahistorical orientalist ethnographies of Chinese societies that saw the lineage structure as a monolith and largely drew on existing theories of lineage from European colonies in Africa as well as nationalist histories that presented a unified Chinese culture. In contrast to such studies, historical anthropologists combine fieldwork and local historical documents to analyze the diverse ways that family lineage developed throughout China. Historical anthropology emerged in China in response to largely ahistorical orientalist ethnographies of Chinese societies that saw the lineage structure as a monolith and largely drew on existing theories of lineage from European colonies in Africa as well as nationalist histories that presented a unified Chinese culture. In contrast to such studies, historical anthropologists combine fieldwork and local historical documents to analyze the diverse ways that family lineage developed throughout China.

Section 3: Ethnography, Lineage, and Modernity
The twentieth century saw the end of dynastic China and with it the bureaucracy staffed by scholar-officials trained in the Confucian tradition. Despite the numerous attacks on traditional culture and the land reform movement that stripped lineages of their land holdings in this period, many lineages throughout China continue to this day. This section focuses on ethnographic studies of how the family lineage has responded to many of the changing social, political, and geographic issues in this period.

title: AN INTERPRETIVE HISTORY OF MAO ZEDONG AND THE CHINESE COMMUNIST REVOLUTION
description:
An Interpretive History of Mao Zedong and the Chinese Communist Revolution [CHI-4001/ HIS-4802/ POL-3090/ IR-3027] [CHI-4001/ HIS-4802/ POL-3090/ IR-3027-1]

Faculty Name
Sayantani Mukherjee [sayantani.mukherjee@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course introduces the historical relationship between Mao Zedong’s philosophy of history and revolution, and the global context of Chinese Revolution in the twentieth century. We will examine Mao’s theories and practice of revolution through a thematic lens: not as biographical artifacts but as thought produced by and constitutive of the revolutionary circumstances in the twentieth-century world at large and China in particular.  Our aim will be to investigate how three modal terms—Chinese, Revolutionary, Marxist—reflect on each other as open questions when Mao Zedong is studied in contextually-embedded and philosophically complex manner.

Situating the world in an intimate dialogic relationship to China, we will ask the questions; was Mao a Marxist? How was Mao’s Marxism inflected by his positionality of being Chinese in a revolutionary twentieth-century world? How was Mao’s Chineseness influenced by his being a revolutionary in the twentieth-century world? How was Marxism impacted by Mao’s articulation of revolution in the twentieth-century world? The readings for this class will mostly be drawn from Mao’s own writings, and students will be expected to read these texts intensively, with an open mind. While this course does not require any previous knowledge of China, as an advanced level class, a familiarity with general twentieth-century world history and/or a background in the history of Marxism will be helpful. Students with prior background in neither will be expected to learn on a very steep curve.

Learning Outcomes

Read intertextually and understand literary productions as artefacts of historical and social construction.

Summarize academic monographs in East Asian studies and introduce salient points in notes and in speech.

Be able to draw connections between works to gain an overview of scholarly and historiographical debates.

Be able to trace theoretical or methodological trends across multiple empirical contexts.

Learn the skills of co-writing and co-presenting to gain a sense of how cooperative work can integrate intellectual property as well as collective clarity.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

You are not required to purchase any materials for this course. All readings will be provided in PDF via email.

Grading Rubric

Requirements and Expectations:        

Assessment & Assignments:

30% - Regular participation in class discussions

70% - Writing Portfolio (summarized below):

10% - Progress meetings (minimum 2)

40% - Report

20% - Op-ed

Attendance, Participation and Discussion Étiquette:

One third of your grade in this class depends on learning how to read written productions “against the grain”. That is to say, scrutinizing the beliefs and attitudes that typically go unexamined in a text, drawing attention to the gaps, silences, contradictions, and unspoken impetus that animate written words, but also reading that text through the various registers of its production and circulation—as an artefact of literary, historical and social conditions that may or may not alter its imagined “original” context. We are reading Mao, but we will never take him for his word.

I will not take attendance in each class meeting, however, participation in weekly class discussions is a mandatory part of your grade and is necessary for succeeding in the course. If you have circumstances that might affect attendance at a specific class meeting, please let me know ahead of time whenever possible. Flexibility is especially important since Covid is still with us. To protect your privacy, please do not describe any medical situations to me; just inform me that the situation exists and be prepared to provide a doctor’s note if requested.

Participation is part of your grade, and should be based on attentive reading, listening, and preparation. Always keep an open mind and be respectful of your classmates and your instructor regardless of what you wish to say, or whether you agree with what has already been said. Being respectful also means that (1) if you have not completed a particular reading, please refrain from commenting on it (2) in the normal course of discussion, if you have just spoken, you should refrain from speaking again until others who wish to contribute have done so (3) contributions to discussion should be based on the readings, lectures, and discussion questions, and should aim to improve our collective understanding of them. In general, please avoid unstructured/unsupported reflections as well as topics that are beyond the scope of the course.

Writing Portfolio

Two-thirds of your final grade for this class will depend on two written pieces that will be thematically related and proceed from each other. The purpose of these pieces is to help you further navigate the landscape of political writing, by interrogating how the processes of (narrative) writing engage with the conveying of “information” in the quest for coherence, conviction, and accessibility.

The first of these pieces will be a Report on an Investigation of the  < > Movement, approx. 5000-6000 words, modeled on Mao’s famous Report on the Hunan Peasant Movement. For this first piece, you may choose between reporting on the working conditions of a) campus workers at Ashoka or b) teaching fellows at Ashoka.

The second text is an opinion piece (no longer than 1,000 words) that condenses your longer report into a piece that should function as a call to action. Unlike the first piece, where your stated purpose is an “investigation”, your purpose in this second piece is to craft an appeal.

Please note that you have the option of writing both the Report and the op-ed as a team project, but that the requirements will change accordingly.

For both pieces, you may choose to conduct interviews in person, speak to campus “experts”, read theoretical texts or works providing historical background. The methodology is entirely up to you, but you are encouraged discuss your thinking and writing process with me through a series of progress meetings. These meetings will count for ten percent of your final grade.

title: DEMOCRACY AND ITS DISCONTENTS
description:
Democracy and its Discontents [POL-3092/ HIS-3811] [POL-3092/ HIS-3811-1]

Faculty Name
Sunil Khilnani [sunil.khilnani@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Course Description:

DEMOCRACY AND  ITS DISCONTENTS

HIS-3811-1 / POL 3092-1
This course examines the conceptual and practical tensions between democracy as a universal norm of political legitimacy and the difficulties of achievement it faces both within established democracies as well as in relatively newer democracies such as India. It takes issues such as inequality, claims to absolute certainty (associated with religion and science), and problems of political representation, and examines theoretical attempts to resolve some of these problems against the historical and cultural realities to be found in Western and Indian democracy. Students will read texts from Plato to the present-day, and consider examples from 18th century France and America, to 21st century India, in order better to understand the theoretical blindspots and the practical potentials of democratic politics in diverse national contexts today
Democracy has established itself as the universal norm of political legitimacy, invoked alike to justify the domestic claims of states as well as their international adventures. Yet even at the height of its apparent historical triumph, it faces serious difficulties, both within the established democracies as well as outside them –engendering disaffection, disappointment, and sometimes outright rejection. This course does not conceive of democracy as a model, nor seek to identify specific norms and values. It is concerned with democratic argument and experience, across different contexts and cultures: with the varieties of political language that have come to be thought of as democratic or anti-democratic. It takes democracy as a problem in modern politics, not as the utopian answer to its riddles. It will draw on a range of thinkers and theoretical arguments, as well as on the varieties of democratic experiences across historical contexts, in order to question the nature of democracy, both as a form of society and as a type of government. Through such questioning, the course hopes to give students a better comprehension of democracy, of its fragilities and its limits, as well as its compelling political and imaginative potency. It is a course in political analysis and argument, which uses history and deploys historical examples to illuminate some of the urgent current predicaments of democracy.

Sunil Khilnani

fullName: HIS-3524, LANDSCAPES, SPORTS, AND MODERNITY: A GLOBAL HISTORY OF MOUNTAINS AND MOUNTAINEERING, GAURAV GARG
title: LANDSCAPES, SPORTS, AND MODERNITY: A GLOBAL HISTORY OF MOUNTAINS AND MOUNTAINEERING,
description:
Landscapes, Sports, and Modernity: A Global History of Mountains and Mountaineering [HIS-3524/ ES-3224/ SOA-3105] [HIS-3524/ ES-3224/ SOA-3105-1]

Faculty Name
Gaurav Churiwala Garg [gaurav.garg@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Most people today find mountains to be beautiful, majestic, and, serene. In contemporary imaginations, mountains are essential for the planet’s survival and indeed our own physical and mental health. But this was not always the case. In pre-modern Europe, for example, mountains were either ignored or depicted in literature as ugly deformities that scarred the Earth’s surface. Why did Europeans think of mountains as ugly? How, when, and why did their aesthetic imaginations change to a point where someone like the celebrated polymath John Ruskin could write that “mountains are the beginning and the end of all scenery”? How did European perceptions of mountains differ from that of the peoples and traditions of South Asia and elsewhere? And what role has South Asian history played in shaping modern human relationships with the mountains?

This course will take students on a journey from early Asia and pre- modern Europe, to the eighteenth-century when the Alps emerged as objects of adventure, veneration, and scientific experimentation, which in turn, kickstarted two new modern practices— mountain tourism and the world’s most literary sport, mountaineering. This course will then explore how these practices were deeply imbricated with colonialism, nationalism, fascism, and masculinity in the nineteenth and the twentieth centuries. The course will end in the late twentieth century where it will focus on commercialization of mountaineering and on issues pertaining to non-European modernity. In other words, this course will take students on a journey from a stage in human history where mountains were at best the abode of gods and spirits, and, at worst, ugly deformities, to a stage where there are now “traffic jams” on Mount Everest.

Focused on the Alps and the Himalaya, this interdisciplinary course will offer a new and exciting vantage point for learning about several fundamental issues and concepts in history and the humanities. Students will learn how scholars in the humanities have rehabilitated mountains as a key terrain where modernity is performed, its limits are exposed, and occasionally transcended. They will also learn about the extent to which our knowledge of the world is framed from the perspective of those who live in the “lowlands.” Overall, this course will motivate students to think of the history of human interactions with mountains as vital for making sense of what it means to be modern, and, for understanding how we got there.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Tenative Course Syllabus

 

Module I: A Cultural History of Mountains

Week 1: Mountains in Pre-Modern European Imagination and World History

Marjorie Hope Nicholson Mountain Gloom and Mountain Glory: The Development of the Aesthetics of the Infinite, pp. 34-71.

James Scott The Art of Not Being Governed: An Anarchist History of Upland South Asia (New Haven: Yale University Press, 2009), pp. 127-177.

Week 2: Mountains in Pre-modern India

Kalidasa, Meghaduta excerpts

Kalidasa, Kumarasambhava, excerpts

Week 3: Scared Mountain in Early to Middle China

Wen-shing Chou Mount Wutai Vision of a Sacred Buddhist Mountain, excerpts

Week 4: Environment and Aesthetics in Modern Europe

Marjorie Hope Nicholson Mountain Gloom and Mountain Glory: The Development of The Aesthetics of the Infinite pp. 324-369.

Allen Carlson Nature and Landscape: An Introduction to Environmental Aesthetics, chapter 1, pp. 1-37.

Jon Mathieu, “The Sacralization of Mountains in Europe during the Modern Age” Mountain Research and Development, 26 (4), pp. 343-349

Week 5: Three interpretations of Change in European Attitudes towards the Mountains

Marjorie Hope Nicholson Mountain Gloom and Mountain Glory: The Development of The Aesthetics of the Infinite pp. 271-323.

Peter Hansen The Summits of the Modern Man: Mountaineering After Enlightenment pp. 30-60.

B. Sprague Allen Tides in the Taste of the English, tbd.

Week 6: Mountains and Science

Charlotte Bigg, David Aubin and Phllip Felsch “Introduction: the laboratory of nature science in the mountains” Science in Context, 22 (2009), pp. 311-321.

K. Maria D. Lane Geographies of Mars (Chicago, University of Chicago Press), pp. 65-96.

Week 7: European Mountaineering in the 19th Century

Peter Hansen, Summits of the Modern Man: Mountaineering After the Enlightenment, excerpts.

[The reading will be divided among students. Each student will read about 1-2 chapter. They will teach the assigned chapter in class].

Week 9: Mountains in 19th century Asian Imagination

Karen Wigan, “Discovering the Japanese Alps”: Meiji Mountaineering and the Quest for Historical Enlightenment, Journal of Japanese Studies Vol 31, no. 1, Winter 2005, pp. 1-26.

Sandeep Banerjee and Shubho Basu “Secularizing the Sacred, Imagining the Nation-Space: The Himlaya in Bengali travelogues, 1856-1901," Modern Asian Studies, Vol 49, Issue 3, 2015, pp 609-649.

Zahid R. Chaudhury Afterimage of Empire: Photography in Nineteenth Century India, ch. 3

Week 10: Mountains and the British Raj

Thomas Simpson The Frontier in British India, excerpts

Mathew Edney Mapping an Empire, excerpts

Dane Kennedy Hill Stations of the British Raj, excerpts

Week 9: Mountaineering and Fascism

Tait Keller Apostles of the Alps: Mountaineering and Nation Building in Austria and Germany, excerpts.

[The reading will be divided among students. Each student will read about 1-2 chapter. They will teach the assigned chapter in class].

Week 10: Cinema and Mountains in the interwar years

[The reading will be divided among students. Each student will read about 1-2 chapter. They will teach the assigned chapter in class].

Grading Rubric

Grading:

Reflection Paper— 30 per cent of total grades: Students (including those auditing) are to write 1-page long reflection on the assigned reading and class discussion in the last 15 mins of the class.

Please note: you will not ordinarily receive feedback on your reflection unless there are some glaring issues that you need to fix. You will be penalized for submitting less than 10 reflection papers. Eg. If overall, you submit 9 papers you will lose 2 points.

Tip: These are low stakes easy assignments. Be sure to max this.

Class Presentations— 20 percent: Students will have to present readings in class twice over the entire course. Details to be decided.

Essay(s)– 50 per cent of grades:

You have two options here.

Write two 1500 -words long essay (approx.) focusing and elaborating on any two theme/group of readings in each of the two modules.

Write one term-end 3000-3500 - word long essay (approx.) focusing and elaborating on one theme/group of readings. You are expected to use primary sources if you pick this option.

Attendance Policy

not compulsory, tbd. 

 

Inform your TA in advance via email if you cannot make it to class and state the reason. Unless there is a compelling reason for your absence (eg illness backed by proof) you cannot submit a reflection paper for a class that you did not attend.

title: ARCHAEOLOGY OF COMPLEX SOCIETIES AND ANCIENT STATES
description:
Archaeology of Complex Societies and Ancient States [HIS-3528] [HIS-3528-1]

Faculty Name
Kalyan Sekhar Chakraborty [kalyan.chakraborty@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This seminar course examines the concept of complexity from an archaeological perspective. It surveys various famous as well as not-so-popular cultural traditions and ancient states from across the world, focusing on issues associated with the emergence and development of social, economic and political complexities. We will look into issues like the emergence of sedentism, early villages, the evolution of urban, literate societies, city states, centralized polities and civilizations. We will evaluate the interaction between human and its natural and cultural environment to understand the emergence and functioning of complex societies and ancient states across the globe. For example, how human-environmental interactions as well as the regional socio-political setups helped in production, distribution and consumption of resources? Human-landscape interaction and how changing socio-politics influenced such interaction? To what extent major climatic events influenced culture change and the expression of social complexities? Students should complete the subject with a critical understanding of historical and contemporary theoretical issues in archaeological research and interpretation concerned with the complexities to develop an understanding of various methodologies utilized towards these interpretative ends.

Learning Outcomes

Students will develop a critical understanding of historical and contemporary theoretical issues in archaeological research and interpretation concerned with the complexity

Develop a global perspective on archeological research and practices

Have knowledge of various methodologies utilized towards the interpretation of complexities in archaeological records 

Critically evaluate scientific and theoretical publications

Students will be able to conduct independent/group research projects.

Prepare and deliver oral presentations

Produce publication-quality reports of their own research projects.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

This course will be divided into three segments. A detailed list of topics under each segment will be provided later.

Segment 1: Understanding what is complexity and how complexity is perceived within the archaeological community

Segment 2: An archaeological review of complex societies and ancient states around the globe

Segment 3: Special topics as developed by the students in consultation with the instructor

Reading list Tentetive

Ross, J.C., & Steadman, S.R. (2017). Ancient Complex Societies (1st ed.). Routledge. https://doi.org/10.4324/9781315305639

Yoffee, N. (2005). Myths of the Archaic State: Evolution of the Earliest Cities, States, and Civilizations. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. doi:10.1017/CBO9780511489662

Adams, R. M. (2001). Complexity in archaic states. Journal of Anthropological Archaeology, 20(3), 345-360.

Feinman, G. M. (2011). Size, complexity, and organizational variation: A comparative approach. Cross-Cultural Research, 45(1), 37-58.

Barton, C. M. (2014). Complexity, social complexity, and modelling. Journal of Archaeological Method and Theory, 21(2), 306-324.

Yerkes, R. W. (2002). Hopewell Tribes: A Study of Middle Woodland Social Organization in the Ohio Valley. In W. A. Parkinson (Ed.), The Archaeology of Tribal Societies (1st ed., pp. 227–245). Berghahn Books. https://doi.org/10.2307/j.ctv8bt29z.16

(eds) Feast, Famine or Fighting?. Studies in Human Ecology and Adaptation, vol 8. Springer, Cham. https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-319-48402-0_5

Grading Rubric

Reading responses: 20% - You will be submitting 1-2 page critical review of each week’s reading. This should be submitted via classroom by 2 pm on the day before class times. You are only exempt from this on the day of your presentation. These documents will be shared with the class and the discussion in the class will be oriented around your comments.

Lead class discussion: 20% - You will be leading 1 weekly classroom discussion based on both primary and secondary readings. You will be submitting a set of questions/discussion points prior to the class that will be shared with the other students to help them participate in the debate/discussion.

In-class presentation / Lecture: 20% - You will be preparing a conference-style presentation using slide presentation on a topic of your choice in consultation with me. This topic should fall within the realm of archaeology and complex societies. In-leu with your presentation you will also assign readings for the class and formulate discussion around the topic of your presentation.

Final paper 30% - You will be writing a 10-12 page paper on a topic of your choice in consultation with me. This paper could be an extension of your presentation topic. This paper is due during the exam week.

Attendance and participation 10% - A 70% attendance is mandatory for this course; failure to do this will result in an automatic fail. You will also be evaluated based on your participation and discussion. I expect you to offer your opinions/critiques/comments/questions without my prompting. Failure to do so will affect your final grade.

Audit only: Audit-only students will cover 50% of the class load. They will have to maintain attendance and participation, submit reading responses and give an in-class presentation/lecture. A case-by-case basis arrangement can be made if necessary.

Attendance Policy

A 70% attendance is mandatory for this course; failure to do this will result in an automatic fail. You will also be evaluated based on your participation and discussion. I expect you to offer your opinions/critiques/comments/questions without my prompting. Failure to do so will affect your final grade.

title: ARCHAEOLOGY OF ANCIENT TECHNOLOGIES
description:
Archaeology of Ancient Technologies [HIS-3529] [HIS-3529-1]

Faculty Name
Kalyan Sekhar Chakraborty [kalyan.chakraborty@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

In this course, we will study the development and critical aspects of pre-industrial technologies through a wide range of theoretical and practical approaches such as readings and discussion of major theoretical topics, watching and reading ethnographic accounts and if possible hands-on experimentation and analysis.

In this course, we will discuss technologies from the current understanding of how material culture was produced and used over the long history of human evolution. We will be focusing on archaeological and anthropological methods for studying ancient technology, and the basic production, organization, and consumption of a variety of crafts in the past, including stone, bone, clay and metal.

This course has two major aims, 1) by looking into the physical and chemical properties of different materials to understand the selection of raw materials, technological choices, use alteration and post-depositional diagenesis, and 2) to examine environmental, social, cultural, economic and functional factors that may have driven technological innovation, adoption, persistence and changes.

Learning Outcomes

Students will be able to apply key themes and theories to study ancient technologies, especially technological variation

Students will be able to understand how physical, cognitive, environmental, as well as socio-political factors, have shaped technological innovation, adoption and changes.

If facilities can be arranged, students will be able to achieve hands-on experience in technological production as well as the physical and chemical techniques used for the analysis of ancient technology and production processes and use.

Critically evaluate scientific and theoretical publications

If facilities can be arranged, students will be able to conduct independent/group research projects.

Use scientific procedures to solve experimental problems

Prepare and deliver oral presentations

Produce publication-quality reports of their own research projects.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Segment 1: Introduction

Segment 2: Technological discussion, analysis and methodological interpretation

Segment 3: Theoretical understanding

title: THE MUGHALS AND THE OCEAN
description:
The Mughals and the Ocean [HIS-3216] [HIS-3216-1]

Faculty Name
Mahmood Kooriadathodi [mahmood.kooriadathodi@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The Mughal Empire is often understood as a land-based agrarian regime without much interest in the sea. “Glory was not won at sea; [it] was bound up with land, and horses racing over the plains,” wrote one historian a few decades ago in order to argue that the Mughal and Gujarat sultans were indifferent to the sea. This course revisits this age-old perspective and explores how these two mighty entities, the Mughals and the ocean, faced each other over 300 years.

For the Mughals, the ocean provided a diverse array of possibilities. From Africa to Arabia and the rest of Asia, the Indian Ocean brought them many unprecedented commodities, communities, animals, ideas and institutions, many of which affected and effected their future course. Utilizing vast horizons of such possibilities, they sought ways to quench their imperial thirst in a potential Age of Mughal Exploration. They knew well that they could not present themselves as conquerors or rulers of the world (with such titles as “jahangir”, “shahjahan” or “alamgir”) without confronting the ocean that covered two-thirds of the earth’s surface. The oceanic border was never an end to the imperial venture, rather it was an integral part of their expansionist and universalist ambitions and a beginning of a different Mughal realm. Their chronicles, memoirs, court records and imperial orders reflect this endeavour, although a majority of historians have neglected this so far.

The intellectual, ideological, and messianic take on the ocean was accompanied by many more pragmatic interests. With diverse economic, religious, cultural, political and even personal demands, the Mughals invested heavily in maritime trade and travel. Many royal ladies, nobles, courtiers, scribes, and scholars crossed the Arabian Sea and the Bay of Bengal in the sixteenth to eighteenth centuries. Akbar himself commissioned a large ship and his one courtier compared ships to horses and camels in the battlefields. His wife, and future ruler Jahangir’s mother, Mariam Zamani (aka Jodha Bai) owned the largest ship of their time. His aunt and wife, together with a large entourage, went across the Arabian Sea on a pilgrimage to Mecca. All these moves were furthered through the maritime involvement of many traditional landlubber groups like the Rajputs and Jats along with the seagoing communities such as Gujaratis, Bengalis, Marathas, Tamils, Dakhinis and Konkanis. During this period, they also combatted the rise and fall of certain European maritime empires, especially the Portuguese, the Dutch and finally the English.

An oceanic gaze at the Mughal Empire thus gives us a completely different perspective on Indian, Mughal, South Asian and Indian Ocean histories. This fresh look from the sea helps us understand the size and breadth of the Empire’s maritime ventures, especially in comparison with the contemporary regimes of the Safavids and Ottomans in the Red Sea and the Arabian Sea, Aceh, Ayutthaya, Banten and Mataram in the Bay of Bengal. The global historical perspective also helps us go beyond the frameworks of European companies and sources, which a few historians have explored in the last three decades.

Through such episodes in the Mughal and Oceanic histories, the course will mainly focus on such themes as ideas, infrastructures, humans, animals and objects. Within these areas, it would zoom onto a few Mughal women who were the biggest risk-takers in the Empire with their extraordinary ventures into maritime trade and travel. Their formidable roles in “bringing the ocean home” through their everyday roles as traders, travellers, shipowners, etc. are yet to be told collectively.

The seminar-cum-lecture course will train students to explore primary sources on their own, articulate their observations as scholarly arguments, and write academically from a global (historical) perspective. From the third week onward, the course will have four tracks: short lectures; writing short notes on primary sources; reading primary and secondary sources; and, discussion of readings and students’ writings.

Learning Outcomes

On the successful completion of this course, you will be able to

  • Understand the Mughal and Indian Ocean histories from comparative and connected perspectives.
  • Approach any major political entities, and human history at large, from an oceanic perspective instead of being locked conceptually by land.
  • Develop advanced skills in reading Mughal sources critically, especially for research and writing.
  • Acquire proficiency in academic writing with a focus on precision, comprehensiveness and commitment to primary and secondary sources.
  • Conceive, write and present a research paper from a global (historical) perspective.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

This course is a lecture-cum-seminar. The instructor would give short lectures at the beginning of each class, but readings and discussions are the central components of this course. It is designed for final-year undergraduates, ASP students, and PhD students. No prior knowledge of History is required.

I will bring to the class most of the (translated) primary sources originally written in diverse languages and we shall read them together. You do not have to read them in advance, except when I require otherwise. We will “deep-read” these sources each week (around 5 pages), but you are also required to read about 15 pages for each class and write a short note of 300 words each week (from the 3rd week onward).

Grading Rubric

The course is assessed and graded on the basis of four criteria:

  • Active participation in classroom discussions (20% of the overall mark).
  • Weekly notes (20%).
  • Engagement with your individual primary sources (20%)
  • Written essay of 4000 words, excluding footnotes and bibliography (40%).
Attendance Policy

Attendance is mandatory. One can take up to 4 notified or unnotified absences.

title: HISTORY AND MEMORY ACROSS ASIA
description:
History and Memory across Asia [HIS-3530] [HIS-3530-1]

Faculty Name
Nayanjot Kaur Lahiri [nayanjot.lahiri@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Course Description:  The course aims to analyze the many meanings that make history and  memory intelligible. What is history? How does memory work?  Is memorialization selective or inclusive? These are some of the questions that will be examined through an exploration of  some  iconic persona and phenomena. On the one hand, four famous personalities will be explored – Alexander the Great (in Europe and Persia), Emperor Ashoka (in South Asia and South East Asia), King Anahwrata (Myanmar) and Mahatma Gandhi (India) – in order to understand the elements that form the title of this course. On the other hand, the phenomena of war will be examined ranging from Massada in the Middle East to the American-Vietnam War in Southeast Asia in order to explore the contested terrain of history and memory. Apart from reading the works of historians, the course will involve analysing excerpts from literature and films.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Note: All reading material will be emailed to students.

 

I. Introducing History, Memory and Memorialization

John H. Arnold. 200. History – A Very Short Introduction, Chapter 7. Oxford: Oxford University Press.

David Lowenthal.  1998. Fabricating Heritage. History and Memory (Volume 10, No. 1)

Anand Patwardan’s film In Memory of Friends.

II. Alexander’s Life and Conquests in Asia, Alexander as a Persian King

Brooke Allen.  2005. Alexander the Great: Or the Terrible. The Hudson Review (Volume 58, No. 2).

A.K. Narain.  1965. Alexander and India. Greece & Rome (Volume 12, No. 2)

III. Ashoka’s life and times, Ashoka’s afterlife in India and Southeast Asia

Nayanjot Lahiri. 2015. Ashoka in Ancient India. Ranikhet: Permanent Black. Selected chapters.

Nayanjot Lahiri. 2022. Searching for Ashoka – Questing for a Buddhist King from India to Thailand. Ranikhet: Permanent Black.

King Anahwrata:  Historical King and Memorialized Unifier

Geok Yian Goh.  2014.The Wheel-Turner and His House – Kingship in a Buddhist Ecumene.Illinois: Northern Illinois University Press. Selected chapters.

V.  Mahatma Gandhi: His life and Ideas; Memorialization in his lifetime and beyond

Dennis Dalton. 1993 (2014 edition). Gandhi’s Power – Nonviolence in Action. New Delhi: Oxford University Press. Selected chapters.

Shahid Amin. 1988. ‘Gandhi as Mahatma: Gorakhpur District, Eastern U.P. 1921-22’  Selected Subaltern Studies, New Delhi: Oxford University Press, pp. 288-348.

Film: Raj Kumar Hirani’s Lage Raho Munna Bhai

VI: Fighting War : On the Battlefield and in Memory 

Yael Zerubavel. 1994. ‘The Death of Memory and the Memory of Death: Masada and the Holocaust as Historical Metaphors’. Representations (No. 45, Winter).

Film: Vietnam war: A Hollywood movie on the Vietnam war will be compared with a movie made by Vietnamese film makers

Grading Rubric

Grade Breakup

Short Writing Assignment 20%

Final Essay 30%

title: THE OTTOMAN EMPIRE 13TH -17TH CENTURIES
description:
The Ottoman Empire 13th -17th centuries [HIS-3531] [HIS-3531-1]

Faculty Name
Seema Alavi [seema.alavi@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The objective of the course is to acquaint the students with a non-European imperial formation, from the 13th to the 18thcenturies. It will teach students the major historiographical interventions in Ottoman history, and how they have changed our understanding of the empire. With a focus on the Ottomans, the course will help students appreciate the complex network of alliances, and forms of communication that sustained and reproduced empires in the late medieval and early modern period. The course has a comparative edge, and will push the students to compare the Ottoman empire with the other contemporaneous empires, in particular the Safavids and the Mughals.

 

Course Content:

Unit 1: (Week 1-2): Asia Minor Before the Ottomans: An Overview

Unit 2: (week 3-4): The Early Ottomans: The idea of frontier and gazi.

Unit 3: (week 5-6): Disintegration and Reintegration: Fall of Constantinople /Conquest of Istanbul (1453).

Unit 4 (week 7-8): Centralisation and its discontents: key institutions

Unit 5 (week 9-10): Harem and Imperial Sovereignty

Unit 6 (week 11-12): Interpretations of Ottoman Economy

Unit 7 (week 13): Concluding Remarks on early modern Empires and global history

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Suggested Readings

Unit 1 (week 1-2); The objective of this unit is to acquaint the students with the political culture in the region before the emergence of the Ottoman empire

Albert Hourani, The Emergence of the Modern Middle East (London: Macmillan, 1981)

Unit 2 (week 3-4): This unit covers the early history of the Ottoman empire, focusing on the conquests and the ideologies of warfare

fullName: HIS-3215, WAR, SOCIETY AND POLITICS 1700-1830, SEEMA ALAVI
title: WAR, SOCIETY AND POLITICS 1700-1830,
description:
War, Society and Politics 1700-1830 [HIS-3215] [HIS-3215-1]

Faculty Name
Seema Alavi [seema.alavi@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Content:

The course considers the early modern ‘military revolution’ in world history, and India as the major testing ground of that revolution between 1700 and 1850.  It discusses the social and political meanings of war and engages with the “new military history” – military history that is concerned with more than tactics, strategy, armaments, logistics and supply, but rather that seeks to both situate those features of war-craft in a social, cultural, and political context and, in the process, say something new about that context. Discussions on violence, criminality and its linkages with economy, state building and identity formations will be a key component of this course.  The 4 themes for this course are as follows:

1.Mughal military culture:

War, society and economy

Warfare and military manuals -the making of a gentleman

2. The Mughal military legacy:

War, society and the portfolio warrior of the 18th century

3. War, economy and the emergence of regional states:

Awadh, Rohilkhand and Mysore

4. The European and the English Company entanglements:

The new style warfare and the re-oriented north Indian military culture:

 Gentleman warriors to peasant  Sepoys.

5. The 1830s age of reforms:

Peasant Sepoys to disgruntled rebels.

title: MODERN INDIA: HISTORY AND POLITICAL THEORY
description:
Modern India: History and Political Theory [HIS-3805/ POL-3094] [HIS-3805/ POL-3094-1]

Faculty Name
Sunil Khilnani [sunil.khilnani@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Modern India: History and Political Theory

HIS 3805/POL 2052

The future of Western political theory will be decided outside the West. And in deciding that future, the  experience of India will loom large. This course explores the preceding proposition, examining ideas of  political theory in relation to modern India’s history. How have concepts of democracy, nation, rights,  citizenship, and global order shaped India, and how has the Indian experience in turn altered them? The  aim of the course is to provide an introduction to modern India’s political thinking while at the same  time challenging our understanding of core political ideas. 

Modern India is constituted through some of the most intricate and intense debates in recent political  history - arguments about identity and difference, representation and dignity, individuality and  communitarianism, justice and inequality, freedom and power. We will consider these debates, and also  the practices and institutions (sometimes innovative, often flawed) to which they have given rise. The  course offers a historically grounded approach to the study of Indian political thinking, while also  examining normative political ideals in comparative context, in order to clarify these ideals.

Thu/Fri: 18.30-20.00

Cap: 50

Email: sunil.khilnani@ashoka.edu.in

title: TEN EUREKAS! A HISTORY OF SCIENCE THROUGH TEN DISCOVERIES
description:
Ten Eurekas! A History of Science through Ten Discoveries [HIS-3532/ BIO-3532] [HIS-3532/ BIO-3532-1]

Faculty Name
Projit Bihari Mukharji [projit.mukharji@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

What is the relationship between science and society? How do social contexts, institutions, and histories shape science? In turn, how does science transform societies and individuals? These are the main questions we will explore in this course.

Though the course is organized around a series of roughly chronological discoveries, rather than presenting any single narrative of scientific progress they will be treated as iconic case studies. Instead of simply seeing these discoveries as constituting a decontextualized global series, we will place each discovery back in their respective thick historical contexts with a view to teasing out what spurred them, how they were imagined by those involved and how they transformed the societies in which they happened.

We will take a rather broad view of a “discovery” covering a range of entities from natural forces, facts, and processes like gravity, vacuum, and evolution, as well as the fabrication of procedures, concepts, and objects such as Pasteurization, the Periodic Table and Insulin. Starting with Sir Isaac Newton in the 17th century we will travel up to the middle of the 20th century. Along the way we will meet such scientific luminaries as Sir Robert Boyle, Charles Darwin, James Joule, Louis Pasteur, Dmitri Mendeleev, Theodosius Dobzhansky, James Watson, Francis Crick and others.

Alongside roughly two articles on each case, we will also read brief extracts from original scientific works each week. The textbooks will be entirely optional and I do not expect any student to be disadvantaged by not reading the textbooks. Neither will students be disadvantaged if they lack any background in science.

fullName: HIS-3214, TRADERS, MERCHANTS, AND CAPITALISTS: BUSINESS HISTORY OF INDIA 1600-PRESENT, GAURAV GARG
title: TRADERS, MERCHANTS, AND CAPITALISTS: BUSINESS HISTORY OF INDIA 1600-PRESENT,
description:
Traders, Merchants, and Capitalists: Business History of India 1600-Present [HIS-3214/ ENT-3015] [HIS-3214/ ENT-3015-1]

Faculty Name
Gaurav Churiwala Garg [gaurav.garg@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Course Overview

When India became independent, it was one of the few countries of the global South with a robust business class and a sizeable private sector. Did this class emerge because of colonialism or despite it? What has been role of businesses in India’s capitalist development and politics? Why are Indian businesspeople from certain communities that hail from the arid parts of South Asia? And what has been the relationship between entrepreneurship, caste, class, community, and gender in India? With these questions in mind, this course will introduce students to the main themes and issues in Indian business history from 1600 to the present. This course will equip students with a firm understanding of the long- term patterns of changes and continuity in Indian business landscape; enable them to make better sense of what is new and what is not about Indian private sector today; and help them critically analyze the discourse on and by businesses in modern India.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Course Structure and Reading:

The course is organized chronologically into 4 modules— 1600-1800; 1800-1914; 1914-1947; 1947 to Present. Each session will incorporate seminar style discussion and lectures.

Basic Texts:

Dwijendra Tripathi and Jyoti Jumanji The Concise Oxford History of Indian Business (OUP 2006).

Medha Kudaisya (ed). The Oxford India Anthology of Business History (OUP 2011).

Tirthankar Roy A Business History of India: Enterprise and the Emergence of Capitalism from 1600 (CUP 2018).

Selected Topical Readings (excerpts will be specified).

1800-1914

Grading Rubric

Grading:

In class assessment 50 per cent: There will be a small in-class assessment at the end of every module. Of the four assessments the best two will be graded. This will carry 50 per cent of the grade.

Term-end Paper 35 per cent: Students will write one term-end paper (approx 2000 words) in which they will have to reflect on one of the following questions in the course:

What has been the relationship between businesses and colonialism in India?

What has been role of businesses in India’s capitalist development and politics?

Why are Indian businesspeople from certain communities that hail the arid parts of South Asia? How have these business communities changed over time?

What has been the relationship between entrepreneurship, caste, class, community, and gender in India?

Annotated Bibliography 15 percent: Students will have to work on an annotated bibliography focusing on the issues they choose to address in their term-end paper.

Not Compulsory. Details to be decided.

title: A HISTORY OF HISTORY (WITH PROFESSOR RUDRANGSHU MUKHERJEE)
description:
A History of History [HIS-5013] [HIS-5013-1]

Faculty Name
Nayanjot Kaur Lahiri [nayanjot.lahiri@ashoka.edu.in] ,Rudrangshu Mukherjee [rudrangshu.mukherjee@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Course Description:

This course seeks to impart a sense of the building blocks of the discipline of history, through important works of history and through the writings of historians on their craft. What ideas of the past can be seen from antiquity till the present?  How have the concerns of history changed? What constitute the facts of history and how are these ascertained? What constitute the protocols of historical discourse? These are questions that will be examined with reference to the works of various historians and scholars within and outside academia. 

Academic Honesty and Plagarism

You are required to uphold academic honesty in all aspects of this course. Think for yourself, do your own work, and cite sources properly.

Syllabus

title: BORDERLANDS: TOWARDS A SPATIAL HISTORY OF EMPIRE
description:
Borderlands: Towards a Spatial History of Empire [HIS-3516/ SOA-3514/ CHI-3203/ IR-3028] [HIS-3516/ SOA-3514/ CHI-3203/ IR-3028-1]

Faculty Name
Sayantani Mukherjee [sayantani.mukherjee@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

What is the violence of a line drawn upon a map? Or on a terrain? How are people produced by such mapping? What anxieties drive the imperial cartographic impulse? What pressures does terra nullis exert in situ? What do the bodies produced in mapped territories look like? What bodies exist in unmapped terrains? What is the relationship between wonder/amazement, and control/annihilation? Where do we locate ourselves as scholars reading these maps? What maps are visible when we visit the landscape? How are narratives produced against maps? How are histories made visible in terrain?

These questions will guide us as we traverse a theoretical terrain of writings on space and territory, and situate ourselves in specific historical moments of imperial mastery over space. We will cover a lot of ground temporally but our geographic focus will be South and East Asia. In this class we will develop skills in reading and understanding the genre of the academic monograph; in understanding how they relate to each other; and in analyzing the theoretical and methodological bases and trends of these works.

Learning Outcomes

Summarize academic monographs in South and East Asian studies and introduce salient points in notes and in speech.

Be able to draw connections between works to gain an overview of scholarly and historiographical debates.

Be able to trace theoretical or methodological trends across multiple empirical contexts.

Analyze and present in writing your interpretation of the role of space and place in a geographical region relevant to your work or interest.

Learn the skills of co-writing and co-presenting to gain a sense of how cooperative work can integrate intellectual property as well as collective clarity.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

You are not required to purchase any materials for this course. All readings will be provided in PDF via email.

Grading Rubric

Assessment & Assignments:

40% - Leading weekly discussion in class and participating in class discussions

60% - Carto-Paper (Optional Team Project)

Attendance, Participation and Discussion Etiquette :

I will not take attendance in each class meeting, however, participation in weekly class discussions is a mandatory part of your grade and is necessary for succeeding in the course. If you have circumstances that might affect attendance at a specific class meeting, please let me know ahead of time whenever possible. Flexibility is especially important since Covid is still with us. To protect your privacy, please do not describe any medical situations to me; just inform me that the situation exists and be prepared to provide a doctor’s note if requested.

 

Participation is part of your grade, and should be based on attentive reading, listening, and preparation. Participation can take many forms. Always keep an open mind and be respectful of your classmates and your instructor regardless of what you wish to say, or whether you agree with what has already been said. Being respectful also means that (1) if you have not completed a particular reading, please refrain from commenting on it (2) in the normal course of discussion, if you have just spoken, you should refrain from speaking again until others who wish to contribute have done so (3) contributions to discussion should be based on the readings, lectures, and discussion questions, and should aim to improve our collective understanding of them. In general, please avoid unstructured/unsupported reflections as well as topics that are beyond the scope of the course.

 

Class lead:

One student per week (both Tuesday and Thursday) will introduce the assigned readings for that week (~10 mins) and facilitate discussion for the rest of the class. Try to keep your presentation to under ten minutes, and use the time to provide a short summary of one or two of the assigned texts, and present to the class your own questions and ideas about the theme through the readings. This exercise will help you condense the readings to their core argument and thereby facilitate review before assignments are due. For this reason, it makes sense to approach every set of readings with a few basic questions: who is the author? What is his or her background? What kind of audience are they addressing? And what is the aim of the text? Is it a purely technical piece of writing or does it raise (or hide?) important political questions? These questions are very basic, but they will help you to structure your contribution to the class. If you would like to additionally discuss reading material or resources not on the reading list in your presentation, please feel free to discuss your ideas for the presentation with me beforehand. Following the week’s discussion, the class lead will collate all the notes for the assigned readings, to structure them into an annotated entry for each text we have read.

Carto-paper:

This assignment will be a 5500-6000 word (Times New Roman 12 pt. font, double-spaced, not including footnotes and bibliography) investigation of a single primary source relevant to the field of cartography, broadly construed: this can be a specific map, a surveyor’s field diary, an object history of a technical instrument, etc. Feel free to discuss your ideas or adjustments, if you prefer, for this project with me beforehand. You may also turn this into a collaborative project if you wish. Your carto-paper is due 11.59 pm May 14, by email to me. We will be discussing two drafts of your paper as a class. These two drafts are due on Monday 11.59 pm February 20 and April 3, by email. Following your submissions, we will intensively workshop everyone’s paper as a group. In these group discussions, you will be expected to have read your peers’ work (as you would when you will attend conferences, workshops, and panel discussions), and offer constructive feedback to help your peers make progress on their projects. Your participation in these discussions will count towards your final grade for the carto-paper.

These essays are an important way to develop your writing skills—particularly the formation of a clear and logical argument, the mobilization of evidence, and the quality of prose. Your essays are intended to help you build the specific skill of making a historical argument, and to that end they should be erudite, specific, supportable and argumentative—not an unstructured reflection, opinion, or summary. They must refer, when needed, to the readings with citations.

 

Late submissions will not be accepted. If you anticipate that for any reason you will be unable to make these deadlines, please email me at least 48 hours in advance for an extension.

 

Your essays must aim to illuminate the texts you have chosen to discuss, rather than simply critique them or identify the gaps in the knowledge of the authors. The effectiveness of your arguments will rest on your plausible articulation of positions and paradigms of thinking that you may be unfamiliar or even disagree with. Thus, both your essays and the feedback you offer your peers should attempt to first reconstruct the carefully considered and rigorously formulated thoughts and arguments of the authors you are reading, before seeking to push that comprehension in a new direction.

fullName: CHI-3204, STONE, PAPER, BAMBOO, SILK: SINOPHONE TEXTUAL CULTURES, ELOISE WRIGHT
title: STONE, PAPER, BAMBOO, SILK: SINOPHONE TEXTUAL CULTURES,
description:
Stone, Paper, Bamboo, Silk: Sinophone Textual Cultures [HIS-3513/ CHI-3204/ VA-3027/ ENG-3413] [HIS-3513/ CHI-3204/ VA-3027/ ENG-3413-1]

Faculty Name
Eloise Wright [eloise.wright@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Today, when so much of our daily communication occurs via text or email, it can be difficult to imagine a world in which writing was the preserve of a tiny minority. Chinese characters are frequently cited as the oldest continuous written tradition, beginning over three thousand years ago, but in that time the physical form of the characters and the materials they were written on have transformed over and over again. We will consider what questions these problems raise for historians' use of textual sources by looking at writing as a social, material, and political act. What were the symbolic meanings attributed to writings that most people could not understand? What practical uses could writing serve? How did access to writing intersect with other social hierarchies, like gender and class? Beginning with the invention of writing in the Yellow River region, we will discuss problems such as: the relationship between speech and writing; changes in writing materials; writing for display and writing for use; censorship; Chinese characters in non-Chinese societies; and debates over script reform.

The written assessment for this class will build towards a final research paper on a topic of the students' choice.

title: READING HISTORY
description:
Reading History [HIS-3001/ SOA-3513/ ENG-3231] [HIS-3001/ SOA-3513/ ENG-3231-1]

Faculty Name
Neeladri Bhattacharya [neeladri.bhattacharya@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

READING HISTORY: FROM POSITIVISM TO CRITICAL THEORY

Neeladri Bhattacharya

Object of the course:

The course will explore how history as a modern discipline comes into being in the nineteenth century, and how it changes over time. It will focus on some of the dominant traditions of historical writing, and the internal dialogues within the traditions. It will move from positivism to critical theory, from Marxism to the Annales, from the French historical tradition to English social history, from Foucault’s discursive turn to Michel de Certeau’s focus on everyday practice. Through this journey, we will reflect on some of the binaries that often shape historical thinking –– the questions of history and myth, certainty and ambiguity, objectivity and prejudice, truth and falsehood –– and see how these notions are questioned and rethought over time.

If historians in the nineteenth century established some of the founding premises of the historian’s craft, the ‘critical turn’ from the 1970s has powerfully questioned many of these assumptions, underlining the complex nature of historical practice. It has persuaded historians to ask: what does it mean to enter the archive and mine the traces of the past, to read the record, to see and represent, to narrate, and to write a story based on evidence? This course will explore what this critical turn has meant to the writing of history, how it has forced historians to question earlier frames, and opened up new worlds of research.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

THEMES AND LECTURES:

Introduction: On Reading History

I: MODERNITY AND HISTORICAL KNOWEDGE

 

1) Ranke, Acton and the Shaping of the Historical Discipline

     Readings:

G. G. Iggers and K. von Moltke (eds), The Theory and Practice of History: Leopold von Ranke, Indianapolis, 1973, Introduction.

John Warren, ‘The Rankean Tradition in British Historiography, 1850-1950’, in Stephen Berger et al., eds., Writing History: Theory and Practice, Hodder Arnold, 2003.

Leonard Krieger, Ranke: The Meaning of History, (Read: Ch. 1: The Dubious Legacy, Ch. 2: The Unscientific Counterpoint, Ch. 3: The Limits of Theory), pp. 1-34.

Acton, A Lecture on the Study of History, Macmillan 1911.

 

2) Ethnocentrism, Teleology and the Idea of Progress:

      

     Readings:  

H. Butterfield, The Whig Interpretation of History. Norton Library, 1965. Chs. 1-3.

Collingwood, The Idea of History, Introduction and Part V, Epilegomena.

Peter Winch, ‘Understanding Primitive Society’, in Bryan Wilson ed. Rationality, Oxford, Basil Blackwell 1970.

Charles Taylor, ‘Understanding and Ethnocentricity’, in Social Theory as Practice (OUP, New Delhi, 1983)

 

3) History and the Narrative Turn

Readings:

Louis O.  Mink, ‘Narrative form as Cognitive Instrument’ in Louis O.  Mink, Historical Understanding, Cornell University Press, 1987.

Hayden White, ‘The Historical Text as a Literary Artifact’, in Hayden White, Tropics of Discourse, John Hopkins University Press, 1978.

Hayden White, ‘The Value of Narrativity in the Representation of Reality’, in White, The Content of the Form, The John Hopkins University Press, 1987.

Paul Ricoeur, ‘On Narrative Time’, Critical Inquiry, Vol. 7, No. 1, Special Issue on Narrative (Autumn, 1980), pp. 169-190.

David Carr, ‘Getting the Story Straight: Narrative and Historical Knowledge’, in Geoffrey Roberts Ed., The History and Narrative Reader, Routledge, 2001, pp. 197-208.

 

II: ANNALES AND THE FRENCH HISTORICAL TRADITION

 

4) The Vision of Total History:

   Readings:

Marc Bloch, The Historian’s Craft, New York 1953.

Lucien Febvre, ‘A New Kind of History’, in Burke, Peter ed., A New Kind of History: From the Writings of Lucien Febvre, Routledge, 1973, pp. 27-43.

Lucien Febvre, ‘Sensibility and History: How to Constitute the Emotional Life of the Past’, in Burke, ed., A New Kind of History: From the Writings of Lucien Febvre, pp. 12-26.

 

5) Braudel and Historical Time

   Readings:

Fernand Braudel, ‘History and the Social Sciences: The Longue Dureé’, Annales E.S.C., No 4, 1958, reproduced in Braudel, On History, The University of Chicago Press, 1980, pp. 25-54.

Peter Burke, ‘The History of the Event and the Revival of the Narrative’, in Peter Burke ed., New Perspectives on Historical Writing, Cambridge: Polity Press, 2001, pp. 283-300.

E. Le Roy Ladurie, The ‘Event and the Long Term in Social History: The Case of Chouan Uprising’, in Ladurie, The Territory of the Historian, The Harvester Press, 1979.

Aron Gurevich, ‘What is Time’, in Aron Gurevich, Categories of Medieval Culture, Routledge, 1985, pp. 152-93.

    

6) Febvre, Le Goff and the History of Mentalite

    Readings:

Jacques Le Goff,  ‘Merchant’s Time and Church’s Time in the Middle Ages’, Time Work and Culture in the Middle Ages, The University of Chicago Press, 1982, pp. 29-42.

Le Goff, ‘Dreams in the Culture and Collective Psychology of the Middle Ages’, Time Work and Culture in the Middle Ages, The University of Chicago Press, 1982, 201-204.

Robert Muchembled, Smells: A Cultural History of Odours in Early Modern Times, Polity, 2020, Chs 1-4.

LaCapra, Dominick., ‘Is Everyone a Mentalite Case?’ in LaCapra, Dominick, History and Criticism, Cornell University Press, 1985.

Peter Burke, ‘Strengths and Weaknesses of a History of Mentalities’, in Burke, Varieties of Cultural Histories, Cornell University Press, 1997 pp. 162-82.

 

III: MARXISM AND HISTORICAL WRITING

 

7) The Beginnings: Karl Marx, Marxism and History

           Readings:

Karl Marx, 18th Brumaire of Louis Bonaparte. 1852.

Marx, ‘Theses on Feuerbach’, 1845.

Eric Hobsbawm, ‘Karl Marx’s Contribution to Historiography’, in Ideology and Social Sciences, Suffolk 1962.

Joseph Stalin, Historical and Dialectical Materialism, 1938.

 

8) Althusser and the Structuralist Vision

     Readings:

Althusser, For Marx, Harmondsworth, 1969.Ch. 1.

Thompson, E.P., ‘Poverty of Theory: or an Orrery of Errors’, in The Poverty of Theory, Merlin, London, 1978, Ch.

Maurice Godelier, ‘The Ideal in the Real’, in Raphael Samuel and Stedman Jones eds., Culture, Ideology and Politics, Routledge, 1982.

 

9) History from Below and New Social History: E. P. Thompson and Beyond

    Readings:

E. Thompson, ‘The Moral Economy Of the English Crowd’, Past & Present, No. 50 (Feb. 1971), pp. 76-136.

Thompson, ‘Rough Music’, in Thompson, Customs in Common, Penguin, 1991, pp. 467-534.

Elizabeth Fox Genovese, “The Many Faces of Moral Economy: A Contribution to the Debate’, Past & Present , Feb., 1973, No. 58 (Feb., 1973), pp. 161-168.

Chris Wickham, ‘Gossip and Resistance among the Medieval Peasantry’, Past & Present, 160 (1998).

R.W. Scribner, ‘Sorcery, Superstition and the Society: The Witch of Urach’, in Scribner, Popular Culture and Popular Movements in Reformation Germany, 1529, The Hambledon Press, 1987, pp. 257-76.

Shahid Amin, ‘Gandhi as Mahatma’, in Ranajit Guha ed., Subaltern Studies III, OUP, 1984.

 

10) Gendering History (student led discussion)

      Readings:

Joan Wallach Scott, ‘Women in the Making of the English Working Class’, in Scott, Gender and the Politics of History, Columbia University Press, 1999, pp. 68-92

Carolyn Steedman, ‘The Price of Experience, Women and the Making of the English Working Class’, Radical History Review, 59, 1994, pp 108-119.

Judith Butler, ‘Speaking Up, Talking Back: Joan Scott’s Critical Feminism’, in Butler and Elizabeth Weed eds., The Question of Gender: Joan Scott’s Critical Feminism, Indiana University Press, 2011, pp. 11-30.

Saidiya Hartman, ‘A Venus in Two Acts’, Small Axe, 12: 26: 2, June 2008, pp 1-14

 

IV: HISTORY AND CRITICAL THEORY

 

11)  Foucault and Histories of Power:

Readings:

Michel Foucault, ‘The Body of the Condemned’, & ‘Docile Bodies’, in Discipline and Punish, Vintage Books, Part I, Ch 1&  Part  III, Ch. 2.

Michel Foucault, ‘Body Power”, & ‘Truth and Power’, in Power/Knowledge, The Harvester Press 1980, pp. 55-62, 109-33.

Foucault, ‘The Subject of Power’, Herbert Dreyfus and Paul Rabinow, Michel Foucault: Beyond Structuralism and Hermeneutics, University of Chicago Press, 1982, pp. 208-28.

 

12) Semiotics and the History of Meanings and Symbols

    Readings:

Robert Darnton, ‘The Great Cat Massacre’, in Darnton, The Great Cat Massacre and Other Episodes in French Cultural History, New York, Basic Books, 1984.

Roger Chartier, ‘Texts, Symbols and Frenchness’, in Chartier, Cultural History:  Between Practices and Representations, Polity Press, Cambridge, 1988.

Dominick La Capra, ‘Chartier, Darnton and the Great Symbol Massacre’, in La Capra, Soundings in Critical Theory, Cornell University Press, Ithaca, London, 1989.

Raphael Samuel, ‘Reading the Signs’, History Workshop, No. 32, 1991, pp. 88-109.

 

13) Michel de Certeau and the Practice of Everyday Life

      Readings:

Michel de Certeau, ‘Walking the City’, in de Certeau, The Practice of Everyday Life, University of California Press, 1988.

Michel de Certeau, ‘Making do: Uses and Tactics’, 115-30, in de Certeau, The Practice of Everyday Life, pp., 29-42.

Chartier, Cultural History:  Between Practices and Representations, Polity Press, Cambridge, 1988, Ch. 1

 

14) Looking at the Small and the Anecdotal: Microhistory and New Historicism

      Readings:

Microhistory: (student discussion)

Carlo Ginzburg, ‘Micro history: Two or Three Things that I Know about it’, Critical Inquiry, No. 1, 1993; reproduced in Threads and Traces, pp., 193-214.

Carlo Ginzburg, The Cheese and the Worms: The Cosmos of a Sixteenth-century Miller, John Hopkins University, 1980, pp. 1-35.

Giovanni Levi, ‘On Microhistory’, in: Peter Burke ed., New Perspectives on Historical Writing (Cambridge: Polity Press, 2001), p. 93-113.

Ranajit Guha, ‘Chandra’s death’, Subaltern Studies, V, OUP, 1987, 135-65.

Tanika Sarkar, ‘Talking about Scandals: Religion, Law and Love in Nineteenth Century Calcutta’, Studies in History, 13: 1 1997, pp. 63-95.

 

  New Historicism:

Stephen Greenblatt, ‘The Poetics of Culture’, Michael Payne ed., The Greenblatt Reader, Blackwell Publishing, 2005, pp. 30-49.

Catharine Gallagher and Stephen Greenblatt, Practicing New Historicism, University of Chicago Press, 1997. Introduction, pp. 1-19

         

Gallagher and Stephen Greenblatt, ‘Counter History and the Anecdote’, in Practicing New Historicism, University of Chicago Press, 1997pp. 49-74.

Gallagher, ‘The Potato in Materialist Imagination’, Practicing New Historicism, University of Chicago Press, 1997, pp.110-35.

 

15) Post Modernism, Post Colonialism and the Writing of History

      Readings

Dipesh Chakrabarty, ‘Postcoloniality and the Artifice of History: Who Speaks for "Indian" Pasts?’, Representations, No. 37 (Winter, 1992), pp. 1-26.

Gabrielle Spiegel, ‘History, Historicism and the Social Logic of the Text in the Middle Ages’, Speculum, lxv, 1990, pp. 59-86.

 Patrick Joyce and Catriona Kelly, ‘History and Post-Modernism’, Past & Present, No. 133 (Nov., 1991), pp. 204-213.

Hayden White, ‘Historical Emplotment and the Problem of Truth’, in Saul Friedlander, Probing the Limits of Representation, Harvard University Press, 1992, pp. 37-54.

Dominick LaCapra, ‘Representing the Holocaust: Reflections on the Historians’ Debate’, Saul Friedlander, Probing the Limits of Representation, Harvard University Press, 1992, pp. 108-127.

Braun, Robert, ‘The Holocaust and the Problems of Representation’, History and Theory, 34, 1, 1995.

Grading Rubric

Assessment:

There are no exams for this course. The structure of assessment will be as follows: (i) 8 short response papers/presentations on readings = 40 per cent of total credits (5% x 8 = 40) and (2) an end semester essay of 2500-3500 words = 60 percent of total credits.

The course has 4 parts. Students will have to write two response papers for each part. You can choose any two readings from those suggested for each part and write notes of about 400 words each, capturing the arguments in the essay and stating your responses to it. These will be discussed in the class on scheduled dates.

The end semester essay will be on a theme selected by the student in consultation with me, and the draft will be discussed in separate discussion groups, each with 5-6 students.

Attendance Policy

There is no compulsory attendance for the lectures, but all students are expected to be there for the scheduled discussions.  Participation in the discussions and student led presentations will be taken into account in grading.

title: GENDER MATTERS IN GLOBAL POLITICS
description:
Gender Matters in Global Politics [IR-2015/ POL-2029] [IR-2015/ POL-2029-1]

Faculty Name
Ananya Sharma [ananya.sharma@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course is concerned with gender ‘in’ International Relations. It is comprehensive introduction to a way of analyzing and researching global politics and international relations that takes gender seriously as a category of analysis.  More specifically, it is concerned with how ideas of war, peace, sovereignty, violence, foreign policy, governance and political economy are sustained by specific masculinities and femininities, and how these particular gender constructions impact on the lives of particular groups of men and women. Set against this, the aim of the course is mainly threefold: firstly, to (re)introduce how the discipline has traditionally thought about war and peace; secondly, to reveal the gendered constructions and inequalities that mark the traditional scholarship; and thirdly, to evaluate the specific contribution that feminist critiques have made as part of the so-called ‘Critical Turn’ in IR. Gender is understood here not as a synonym for ‘woman’ but as a hierarchical coding of masculinity and femininity that pervades social relations and institutional practices, with systemic (though not deterministic) effects on inequalities. Gender meanings and practices permeate our lives, and a closer look at these processes is more illuminating than many anticipate, with relevance and implications for who we are, how we think, and how we act – as individuals, groups, communities and nation-states.

Learning Outcomes
  • Understand the landscape of feminist international relations thought and challenge gender-blind and gendered approaches to global politics
  • Complicate understandings of global politics by identifying relationship between global crises and global gender(ed) divisions
  • Appreciate that the international is personal and the personal is international and  recognize the necessity and complexity of taking gender seriously in global politics.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Pre-requisite- a 100 level introductory IR course.

Grading Rubric

It is a continuous process- Class presentations, mid-term assessment, group project and end term assessment.

Attendance Policy

There are three excused absences allowed for the semester.

title: INTERNATIONAL CONFLICT ANALYSIS
description:
International Conflict Analysis [IR-2028/ POL-2004] [IR-2028/ POL-2004-1]

Faculty Name
Bann Seng Tan [bannseng.tan@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course introduces basic concepts and theories in the field of international security. The field is organized around the study of war, its causes, its characteristics and its mitigation. War is costly and yet both states and leaders resort to the use of force. Our task is to understand the rationale for this phenomenon.

The course is structured as follows. We start with the major theoretical approaches, realism, liberalism, and constructivism, and their understanding of the causes of war. We will then turn to the rationalist perspective to war and apply it to various issue-areas that have preoccupied both the scholarship and policy-making world.  Issue-areas that will be covered include the nuclear proliferation, democratic peace, coups, and terrorism.

The attached syllabus is obviously a draft.

Learning Outcomes

War is costly and yet both states and leaders resort to the use of force. Our task is to understand the rationale for this phenomenon.

This is not a course on current events. We will focus rather on the concepts that underpin the behavior of states and leaders with regards to international conflict.

title: DEMOCRATIZATION AND FOREIGN AID
description:
Democratization and Foreign Aid [POL-3074/ IR-3021] [POL-3074/ IR-3021-1]

Faculty Name
Bann Seng Tan [bannseng.tan@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The core concern of the course is to analyse the ways foreign aid might or might not work when it comes to democracy promotion. Since this concern links two concept groups, this course doubles as a stylized and brief introduction to the literature on foreign aid and democratization. In democratization (Part I), we will consider the type of foreign interventions, the drivers of democratization, the special role of elections and the varieties of authoritarianism. In Foreign aid (Part II), we will cover the types of foreign aid, the efficacy debate, the modalities of democracy aid, the incentive of aid donors and recipients and donor switching.

 

After the theoretical overview, we consider a practical approach to existing political constraints (Part III), as articulated in my book, Liberalization at the Margins. We skim the empirics and put more emphasis on the case studies of the aid-democratization dynamic for Egypt, Fiji, and Myanmar. We conclude by considering the policy implications of such strategies with an emphasis on the authoritarian backlash (and authoritarian strategies for international law.)

The attached syllabus is obviously a draft.

Learning Outcomes

Through the course, students should be able to 1) identify the major issues and debates in foreign aid, 2) analyse the costs and benefits of various modalities of democracy aid, and 3) consider the policy implications of democracy promotion. Students also have the opportunity, through the term essay, to specialize on the aid dynamics of a given country and understand why democracy promotion frequently fails. As a bonus, students get a sense of the background work that goes into the writing of a book, They may appreciate (or not!) that what you see the finished product – the book - is merely the tip iceberg. It is the part that is underwater and not immediately obvious where the real labor lies.

This is not a course on current events.
