title: AN INTERPRETIVE HISTORY OF MAO ZEDONG AND THE CHINESE COMMUNIST REVOLUTION
description:
An Interpretive History of Mao Zedong and the Chinese Communist Revolution [CHI-4001/ HIS-4802/ POL-3090/ IR-3027] [CHI-4001/ HIS-4802/ POL-3090/ IR-3027-1]

Faculty Name
Sayantani Mukherjee [sayantani.mukherjee@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course introduces the historical relationship between Mao Zedong’s philosophy of history and revolution, and the global context of Chinese Revolution in the twentieth century. We will examine Mao’s theories and practice of revolution through a thematic lens: not as biographical artifacts but as thought produced by and constitutive of the revolutionary circumstances in the twentieth-century world at large and China in particular.  Our aim will be to investigate how three modal terms—Chinese, Revolutionary, Marxist—reflect on each other as open questions when Mao Zedong is studied in contextually-embedded and philosophically complex manner.

Situating the world in an intimate dialogic relationship to China, we will ask the questions; was Mao a Marxist? How was Mao’s Marxism inflected by his positionality of being Chinese in a revolutionary twentieth-century world? How was Mao’s Chineseness influenced by his being a revolutionary in the twentieth-century world? How was Marxism impacted by Mao’s articulation of revolution in the twentieth-century world? The readings for this class will mostly be drawn from Mao’s own writings, and students will be expected to read these texts intensively, with an open mind. While this course does not require any previous knowledge of China, as an advanced level class, a familiarity with general twentieth-century world history and/or a background in the history of Marxism will be helpful. Students with prior background in neither will be expected to learn on a very steep curve.

Learning Outcomes

Read intertextually and understand literary productions as artefacts of historical and social construction.

Summarize academic monographs in East Asian studies and introduce salient points in notes and in speech.

Be able to draw connections between works to gain an overview of scholarly and historiographical debates.

Be able to trace theoretical or methodological trends across multiple empirical contexts.

Learn the skills of co-writing and co-presenting to gain a sense of how cooperative work can integrate intellectual property as well as collective clarity.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

You are not required to purchase any materials for this course. All readings will be provided in PDF via email.

Grading Rubric

Requirements and Expectations:        

Assessment & Assignments:

30% - Regular participation in class discussions

70% - Writing Portfolio (summarized below):

10% - Progress meetings (minimum 2)

40% - Report

20% - Op-ed

Attendance, Participation and Discussion Étiquette:

One third of your grade in this class depends on learning how to read written productions “against the grain”. That is to say, scrutinizing the beliefs and attitudes that typically go unexamined in a text, drawing attention to the gaps, silences, contradictions, and unspoken impetus that animate written words, but also reading that text through the various registers of its production and circulation—as an artefact of literary, historical and social conditions that may or may not alter its imagined “original” context. We are reading Mao, but we will never take him for his word.

I will not take attendance in each class meeting, however, participation in weekly class discussions is a mandatory part of your grade and is necessary for succeeding in the course. If you have circumstances that might affect attendance at a specific class meeting, please let me know ahead of time whenever possible. Flexibility is especially important since Covid is still with us. To protect your privacy, please do not describe any medical situations to me; just inform me that the situation exists and be prepared to provide a doctor’s note if requested.

Participation is part of your grade, and should be based on attentive reading, listening, and preparation. Always keep an open mind and be respectful of your classmates and your instructor regardless of what you wish to say, or whether you agree with what has already been said. Being respectful also means that (1) if you have not completed a particular reading, please refrain from commenting on it (2) in the normal course of discussion, if you have just spoken, you should refrain from speaking again until others who wish to contribute have done so (3) contributions to discussion should be based on the readings, lectures, and discussion questions, and should aim to improve our collective understanding of them. In general, please avoid unstructured/unsupported reflections as well as topics that are beyond the scope of the course.

Writing Portfolio

Two-thirds of your final grade for this class will depend on two written pieces that will be thematically related and proceed from each other. The purpose of these pieces is to help you further navigate the landscape of political writing, by interrogating how the processes of (narrative) writing engage with the conveying of “information” in the quest for coherence, conviction, and accessibility.

The first of these pieces will be a Report on an Investigation of the  < > Movement, approx. 5000-6000 words, modeled on Mao’s famous Report on the Hunan Peasant Movement. For this first piece, you may choose between reporting on the working conditions of a) campus workers at Ashoka or b) teaching fellows at Ashoka.

The second text is an opinion piece (no longer than 1,000 words) that condenses your longer report into a piece that should function as a call to action. Unlike the first piece, where your stated purpose is an “investigation”, your purpose in this second piece is to craft an appeal.

Please note that you have the option of writing both the Report and the op-ed as a team project, but that the requirements will change accordingly.

For both pieces, you may choose to conduct interviews in person, speak to campus “experts”, read theoretical texts or works providing historical background. The methodology is entirely up to you, but you are encouraged discuss your thinking and writing process with me through a series of progress meetings. These meetings will count for ten percent of your final grade.

Attachment
An Interpretive History of Mao Zedong and the Chinese Communist Revolution.docx

fullName: POL-2088/IR-2043, WOMEN, WAR, AND POLITICS: GENDER IN POLITICS AND IN VIOLENCE, DIPIN KAUR
title: WOMEN, WAR, AND POLITICS: GENDER IN POLITICS AND IN VIOLENCE,
description:
Women, War, and Politics: Gender in Politics and in Violence [POL-2088/ IR-2043] [POL-2088/ IR-2043-1]

Faculty Name
Dipin Kaur [dipin.kaur@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course makes a semester-long case for using gender as an effective lens to understand political participation, with a focus on contexts affected by political violence. While it is well established that male bodies make up the vast majority of decision-makers and participants in quotidian electoral politics, the same logic applies to contexts affected by conflict and war. Conventionally, male bodies are considered to be at the forefront of decision-making about whether to go to war, and on the frontlines of said wars as fighters.

In the last few decades, however, these constructions of masculinity and femininity in conflict have come to be questioned. Instead, the understanding that gender affects the way in which we see and make sense of the world around us – and that men and women experience and affect wartime dynamics differently – has come front and center. In the same spirit, we will focus on the role of women in political decision-making and participation; their role both as perpetrators of violence as combatants (and terrorists), as victims and as survivors of male-victimizing atrocities; the militarization of gendered bodies and the impact of gender-based violence in armed conflict.

Finally, we will reflect on the gendered aspects of women’s restructuring of economies in male absence, their resistance to political violence, and their role in peacekeeping and rebuilding societies after war. As we cover each theme, we will pay particular attention to what feminists have described as intersectionality and the continuum of violence, from the “private” to the “public” sphere, from the militarization of everyday living to overt violent conflict.

title: CRITICAL INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS: CONSTRUCTIVISM AND BEYOND
description:
Critical International Relations: Constructivism and Beyond [IR-2040] [IR-2040-1]

Faculty Name
Amit Jai Pal Julka [amit.julka@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Introduction

Think about the image that comes to your head when you hear the words “International Relations”. Missiles, power balance, catchy acronyms/names (QUAD, MAD), fighter jets, men sitting around a round table with serious faces, taking decisions. This course is an attempt to rip apart that image to see what lies underneath — ordinary (and extraordinary) human beings caught in webs of meaning and power. In other words, we go beyond the standard pedological structure of the discipline that is centered around the ‘big three’ – realism, liberalism, and constructivism. Instead, we begin the story from constructivism and slowly make our way through major strands of critical theory – feminist, post-structural, anti-caste, postcolonial, anti-imperial, and Marxist.  

 

Assessment

Component

Weightage

Format

Midterm Essay (Submit any time between Week 4-7)
End of week 7 (Friday, March 17)

20

Mid Term Essay (3k)

Student Presentation

10

6 Memos (You can choose any 6 weeks between Week 2 – Week 13)

20

Memos (<500 words)

Final Essay (Submit anytime between Week 8-May 10)

30

Essay (5k-8k)

Participation

20

Participation + Attendance (both in class and Thursday seminars)

*All word limits exclude references

Mid term assignment – Can be a critique of a critical school of thought of your choice

Final assignment — Apply a critical theory to a puzzle/phenomenon in international politics. In other words, explain the puzzle/phenomenon through a critical theory of your choice. You may also combine two critical perspectives, or use these critical perspectives to form a critical theory of your own.

Learning Outcomes

see above

title: THE POLITICS OF PEACE: RECONSTRUCTION AND JUSTICE IN POST-CONFLICT SOCIETIES
description:
The Politics of Peace: Reconstruction and Justice in Post-Conflict Societies [IR-2041/ POL-2096] [IR-2041/ POL-2096-1]

Faculty Name
Dipin Kaur [dipin.kaur@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

In this course, we will aim to impart agency to states, insurgents, aid agencies, and civilians in narratives of post-conflict politics. Specifically, we will explore various cases from around the world to think about questions such as:

- What do survival strategies look like for civilians in conflict? Why do some civilians flee spaces of conflict while others stat back?

- Does international aid help states to protect civilians, engage in hearts and minds, or build military coercive capacities?

- How do states that receive peacekeeping to end conflict fare differently in terms of long-term violent outcomes than those that don’t?

- Why do some rebel groups translate into political parties, while others don’t? What are the impacts of insurgent political participation on post-conflict democracy?

- What are the current principles of accountability in the international system, including truth and reconciliation commissions, international criminal tribunals, and legal actions by third-party countries? 

- What are some domestic obstacles to peacekeeping, reconstruction, and justice? How do conflict-affected groups draw boundaries between retraumatization and accountability in the absence of state processes?

title: MAKING MEANING QUALITATIVE METHODS IN IR & POLITICAL SCIENCE
description:
Making Meaning: Qualitative Methods in IR and Political Science [IR-2042/ POL-2103] [IR-2042/ POL-2103-1]

Faculty Name
Amit Jai Pal Julka [amit.julka@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Introduction

Usually, methods are seen as the boring side of research. On top of that, qualitative/interpretivist methods are often viewed as ‘airy-fairy’, soft, & inconclusive as opposed to the solid, robust & conclusive nature of quantitative research. This course aims to demolish all these myths and drive home the following points — qualitative/interpretivist method research is fun, challenging, nuanced, and as ‘robust’ as conventional positivist research. Furthermore, the course is rooted in the belief that the binaries of qualitative/quantitative or interpretivist/positivist are not only exaggerated, but also unhelpful.

Now, given the enormity of the tasks at hand, the course will be challenging (which is not the same as difficult). Which means, that you will be required to read a lot, reflect, engage, critique, and apply. You have been warned.

Objectives

The aims of the course are fourfold:

First, to not just study methods/methodology in instrumentalist terms, but to root ourselves in philosophy of science - so we start with Popper, Kuhn, and Lakatos to understand the nature of scientific inquiry. Then, we try to overturn all of them by reading Feyerabend's provocative treatise 'Against Method'.

Second, the module covers foundational literature on how to select one's case studies, along with basics such as conceptualization and operationalization. After that, we deep-dive into the methods themselves - discourse analysis, visual analysis, ethnography, quantitative text analysis, interviews etc.

Third, the module's aim is also to acquaint you with exemplars (mostly) of qualitative research from Pol Sci/IR - to show you how things have been done, and to provoke you into thinking how they could have been done better. For instance, we see how James Scott's ethnography uncovered micropolitics of resistance in Southeast Asia, or how Carol Cohn stumbled upon the masculinized/sexualized world of defence intellectuals in the United States.

Fourth, we try to get our hands dirty and do some discourse analysis ourselves. So, a workshop will be organized where students try analyzing a text of their choice - which could be a film, piece of music, novel, or a government record.

Learning Outcomes

See above

title: BORDERLANDS: TOWARDS A SPATIAL HISTORY OF EMPIRE
description:
Borderlands: Towards a Spatial History of Empire [HIS-3516/ SOA-3514/ CHI-3203/ IR-3028] [HIS-3516/ SOA-3514/ CHI-3203/ IR-3028-1]

Faculty Name
Sayantani Mukherjee [sayantani.mukherjee@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

What is the violence of a line drawn upon a map? Or on a terrain? How are people produced by such mapping? What anxieties drive the imperial cartographic impulse? What pressures does terra nullis exert in situ? What do the bodies produced in mapped territories look like? What bodies exist in unmapped terrains? What is the relationship between wonder/amazement, and control/annihilation? Where do we locate ourselves as scholars reading these maps? What maps are visible when we visit the landscape? How are narratives produced against maps? How are histories made visible in terrain?

These questions will guide us as we traverse a theoretical terrain of writings on space and territory, and situate ourselves in specific historical moments of imperial mastery over space. We will cover a lot of ground temporally but our geographic focus will be South and East Asia. In this class we will develop skills in reading and understanding the genre of the academic monograph; in understanding how they relate to each other; and in analyzing the theoretical and methodological bases and trends of these works.

Learning Outcomes

Summarize academic monographs in South and East Asian studies and introduce salient points in notes and in speech.

Be able to draw connections between works to gain an overview of scholarly and historiographical debates.

Be able to trace theoretical or methodological trends across multiple empirical contexts.

Analyze and present in writing your interpretation of the role of space and place in a geographical region relevant to your work or interest.

Learn the skills of co-writing and co-presenting to gain a sense of how cooperative work can integrate intellectual property as well as collective clarity.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

You are not required to purchase any materials for this course. All readings will be provided in PDF via email.

Grading Rubric

Assessment & Assignments:

40% - Leading weekly discussion in class and participating in class discussions

60% - Carto-Paper (Optional Team Project)

Attendance, Participation and Discussion Etiquette :

I will not take attendance in each class meeting, however, participation in weekly class discussions is a mandatory part of your grade and is necessary for succeeding in the course. If you have circumstances that might affect attendance at a specific class meeting, please let me know ahead of time whenever possible. Flexibility is especially important since Covid is still with us. To protect your privacy, please do not describe any medical situations to me; just inform me that the situation exists and be prepared to provide a doctor’s note if requested.

 

Participation is part of your grade, and should be based on attentive reading, listening, and preparation. Participation can take many forms. Always keep an open mind and be respectful of your classmates and your instructor regardless of what you wish to say, or whether you agree with what has already been said. Being respectful also means that (1) if you have not completed a particular reading, please refrain from commenting on it (2) in the normal course of discussion, if you have just spoken, you should refrain from speaking again until others who wish to contribute have done so (3) contributions to discussion should be based on the readings, lectures, and discussion questions, and should aim to improve our collective understanding of them. In general, please avoid unstructured/unsupported reflections as well as topics that are beyond the scope of the course.

 

Class lead:

One student per week (both Tuesday and Thursday) will introduce the assigned readings for that week (~10 mins) and facilitate discussion for the rest of the class. Try to keep your presentation to under ten minutes, and use the time to provide a short summary of one or two of the assigned texts, and present to the class your own questions and ideas about the theme through the readings. This exercise will help you condense the readings to their core argument and thereby facilitate review before assignments are due. For this reason, it makes sense to approach every set of readings with a few basic questions: who is the author? What is his or her background? What kind of audience are they addressing? And what is the aim of the text? Is it a purely technical piece of writing or does it raise (or hide?) important political questions? These questions are very basic, but they will help you to structure your contribution to the class. If you would like to additionally discuss reading material or resources not on the reading list in your presentation, please feel free to discuss your ideas for the presentation with me beforehand. Following the week’s discussion, the class lead will collate all the notes for the assigned readings, to structure them into an annotated entry for each text we have read.

Carto-paper:

This assignment will be a 5500-6000 word (Times New Roman 12 pt. font, double-spaced, not including footnotes and bibliography) investigation of a single primary source relevant to the field of cartography, broadly construed: this can be a specific map, a surveyor’s field diary, an object history of a technical instrument, etc. Feel free to discuss your ideas or adjustments, if you prefer, for this project with me beforehand. You may also turn this into a collaborative project if you wish. Your carto-paper is due 11.59 pm May 14, by email to me. We will be discussing two drafts of your paper as a class. These two drafts are due on Monday 11.59 pm February 20 and April 3, by email. Following your submissions, we will intensively workshop everyone’s paper as a group. In these group discussions, you will be expected to have read your peers’ work (as you would when you will attend conferences, workshops, and panel discussions), and offer constructive feedback to help your peers make progress on their projects. Your participation in these discussions will count towards your final grade for the carto-paper.

These essays are an important way to develop your writing skills—particularly the formation of a clear and logical argument, the mobilization of evidence, and the quality of prose. Your essays are intended to help you build the specific skill of making a historical argument, and to that end they should be erudite, specific, supportable and argumentative—not an unstructured reflection, opinion, or summary. They must refer, when needed, to the readings with citations.

 

Late submissions will not be accepted. If you anticipate that for any reason you will be unable to make these deadlines, please email me at least 48 hours in advance for an extension.

 

Your essays must aim to illuminate the texts you have chosen to discuss, rather than simply critique them or identify the gaps in the knowledge of the authors. The effectiveness of your arguments will rest on your plausible articulation of positions and paradigms of thinking that you may be unfamiliar or even disagree with. Thus, both your essays and the feedback you offer your peers should attempt to first reconstruct the carefully considered and rigorously formulated thoughts and arguments of the authors you are reading, before seeking to push that comprehension in a new direction.

title: ALGEBRA 2
description:
Algebra II [MAT-2002] [MAT-2002-1]

Faculty Name
Conjeeveram Srirangachari Rajan [cs.rajan@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The classical problems which the Greeks raised but

could not solve are the following: using ruler and compass constructions,

can one trisect any angle? can the cube of unit length be doubled and finally

can the circle be squared. To this, we can add the problems of explicitly solving higher

degree polynomial equations in one variable, just as it can be done for the quadratic

equation; or which regular n-gons can be constructed?

 

The solutions to this questions come from a study of

polynomial equations, what is known as field theory.

The answer given by Galois (Gauss, Abel and others) is to consider

the symmetries of the roots of a polynomial equation, bringing in

group theory and linear algebra.

 

If time permits, we may cover further topics oriented towards number theory or

geometry.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Prerequisites: Linear Algebra and Algebra I.

The reading material is the same as I had given for

Algebra I. Any good book on Algebra will cover the above

topics.

 

Here are some book recommendations:

1. Emil Artin: one of the first books on Galois theory from

one of the masters of the subject. All books from Emil Artin

are extremely readable. However this book has possibly no exercises and

the notation is slightly out of date.

 

2. Ian Stewart: Galois theory. A popular book and highly recommended online.

 

3. Steven H Weintraub: Galois theory. Another highly recommended online.

 

The books I had suggested last semester also are very good for learning

Galois theory and other aspects of Algebra that I may cover in the course.

For example, the books by Dummit and Foote, Jacobson, Artin,

Herstein, Lang, van der Waerden and many others will more or less

cover the above material.

Grading Rubric

Roughly 30% for homework; the rest split

between mid-terms and final.

Attendance Policy

Attendance is not compulsory but recommended. Note that the material I cover may

not be from one single book. Further I might place emphasis on some

topics and examples different from that available in books.

title: ELEMENTARY DIFFERENTIAL GEOMETRY
description:
Elementary Differential Geometry [MAT-3000] [MAT-3000-1]

Faculty Name
Pritam Ghosh [pritam.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course will serve as an introduction to the theory of differential geometry. Topics which will be covered include:

Topic 1) (1 week) Review of multivariable Calculus , Directional derivatives, Jacobians, Inverse function theorem, Local study of immersion and submersion, Smooth functions with compact support, Existence of solutions of ODE.

Topic 2) (3 weeks) Theory of curves - Smooth curves, tangents, curvature, torsion, planar curves, Frennet frame.

Topic 3) (5 weeks) Theory of surfaces - Manifold structure, First and second fundamental forms, Curvatures, Gauss' excellent theorem, Parallel transport and geodesics.

Topic 4) (4 weeks)  Integration on manifolds,  Gauss-Bonnet and other miscelleneous topics. 

Approximately one assignment every alternate week, roughly 12 - 15 problems in every set. Revise your Multivariable Calculus (especially the differentiation part) and Linear Algebra thoroughly before the semester begins.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Revise your Linear algebra and MVC thouroughly. 

Books for the course: 

1. M P. do Carmo: Differential Geometry of Curves and Surfaces, Prentice-Hall, 1976. (primary text)

2. A. Pressley: Elementary Differential Geometry, Springer, 2010. (primary text)

3) S. Kumaresan and G.Santhanam : An Expedition to Geometry. (special topics)

4) S. Kumaresan : A Course in Differential Geometry and Lie Groups. (special topics)

 

Grading Rubric

Assignments 40%

Midsem 30%

Final 30%

Attendance Policy

Not mandatory but stronly recommended.

title: FOURIER SERIES
description:
Fourier Series [MAT-3101] [MAT-3101-1]

Faculty Name
Rajendra Bhatia [rajendra.bhatia@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The course has two parts: Fourier Series and Finite Fourier Transforms. Both topics are at the heart of pure and applied mathematics.

The first part will begin with the history of the subject rooted in problems related to vibrations and heat flow. The solution of the problem via Fourier series, and questions about their convergence and divergence will be studied. This will be followed by some applications. Along with learning new material, this will be an opportunity to deepen our understandng of concepts learnt earlier in Real Analysis.

In the second part we will study Finite Fourier Transforms and Fast Fourier Transforms and their applications. This draws on concepts learnt in Linear Algebra and Matrix Analysis, and will also lead to a better understanding of some of that subject.

 

 

Learning Outcomes

At the end of the course students would have learnt Fourier Series and Finite Fourier Transforms, and seen concepts from Real Analysis and Limnear Algebra in action.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Students must have taken the Real Analysis course. They should also have taken the basic Linear Algebra course, and preferably the second course Linear Algebra and Matrix Analysis. Basics of complex numbers are also required.

The first part will closely follow

R. Bhatia, Fourier Series, Hindstan Book Agency (inexpensive paperbck edition).

The second part will draw upon

M. Frazier, Wavelets Through Linear Algebra, Springer.

Grading Rubric

A mixture of class tests and a final exam. Details will be discussed in class.

Attendance Policy

Regular attendance is encouraged, and is necessary for keeping up with the course.

title: TOPLOGY
description:
Topology [MAT-4100] [MAT-4100-1]

Faculty Name
Conjeeveram Srirangachari Rajan [cs.rajan@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course will be more of an introduction to some aspects of

Algebraic Topology, focussing especially on homology.

 

Algebraic Topology  and the language that comes with it is central to much of

modern mathematics, especially so

for the subjects of Geometry, Algebraic Geometry and Number theory. Completely

indispensable and integral to the development of these subjects.

 

Depending on the class, I will review some aspects of general topology, especially

that of quotient spaces. An early development in Algebraic Topology is a result going

back to Euler, on the alternating sums of number of vertices, edges and faces defined

by a graph. We will start by exploring these ideas, see how they lead to a classification

of surfaces and then consider generalizations of the theory. Along the way, we will also

study some geometric objects like the sphere, projective spaces, Grassmanians, etc. This

will necessitate the study of some relevant aspects of Algebra and Geometry.

One aspect of the course will

be give an introduction to homological algebra.

 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Algebra I, Analysis I. Multivariable calculus preferred (but we will

not use it). Preferable also to have had some exposure to topological

spaces (not essential, if required we will cover it in the initial lectures).

 

There are many good books on this subject. Most of them are comprehensive,

but we will cover only some part of the material.

 

0. V V Prasolov, Intuitive topology.  Supposed to be a good readable introduction.

 

1. E. Spanier, Algebraic Topology, an old classic relevant still today. A difficult book

but still stays as a reference. The chapter on simplicial complexes is well written.

 

2. Books by Massey, Dold, Greenberg and Harper, Vicks, Rotman, Tom Dieck,

Peter May, Hatcher, Bredon (Geometry and Topology) and many more out there.

Grading Rubric

As usual we will try to have

some homework, mid-term, final, etc. Depending on the

class strength, these might take the form of presentations, etc.

Attendance Policy

Attendance not compulsory but recommended.

The material I cover will not come from a single book.

title: LINEAR ALGEBRA
description:
Linear Algebra [MAT-1001/ CS-2210/ PHY-1001] [MAT-1001/ CS-2210/ PHY-1001-2]

Faculty Name
Gaurav Bhatnagar [gaurav.bhatnagar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Linear algebra is one of the most important parts of mathematics, perhaps as important or more than the Calculus. Peter Lax (NYU) has remarked: "If you can reduce a mathematical problem to linear algebra, you can most likely solve it". The introductory concepts (that we will study in this course) are easy to understand, but are powerful and apply in many contexts. 

The applications to various fields are too numerous to mention. Lets  just say that the modern world would not be so modern without the application of linear algebra,  nor would our understanding of the universe would be where it is now. And neither would mathematics be as developed if all kinds of mathematical objects are not studied using linear algebra.  

However, the course is mostly mathematical. Applications will be to understand some mathematical objects.The subject unfolds slowly over the semester. As you work through the semester, you learn how to extend your intuition of two and three dimensions to work in an n-dimensional space. At the same time, as the title of the main textbook reflects,  this course may be regarded as an introduction to abstract mathematics. So you learn how to apply logical arguments to prove statements.

Its a busy course requiring a lot of effort and enthusiasm. You have to be young and energetic and want to learn a lot very quickly. But why am I saying this? You are Ashoka students. Of course you are young and energetic and want to learn a lot very quickly!

Learning Outcomes

The syllabus in the course handbook is as follows.

Syllabus: Real vector spaces, subspaces, spanning sets, basis sets, dimension of a vector space.  Solution of a system of linear equations. Row space and column space of a matrix, rank of a matrix, elementary row and column operations of a matrix. Inversion of square matrices, rank factorization of a matrix. Properties of determinants. Linear transformations, range and null space of a linear transformation, rank-nullity theorem. Matrix representation of a linear transformation. Inner product spaces, normed linear spaces, examples of different normed linear spaces, orthonormal basis sets. Eigenvalues, eigenvectors, characteristic polynomials. Spectral theorem for real symmetric matrices. Singular value decompositions.

We are likely to do all the above for vector spaces over Complex numbers. The proof of the Spectral theorem is a little easier for this. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Text book:

Isaiah Lankham, Bruno Nachtergaele and Anne Schilling, Linear Algebra - As an Introduction to Abstract Mathematics, Free online text available from: 

https://www.math.ucdavis.edu/~anne/linear_algebra/

We will cover most of the book including Appendix A.

The course material is roughly from this book, but I may deviate considerably. 

Additional References.

You may find the following books helpful as supplementary reading in case something is not clear from the textbook.

1. S. H. Friedberg, A. J. Insel and L. E. Spence, Linear algebra, Pearson, 2015. (Good book for extensive explanations, lots of problems for you to make sure you have understood the topics.)

2. P. Bogacki, Linear Algebra, Concepts and Applications, AMS/MAA Textbooks, Vol 47, 2019. (Good for matrix examples.)

3. Gilbert Strang, Linear Algebra and its Applications, (4th or 5th edition). (The classic textbook. Covers a lot. At some point in your career, you should become familiar with it. Lectures are also available for these.)

4. T. Shifrin and M. R. Adams, Linear Algebra: A Geometric Approach, WH Freeman (2nd edition). (Nice book with a geometric flavor. Great for gaining intuition.)

5. Wikipedia is great for mathematics. 

6. I will hand out a problem set which includes (most of) Professor Bhatia's problems from a few years ago. 

Computer algebra system.

We will make extensive use of the computer algebra system SAGE. In the real world, Linear Algebra is done using many different numerical packages. However, we use a symbolic algebra package. SAGE is available at:

www.sagemath.org

Please install it before coming to class. Write to me in case of difficulties. There is a possibility of using it online too, but that has become very slow and irritating. It has to be used as a last resort.

Grading Rubric

There will be 10 quizzes (in lecture) (on occasion replaced by Assignments) (33.33% of grade),  2 midterms (in lecture) (33.33%) and a take home final (33.33%).  Midterms 1 and 2 are  in-class exams. More details will be provided on the first day of class. A max of 2 missed quiz scores can be replaced by average of rest.  

Attendance Policy

While there is no formal requirement to attend lectures and DS sessions, it may be a good idea to do so because we may deviate or add to the material in the textbook which may show up on quizzes and tests. In general, its easier to read the book when you know whats going on in the lectures. Further, there will be no makeup exams (Quizzes or midterms) and these will happen during class times. Usually for math courses expect to spend a minimum of 4-5 hours outside of class every week to keep up.

title: METRIC AND TOPOLOGICAL SPACES
description:
Metric and Topological Spaces [MAT-2026] [MAT-2026-1]

Faculty Name
Kumarjit Saha [kumarjit.saha@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The idea of this course to start with n-dimensional Euclidean spaces and extend the theory for general metric spaces. In, particular we will study in detail sequence spaces and function spaces. We will duscuss the notion continuity of a mapping from one metric space to another. Charaterization of compact subsets for general metric spaces will also be discussed. One of the goal of this course to enable you to extend your analysis on real number system for a general metric space. If time permits, general topological spaces also will be introduced. 

Learning Outcomes

In this course we will try to understand the following topics: Euclidean spaces, (general) metric spaces, normed linear spaces, examples of different normed linear spaces, sequence spaces, function spaces and general topological spaces. We will discuss open and closed sets, boundaries.

Continuous functions (as a mapping from a general metric space to another), Uniform continuity and equicontinuous families.

We will talk about the notions of connectedness and path connectedness for subsets of general metric spaces.

Completeness and separability (examples involving sequence spaces and function spaces), Baire category Theorem.

Compactness, characterization of compact spaces (as subsets of Euclidean spaces and general metric spaces). We will talk about Arzela Ascoli theorem which gives charaterization of compact subsets of function spaces.

Product spaces, Tychonoff’s theorem.  We will also cover the following topics: Functions of several variables, Inverse function theorem and Implicit function theorem.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Following books are suggested as references:

1. G. F. Simmons: Introduction to Topology and Modern Analysis, Tata McGraw- Hill, 2013.

2. S. Kumaresan: Topology of metric spaces, Narosa. 
3. M. O. Searcoid: Metric Spaces, Springer, 2007. 
4. S. Shirali and H. L. Vasudeva: Metric Spaces, Springer, 2006.

Grading Rubric

Will be mentioned when course starts.

Attendance Policy

Will be mentioned when course starts.

title: CALCULUS
description:
Calculus [MAT-1000] [MAT-1000-1]

Faculty Name
Guhan Venkat [guhan.venkat@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This will be a first course in Calculus (not Pre-Calculus). While the course will be rigorous mathematically, we shall also explore applications of the Theory of Calculus to everyday problems in Economics and Physics such as Optimisation Problems and Classical Mechanics (time permitting).

Learning Outcomes

Syllabus:-  Number systems. Sequences and series. Functions of a real variable. Graphs of functions. Limits and continuity. Differentiation. Mean value theorem. L’Hospital rule. Maclaurin and Taylor series. Curve tracing. Riemann integral. Definite and indefinite integrals. Fundamental theorem of calculus. Applications of differential and integral calculus in areas such as optimisation and mechanics (time permitting).

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Textbooks :-

1.  Stewart, Early transcendentals (Calculus), Cengage Publishers, 2012.

Other material will be made available in class.

Quiz 1 : Feb 2nd 

Quiz 2 : Feb 16th

Mid-term Exam : March 2nd

Quiz 3 : March 23rd

Quiz 4 : April 6th

Final Exam : 7th - 13th May (one of the days in the exam week)

30% each for Final and Mid-term exam and 10% each for the quizzes (Best 4 of 5 quizzes will be considered).

title: ELLIPTIC CURVES AND CRYPTOGRAHY
description:
Elliptic Curves and Cryptography [MAT-4030] [MAT-4030-1]

Faculty Name
Guhan Venkat [guhan.venkat@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course will be suitable for 3rd and 4th year Mathematics students. The first half of the course will focus on the theory of Elliptic curves from a Number Theoretic perspective. The second half of the course will focus on algebraic aspects of Cryptography with focus on Elliptic Curve Cryptography (ECC) as well as computational aspectes of Elliptic curves using SAGE/PARI GP.

Learning Outcomes

 Basic theory of Elliptic curves: Weierstrass equation, doubly periodic func- tions, group law, torsion points, Elliptic curves over finite fields, Congruent Number Problem and its connection to Elliptic curves, Elliptic Curve Cryptography.

 

Pre-requisites : Algebra 1. Complex Analysis and Algebra 2 are recommended but not necessary. Students who don't have sufficient background in Algebra 2 or Complex Analysis must be willing to learn necessary background by themselves as and when necessary.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Textbooks 

1. Elliptic curves, Modular forms and Their L-functions, Alvaro Lozano-Robledo, Student Mathematical Library, AMS.

2. Lawrence C. Washington, Elliptic Curves : Number Theory and Cryptography (Second Edition), Chapman & Hall/CRC 2008.

3. Neal Koblitz, Introduction to Elliptic Curves and Modular Forms (Third Edition), GTM Vol. 97, Springer-Verlag 199

 

Grading Rubric

Will be announced in class.

Attendance Policy

No attendance policy.

title: APPLIED STOCHASTIC PROCESSES
description:
Applied Stochastic Processes [MAT-4101] [MAT-4101-1]

Faculty Name
Kumarjit Saha [kumarjit.saha@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This is a higher level probability course where we will learn thories and applications of some stochastic processes, e.g., which are commonly used in practise.  

Learning Outcomes

Rough plan is the following (it can be modified slightly if need arises):

1. Discussion of different convergence concepts and basics of probabilistic measure theory, Borel \sigma field on \R and on general metric spaces.

2. Notion of convergence of distributions on general metric spaces (Portmanteau theorem)

3. introduction to theories some stochastic processes (viz.):

    a) Markov chain

   b) Martingales

4. Examples (rather applications) of these processes: Branching process (if time permits) and Brownian motion.

 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

1. Topology of metric spaces : S Kumaresan

2. Weak convergence of probbaility measures : Patrick Billingsley

3. Probability with martingales : David J Williams

4. Brownian motion : Yuval Peres, Peter Morter

fullName: MS-1201, MEDIA, CULTURE & SOCIETY , TISHA SRIVASTAV
title: MEDIA, CULTURE & SOCIETY ,
description:
Media, Culture and Society [MS-1201] [MS-1201-1]

Faculty Name
Chahat Rana [chahat.rana_tf@ashoka.edu.in] ,Tisha Srivastav [tisha.srivastav@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

MS 1201 MEDIA, CULTURE & SOCIETY   TISHA SRIVASTAV, CHAHAT RANA    11.50 AM – 1.20 PM  TUESDAY & THURSDAY COURSE CAP 50   

TF (Chahat Rana) takes 3 Discussion Sections

This gateway course has been created to recognize the utmost need for media literacy in contemporary times. It aims to give students a broad based understanding of mass media form, be it the newspaper or social media or cinema.  It introduces key communication theorists who help reflect on the cultures, within which media emerge in particular ways. An understanding of media in terms of attitudes, consumption and engagement with communities and society, forms the final part of the course.

There will be one field trip as part of the course. The date for this will be mutually arrived at.

Students not only reflect on ways of seeing and listening, they get to explore how our everyday engagements with media are connected with broader economic, political, ideological, and social contexts. It also introduces students to all the four streams offered in media studies courses.

 No Prerequisites. This is a mandatory gateway course for all Media Studies Minor and Concentration students.  

 

Learning Outcomes

Media Literacy basics will fall in place and students can assess their own interest level in Media Studies more accurately.

Students will be able to better choose course streams within the Media Studies list after doing this gateway course.

title: CONTENT ANALYSIS AND COMMUNICATION RESEARCH METHODS
description:
Content Analysis and Communication Research Methods [MS-3215/ PSY-3153] [MS-3215/ PSY-3153-1]

Faculty Name
Purnima Mehrotra [purnima.mehrotra@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Content Analysis and Audience Response: Understanding Behaviour Change through Communication How does one formulate the “right” questions? What are the ways and means of information retrieval, processing, and organization? How does one summarize and articulate the information or "research results" in a lucid manner? All of these are important questions that this course will help you address. Students of communication studies need to develop a strong understanding of and ability to use research methods as it is a practical and important skill that will be required in further studies, internships and future professional positions.

This course will provide an overview of research methods used in communication with a specific focus on content analysis. Content Analysis is the systematic and objective analysis of message characteristics and is one of the fastest growing methods used in communication research. It is a powerful tool because it enables one to examine a wide ranging set of social and cultural patterns in communication that are often subtle or difficult to detect through other means. While outlining commonly used communication research methods, this course will provide an overview of the potential and the challenges of conducting content analyses, as well as the specific procedures relevant to carrying out this type of research so that you will be able to design and execute such research independently.

Learning Outcomes

Students will understand the various methods employed in communication research. They will learn to analyze media messages, including audio/video, print, and visuals.Learn about sampling, validity and reliability, category construction, calculation of intercoder reliability,and analysis of data.
Each student will undertake a research project using this methodology.

title: UNDERSTANDING URBAN POVERTY
description:
Understanding Urban Poverty [MS-2811/ SOA-2507/ POL-2104] [MS-2811/ SOA-2507/ POL-2104-1]

Faculty Name
Neha Dixit [neha.dixit@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

MONDAY/ WEDNESDAY : 11:50 - 13:20 

More than 25 per cent of the urban population is below the poverty line. By 2030, urbanisation in India is projected to reach 50 per cent. This intensified complex, urban issues including land, water and sanitation. The course will focus on looking at socio-economic disparities in Urban India. Key teachings will be navigating geographical landscapes, government bureaucracies and hierarchies of resources and trauma in urban spaces.
Through lectures, readings, films, news reports and assessment of a wide range of issues like affordable housing, unequal distribution of resources-electricity, public spaces, unorganised workforce, gender gap and more importantly, a lack of representation and voice in framing of urban policies, students will be taught how to report and analyse urban poverty in an ethical, comprehensive and impactful manner.

title: FILM THEORY
description:
Film Theory [ENG-3801/ MS-3481] [ENG-3801/ MS-3481-1]

Faculty Name
Abir Bashir Bazaz [abir.bazaz@ashoka.edu.in] ,Madhura Kar [madhura.kar_ma23@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

What is cinema? This classic question posed by early film theory will guide our survey of theoretical approaches to the study of film from its beginnings in the 1910s to the present. We will study major film theories such as the realist film theory, formalist film theory, auteur theory, feminist film theory, apparatus theory, semiotic and psychoanalytic film theory but also turn to film-philosophical approaches to cinema. We will be discussing the debates and arguments that have shaped film studies and situate film theory in the context of larger intellectual movements such as Phenomenology, Russian Formalism, Marxism, Existentialism and Poststructuralism. We will discuss major film theories in relation to different film genres, film movements and national cinemas. Film theorists studied will include Hugo Munsterberg, Béla Balázs, Walter Benjamin, Rudolph Arnheim, Sergei Eisenstein, Siegfried Kracauer, Andre Bazin, Jean-Louis Baudry, Christian Metz, Laura Mulvey and Gilles Deleuze. Film screenings will include the works of Sergei Eisenstein, Chris Marker, Terrence Malick, Max Ophuls, Abbas Kiarostami, Paul Thomas Anderson, Agnes Varda, Ang Lee and Chang-dong Lee. Students who opt for this course must be familiar with basic terms and concepts in film studies (such as montage, mise-en-scène, continuity editing) or have taken an introductory course in film studies.

title: ART OF DOCUMENTARY FILMMAKING
description:
Art of Documentary Filmmaking [MS-3061] [MS-3061-1]

Faculty Name
Nakul Singh Sawhney [nakul.sawhney@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

FRIDAY ((15:00- 16:30) ( 16:40 - 18:00)

While classes will be held on Fridays, documentary film screenings will be conducted by the TA every Saturday during the course duration. 

15 students ( Media Lab based course)  

Students who have done the courses, Introduction to Audio Video Production (Course Code: MS 1001-1), Storytelling in the Digital Age (Course MS- 3051/ CW- 2051) are highly advised to take up this course. 

Alternatively, students who have prior experience or training in audio-visual production can also join. We will need samples of past work as evidence of previous work.

This thirteen-week documentary filmmaking course is an intensive and practical course that equips students with the fundamental skills and focuses on the challenges of the documentary genre, such as working with people and filming reality.

It is designed to improve student understanding, knowledge and practice in the following areas:


An understanding of various genres of documentary films and its different forms. Distinguishing between news features, social media videos and documentary film format. The ability to research effectively, and develop and structure proposals. Gain the knowledge and skills to visualise a film, sound recording, non-linear editing, sound design and other elements of post-production. Build an appreciation of the importance of narrative and storytelling in documentary filmmaking and developing a voice as a documentary storyteller.

The objective of the course is to teach students the art of documentary filmmaking and to instruct students through a strict regimen consisting of lectures, hands-on workshops, and supervised editing to excel in the creative art of documentary storytelling.

 

Week 1- 

Watching and analysing feature length documentary films and short to medium length documentary films

 

Week 2- 

Watching and analysing short to medium length documentary films, anywhere between 15 mins to 45 mins. 

 

Students will be divided in groups for the films they will work on. The size of the group could vary from 3 to 5. The size of each group would depend on how many students will enroll for the course. Each group will have to start thinking of a topic they wish to make their film on. 

 

Week 3- 

Watching and analysing short documentary films (anywhere between 3 to 10 minutes) 

 

Each group will present their topics to class. Each topic will be fleshed out. How to research the topic, discuss what is to be looked out for. The approach, in terms of narrative, how to visualise their films etc. 

 

Week 4- 

Watching and analysing short documentary films (anywhere between 3 to 10 minutes)

 

Each group will finalise their proposals. Shoot schedules will be drawn out. As an exercise, each group will also have to prepare rough budgets for their shoots. Students will also be told reference films which they will watch to find references on how they can shoot their own films. In case groups have to shoot interviews, the interviews will be prepared. 

 

Week 5- 

Groups will start shooting their films. The rushes will be watched, transferred and discussed. 

 

Week 6- 

Groups will continue shooting their films. The rushes will be watched and discussed. Those who have completed shooting will start logging their footage. The process of logging will be explained. 

 

Week 7- 

Each group will start preparing their paper edits and start working on their line ups on the edit machines. 

 

Week 8- 

Groups will continue with their line-ups and begin their rough cut. Again, through the edit process, different films and scenes from films will be shown as references to help them understand various narrative forms. 

 

Week 9-  

Groups will continue with their edits and aim to finish their rough cuts by this week. 

 

In case, students feel they need to do some patchwork shoot, then that needs to be planned as well. 

 

Week 10- 

Start finalising edits. 

Finish all patchwork shoots by this week. 

 

Week 11- 

Finalise edits.  Start subtitling and graphics/ text plates/ opening and end credits.

 

Start sound-production. Start basic sound levelling and cleaning up and start sound design. Groups that have voice overs in their films, will record them this week.

 

Week 12- 

Continue with sound post-production. Groups that have background scores in their films, will record them this week. Finish sound design in this class. 

 

Week 13- 

Finalise sound design. Review the films one last time and take final exports. 

 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Students who have done the courses, Introduction to Audio Video Production (Course Code: MS 1001-1), Storytelling in the Digital Age (Course MS- 3051/ CW- 2051) are highly advised to take up this course. 

Alternatively, students who have prior experience or training in audio-visual production can also join. We will need samples of past work as evidence of previous work.

Grading Rubric

1. Attendance- 15% (special focus on attendance for shoots)

2. Class participation- 15%

3. Class assignments which include Project pre-production (includes pre-shoot script/ concept note, conceiving your film etc.)- 20% 

4. Quality and efficiency of shoot- 20%

5. Rough cut and final edit- 20%

Please note the grading rubric assigned by this professor:

80 and above- Grade A 

75-79- Grade A-

70-74- B+

65-69- B

60-64- B-

55-59- C+

50-54- C

45-49- C-

40-44- D+

35-39- D

30-34- D- 

 

6. Sound post-production- 10%

Attendance Policy

Students will not be allowed to miss more than 3 classes.

title: CINEMAS OF INDIA
description:
Cinemas of India [MS-3451/ VA-3019] [MS-3451/ VA-3019-1]

Faculty Name
Aakshi Magazine [aakshi.magazine@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

 MS 3451 Cinemas of India  Aakshi Magazine

 Monday and Thursday 11.50- 13:20 Course Cap: 20

This course is interested in exploring the cinematic language of Indian cinema -  its nuances, pleasures, possibilities, limitations. It is divided into four units - each explores a particular film style or industrial and production context. The units are - Melodrama, Parallel cinema, Bollywood and Independent cinematic practices. We will watch selected films that will help us understand these concepts. Engaging with the narrative style, formal elements, industrial and social context of the chosen films, at the end of the course we will hope to have a nuanced understanding of the broad category that is “Indian cinema”.

Students will be required to watch films every week before class (on some weeks, there might be 2 films) and read film scholarship on Indian cinema. Some familiarity with basic film studies concepts will be helpful, though not a prerequisite to sign up for the course.



 

 

Learning Outcomes

Develop skills in film analysis and criticism

Introduction to Indian cinema

Grading Rubric

2 assignments (One mid term essay and one end term essay) 

1 class presentation

Class participation 

 

Attendance Policy

3 excused absences allowed

title: WRITING NARRATIVE NON-FICTION: CRAFT & PRACTICE
description:
Writing Narrative Non-fiction: Craft and Practice [MS-2241/ VA-2013] [MS-2241/ VA-2013-1]

Faculty Name
Natasha Badhwar [natasha.badhwar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

A short, succinct description of creative nonfiction is: True stories, well told. As a genre, narrative non-fiction relies on identifying the core questions and conducting deep research and interviews to seek answers and connections. The craft borrows from the toolkit of fiction to create compelling, honest writing that resonates with readers and kindles their curiosity. 
This practical course will include reading and writing of reported narratives, profiles, first person essays, reviews, travel, food, history, films, true crime and memoir. The focus will be on both substance and style.

Learning Outcomes

Guiding students with tips, prompts, exercises and analysis to learn and experiment with form and write visually. Students will be encouraged to find their voice and create honest, evocative, publishable essays.

title: ANTHROPOLOGY OF MASS MEDIATION
description:
Anthropology of Mass Mediation [SOA-3095/ SOA-6107/ MS-3251] [SOA-3095/ SOA-6107/ MS-3251-1]

Faculty Name
Kathryn Collins Hardy [kathryn.hardy@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Mass mediation is sometimes seen as a destructive force, driving out "authentic culture" and homogenizing thought. Conversely, some recent opinions have seen mass mediation as a pure source of grassroots political expression. In this course, we will complicate both these extremes. We shall see how media technologies do not just transmit or allow access to "culture," but are themselves cultural practices. This course considers film, television, radio, and various online media forms to explore the social processes and practices of mass mediation. Using the tools of anthropology, cultural studies, and media studies, we will explore a diverse range of ideas, objects, and forms of sociality engendered by technological mediation, as well as the material practices and processes through which meaning moves.

title: VISUALISING THE MAJOR
description:
Visualising the Major [VA-2050/ MS-2871] [VA-2050/ MS-2871-1]

Faculty Name
Vishwajyoti Ghosh [vishwajyoti.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Introduction: Visualising in the academic space

In these times as one’s reading engagement is rapidly shrinking into our mobile handsets, especially in the post pandemic world, it is the interaction with the visual which forming a new reading relationship. Be it on an interest-based website or platform, or the social media platforms that are constantly pushing towards a stringer visual language. As the schism between the written word and visuals are challenged, often the text is now the new image. In these times visual articulation is making a strong space for itself in every form of information or content, be it journalism, daily expression and even academics. In a post Covid world, much of the health information has moved to a visual plane, similar to explaining economics to the common man amidst the turbulence, or the Refugee crisis in Syria, and many others. The visual approach is now the new language of communication across the spectrum to make an engaged form of communication, information and understanding.

With the advent of social media and personalization of content consumption, visual communication has been fast and consistently evolving. From the black board in the classroom to the white board animations on social media, from informative visual pamphlets to educational comics, the blending of the academic information and the visual articulation, a new platform for educational dissemination and discussion has emerged both in the digital and analogue spaces.

The new forms of information, whether through print or the digital, through picture books to animations to pocket sized visual bites on the mobile, the new visual based forms have found both audience and acceptance. This has now brought forth a demand for content makers and practitioners who are willing to engage with it visually in terms of practice. In the visual world we live now, it is a form with a moving language now blending with technology. This course will blend these influences into ones’ own academic major to create content that helps demystifying the respective discipline through visual content lime comics, graphic narratives, zines and basic animations to reach out to a wider audience.

Visual led approach for awareness building, information sharing and education has now evolved both as a form and a medium that is now used in every discipline, as an independent genre both in the online and offline worlds. Today the visual form has drawn inspiration and been influenced by multiple disciplines like painting, filmmaking, animations, the printed text, gaming pushing it to the next gen ux/ui platforms. It’s this multi-disciplinary influence and framework this course seeks to work with.

This course seeks to blend one’s academic interest with the omnipresent visual world through storytelling, visual narratives, blending academics and practice with a research led inter-disciplinary approach.

What this course is about

Exploring possibilities of visual based information dissemination, visual discussion and engagement, this course plans to engage with extending ones’ academic learning to visual based practice. Exploring the genre as a tool and a form that can be incorporated in one’s individual academic discipline. This approach can help the students in articulating their learnings, research and storytelling in multi-disciplinary formats. In these times when visual storytelling is a pervasive and a popular form of information, opinion and communication, the practice-based engagement will help students open up their learnings to a multi-disciplinary articulation as new age academic content creators.

Course Modules:

The preliminary module of this course of 2 weeks will be a curated overview of the published, popular and the prevalent and emerging forms of visual based information through different genres and mediums. The idea would be exploring the diversity of practice across the globe and the processes involved in content creation of such types. The idea here will be to discuss the forms and works to bring new practice-based influences and ideas, their working process and explore the architecture of visual practice in these works.

Week I & II: Present /discuss works of visual based academic information through presentation, film clips. Present /discuss relevant visual narratives, academic comics, mobile episodes, comic strips, web shows and academic narratives in social media.

This will be a presentation and discussion-based approach discussing the presented works in detail and the stories behind making many of these works. The idea will be to discuss the journey of the works from the intent to execution and the struggles and transformations that make the narrative in the final output. For example, Logicomix, a graphic novel that discusses Bertrand Rusell’s works and philosophy through a comic, The Beginner series across various subjects, Medical comics and such that are some of the well-articulated works closer to this course.

This will be followed by 3 weeks to ideate, research, explore ideas of student’s interest in their areas of discipline followed by field work, data collection and research on the ground. This will include visual data collection, interviews, recording, documentation and conceptualizing the idea based on the research.

Documentation of the research will be followed to process and distill the findings to create the core conceptual idea and be presented in the studio sessions for the benefit of collective brainstorming and discussions. These discussions with fellow classmates will led to an inter-disciplinary ideation and conceptualization, moving closer to shape and sharpen the core project ideas of the students. The students will also be expected to share the processing of their research findings along with their influences and inspirations.

Moving on from research the course will discuss the working process of creating a visual content using multiple influences of form and genres. Depending on the student’s interest and academic major, this 1-week study will include detailed discussions on the various possibilities of the form i.e. different forms that can be explored - doodle narratives, zines, comics, mobile based narratives, photo comics, design, layouts, page architecture, typography, sequential storytelling and the work process involved in each, enabling the students to make informed choices in sync with their ideas.

The following week the students will be expected to present their ideas and preliminary drafts as scribbles/ sketches with fellow batchmates, followed by open discussions, suggestions and ideation to evolve a clear understanding to flesh out the final narrative.

Each student/ project will be further exposed to similar works through display and in-depth discussions on influences and ideas related to the project to lend a visual articulation, enabling the student to take one’s academic learnings further.

Finally, the semester will move to its last 6 weeks to create 1 visual based academic content.

A mid-sem draft presentation will be shared in the studio to display the work in progress after 2 weeks then followed by the final 4 weeks or the end of the semester, ready for display, presentation and production. Studio presence in these weeks will be a must.

Segmented timeline:

Weeks 1-2: Discuss works of visual based academic information through presentation, film clips, relevant visual narratives, academic comics, mobile episodes, comic strips, web shows and academic narratives in social media.

Weeks 3-5: Ideate, research, explore academic themes and its relevant visual mediums.

Weeks 7: Conceptualize through possibilities of form, information, medium, architecture etc.

Weeks 8: Presentation of idea followed by discussion on similar ideas & influences.

Weeks 9-14: Final completion with a mid-semester presentation in week 11.

Total Weeks: 14

Learning Outcomes

The semester will be a segmented flow from exploring multiple visual forms and practice like academic graphic novels, mobile episodes, zines, comic strips extending to a practice- based approach in sync with one’s academic major.

Through the semester students will learn to negotiate between the visuals and the academic world and dive deep in the process of creating their individual content. The students will also explore and practice the modes and methods of visual practice through their chosen forms, styles and influences. The expected outcome for the students will be practice based learning to develop their visual storytelling language, exploring the fluid connections between academic learning and visual articulation.

Output Participation:Though the output will be individual, the process of production will be based on field research, short studio collaborations and conversations with subject experts and work-in-progress presentations at regular intervals as discussed above.

Course Deliverables: Every student will be expected to develop, produce 1 research-based short visual story on the lines of graphic narrative/ comic.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Prerequisites: Basic academic research based on one’s Major, writing, very basic drawing/ doodling, basic research and mobile photography.

Preliminary Reading List:

Understanding Comics / Scott Mcloud/ William Morrow Paperbacks; Reprint edition (27 April 1994)/ ISBN-10: ‎006097625X

Habibi / Craig Thompson/ Pantheon Graphic Library

Journalism / Joe Sacco/ Jonathan Cape (14 June 2018)/ ISBN-10: ‎178733130X

Explained Series / Netflix

Logicomix an Epic Search for Trurh: An Epic Search for Truth/ Apostolos Doxiadia, Christos H. Papadimitriou  

http://darryl-cunningham.blogspot.com/

Mom's Cancer/ Brian Fies

Beginners Series / Pantheon Documentary comics

Grading Rubric

20% for quality and depth of research

20% for themes and ideas

40% for visualization and production

20% for participation, articulation and engagement in studio sessions

Attendance Policy

90% minimum attendance

title: DRAWING AS EXTENDED PLAY
description:
Drawing as Extended Play [VA-3025/ MS-3253] [VA-3025/ MS-3253-1]

Faculty Name
Anni Kumari [anni.kumari@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

 

Basic drawing/ photography and research skills are welcome.

This course examines the intersections between drawing and photography, drawing and video, drawing and performance, and drawing and popular culture. We will be looking at the practice of four contemporary artists, including Chitra Ganesh, Nalini Malani, Nikhil Chopra, and Pushpamala N in trying to understand how strands of history, memory, mythology, iconography, ethnography, and identity become visible through their image-making process. We will try to uncover how individual artistic practices are shaped by popular imagery, art history, and visual culture. 

In thinking of every day through the prism of theatrical reality, the course encourages inquiry about how can drawings and the act of drawing itself is a dialogue about provisionality, uncertainty, and change. How do artists and artistic explorations address issues of meaning-making and shared history, politics, and culture?

How does the process of repetition, layering, overlapping, erasure, and incision transform an image, leading to alternative perspectives about how we perceive and engage with the known? How can we tell the same story in different media, material, and socio-cultural contexts?

Recognizing the importance of contradictions, ambiguity, and serendipity as integral to processes of meaning-making, students have the flexibility to make interventions that can vary from being poetic, polemic, dramatic, metaphorical, provocative, or incisive. You are encouraged to borrow from processes of handmade cinema posters, comics book, experimental theatre, set design, printmaking, photo performance, etc.

By taking figures and forms out of their familiar settings and putting them in a ‘fluid’ and fantastical environment where seemingly unrelated ideas respond to one another, the course encourages students to attempt blurring of boundaries between fiction and reality.

Modules

Module 1: Narrating and re-narrating

Duration-3 weeks

Class exercises will include the study of selected Kalighat paintings, Amar Chitra Katha, hand-painted posters of early Indian cinema, and the viewing of works from the early 20th-century experimental theatre. Students will be introduced to processes of printmaking, graffiti, and visual storytelling (graphic novels/comics books)

Materials required: Cartridge Sheets, Graded pencils (B, 2B, and 4B), Indian ink, Charcoal & Watercolours

References to Artists and their works: comics book series of Chitra Ganesh; site-specific drawings and installations of Nalini Malani

Assignment 1: Submission of a minimum of 6 drawings as a culmination of class exercises

Module 2: Performing the Image

Duration -4 weeks

Class exercises will involve researching archives; visit to the National Museum and the National Gallery of Modern Art (NGMA), Delhi

Frameworks: Situating the body; masquerading and seduction; entry and exit points; points of intersections; colonial history and Euro-centric sensibilities; the protagonist and the provocateur

References to Artists and their works: Ethnographic series of photo-performances by Pushpamala N; drawing-based performances by Nikhil Chopra

Assignment 2: Submission of a photo book/artist book

Module 3: Collective Project

Duration -6 weeks

Students are expected to work on a collective project drawing from the experience of engaging with the archives, devising their own strategies and methodologies of engaging with space, material, and moment.

Learning Outcomes
  • Familiarity with histories of image making, reproduction, and consumption of images in the form of popular media.
  • Introduction to drawing as a visual language with trans-disciplinary possibilities. 
  • Insight into how/ what individual artistic sensibilities lend to and borrow from mass media and visual culture
  • Media Studies students will get an insight into the practice of drawing, popular culture and visual media.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Reading List

Pinney, C. (2011). Photography and Anthropology. United Kingdom: Reaktion Books.

Pinney, C. (2008). The Coming of Photography in India. London: British Library.

Jain, J. (1999). Kalighat Painting: Images from a Changing World. India: Mapin Pub.

Indian Art, an Overview. (2003). India: Rupa & Company.

Archer, W. G. (1953). Bazaar Paintings of Calcutta. United Kingdom: H.M. Stationery Office.

A Companion to Indian Cinema. (2022). United Kingdom: Wiley.

Gokulsing, K. M., Dissanayake, W. (1998). Indian popular cinema: a narrative of cultural change. India: Trentham Books.

Amar Chitra Katha: The Ultimate Collection. (2015). India: Amar Chitra Katha Pvt Limited.
