fullName: VA-3018/MS-2239, ON PHOTOGRAPHY: HISTORIES, THEORIES, PRACTICE, SRAMAN MUKHERJEE AND RAKHI PESWANI
title: ON PHOTOGRAPHY: HISTORIES, THEORIES, PRACTICE, SRAMAN MUKHERJEE AND RAKHI PESWANI,
description:
On Photography: Histories, Theories, and Practices [VA-3018/ MS-2239/ SOA-3106] [VA-3018/ MS-2239/ SOA-3106-1]

Faculty Name
Rakhi Peswani [rakhi.peswani@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sraman Mukherjee [sraman.mukherjee@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course will bring together image making histories, concerns, theories and practices, based on photographic techniques and technologies. The course will comprehensively introduce
proto-photographic methods and re-trace those with modern and contemporary material as well as some nineteenth and twentieth century cultural reactions and theories of photographic
image-forms. Considering its interdisciplinary nature, the media of photography will be introduced and explored through its social and cultural histories, contemporary usage as well as creative possibilities, bringing in perspectives from Art History, Visual Culture as well as artistic practice of the form.

Detailed description: 

Instructors: Rakhi Peswani, Sraman Mukherjee

Class timing: Monday and Wednesday – 11:50 am -1:20pm  

Course Pre-requisites for students (if any) :Curiosity and interest in photography history or practices. Any VA practice courses whether elective or gateway, preferred. Media Studies students with an interest in still photography are encouraged to apply as well.

Details of Course Modules along with readings for every module:

Module 1: Proto-photography techniques and histories:

This module will emphasise the early techniques and technologies that led to the invention of the photographic camera as we know it.

Various histories of image making will be excavated to understand the concepts of photography.

This module will also delve into the interdisciplinary nature of photography, the relation of art and science, its quality of light sensitivity, differences in technique and  technology, and the  impact photography had in shaping global modernity.  

      Proto-photography and various techniques of image making:

Fading of a color or a surface due to light as reaction or creation of an image due to light sensitivity.

Camera Obscura

Camera Lucida

Proto-photographic methods and image making in oil painting- development of Single Point (Linear) Perspective.

Linear perspective and development of photography

Tableaux Vivant for painting- history painting, Caravaggio and baroque light.

Shroud of Turin and the ‘miraculous’ image form.

Readings:

Mike Ware- Proto Photography and the Shroud of Turin

Peter Galassi – Before Photography

Artists’ references:

Single Point Perspective-

Some paintings, drawings and images of Masaccio, Giotto, Durer, Raphael, Caravaggio,

Cyanotype and Daguerreotype:

Anna Atkins, Henry Talbot- Cyanotypes. Louise Daguerre.

             Practice exercise :

Practice Workshop - Making Cyanotype images.

1 day- 3 hours. VA studio.

Assignment 1, create 4-5 image forms using any one or two proto-photographic methods introduced in class. 

The assignment will be based on experimenting and producing images with the aid of tools that seemingly appear familiar or simplistic.

Use some or any of the methods as tools to create 4-5 images and reflect (write an essay) on the experience, technique the outcome of the images, especially considering what are the significant markers of making images in such ways? what kind of aesthetic attitude or aesthetic form does such a method entail? 

Alternate assignment  – Cyanotype workshop exploring photo-chemicals and sun exposures to create image forms.

(Considerations of Dark room, safe light, 2 D and 3D image forms, imagination and image creation. )

Module 2: Photography as Representation and as Reproduction

This module will explore early and mid 20th C photography, through its defiing features of reproduction and representation.

Both these tropes will be explored to understand how photographic images played a role in the political, social, cultural shaping of individuality, modernity, urbanism, and nationalism. 

Readings:

Walter Benjamin (1931) - Little History of Photography

Walter Benjamin (1936) – The Work of Art in the Age of Mechanical Reproduction

Artists References:

Louise Dagguere, Edward Muybridge, Henry talbot, Karl Blossfeldt, David Octavius Hill, Julia Margaret Cameron, Victor Hugo, Felix Nadar., August Sander, Man Ray, Laslo Moholy Nagy,  Sasha Stone, Henri Cartier Bresson, Eugene Atget, Raghu Rai,

Practice exercise :

Assignment 2: Making a Photo Essay-

Representation, Reproduction, Sequentiality and Narration 

Using some of the most basic aspects of photographic form, representation and reproduction, construct a sequential arrangement of photo images that shape a narrative of your choosing. 

Early Photography had its claim in indexicality- a 'true' 'impression' of an object or event that has existed in front of the camera lens. While photographic images stand for real/truth of an image, ie, 'this exists' in a moment in time, it is also a framing device; it is an apparatus that lends itself to re-presentation and reproduction of an image. 

While a still image captures the fleeting momentary aspect of a world we live in, it represents this moment in specific ways. It reproduces this moment, frames it and imbues it with the subjectivity of the photographer. 

It is this aspect of photography that this assignment explores, especially in relation to early photographic folios, albums and other incunabula as Walter Benjamin points out to us.

Note:  Sequentiality and Repetition could be utilised to hold certain directorial vision or poetic aspects to the narrative. Also you could utilise the inherent qualities of a photograph- that a photograph manages to capture a fleeting moment of a second (shutter speeds), as well as varying qualities of light (aperture);  it captures certain frames that human eye cannot capture, including a point of view where human eye may not be able to reach.) 

Module 3: Photography and Identities:

This module will address the complex lines of the real and the fictional in relation to photographic images. The two readings will address the forms and formations of identity and the political nature of representation, distribution and circulation of photographic images.

The module will emphasise on aspects of photography that spill into the amateur, the cinematic, and the everyday. Its ubiquitous aspects will be explored through various lenses.

The practice exercise will be a way for students to address the complex space of creating meanings and identities through photographs.

            Tableaux Vivant and Photography.   

Photography and Anthropology,

Archival Practices and Photography.

Artists References:

Hippolyte Bayard,  Marcel Duchamp, Homai Vyarawalla, Helmut Newton, N. Pushpamala, Cindy Sherman, Sheba Chachi, Annie Leibovitz, Robert Mapplethorpe, Jitish Kallat

Readings:

            Christopher Pinney  (1997) - Camera Indica          Chapter- Chamber of Dreams

            Susan Sontag   (1973)           On Photography          Chapter- On Melancholy

Practice exercise:

Assignment 3: Shifting from the premise of photography as that representing a reality, create a series of images that provide a convincing impression of a construction and framing of a tableau. Use lights, props, models, or any required additional elements to create a ‘subject’ of description through photography.

Bibliography of further readings

Additional reading:

Roland Barthes (1980)-  Camera Lucida- Reflections on Photography

Christopher Pinney (2004): Photos of the Gods : The Printed Image and Political Struggle in India

Susan Sontag (1977)-  On Photography

John Berger (1972) – Ways of Seeing

 Aileen Blaney and Chinar Shah (2018): Photography in India from archives to Contemporary Practice

Details of grading rubric

Cumulative grading through three assignments. 

Each assignment will have components of practice plus one written essay based on a verbal or image prompt (Time frame : 4 weeks for each assignment.)

Each assignment will have a historical and theoretical framework to generate creative and investigative processes in the assignment.

Each assignment will have modules of a written essay and a practice oriented work. The rubrics will be : 

40% practice

·      Techniques in crafting of an image,

·      Image structure and composition,

·      Thematic concerns

40% essay

title: STORYTELLING IN THE DIGITAL AGE
description:
Storytelling in the Digital Age [MS-3051/ CW-2051/ VA-2015] [MS-3051/ CW-2051/ VA-2015-1]

Faculty Name
Natasha Badhwar [natasha.badhwar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course will focus on the creative process of using digital technology as a medium and a tool of narrating personal histories. We will create podcasts and videos using apps and software, but more importantly our own talent and skill with scripting, drawing, interview, monologue, multimedia visualization, videography, design and editing. 


AIM: The aim of this course is two-fold. Students will experiment with form using multimedia tools to combine audio, images, and video clips to tell a story. They will learn to create digital stories that explain a concept, make an argument, reflect on a personal experience and retell a family or community history. 
Through workshops and targeted assignments, each student will be encouraged to craft personal narratives that delve into conflicts of identity and privilege and lead to a deeper understanding of one’s own location in the intersecting grid of socio-economic, cultural as well as political hierarchies that dominate the times we live in. 

 

 

 

Learning Outcomes

Through practical exercises, writing and collective brainstorming, students will get familiar with both form and content of digital storytelling. They will acquire multimedia skills as well as engage in critical thinking and analysis as they complete their final projects for this course.

title: INTRODUCTION TO AUDIO VIDEO PRODUCTION
description:
Introduction to Audio Visual Production [MS-1001/ VA-2014] [MS-1001/ VA-2014-1]

Faculty Name
A K Ranjit [ak.ranjit@ashoka.edu.in] ,Kiran Singh [kiran.singh_asp23@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This is an introductory technical course on audio-visual media; students will learn to listen, watch and create audio-visual stories of their own. This includes an introduction to handling audio and video recording systems. From microphones to cameras, basic audio and video editing. The course would begin with a brief introduction of the various roles required to be taken up for the smooth running of a studio. We will cover camera handling and basic techniques to take good-quality videos. We learn about the kinds of different microphones and where and when to use which one. While learning audio and video, we will simultaneously begin basic editing to stitch together the shots and audio samples we take. Gradually we get into more nuanced editing techniques followed by studio lighting.

 

 

Learning Outcomes

Media Literacy on how to hear & watch media in the audio-visual format, separately and together.

- Comprehending basic camera operations.

-  Lighting Technique

- Basic Audio-Video Editing tools like Adobe Premiere, Adobe Audition

- Sound and Video recording

- Constructing an audio and audio-visual narrative from end to end

- Mastering fundamental elements of storytelling from scripting to logging, from production to preview.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The student has to think beyond the box with empirical planning of implementing it onscreen with time limits. 

Grading Rubric

Class participation- This will include
a) your participation within your groups and interaction with other peers and Professor.
b) your performance on in-class quizzes.                                   

The students will have to submit three assignments throughout the semester. The First and Second assignments will be done in groups, and the Final assignment will be individual. The exact details of the assignment will be shared during the class. 

1. Attendance: 10%
2. Class Participation: 10%
3. Assignment 1(Group): 15%
4. Assignment 2 (Group): 25%
5. Final Assignment (Individual): 35%
6. Viva: 5%

 

* Late Submission will get a 10% grade cut on each Assignment. In case of an emergency, the students must email the Professor cc-ing the TA 24 hours before the submission is due. The professor will grant an extension if the reason is valid and supported with evidence. No last-time requests will be entertained.

Attendance Policy

There are three unexcused absences. 5% will be deducted from the attendance grade for every class missed beyond three classes.:

title: COMMUNICATION THEORY AND BEHAVIORAL CHNGE
description:
Communication Theory and Behavioral Change [MS-3210/ PSY-3141/ VA-3020] [MS-3210/ PSY-3141/ VA-3020-1]

Faculty Name
Purnima Mehrotra [purnima.mehrotra@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

“There is nothing so practical as a good theory.”— Social psychologist Kurt Lewin


We live in an era in which the processes of content production and the patterns of media consumption are changing rapidly. Even the most  seasoned media professionals are struggling to determine what the media landscape of the future will look like and what business models can be
used to support it.  It is in times like these when theories of mass communication are particularly valuable.  The broadly explanatory concepts of theory help us understand some of the underlying ways in which humans respond to and share different types of information, and can help us make some informed predictions about what the future may hold. This course will introduce students to mass communication theory, and will focuses on theories of audience and effect. This class will provide you with an overview of some of the important theories in the field, and
will encourage you to think about how these apply to the real world and how they will inform your future work, perhaps, as a media professional.

This course is cross-listed with Psychology as the two disciplines are closely related. Some studies that are considered seminal in the field of communication were originally conducted by psychologists, e.g. works by Hovland, Bandura, Lasswell, Lewin, Festinger and Fishbein. The two disciplines continue to enrich and enhance each other such that there are many common publication platforms, partnerships among scholars, and common faculty across departments. In terms of the historical evolution of the two fields psychology is an older and more established discipline than communication, hence communication continues to draw on the more consolidated approaches of psychology.


 

 

 

Learning Outcomes

Learning Outcomes

Understand the historical development of Mass Communication theories and how they link with historically important social, political and technological developments in the field of communication

Develop an understanding of the most often used theories of mass communication and the ability to apply them in research and practice

Critically evaluate theories as applied to practical mass communication problems e.g. media portrayals of sex and violence

Understand how mass communication is a powerful tool of persuasion and how it has been and continues to be used across sectors - adverstising, politics, development etc.

 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Reading materials will be shared with students at the beginning of the semester either as a compendium for the entire semester or in batches arranged according to major theoretical traditions in communication theory.

Some easy reads that students might find useful:

A First Look at Communication Theory by EM Griffin

Mass Communication Theory by Dennis McQuail

Grading Rubric

Class participation:                                                                                                   15%
Brief written critique of selected readings/quiz/other weekly assignments:              20%
Presentations:                                                                                                          20%
Mid-term paper:                                                                                                        20%
Final paper:                                                                                                              25%

Attendance Policy

Students should not miss more than 2 class sessions as we will cover a lot of material in each session. Too many absences will impede your ability to follow, learn and absorb the material. For any absences, students are required to notify the instructor.

title: GENDER LENS REPORTING
description:
Gender Lens Reporting [MS-2115/ VA-2012] [MS-2115/ VA-2012-1]

Faculty Name
Neha Dixit [neha.dixit@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

MONDAY WEDNESDAY 15:00- 16:30  Neha Dixit

Patriarchal agendas still form the bedrock of public discourse. Media outlets refuse to treat marginalised genders as equal participants in the nation and its politics.  

Many news organisations believe that they are pulling their weight because they publish a few pieces that cater to gender – the odd inspirational business story, something about reproductive health, the occasional report of domestic or sexual assault, harassment, violence, government schemes or aid for the trans community. 

So, how can we begin to fix this problem? The answer is that we can apply something known as a gender lens. A gender lens is not a tangible object; it is a way of looking at things, a means to critically assess a wide range of social and political situations, to see how gender-inclusive or gender-sensitive they are.

It highlights the difference in interests for various genders– within the same household, state, country, or globally – and also shows how they interact.

 Simply put, it is like a pair of spectacles that correct the prevailing view of marginalised genders and their place in the world.

In this course, you will learn how across the global media, gender stereotypes are used to trivialise, objectify and sexualise. With the application of the gender lens, you will be provided with a viewfinder that filters all of that out and exposes the roots of inequality. It will help the students place the spotlight on the realities, needs and perceptions of all genders. 

With a few exceptions 'gender issues' are always seen as exclusive of the wider world of economics, politics, sport and current affairs. This class will study reportage on women, men, and LGBTQI issues from an intersectional perspective, as tempered by race, ethnicity, nationality, caste and class – as well as other factors such as religion, culture and ideology. Through, news reports, films, exercises, field trips, seminars, and discussions, the students will learn how to cover essential stories – be they of war, poverty, or crime – objectively and responsibly, by looking for the intersections of gender and these “bigger” issues. The students will be taught how to use these intersections to write ground reports, narrative pieces and profiles. 

Two field trips are included in this course

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Prerequisite:  Student should have done either the Media Studies Course - Introduction to Newswriting and Reporting

OR 

Any other Gender based course (offered by any department at Ashoka, in any of the semesters before this Spring semester. Please see list attached in AMS under Gender Lens Reporting Course details)

title: DEVELOPING PERFORMANCE SKILLS
description:
Developing Performance Skills [PA-1003] [PA-1003-1]

Faculty Name
Navtej Johar [navtej.johar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Taught by Navtej Singh Johar

Movement, text, sound, music- these are some of the areas touched upon while developing skills in performance.  The emphasis is on building a vocabulary of performance techniques. These techniques can include breathing, movement improvisation, and voice modulation, as well as exercises in awareness and musicality. These ‘tools of performance’ are often  tempered by a plethora of contemporary performance outlooks. The emphasis in this most preliminary of Ashoka’s performing arts courses is on the individual as a performing entity. The consciousness of one’s own self vis-à-vis performative potentialities lays the foundations for the group work so essential to later performing arts courses.  The course work will proceed in a series of ‘etudes’ or studies which will result in small performance ‘moments’ or phrases. Some of the coursework will be based on texts and scripts to be chosen afresh each semester.  Other coursework can be based on non-textual concepts.

No previous experience is required. This course is a presumed prerequisite for higher-level performing arts courses.

This course is mandatory for all students wanting to pursue a minor in performing arts.

Grading Rubric

Students will be graded based on participation in class and attendance.

Attendance Policy

More than 4 unexcused absences will affect the student’s grade.

title: PERFORMING ARTS PRACTICES
description:
Performing Arts Practices [PA-1009] [PA-1009-1]

Faculty Name
Thomas Michael Mccarthy [justin.mccarthy@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Taught by Justin McCarthy

This course guides students through a multiplicity of performance practices existing on the subcontinent. These practices include the locally specific, the socially specific, the traditional, the hereditary, the rural, the nomadic, the urban, the pan-Indian, as well as those practices with discernible connections to performance conventions beyond the specifically Indian context. An important premise of this course is that music, dance and theatre are three strands of an intertwined whole. Their closely related cultural, social and aesthetic histories will constitute the core material to be studied. While acknowledging a cultural corpus often possessing obvious mutual affinities, this course will give pride of place to the wide varieties of performance practices found in India and the divergent histories accompanying them.  Though mainly academic, the course can contain performance elements depending on the students’ inclinations and their performative relationship to the material being studied.

There is no prerequisite for this course.

This course is mandatory for all students wanting to pursue  a minor in performing arts.

Grading Rubric

Students will be graded based on participation in class and attendance.

Attendance Policy

More than 4 unexcused absences will affect the student’s grade.

title: INTRODUCTION TO PERFORMANCE STUDIES
description:
Introduction to Performance Studies [ENG-2610/ PA-2610/ ENG-4610] [ENG-2610/ PA-2610/ ENG-4610-1]

Faculty Name
Vivek Venkitaraman Narayan [v.v.narayan@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Is everyday life a performance? Are our social interactions forms of playacting? How about the ways in which we present ourselves—as gendered bodies, as students, as friends, as professors, and as so many other less nameable identities—are these too performances? What would it tell us if we were to think of everyday social interaction and self-presentation as performance? Does this mean our interactions are shallow, our relationships fake, and our personalities mere pretense? Or will it reveal aspects of everyday life that otherwise remain hidden in plain view?   

These are some questions that inspire this course to explore the social phenomenon of performance and its theoretical value to the humanities. We will investigate the ways in which our everyday behaviours and the stories we tell shape our identities and our experience of the world. We will see how thinking of, with, and through performance can help us investigate social behaviour, individual and collective identity, and embodied knowledge. 

We will do so by focusing on three recurring themes: first, the relationship between representation and performance, which will help us understand social behaviour; second, the paradigm of performativity, which is significant to theorizing identity; and third, the debate between whether performance is an ephemeral or enduring phenomenon, which is central to conceptualizing embodied knowledges. We will see, in short, how performance—as object, method, and analytic—can help us understand societies and cultures by focusing on acts of doing, ways of being, and modes of knowing. We will read Judith Butler, JL Austin, Diana Taylor, Richard Schechner, Susan Sontag, Harry Elam, Victor Turner, Bishnupriya Dutt, Erving Goffman, Clifford Geertz, Aparna Dharwadker, Ngugi wa Thiong’o, and Paulla Ebron. We will also engage with Dharamvir Bharati’s Andha Yug, Maya Rao’s Walk, and the real-life cases of Rachel Dolezal and Jessica Krug. 

(Undergrads may sign up for ENG-2610 or PA-2610, while grads are welcome to sign up for ENG-4610.)

title: MULTIPLE HISTORIES OF BHARATANATYAM
description:
Multiple Histories of Bharatanatyam [PA-2013] [PA-2013-1]

Faculty Name
Thomas Michael Mccarthy [justin.mccarthy@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Taught by Justin McCarthy

The dance now known as bharatanatyam can be seen through the light of a number of parallel histories. Fragments of these histories can be found in documents, letters, treatises, books, and dramatic and poetic texts.  But they also exist in less substantive archives like music, aural narratives, informal reminiscences and, most importantly, in the body. Changing movement patterns, the shifting intentions behind the dance’s gestural language, and evolving sequences of mores and ideas of the self can all be felt or seen in the body of the dancer. This course will look at bharatanatyam through a combination of all of these approaches. There will also be a consistent practical component closely allied with the ideas in the course.

Grading Rubric

Students will be graded based on participation in class and attendance.

Attendance Policy

More than 4 unexcused absences will affect the student’s grade.

title: MUSIC AND THE POPULAR IMAGINATION
description:
Music and the Popular Imagination [PA-2016] [PA-2016-1]

Faculty Name
Sumangala Damodaran [sumangala.damodaran@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Taught by Sumangala Damodaran

This course is about understanding the realms of the ‘aural’ in and as popular performance in the contemporary period, as a bearer of creative processes embedded in the social and historical context of modernity. It aims to expose students to two major dimensions of musical performance, one theoretical and historical and the second, listening and practice oriented. It will (a) take students through conceptualisations and creations of ‘the popular’ in the analysis of art and culture, (b) lay out theoretical perspectives, historical contexts and expositions of range and variety in traditions of music from the twentieth century, (c) expose students to ‘ways of listening’ that allow for understanding popular music as a distinct part of an ‘aural imagination’ and as being constituted by many impulses ranging from the commercial to the consciously political and in performing nation, difference and identity. The delivery of the course will involve lectures, listening sessions and practical exercises involving voice and instruments.

Grading Rubric

Students will be graded based on participation in class and attendance.

Attendance Policy

More than 4 unexcused absences will affect the student’s grade.

title: PHRASING THE BODY: COMPOSING MOVEMENT FOR PERFORMANCE
description:
Phrasing the Body: Composing Movement for Performance [PA-2017] [PA-2017-1]

Faculty Name
Abhinaya Penneswaran [abhinaya.penneswaran@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Taught by Abhinaya Penneswaran

What does creating a diverse movement vocabulary entail? How to compose dance phrases? What different aspects should we consider while attempting to stage these compositions? Using different forms for familiarization and composition (contemporary dance, bharatanatyam, freestyle exploration), and staging techniques, this course aims to equip the student with tools and techniques to be able to compose movement phrases and stage them effectively.

Prior experience with dance and movement would be helpful for the student but not a prerequisite for the course.

Grading Rubric

Students will be graded based on participation in class and attendance.

Attendance Policy

More than 4 unexcused absences will affect the student’s grade.

fullName: PA-3015, RESEARCH IN THE PERFORMING ARTS, HANNE DE BRUIN, P RAJAGOPAL
title: RESEARCH IN THE PERFORMING ARTS, HANNE DE BRUIN,
description:
Research in the Performing Arts [PA-3015] [PA-3015-1]

Faculty Name
Hanne De Bruin [hanne.bruin@ashoka.edu.in] ,P. Rajagopal [p.rajagopal@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Taught by Hanne de Bruin, P Rajagopal

This course explores different ways of doing research on and through the performing arts and different ways of producing knowledge about them. What makes doing research of and within the performing arts so difficult? What are the barriers we run into and how can we try to transcend them? In addition to being experiential, the performing arts in India display an enormous variety. Socially and culturally, they are being valued, appreciated, supported, learned and consumed differently by different kinds of audiences. We will look at a variety of research tools and methodologies, ranging from asking questions to using a performance itself as a tool to explore the content and boundaries of a form from within.

Grading Rubric

Students will be graded based on participation in class and attendance.

Attendance Policy

More than 4 unexcused absences will affect the student’s grade.

fullName: VA-3040/ PA-3800, CRAFTING IDENTITIES: ARTS, CRAFTS AND PERFORMATIVE PRACTICES FROM CENTRAL INDIA, PREETI BAHADUR RAMASWAMY
title: CRAFTING IDENTITIES: ARTS, CRAFTS AND PERFORMATIVE PRACTICES FROM CENTRAL INDIA, PREETI BAHADUR RAMASWAMY,
description:
Crafting Identities: Arts, Crafts and Performative Practices from Central India [VA-3040/ PA-3800/ SOA-3103] [VA-3040/ PA-3800/ SOA-3103-1]

Faculty Name
Preeti Bahadur Ramaswami [preeti.ramaswami@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course  seeks to enlarge the boundaries of art history as a discipline by focussing on art practices  of persons seen as belonging to marginalised communities. What are the forces that shape the lives and practices of individuals referred to in public discourse as craftsmen, or ‘folk ‘and ‘tribal’ artists in post -colonial India? How much agency do they have over their lives and practice and to what extent are they ‘manipulated’ by ‘outside’ mediations? And how do tradition and modernity parley with each other in the shaping of their work and careers? This course is designed to make students actively debate and engage with these issues and beyond, through case studies of practitioners of both material and performative practices from Central India. It  examines trajectories in artisanal and performative practices from the region of Madhya Pradesh and the recently created state of Chhattisgarh. 

The course will acquaint students with case histories of practitioners, from the ground,  to trace trajectories of transformation. Students will engage with questions of caste and community, agency, selfhood, and gender, to understand the shaping of art forms and their contexts. They will be led to look at  shifting contexts for the production  and reception of art practices, examining  the role of the state, museums and institutions, exhibitions and the market in creating binary categories of ‘art’ verses ‘craft’. A key component will be unravelling histories and modes of intervention following developmental or anthropological paradigms in the field.

Discussions will be largely based on films and video recordings from the ‘field’, interviews, exhibition catalogues and on- site visits to the crafts museum  and art galleries. 

Course Structure and modules

The course syllabus focuses on the following set of practices and forms from Central India. It follows developments in the lives of practitioners and their practice. 

Modules

‘Gond’ art

In 2001, the artist Jangarh Singh Shyam committed suicide at a Museum in Japan, unable to return home before  paintings that had been  commissioned by the Museum  were completed. He was a Gond Pradhan,  from an ‘adivasi' community in Central India, famously ‘discovered’ by the art world in 1981. This module charts his life and art through films, art works and publications and examines the role of played by art world interlocutors in shaping his life and career. Lectures will look at  ‘Gond art ‘ as  a tradition that was ‘invented’  in recent times, and look at individuals who followed Jangarh Singh Shaym to trace trajectories in their practice.  It will also look at  ‘primitivism’ as a phenomenon in 20th century modern art  to unpack ideologies that informed the discovery of ‘adivasi’ artists.  

Rajwar clay sculpture 

 Valorised as a woman sculptor whose art was born of loneliness, Sona Bai’s life changed completely after her discovery by teams from Bharat Bhavan, an art intitution based in  Bhopal. Her art which was made from local clay found in  Sarguja in Chhattisgarh  shaped into sculptures and screens, began to  adorn museums and exhibition spaces.   What did this shift from a domestic space  in the interiors of Chhattisgarh to sites of international exhibition do to her art and how much agency did she have in shaping her life or work? Which markets defined her work  as individualistic  art practice and which defined it as  craft born of women’s labour?  What happens when her work, which was domestic and therefore private,  enters a larger public sphere for staging ethnicities? Students will look at films, exhibition catalogues and in situ installations to understand her art and that of others who followed her. 

Gadhwa metal sculpture, Bastar. 

The module will  focus on the transformation of  metal sculptures from Bastar, from objects of ritual use to highly sought after objects in the art market.  Jaidev Baghel, metal sculptor from Bastar, was able to negotiate a space for himself across markets, moving between art worlds and sites for the marketing of  ‘crafts. Students will look at his work and that of the modernist sculptor Meera Mukherjee  who apprenticed under him to see how both practices changed through the interaction. They will also examine how the idea of the ‘folk’ feeds into ideas of authenticity and nationality. 

Between ethnography and anthropology 

How have ethnography and anthropology as disciplines shaped the work of largely urban based individuals and institutions to inform interventions in the field?  Students will look at the work of the anthropologist Verrier Elwin, artist and adminsitrator  J . Swaminathan, photographer Sunil Janah, culture activist Pupul Jaykar, artists Meera Mukherjee, Navjot Altaf to raise questions about ethics and intentionality. ‘

Performative practices

This module looks at  shifts in the performances of the Pandvani, (stories of the Pandavas recited in Chhattisgarh), and the Lorik Chanda , tracing the emergence of  ‘professional artists’ and the shifts from oral to textual sources of storytelling. What are emic understadigns of this shift ? Student will also looks at ‘Nacha’ a form of theatre that became popular in Chhattisgarh in the early years of the twentieth century, examining interventions by Habib Tanvir, well known modernist theatre director,  and the trope of  ‘indigenism’ in modernist art discourse.   

Subalternity in Chhattisgarh. 

This module will focus on practices that define subalternity in this region, and their resistance to the culture of upper caste communities.  Many of these are highly charged performative practices that have, so far,  also resisted being co- opted into mainstream culture. One of the most compelling of these are the Ramnamis, a community that perform  bhakti and resist upper caste practices by tattooing their bodies with the name of the divine. 

Discusssion themes include:  

  • the  performance of oral epics (Pandvani and Lorik Chanda), by stellar performers from this region and their adaptation by the modernist theatre director and activist Habeeb Tanvir.
  • the life and art of  Jangarh Singh Shyam, painter from Patangarh, Madhya Pradesh and the phenomenon of ‘Gond painting’.
  • performing identities of ‘artist ‘and ‘craftsperson’ in the lives and practice of modernist sculptor Meera Mukherjee and  Jaidev Baghel, metal sculptor from Bastar.  
  • the role of key museums and institutions in the ‘discovery’ of art forms and  the creation of  exhibition paradigms.(Bharat Bhavan, Crafts Museum, Tribal Museum) 
  • the role of interlocutors from art worlds, such as J.  Swaminathan, Bhasakar Kulkarni , Pupul Jaykar etc and their impact in transforming practices.   
  • seeking the indigenous in the ‘folk .
Learning Outcomes

this course will enable students to 

  • trace  shifts in art practices of marginalised constituencies in post- independence India. 
  • debate the binaries of ‘art’ and ‘craft ‘ as categories created within different social and institutional contexts. 
  • debate the nature  and extent of agency  exercised by creative persons from marginalised communities.

  • re imagine modes for alternative interventions in art practice. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Themes outlined in the readings below will inform discussions on the modules listed above. 

Central India: mapping the field 

Gregory, Christopher A. "Chhattisgarh: At the crossroads." The Modern Anthropology of India. Routledge, 2013. 60-79.

Lamb, Ramdas. Rapt in the Name: The Ramnamis, Ramnam, and Untouchable Religion in Central India. SUNY Press, 2002

Dalmia, V. . Folk Theatre and the Search for an Indigenous Idiom:: Brecht in India. In Poetics, Plays, and Performances: The Politics of Modern Indian Theatre. : Oxford University Press,2008.

Perera, Sasanka, and Dev Nath Pathak, eds. Intersections of Contemporary Art, Anthropology and Art History in South Asia: Decoding Visual Worlds. Springer, 2019.

Price, Sally. "The Enduring Power of Primitivism: Showcasing “the Other” in Twenty‐First‐Century France." A Companion to Modern African Art (2013): 445-465.

Garimella, Annapurna. "A Tree Grows in a Painting: Tribal Artists and the Museum."  MARG-A MAGAZINE OF THE ARTS71.3 (2020): 40-51.

Garimella, Annapurna, ed. Vernacular in the Contemporary 1. Devi Art Foundation, 2010.

Venkatesan, Soumhya. Craft matters: Artisans, development and the Indian nation. Orient Blackswan Private Limited, 2009.

Dutta, Arindam. The bureaucracy of beauty: Design in the age of its global reproducibility. Routledge, 2006.

Performative practices, material culture

Gregory, Chris A. "The oral epics of the women of the Dandakaranya Plateau: a preliminary mapping." Journal of Social Sciences 8.2 (2004): 93-104.

Hacker, Katherine. "Dismantling or Rehabilitating the Cult of the Craftsman Paradigm: Some Reflections on Jaidev Baghel’s Practice." The Journal of Modern Craft 9.2 (2016): 139-159

Becoming Artists: Selfhood and agency

Jyotindra Jain, Other Masters: Five Contemporary Folk and Tribal Artists of India ( Crafts Museum) 1998. 

Jyotindra Jain, Jangarh Singh Shyam: A Conjurer’s Archive (Mapin), 2019.

Chatterji, Roma. op.cit

Swaminathan, Jagdish. "Art and the Adivasi." India International Centre Quarterly 19.1/2 (1992): 113-127.

Jain, Jyotindra. "Women Artists of Rural India." Women of India: Colonial and Post-Colonial Periods (‘History of Science, Philosophy and Culture in Indian Civilization’, 9.3 (2005): 501-523.

Grading Rubric

Students will be assessed continually through the entire semester including active class participation, mid semester and end semester evaluations. The assessment and grading pattern will broadly be as follows:

Class participation and engagement : 20% of total grades. 

Class presentations and mid semester assignment: 60% of total grades.

End semester curatorial project: 20% of total grades. 

Attendance Policy

Students will need 90% class attendance. Absenteism beyond this will need permission from the course instructor.

title: INTRODUCTION TO THE PHILOSOPHY OF LANGUAGE
description:
Introduction to Philosophy of Language [PHI-2300] [PHI-2300-1]

Faculty Name
Eric Paul Snyder [eric.snyder@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course is an introduction to the Philosophy of Language. Its purpose is to introduce students to the most important issues, views, and debates within  of this subfield of Philosophy. Topics covered will include: reference, meaning, truth, implicature, descriptions, direct reference, the causal theory of reference, indexicality, and propositional attitudes. Philosophers covered will include: Frege, Tarski, Russell, Strawson, Quine, Kripke, Kaplan, Grice, and Perry. There are no prerequesites for the course, although familiarity with symbolic logic will be beneficial (but not necessary).

title: INTRODUCTION TO PHILOSOPHY
description:
Introduction to Philosophy [PHI-1000] [PHI-1000-1]

Faculty Name
Daniel Benjamin Weltman [danny.weltman@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

In this course, you will be introduced to academic philosophy through an investigation of a few of the key issues that philosophers have investigated over the years. We will begin with miscellaneous initial topics. The majority of topics will be chosen by class vote.

Initial Topics

Jan 25: Lewis Carroll, “What the Tortoise Said to Achilles”

Jan 27: Patricia Churchland, “Are Mental States Irreducible to Neurobiological States?”

Feb 1: Kristen Intemann, “Science and Values: Are Value Judgments Always Irrelevant to the Justification of Scientific Claims?”

Feb 3: Mary Midgley, “On Trying Out One’s New Sword”

Feb 8: Julia Driver, “Caesar’s Wife: On the Moral Significance of Appearing Good”

Feb 10: Roy Sorensen, “Permission to Cheat”

Feb 15: Amartya Sen, “The Global Reach of Human Rights”

Feb 17: Mary Korsmeyer, “Delightful, Delicious, Disgusting”

The rest of the schedule will be determined via voting on topics.

Possible Topics

The readings listed below for each topic may vary to some degree once we pick our final topics, so as to accommodate enthusiasm for topics and a sensible reading and assignment schedule.

Abortion: Warren, “On the Moral and Legal Status of Abortion” and “The Moral Difference Between Infanticide and Abortion: A Response to Robert Card”; Card, “Infanticide and the Liberal View of Abortion”; Thomson, “A Defense of Abortion”

AI Consciousness: Searle, “Minds, Brains, and Programs”; Boden, “Escaping from the Chinese Room”; Churchland and Churchland, “Could a Machine Think?”; Ben-Yami, “A Note on the Chinese Room”

Ancient Greek Philosophy: Plato, Euthyphro, Apology, Crito, Symposium

Can Art Lie?: Cooke, “When Art Can’t Lie”; Dixon, “Lies in Art”

Classical Chinese Philosophy: Selections from Kǒngzǐ, Mòzǐ, and Xúnzǐ

Classical Islamic Philosophy: Ibn Rušd, The Incoherence of the Incoherence

Communism: Marx, “Theses on Feuerbach,” Critique of the Gotha Program Part I and Parts II-IV and Appendix, “The British Rule in India,” “Future Results of the British Rule in India”; Engels, “The Principles of Communism”

Death: Nagel, “Death”; Rosenbaum, “How to Be Dead and Not Care”; Suits, “Why Death Is Not Bad for the One Who Died”; Kamm, “Why is Death Bad and Worse than Pre-Natal Non-Existence?”; Timmerman, “A dilemma for Epicureanism”;

Early Modern European Philosophy: Hume, “The Standard of Taste” and “Suicide”; Descartes, Meditations on First Philosophy; Selections from Princess Elisabeth of Bohemia’s correspondence with Descartes

Eating Animals: Norcross, “Puppies, Pigs, and People”; Callicott, “The Environmental Omnivore’s Dilemma”; Driver, “Individual Consumption and Moral Complicity”; Levy, “Vegetarianism: Toward Ideological Impurity”; Narain, “Why I Would Not Advocate Vegetarianism”

Existentialism: Sartre, “Existentialism is a Humanism”; Beauvoir, “Introduction to an Ethics of Ambiguity” and “What is Existentialism?”

Free Will: Frankfurt, “Alternate Possibilities and Moral Responsibility”; Ginet, “In Defense of the Principle of Alternative Possibilities”; Frankfurt, “Freedom of the Will and the Concept of a Person”; Ekstrom, “Toward a plausible event-causal indeterminist account of free will”; Strawson, “The Impossibility of Moral Responsibility”

Gender: Barnes, “The Metaphysics of Gender”; Haslanger, “The Sex/Gender Distinction and the Social Construction of Reality”; Mikkola, “Gender Essentialism and Anti-Essentialism”; Mikkola, “Elizabeth Spelman, Gender Realism, and Women”; Stoljar, “Different Women, Gender, and the Realism-Nominalism Debate”

Hellenistic Greek Philosophy: Epicurus, “Letter to Menoeceus” and “The Principal Doctrines”; Selections of Stoic writings; Selections of Skeptic writings

Indian and Buddhist Philosophy: Selections from Questions of King Milinda; Selections from Śaṅkara’s Vaiśeṣika-sūtra-upaskāra; Selections from Vasubandhu’s Abhidharmakośabhāṣya

Love: Zangwill, “Love: Gloriously Amoral and Arational”; Smuts, “Normative Reasons for Love, Part II” and “Part II”; Naar, “Subject-Relative Reasons for Love”; Protasi, “Loving People for Who They Are (Even When They Don’t Love You Back)”; Han, “Do We Love For Reasons?”

Multiculturalism and Sexism: Okin, “Is Multiculturalism Bad for Women?”; Selected replies

Personal Identity: Blackmore, “The Self”; Parfit, “Personal Identity”; Williams, “The Self and the Future”; Schechtman, “The Narrative Self”; Swinburne, “Personal Identity: the Dualist Theory”

Patriotism and Nationalism: Nathanson, “In Defense of Moderate Patriotism”; Gomberg, “Patriotism is Like Racism”; Hurka, “The Justification of National Partiality”; Lichtenberg, “Nationalism, For and (Mainly) Against”

Scientific Realism: Putnam, “What is ‘Realism’?”; van Fraasen, “Arguments concerning scientific realism” and “To save the phenomena”; Psillos, “In defence of scientific realism” and “Constructive empiricism scrutinised”

Skepticism: Selections from Hume, A Treatise of Human Nature; Selections from Descartes, Meditations on First Philosophy; Selections from Zhuangzi; Putnam, “Brains in a Vat”; David, “Neither Mentioning ‘Brains in a Vat’ nor Mentioning Brains in a Vat Will Prove that We Are Not Brains in a Vat”

Terrorism: Wellman, “On Terrorism Itself”; Held, “Legitimate Authority in Non-state Groups Using Violence”; Jaggar, “What Is Terrorism, Why Is It Wrong, and Could It Ever Be Morally Permissible?”; Medina, “Unconditional vs. Conditional Critics of Terrorist Violence”; McPherson, “Is Terrorism Distinctively Wrong?”; Glasgow, “A Straightforward Analysis of Terrorism”

The Annihilation of Caste: Dhanda, “Philosophical Foundations of Anti-Casteism”; Ambedkar, “The Annihilation of Caste”; Gandhi, “A Vindication of Caste”; Ambedkar, “A Reply to the Mahatma”

The Meaning of Life: Gowans, “The Buddha's Message”; Siderits, “The Buddha”; Chakrabarti, “Vyasa”; Camus, “The Myth of Sisyphus”; Taylor, “The Meaning of Life”; Wolf, “Meaning in Life and Why it Matters”; Nagel, “The Absurd”

The Riddles of Induction: Selections from Humse's Enquiry Concerning Human Understanding; Goodman, “The New Riddle of Induction”

Learning Outcomes
  • Learn a bit about what philosophy, as a field of academia, has studied
  • Form some initial thoughts about some of the key questions and topics in philosophy
  • Get practice with reading, writing, talking about, and thinking about philosophy in an academic setting
  • Develop your reading and writing skills with a focus on reading complicated texts and writing about them clearly, concisely, and accurately
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

All reading material will be available on the course Canvas website.

Grading Rubric

There are 4 kinds of assignments in this class: reading quizzes, Perusall annotations, four sentence papers, and 500 word papers.

Reading Quizzes are to help you focus on the important parts of the reading and to get instant feedback on whether you have understood the reading. There is one quiz per reading.

Perusall Annotation Assignments allow you to collaboratively read the readings by using the Perusall website.

Four Sentence Papers are the first way you will practice writing philosophy. They will introduce you to summaries and arguments. There are 4 due.

500 Word Papers are your opportunity to get more practice writing concisely about philosophy. They should summarize a point from one of the readings, and then offer a question, an extension of the idea or argument, or a critique of the idea or argument. There are 4 due.

Attendance Policy

If you do not foresee being able to attend this class you should not enroll in this class.

title: INTRODUCTION TO PHILOSOPHY
description:
Introduction to Philosophy [PHI-1000] [PHI-1000-2]

Faculty Name
Reva Shinghal [reva.shinghal_ug23@ashoka.edu.in] ,Tatyana Aleksandrovna Kostochka [tatyana.kostochka@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

“To do philosophy is to explore one’s temperament and at the same time to attempt to discover the truth.” - Iris Murdoch

In this course, we will examine some of the most foundational questions of philosophy: What exists? How do we know anything? What are we? What is morality? What is justice? What is beauty? We will investigate classic formulations of these questions and the ways that philosophers from various time periods and philosophical traditions have tried to answer them. At the same time, we will also look into the ways that these questions apply to our daily lives. In the process, you will not only practice thinking, discussing, and writing about complex ideas in a clear, critical, and structured manner but also explore your own relationship to the world and the other being in it.

title: SYMBOLIC LOGIC
description:
Symbolic Logic [PHI-1060/ CS-2160] [PHI-1060/ CS-2160-1]

Faculty Name
Eric Paul Snyder [eric.snyder@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This is an introductory course to symbolic logic. Generally speaking, logic is the study of correct reasoning. Informal logic studies correct patterns of inference, in a relatively informal way. Formal logic, on the
other hand, studies correct patterns of inference, in a relatively formal way.  By “formal”, we just mean the way a mathematician might do it. Symbolic logic is formal logic, where correct patterns of inference are symbolized into an artificial language. This class will cover both informal and formal logic, and so will contain a mixture of symbolic and non-symbolic representations of arguments. The aim is to introduce students to basic logical concepts, different logical systems, various paradoxes and other conundrums central to the development of formal logic, and perhaps most importantly, to learn how to reason better, primarily through learning how to diagram and evaluate arguments, not only those found “in the wild”, but also one’s own arguments. Topics will include: logical notations, diagramming arguments, quantification, formal proofs, paradox, classical logic, modal logic, various non-classical logics, inductive logic, computer logic, metalogic, and some (light) set theory.

title: SYMBOLIC LOGIC
description:
Symbolic Logic [PHI-1060/ CS-2160] [PHI-1060/ CS-2160-2]

Faculty Name
Tammo Lossau [tammo.lossau@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Suppose that all Germans like Sauerkraut. Then, you may use the fact that I am a German to infer that I like Sauerkraut. However, you should not use the fact that Sarah likes Sauerkraut to infer that Sarah is German. Formal logic studies cases like this and provides us with a notion of deductive validity that can explain why the first inference is better than the second. In this course, we will develop this notion, along with a few others, by studying two formal languages called "propositional logic" and "first-order logic". These languages will allow us to precisely define validity and to check whether a given argument is valid in these languages. Understanding these languages will also be helpful for analyzing spoken languages, and it gives us an insight into computer processing and programming languages as well.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

No prerequisites or required readings. The course will be formally consistent with Volker Halbach's book The Logic Manual, but buying this book will not be necessary.

Grading Rubric

Weekly sets of homeworks plus two exams

Attendance Policy

Attendance mandatory

title: INTRODUCTION TO INDIAN PHILOSOPHY
description:
Introduction to Indian Philosophy [PHI-2360] [PHI-2360-1]

Faculty Name
Dimitry Shevchenko [dimitry.shevchenko@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course is an opportunity to learn about an ancient tradition of philosophy, which has developed in complete independence from European philosophical trends, but which has left its impact not only here in India, but also affected Chinese, Tibetan, and other philosophical traditions. Indian philosophers developed sophisticated systems of argumentation and reasoning, epistemology, aesthetics, metaphysics, philosophy of mind, and philosophy of language. They explored questions about the nature and the existence of the self, the fundamental structure and the reality of the world, the existence of God, and the relationship between mind and matter.

During the course, we will zoom in and out, now discussing particular problems and arguments put forward by Indian philosophers, and next getting a broader context of ideas, philosophical systems, and individual thinkers. We will get to know the major Brahmanical, Buddhist, and Jain philosophical schools, and read from the texts of such philosophers as Vasubandhu, Patañjali, Vātsyāyana, Īśvarakṛṣṇa, and Śaṁkara. The course both aims at giving you a taste of Indian philosophy and at drawing a philosophical map, which would assist in your future studies of various aspects of Indian philosophy.

title: PSYCHOTHERAPY AND THE PHILOSOPHY OF MIND
description:
Psychotherapy and the Philosophy of Mind [PHI-2430/ PSY-3166] [PHI-2430/ PSY-3166-1]

Faculty Name
Alexander Bruce Watson [alex.watson@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The course is primarily intended for those wanting to major in PsyPhi, but is open to anyone.  It will consider whether the ways of thinking characteristic of Philosophy of Mind can yield any fruit when applied to the topic of Psychotherapy, and whether the Psychotherapy literature is of use to any of the debates in the Philosophy of Mind.

We will start with Freud's case study of Elisabeth von R., who, it turns out, was in love with her sister's husband without knowing it.  How can one be in love with someone without knowing it?  This paradox led to Freud's distinctive map of the psyche with its division into conscious and unconscious parts.  A censor stands at the gateway dividing these two, deciding what it is safe to let pass from the unconscious to the conscious.  We will consider Sartre's critique of the coherence of this idea of the censor.

You will be introduced to some of the central debates in the Philosophy of Mind so that we can think about their application to psychotherapy.  If conversations with a psychotherapist can indeed result in significant changes in our mental life and our behaviour, does this imply mutual causation between the physical and the mental?  If so, is it more compatible with some positions than others in debates about the mind-body problem and free will?

Learning Outcomes

You will emerge from the course familiar with

  • central issues in the Philosophy of Mind
  • the theory and practice of several modalities within Psychotherapy: Psychodynamic, Humanistic (gestalt, person-centred), Existential

and having reflected on what light these two areas of enquiry can throw on each other

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The reading list is not yet finalized, but it will include readings by

Freud

Karen Horney

Frits Perls

Alice Miller

Brian Thorne and David Mearns

Carl Rogers and Rollo May

Anthony Storr

Irvin Yalom

Alexander Lowen

Jean-Paul Sartre

Peter Smith and O.R. Jones (The Philosophy of Mind: An Introduction)

 

Grading Rubric

Your final grade will be calculated from a combination of five scores. These will be weighted in the following way:

10% Presentation

27% Mid-length assignments

20% Engagement with the course through Perusall annotations

27% Final Essay

16% Quiz questions

title: BIOETHICS
description:
Bioethics [PHI-2660] [PHI-2660-1]

Faculty Name
Rachel Kathleen Harbin [kathleen.harbin@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Bioethics is the application of philosophical theories and methods to questions about the relationship of medicine and biological science to our lives. We will begin this course by discussing the major philosophical methods and theories used in bioethics. We will then spend the bulk of the semester applying these theories to a variety of challenging and important moral issues in bioethics including the nature of human life and death, human enhancement, reproductive healthcare and reproductive technologies, discrimination and bias, and the allocation of resources for healthcare.

Grading Rubric

Perusall engagement with readings (10%)

Weekly Quizzes (10%)

Paper I: 1,200 Words (20%)

Midterm Exam (15%)

Paper II: 1,500 Words (25%)

Final Exam (20%)

title: AI ETHICS
description:
AI Ethics [PHI-2678/ CS-3260/ POL-2097] [PHI-2678/ CS-3260/ POL-2097-1]

Faculty Name
Daniel Benjamin Weltman [danny.weltman@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This is a course examining the ethics of artificial intelligence. AI is having an increasingly large effect throughout the world and its use raises many ethical questions, both practical and theoretical. We will begin with some introductory topics. After that, the remaining topics will be chosen by class vote. If you have suggestions for topics, please let me know.

Learning Outcomes

Investigate some of the main issues in the intersection of AI and ethics

Improve your writing skills with a focus on concise summary and argumentation

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Jan 25: Shevlin, Vold, Crosby, and Halina, “The limits of machine intelligence”

Jan 27: Cave, Nyrup, Vold, and Weller, “Motivations and Risks of Machine Ethics”

Feb 1: Bostrom, “The Superintelligent Will: Motivation and Instrumental Rationality in Advanced Artificial Agents”

Feb 3: Schulz, “Machine Grading and Moral Learning”

Feb 8: Christiano, “Algorithms, Manipulation, and Democracy”

Feb 10: Hull, “Successful failure: what Foucault can teach us about privacy self-management in a world of Facebook and big data”

Feb 15: Benn and Lazar, “What’s Wrong with Automated Influence”

Feb 17: Talbot, Jenkins, Purves, “When Robots Should Do the Wrong Thing”

The rest of the schedule will be determined via voting on topics.

Possible topics include AI agency and responsibility, AI governance, AI moral patients, algorithm bias, algorithm fairness, autonomous vehicles, black boxes, human responsibility for AI, criminal law, killer robots, medical AI, moral robots, trust, and value alignment.

Attendance Policy

If you do not foresee being able to attend this class you should not enroll in this class.

title: MORAL PSYCHOLOGY
description:
Moral Psychology [PHI-2702/ PSY-3165] [PHI-2702/ PSY-3165-1]

Faculty Name
Tatyana Aleksandrovna Kostochka [tatyana.kostochka@ashoka.edu.in] ,Yash Agarwal [yash.agarwal_asp23@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

"The job of moral psychology is to tell us how, in acting, feeling, and thinking, we end up related to the right and the good, or the wrong and the bad."

- Nomy Arpaly and Timothy Schroder, In Praise of Desire, p. 1

The world is a messy place and we are messy parts of it. We rationalize our bad actions, act against our better judgment, and want things that we believe to be bad for ourselves and others. In this course, we will explore some aspects of our psychology that have an important relationship to morality—belief, desire, emotion, motivation, intention, and character. The topics are broken up into four rough categories: thinking, feeling, planning, and acting. As we try to get a grasp on these psychological matters, we will wrestle with the questions: “what we are morally responsible for?” and “when we are worthy of praise or blame?”

title: PHILOSOPHY OF RACE AND IDENTITY
description:
Philosophy of Race and Identity [PHI-2820] [PHI-2820-1]

Faculty Name
Lantz Eugene Miller [lantz.miller@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

“Race” has become so smeary and malign a term, in the sense of ethnic discrimination, that it is a challenge to face head-on what exactly this concept entails. Very few scientists would confess the term or concept has any scientific validity whatsoever. It is also a fairly recent concept per se to appear in discourse. Nevertheless, the term is also essential in referring to the pertinent concepts that racists laud. There is an apparent inconsistency, then, between those who refer approvingly to the content and those who would rather the concept fizzle away—but then must refer to that concept somehow.This course begins with some historical tracing of the term and—apparently arising later—the concept, which may have come much earlier than the term. Pre-20th Century Philosophers’ investigation into race include Hume, Kant, and Mill, include Darwin and those he influenced, and in the 20th Century, this philosophical question has grabbed the interests of a range of thinkers, including anthropologists, political theorists, and biologists. While this growth has soared, real and dangerous cases persist to this day, as in race-based slavery in Sudan, caste systems, and not to speak of “white” Americans whose racial hatred continues to boiling up in atrocities. This course is at once theoretical and inspiring concern for how action may be taken against this ongoing scourge.

 

One curious result of this ongoing inquiry and activism is that persons affected by racism may also find that their personal identity takes an unexpected turn when they find themselves identifying themselves with fellow groups that were established by racist divisions. That is, both white persons and black may find ng themselves with groups labelled black by “white” groups clustering blacks into a natural kind. Personal identification with those who negatively defined them becomes a not-easily-resolved problem.

 

Depending on student preference, we may also turn to the twin sister of social discrimination and personal identity, gender identity. This area of research grew out of feminism, with surges intensifying in the 1970s and 80s. Feminism has been one great spur to this area, in opening thinkers to defying the gender status quo and even embracing it as an identity in which they grew up, as seen in the Queer movement in which activists admitted to being what had long been considered an epithet.

 

Grades are based on student attendance and active class participation, final exam, and a term paper (roughly 30% of total in counted under each of these four criteria).

title: ETHICS OF BELIEF
description:
Ethics of Belief [PHI-3190] [PHI-3190-1]

Faculty Name
Benjamin Ian Winokur [benjamin.winokur@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

In philosophy, it is often said that ethics concerns how we should act, and hence is guided by practical considerations about value. It is also often said that epistemology concerns how we should think, and hence is guided by theoretical considerations about truth. This suggests that, even though believing X might make you feel nice or make you money, these are bad reasons to believe X because they are not evidence that X is true. However, in recent years, many philosophers have begun to suspect that value factors are relevant to what we should believe. For example, perhaps we should believe our friends more easily and strongly than we believe strangers because of the moral duties of friendship, or perhaps we should not form certain beliefs about people even when we have strong evidence for these beliefs, because forming these beliefs would be prejudiced or rude. Maybe our beliefs can cause injustice against others and cause them harm. Maybe believing in conspiracy theories, fake news, and other sources of misinformation is bad because of its moral consequences. This course explores these and other debates at the intersection of ethics and epistemology. Our goal is to see whether ethics and epistemology really are separate. If they are separate, then they are each guided by their own principles, even if these principles conflict with each other. If they are not separate, then they are guided by the same principles, some of which might surprise us.

title: THE PHILOSOPHY OF COMPUTABILITY
description:
The Philosophy of Computability [PHI-3250/ CS-3360] [PHI-3250/ CS-3360-1]

Faculty Name
Ernst Love Eric Johannesson [ernst.johannesson@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course provides an introduction to the technical notion of computability and to some of the philosophical issues surrounding it. More specifically, it will address questions such as:

  • What is a computable function?
  • What is a decidable problem?
  • What is a hard problem?
  • What is the relation between computability and formal reasoning?
  • What is the connection between the existence of undecidable problems and Gödel’s first incompleteness theorem?
  • What is the essential difference between a proof and a valid argument?
  • Does the existence of undecidable problems imply that the universe is inherently unpredictable?
  • What is it for a concrete physical system to implement an abstract computable function?
  • What is a machine learning algorithm, essentially?

Link to full course description: https://www.dropbox.com/s/fi58nwunppqg7sl/philosophy_of_computability.pdf?dl=0

title: AESTHETIC EXPERIENCE: HISTORICAL AND CONTEMPORARY APPROACHES
description:
Aesthetic Experience: Historical and Contemporary Approaches [PHI-3440/ ENG-3906] [PHI-3440/ ENG-3906-1]

Faculty Name
Rachel Kathleen Harbin [kathleen.harbin@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

What is special about the experience of a beautiful flower, a vast landscape, or a haunting piece of music? We seem to have distinctive relationships to aesthetically compelling objects and artworks, but it is difficult to explain why. This course explores questions about the nature of aesthetic experience. Are there ways of perceiving that are unique to the aesthetic? If so, what are they and what makes them special? Are aesthetic experiences universal, or are they dependent on our exposure to certain cultures or ideas? We will explore both recent and historical answers to these questions, and we will consider both whether these answers are satisfactory and how they apply to a variety of objects (e.g., paintings, musical compositions, natural objects, and landscapes).

title: THE PHILOSOPHY OF PROBABILITY AND STATISTICS
description:
The Philosophy of Probability and Statistics [PHI-4240] [PHI-4240-1]

Faculty Name
Ernst Love Eric Johannesson [ernst.johannesson@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course offers an introduction to probability theory and the philosophical problem of inter-
preting it. There are two main categories of interpretations: objectivist and subjectivist. The
course covers some of the philosophical problems associated with each, as well as some of the
technical results pertaining to them  (in particular, it provides a detailed account of various
so-called Dutch book theorems). Corresponding to the two categories of interpretation, there
are two main statistical paradigms: classical/frequentist and Bayesian. The course offers an in-
troduction to these paradigms, and to some of the problems associated with them. It also covers
some intriguing puzzles and paradoxes in probability theory, such as the Monty Hall problem
and the two-envelope paradox.

Link to full course description: https://www.dropbox.com/s/qy0judbs4hqfraq/philosophy_of_probability_and_statistics.pdf?dl=0

title: BUSINESS ETHICS
description:
Business Ethics [PHI-1679/ ENT-2029] [PHI-1679/ ENT-2029-1]

Faculty Name
Lantz Eugene Miller [lantz.miller@ashoka.edu.in] ;

title: INTRODUCTION TO COMPUTER PROGRAMMING
description:
Introduction to Computer Programming [CS-1101/ PHY-1101] [CS-1101/ PHY-1101-1]

Faculty Name
Subhashis Banerjee [suban@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Concept of an algorithm; principle of mathematical induction; correctness of algorithms; efficiency of algorithms - time and space measures; algorithms to programs; specification, top-down development and step-wise refinement; the notion of state and finite state machine; imperative programs; correctness and loop invariants; basic algorithm design techniques; encapsulation, abstractions and modularity; basics of object-oriented programming; basic logic, soundness and completeness, example of a propositional resolution; an example of concurrency; an intro to numerical computation.

The course will be programming language independent, and will involve programming in multiple programming languages, in both functional and imperative styles.

The course will expect familiarity with class 12 level mathematics, but not necessarily with programming.

Learning Outcomes

The course will address the following issues:

  1. Problem formulation in a precise and concise fashion and independent of language considerations.
  2. The design of simple algorithms from the problem specification -- their correctness and analysis of  efficiency.
  3. The intermediate steps in the design of a program from an algorithm through a process of step-wise refinement. Language dependent considerations may be used in this process, but not elsewhere.

The emphasis throughout the course will be on the analysis required while designing correct and efficient algorithms. The course is intended to teach a student a systematic process of design - beginning with problem formulation from an informal specification, through convincing arguments to algorithms, the analysis of their correctness and efficiency, and finally arriving at programs through a process of step-wise refinement. A programming language bias will be avoided and programs will be developed in both imperative and functional styles. 

The first part of the course will introduce the basics of the functional and imperative models of computation, recursive and iterative processes, and the basics of programming using higher-order functions. 

The second part of the course will  introduce data-directed programming. It will emphasize on programming with records, lists, trees, arrays and developing abstract data types. 

The third part of the course will address the issues in design and analysis of simple algorithms. Examples will be taken from Divide and conquer, Backtracking, Logical resolution, Numerical algorithms, Randomized algorithms and Geometric algorithms.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Reading material: Mostly class notes and  examples worked out in the class.

Grading Rubric

 Assignments: 45%, Quizes: 25%, Midterm: 15%, Final exam: 15%. There will be a quiz every week.

Attendance Policy

100% attendance is required, though attendance will not be recorded or monitored.

title: PHYSICS LAB 1:INTRODUCTION TO PHYSICS THROUGH EXPERIMENTS
description:
Physics Lab 1:Introduction to Physics through Experiments [PHY-1010] [PHY-1010-1]

Faculty Name
Bikram Phookun [bikram.phookun@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This is a gateway course — mandatory for those intending to major or minor in physics, though also of more general interest. The purpose of this course is to introduce students to the way in which physicists observe the world around them — what they notice, how they design experiments and make observations, how they analyse the information collected, how they match them against theory-based expectations, and how in general they draw inferences. Anyone with an interest in experimental science is welcome — there are no pre-requisites. 

 

Learning Outcomes

Designing (and appreciating the design of) experiments.

Understanding instruments, appreciating their design, and using them appropriately.

Acquiring data correctly, using appropriate instruments.

Understanding the limits of your measuring instruments, which are related to their least count and, in the case of time measurement, also to your reaction time. This leads to what is usually called error (but perhaps better called precision).

Recording data appropriately in your logbook, with the correct units.

Graphing your data, and fitting lines and curves to them if necessary.

Doing the necessary calculations, with sensitivity to dimensions and units.

Drawing conclusions, and stating them correctly. This includes understanding how measurement errors propagate into your conclusions.

Writing lab reports.

Grading Rubric

Will be discussed in class.

Attendance Policy

100% attendance normally required, with exceptions only for valid reasons.

fullName: PHY-2110-1, MATHEMATICAL PHYSICS 2, SURATNA DAS, AMIN AHMAD NIZAMI
title: MATHEMATICAL PHYSICS 2, AMIN AHMAD NIZAMI,
description:
Mathematical Physics 2 [PHY-2110] [PHY-2110-1]

Faculty Name
Amin Ahmad Nizami [amin.nizami@ashoka.edu.in] ,Suratna Das [suratna.das@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Brief Course Description:

This mathematical physics course aims to be an introduction to differential equations with a view towards physical applications (especially in later physics courses). The course will be in two parts. Part I on first order ODEs, linear systems and dynamical systems will be taught by Amin A. Nizami and Part II on second order ODEs, special functions, Fourier analysis and PDEs will be taught by Suratna Das.

Part 1 (AAN, 12 lectures)

Ordinary differential equations (first order):
Overview and importance. Rate of change problems, modeling simple systems, population growth, logistic curve. First order linear equations, Integrating factors. linear ODEs with constant coefficients. Phase plane, coupled systems of linear first order ODEs.

Nonlinear ODEs and Dynamical systems: phase portraits, flows and vector fields, phase plane analysis, linearisation about fixed points, stability analysis, limit cycles and bifurcations. Brief discussion of chaos.

 

Part 2 (SD, 12 lectures)

Second order ODEs:  Power series solutions, some special functions (Bessel, Legendre and Hermite). 

Fourier Series and Fourier integrals with a few physical applications 

Partial differential equations:
Linear first and second order PDEs, separation of variables, illustration through Laplace’s equation/ wave equation/ diffusion equation.
 

Learning Outcomes

A familiarity with linear differential equations and analytical ways of solving them; Also an acquaintance with basic geometric/qualitative ways of understanding nonlinear sytems (linearisation, stability, fixed points, flows, phase portraits etc.)

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Prerequisites: Multivariable calculus and partial differentiation besides the differential and integral calculus covered at the senior secondary school level. Some familiarity with basic linear algebra - eigenvalues and eigenvectors.

We will use the following textbooks:

G F Simmons, Differential Equations with Applications and Historical Notes 2nd edition (McGraw Hill)\

Steven Strogatz, Nonlinear Dynamics and Chaos, 2nd edition (CRC press) 

Other books useful for reference and supplementary reading are:

Edwards and Penney, Differential Equations and Boundary Value Problems (Pearson)

Smale, Hirsch and Devaney, Differential equations, dynamical systems and an introduction to chaos, 3rd edition (Academic Press)

These are all available in Indian editions

Grading Rubric

Assignments (40%), exams (50%), and class participation and attendance (10%).

Attendance Policy

Students are expected to attend all the lecture and DS sessions.
