title: DATA SCIENCE FOR SOCIAL SCIENCE RESEARCH
description:
Data Science For Social Science Research [POL-2094/ ECO-3406] [POL-2094/ ECO-3406-2]

Faculty Name
Anustubh Agnihotri [anustubh.agnihotri@ashoka.edu.in] ;

fullName: POL-2088/IR-2043, WOMEN, WAR, AND POLITICS: GENDER IN POLITICS AND IN VIOLENCE, DIPIN KAUR
title: WOMEN, WAR, AND POLITICS: GENDER IN POLITICS AND IN VIOLENCE,
description:
Women, War, and Politics: Gender in Politics and in Violence [POL-2088/ IR-2043] [POL-2088/ IR-2043-1]

Faculty Name
Dipin Kaur [dipin.kaur@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course makes a semester-long case for using gender as an effective lens to understand political participation, with a focus on contexts affected by political violence. While it is well established that male bodies make up the vast majority of decision-makers and participants in quotidian electoral politics, the same logic applies to contexts affected by conflict and war. Conventionally, male bodies are considered to be at the forefront of decision-making about whether to go to war, and on the frontlines of said wars as fighters.

In the last few decades, however, these constructions of masculinity and femininity in conflict have come to be questioned. Instead, the understanding that gender affects the way in which we see and make sense of the world around us – and that men and women experience and affect wartime dynamics differently – has come front and center. In the same spirit, we will focus on the role of women in political decision-making and participation; their role both as perpetrators of violence as combatants (and terrorists), as victims and as survivors of male-victimizing atrocities; the militarization of gendered bodies and the impact of gender-based violence in armed conflict.

Finally, we will reflect on the gendered aspects of women’s restructuring of economies in male absence, their resistance to political violence, and their role in peacekeeping and rebuilding societies after war. As we cover each theme, we will pay particular attention to what feminists have described as intersectionality and the continuum of violence, from the “private” to the “public” sphere, from the militarization of everyday living to overt violent conflict.

title: WESTERN POLITICAL THOUGHT II
description:
Western Political Thought II [POL-2017] [POL-2017-1]

Faculty Name
Vivek Yadav [vivek.yadav@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course is the second part of a year-long survey of the Western tradition of political thought. This semester the course will be divided into roughly three parts. We will begin with a survey of the German enlightenment—reading selections from the works of Kant, Hegel, Marx, and Nietzsche. The second part of the course will go over some of the key texts in the history of modern political liberalism and representative government. Here we will read Adam Smith, the Federalist papers, Sieyes, Condorcet, Tocqueville, and Mill. The third and final part of the course will be devoted to a reading of the works of Schmitt, Habermas, Rawls, and Arendt. No prerequisites 

Course requirements: Two essays (~3000 words each)

title: THE RASA OF POLITICS: INTRODUCTION TO POLITICAL THEATER
description:
The Rasa of Politics: Introduction to Political Theater [POL-2095/ ENG-2611] [POL-2095/ ENG-2611-1]

Faculty Name
Vivek Yadav [vivek.yadav@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course is a political introduction to the Indian philosophy of drama. The course is divided into two unequal parts. The first and longer part is an introduction to the central strand of Indian philosophical aesthetics—the Rasa tradition. In particular, we will read English translations of sections from three texts: the Natyasastra (the founding text of Indian aesthetics), the Dasarupaka (a famous text of dramatics written in the tenth century), and the Abhinavabharati (the mature work of the famous philosopher Abhinavagupta, also written in the late tenth century A.D.). Having introduced the basic concepts of the Rasa tradition in the first part of the course, the second part will then turn to an analysis of examples taken from contemporary cinema and politics. In this second part, students will learn how to apply the concepts of the Rasa tradition to make sense of the various proliferating forms of drama in our society. No prerequisites

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

 

The base text for the course and the source of most of the readings will be Sheldon Pollock's Rasa Reader: Classical Indian Aesthetics. We will read translated selections from the Natyasastra, the Dasarupaka (of Dhanika and Dhananjaya), Dhvanyaloka (of Anandavardhana) and Abhinavabharati (of Abhinavagupta). Some readings will also be drawn from The Bloomsbury Research Handbook of Indian Aesthetics and the Philosophy of Art edited by Arindam Chakrabarty, Teleology of Poetics in Medieval Kashmir by Lawrence McCrea. Apart from the readings, the course will involve watching a variety of contemporary forms of drama--movies, episodes from television series, television news shows and debates, political satire etc.

Grading Rubric

(Tentative) 

Two essays: 40% + 40%

Class participation: 20%

title: DEMOCRACY AND ITS DISCONTENTS
description:
Democracy and its Discontents [POL-3092/ HIS-3811] [POL-3092/ HIS-3811-1]

Faculty Name
Sunil Khilnani [sunil.khilnani@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Course Description:

DEMOCRACY AND  ITS DISCONTENTS

HIS-3811-1 / POL 3092-1
This course examines the conceptual and practical tensions between democracy as a universal norm of political legitimacy and the difficulties of achievement it faces both within established democracies as well as in relatively newer democracies such as India. It takes issues such as inequality, claims to absolute certainty (associated with religion and science), and problems of political representation, and examines theoretical attempts to resolve some of these problems against the historical and cultural realities to be found in Western and Indian democracy. Students will read texts from Plato to the present-day, and consider examples from 18th century France and America, to 21st century India, in order better to understand the theoretical blindspots and the practical potentials of democratic politics in diverse national contexts today
Democracy has established itself as the universal norm of political legitimacy, invoked alike to justify the domestic claims of states as well as their international adventures. Yet even at the height of its apparent historical triumph, it faces serious difficulties, both within the established democracies as well as outside them –engendering disaffection, disappointment, and sometimes outright rejection. This course does not conceive of democracy as a model, nor seek to identify specific norms and values. It is concerned with democratic argument and experience, across different contexts and cultures: with the varieties of political language that have come to be thought of as democratic or anti-democratic. It takes democracy as a problem in modern politics, not as the utopian answer to its riddles. It will draw on a range of thinkers and theoretical arguments, as well as on the varieties of democratic experiences across historical contexts, in order to question the nature of democracy, both as a form of society and as a type of government. Through such questioning, the course hopes to give students a better comprehension of democracy, of its fragilities and its limits, as well as its compelling political and imaginative potency. It is a course in political analysis and argument, which uses history and deploys historical examples to illuminate some of the urgent current predicaments of democracy.

Sunil Khilnani

Thu/Fri: 16.50-18.20

Cap: 50
Email: sunil.khilnani@ashoka.edu.in

title: ADVANCED TOPICS IN POLITICAL AND LEGAL THEORY
description:
Advanced Topics in Political and Legal Theory [POL-3093] [POL-3093-1]

Faculty Name
Bastian Steuwer [bastian.steuwer@ashoka.edu.in] ,Pulari M Baskar [pulari.baskar_asp23@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course is a research and writing course for students interested in political and legal theory. While the course has no single theme, likely topics to be discussed are equality and discrimination, free speech, secularism, Indian political theory. The course includes a number of outside speakers giving talks of their current work in progress. Currently confirmed speakers for this semester are Cécile Laborde (Oxford), Vidhu Verma (JNU), Udit Bhatia (York), Kasper Lippert-Rasmussen (Aarhus), Serena Olsaretti (UPF), and Arudra Burra (IIT Delhi). A small number of talks will be held on Zoom, but most talks will be in-person. Each speaker session will be paired with the preparatory session in which we will discuss some background for the talk. The aim of the course is to equip you to read, write, and engage with political and legal theory.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

One prior course in political theory and/or philosophy is required. This includes, but is not limited to, Western Political Thought or Introduction to Political Theory.

title: THE POLITICS OF PEACE: RECONSTRUCTION AND JUSTICE IN POST-CONFLICT SOCIETIES
description:
The Politics of Peace: Reconstruction and Justice in Post-Conflict Societies [IR-2041/ POL-2096] [IR-2041/ POL-2096-1]

Faculty Name
Dipin Kaur [dipin.kaur@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

In this course, we will aim to impart agency to states, insurgents, aid agencies, and civilians in narratives of post-conflict politics. Specifically, we will explore various cases from around the world to think about questions such as:

- What do survival strategies look like for civilians in conflict? Why do some civilians flee spaces of conflict while others stat back?

- Does international aid help states to protect civilians, engage in hearts and minds, or build military coercive capacities?

- How do states that receive peacekeeping to end conflict fare differently in terms of long-term violent outcomes than those that don’t?

- Why do some rebel groups translate into political parties, while others don’t? What are the impacts of insurgent political participation on post-conflict democracy?

- What are the current principles of accountability in the international system, including truth and reconciliation commissions, international criminal tribunals, and legal actions by third-party countries? 

- What are some domestic obstacles to peacekeeping, reconstruction, and justice? How do conflict-affected groups draw boundaries between retraumatization and accountability in the absence of state processes?

title: MODERN INDIA: HISTORY AND POLITICAL THEORY
description:
Modern India: History and Political Theory [HIS-3805/ POL-3094] [HIS-3805/ POL-3094-1]

Faculty Name
Sunil Khilnani [sunil.khilnani@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Modern India: History and Political Theory

HIS 3805/POL 2052

The future of Western political theory will be decided outside the West. And in deciding that future, the  experience of India will loom large. This course explores the preceding proposition, examining ideas of  political theory in relation to modern India’s history. How have concepts of democracy, nation, rights,  citizenship, and global order shaped India, and how has the Indian experience in turn altered them? The  aim of the course is to provide an introduction to modern India’s political thinking while at the same  time challenging our understanding of core political ideas. 

Modern India is constituted through some of the most intricate and intense debates in recent political  history - arguments about identity and difference, representation and dignity, individuality and  communitarianism, justice and inequality, freedom and power. We will consider these debates, and also  the practices and institutions (sometimes innovative, often flawed) to which they have given rise. The  course offers a historically grounded approach to the study of Indian political thinking, while also  examining normative political ideals in comparative context, in order to clarify these ideals.

Thu/Fri: 18.30-20.00

Cap: 50

Email: sunil.khilnani@ashoka.edu.in

title: ECOLOGY AND UNREST
description:
Ecology and Unrest [ES-3406/ SOA-3503/ POL-3050] [ES-3406/ SOA-3503/ POL-3050-1]

Faculty Name
Aniket Pankaj Aga [aniket.aga@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Ecology and Unrest

Tue/Thu - 11:50 am - 1:20 pm

AC 02 TR 009

This is a seminar cum practicum course i.e. we will explore theoretical issues and empirical findings in class AND do small group research projects in the field, to test out our classroom discussions. About half the course will be related to designing a small, do-able research project and grappling with issues of research design and methods.

This course takes up the issue of political violence and explores their underpinnings to ecological politics and conflicts over what are labeled ‘natural resources’. Human lives and livelihoods are fundamentally embedded in cultural and ecological landscapes, and by implication, actors and institutions such as states, castes, political parties, social movements often (not always) have specific political and ecological bases. In this course, we will go over issues related to mining, forests, water, shifting and settled agriculture, race and caste, etc. and link these to insurgencies, agitations, political unrest and movements for self-determination. We will explore cases from India, South Asia, and other parts of the world.

Learning Outcomes

Course Objectives

Students will…

1. Understand the interplay of domination and hegemony in state-centered politics. 

2. Connect issues of natural resources with political actors such as states, parties and social movements.

3. Explore the ecological bases of some important social and political conflicts.

4. Embed familiar concepts of freedom, autonomy, and rights in cultural and ecological systems.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Pre-requisites: None

description:
Introduction to Psychology [PSY-1001] [PSY-1001-1]

Faculty Name
Sramana Majumdar [sramana.majumdar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Course Description: 

Welcome to PSY 101! This course will introduce you to the central principles of the field of psychology. You may be familiar with the definition of psychology as the scientific study of  thought and behaviour. What does this mean exactly? Understanding psychology as an empirical  science will be our starting point. Without rigorous standards for examining human behaviour,  psychology would be little more than intuition, opinion, whim or belief.

title: STATISTICS AND RESEARCH METHODS I
description:
Statistics and Research Methods I [PSY-2001] [PSY-2001-1]

Overview

Do women talk more than men? Are Indians more interdependent than Americans? Does nutrition improve IQ? The answers to these questions and related ones are not absolute but statistical – they involve gathering data from a sample and then synthesizing the information using a relevant statistic to reach a conclusion. In this course, you will learn how to use statistical tools (central tendency, variability, probability, hypothesis testing, t-tests, ANOVA, regression, etc.) to answer questions of psychological interest. The emphasis is on understanding statistical concepts and performing basic statistical analyses, not on mathematical formulas and derivations

Learning Outcomes

This course is primarily designed for undergraduate students. By the end of this course you
will be able to
• Understand basic theoretical and applied principles of statistics.
• Gain proficiency in using statistical software for data analysis.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

This is a restricted list of various interesting and useful books that will be touched during the course.
You need to consult them occasionally.
• Garett C. Foster,David Lane, David Scott,Mikki Hebl,Rudy Guerra An Introduction to Psychological
Statistics,University of Missouri, St. Louis, 2018.
• David C. Howell, Fundamental Statistics for the Behavioral Sciences , Wadsworth Publishing, 2010.
• Tenko Raykov, George A Marcoulides Basic Statistics, Introduction with R , Rowman & Littlefield
Publishers, Inc.

title: COGNITIVE PSYCHOLOGY
description:
Cognitive Psychology [PSY-2021] [PSY-2021-1]

Faculty Name
Dipanjan Ray Ray [dipanjan.ray@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Cognitive psychology is the study of how we think, and how we make sense of the
external (and internal) environment using our prior experiences, and determine how
to respond to an ever changing environment. While the main purpose of this course
is to introduce you to the scientific study of the mind, you will also begin to understand
the central role cognition plays in our everyday lives.

Learning Outcomes

Upon completing this course, students should be able to:
• Trace the history of cognitive psychology and its influence on other fields of
psychology.
• Critically compare and contrast different theories of cognitive function.
• Demonstrate knowledge of the basic methods of cognitive research, plus their
strengths and weaknesses.
• Apply communication skills using oral and written materials to discuss topics
related to human cognition or to critically review a paper.
• Explain how theories and research findings from cognitive psychology can inform
everyday problems.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Required Texts

Goldstein, E. B. (2014). Cognitive psychology: Connecting mind, research and everyday experience. Cengage Learning.

Recommended Text

Gobet, F., Chassy, P., & Bilalic, M. (2016). Foundations of cognitive psychology. Mc-Graw Hill.

Other
Any required journal articles and book chapters will be provided on google classroom.

65-69; C= 60-64 ;C-= 55-59; D+= 50-54; D= 45-49; D-= 40-44; F= Below 40.

title: SOCIAL PSYCHOLOGY
description:
Social Psychology [PSY-2051] [PSY-2051-1]

Faculty Name
Sramana Majumdar [sramana.majumdar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Course description: Social psychology is the branch of psychological science that examines how an individual's thoughts, emotions and behavior are shaped by social norms and the larger social context. We will explore how the presence of others shapes and influences our motivations, cognition, attitudes, emotions and behavior, by looking at group processes involved in cooperation, conflict and competition.

Learning Outcomes

To introduce major theories, concepts, empirical findings and debates in social psychology. 

To familiarize students with methods within social psychological research.

To critically engage with social psychological findings and explore how they apply to our cultural contexts. 

To understand the intersections between ‘social’ and ‘individual’ and the multi-layered problems that social psychologists examine. 

To facilitate the development of interest in exploring social psychological questions of enquiry among students. 

 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Prerequisites- SRM 1 & Introduction to Psychology/ Thinking Like A Psychologist

title: STATISTICS AND RESEARCH METHODS II
description:
Statistics and Research Methods II [PSY-2002] [PSY-2002-1]

Faculty Name
Krishna Venkata Melnattur [krishna.melnattur@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Quantitative psychological data is frequently a bunch of structured numbers. These cannot be interpreted meaningfully until one understands and appreciates how the data came about and what can be properly inferred from the data. In this course, we will focus on quantitative methodology. This course is for students who know the basics of statistical analyses. The aim is to develop a trained eye for sound methodology to better evaluate other scientists’ research, as well as their own. Students will also learn about planning, ethical conduct, and reporting of findings from a survey and experimental study. Along with some of the most widely-used quantitative methods in psychology (e.g., surveys and experiments), students will also understand how these methods are different from alternative methodologies (i.e., qualitative methods, mixed methods).

 

Learning Outcomes

By the end of this course, you will be able to:

  • Understand various quantitative methods that psychologists use to investigate research questions.
  • Plan, design, and conduct a psychometrically-sound survey; formulate hypotheses, test them, analyze the results, interpret them
  • Write report of a survey study to effectively communicate your results
  • Plan, design, and conduct an experimental study; formulate hypotheses, design and conduct an experiment to test the hypotheses, analyze the results, interpret them
  • Write report of an experimental study to effectively communicate your results
  • Understand alternative methodologies available for researchers (qualitative and mixed-method) and when to use them
  • Grasp, analyze, and critique academics research papers in psychology
  • Become literate consumers of scientific information.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Prerequisites: Pass in Statistics and Research Methodology I, or equivalent modules in math, economics, or political science.

Required materials:

Shaughnessy J. J., Zechmeister, E. B., Zechmeister, J. S., & (2012). Essentials of research methods in psychology. (9th ed.) Tata McGraw-Hill.

 

Grading Rubric
  1. Quizzes (including syllabus quiz): 20%
  2. Survey Research Report [Group]: 30%
  3. Experimental Research Report [Group]: 35%
  4. Participation: 10%
  5. Attendance: 5%

  • Missing 6 classes: One grade cut on the final grade for the course

title: CLINICAL PSYCHOLOGY
description:
Clinical Psychology [PSY-2041] [PSY-2041-1]

Faculty Name
Simi Ghosh [simi@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course focuses on understanding the phenomenology (description), etiology (causes), and treatment of abnormal behavior. Major psychological syndromes will be discussed along with the current APA classification system (DSM-5) and other classification systems. Genetic, biological, social, and psychological parameters implicated in the etiology of these syndromes will be introduced

Learning Outcomes
  • Understand the merits and limitations of research methods and assessment techniques for clinical psychology
  • Learn basics of critical and analytical skills required to read a journal article on clinical psychology
  • Understand and be able to describe the current APA classification system (DSM-5) and show appreciation for other classification systems internationally
  • Understand and be able to describe the major psychological disorders
  • Describe the genetic, biological, social, and psychological influences on these disorders
  • Understand the influence of societal, cultural, historical, and environmental influences on these disorders
  • Appreciate the concept of comorbidity
  • Discuss mental health services historically and contextually
  • Understand ethical issues involved with mental health services
  • Learn the importance of vocabulary, empathy and nuances in abnormal behavior
  • Be able to navigate and think through elementary clinical problems in practice
  • Learn to write an interview questionnaire based on a clinical case study
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Text : Butcher J.N, Mineka S, Hooley J.M, Kapoor P (2019) Abnormal Psychology (18th ed) Pearson India
https://www.amazon.in/dp/9353065593?tag=pearindieduc-21 ( Rs.781 from amazon India for paperback, Rs. 389 for Kindle edition) Students are highly encouraged to get their own copy of the south asian edition)

title: INTRODUCTION TO COUNSELING
description:
Introduction to Counseling Psychology [PSY-3042] [PSY-3042-1]

Faculty Name
Soumya Madabhushi [soumya.madabhushi@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Course Description:

This course is designed to provide the students with an overview of Counseling Psychology as a profession and define the subject matter of this field. The history, philosophy, values, and organization of counseling psychology both as an academic discipline and as a helping profession are explored. The course will provide students with an introduction to the major therapeutic approaches and an exploration of issues associated with values, ethics, research design, and more. Discussions, demonstrations, and exercises give students an opportunity to explore counseling psychology as a career path.

 

Learning Outcomes

By the end of the semester students will be able to:

  • distinguish counseling psychology as a profession from other areas of contemporary applied psychology and define its subject matter;
  • recognize the ethical issues associated with the field of counseling psychology;
  • describe and evaluate the theories and research pertaining to a range of topics in counseling psychology;
  • compare and contrast different psychotherapy orientations;
  • reflect on the role of social issues, privilege and oppression, and multicultural issues related to psychotherapy and mental health
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Required Readings:

Gelso, C. J., Nutt Williams, E., & Fretz, B. R. (2014). Counseling psychology (3rd ed.). Washington, DC: American Psychological Association. https://doi.org/10.1037/14378-000 (ISBN: 978-1-4338-1711-3)

APA Style Tutorials & Webinars: https://apastyle.apa.org/instructional-aids/tutorials-webinars/

title: PSYCHOACTIVE DRUGS
description:
Psychoactive Drugs [PSY-3043] [PSY-3043-1]

Faculty Name
Simi Ghosh [simi@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course will provide an overview of psychoactive drugs and their use in treatment of common mental health disorders. The course will be conducted at an advanced level and the content will be a mix of didactic lectures by the instructor and student run presentation of selected clinical trials. There will be a considerable amount of neurobiological/ pharmacological topics covered in the course. The instructor will try to foster critical thinking and analytical skills to the class. Apart from dissemination of topic specific knowledge, the instructor will strive to teach students a set of rules, generalizable principles, looking at data with a critical eye and help students develop analytical skills that they can attribute to any problem of their choosing in the future, within the larger domain of psychopharmacology. A large part of this class will be about class participation and class discussion. Students are encourage to express and voice their thoughts and concerns, and most importantly, to ask questions at all times. Students are also encouraged to think of the material from a biological, ethical, practical and clinical perspective.
Prerequisites:
Required: Clinical Psychology (PSY2041) SRM-2(PSY2002) Recommended: Biological Psychology/Introduction to Neuroscience (PSY 2011)

Learning Outcomes

By the end of this course students will be able to

  • Evaluate clinical research on psychological disorders with a critical eye
  • Understand the broad mechanisms of action, functional systems acted upon, efficacy, safety and side effects of major classes of psychoactive drugs
  • Develop an understanding of essential pharmacological concepts
  • Understand the complex issues triaging on market strategies, pharmaceutical industries pushing certain drugs, efficacy and safety parameters of psychoactive drugs and patient compliance and side effects, that determine the ultimate usage of a drug as a safe treatment option
  • Understand the historical framework of how certain psychoactive drugs came to be of routine usage
  • Critically read, interpret and analyze clinical trial data
  • Develop presentation and group discussion skills
  • Develop collaboratively analytical skills
  • Discuss mental health services historically, and in today's India, and appreciate international differences
  • Understand ethical issues involved with mental health services
  • Improve writing and peer reviewing skills
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

1. Brunton LL, Chabner BA, Knollman BC, (2012), Goodman & Gilman's The pharmacological basis of therapeutics, 12th ed, New York, McGraw Hill Medical. (Reference)

title: EVOLUTIONARY COGNITION
description:
Evolutionary Cognition [PSY-3012/ BIO-3204/ BIO-6204] [PSY-3012/ BIO-3204/ BIO-6204-1]

Faculty Name
Bittu R [bittu@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The goal of this course is to delve into the complicated question of how cognition has been shaped by Evolution. This question has been addressed by various disciplines, including the fields of “Evolutionary Psychology”, “Sociobiology” and “Physical Anthropology”. The common problem with the construction of the framework of these fields is the chain of untested assumptions underlying the historical ideas in the field, and the development of ideas unmoored to the physiological basis of either evolution or cognition. We will break down each model used to teach Evolutionary Psychology to critically examine each system, and each system feeds into a larger understanding of what is involved in the evolution of cognitive abilities. This course looks at the question of whether there are aspects of behaviour and cognition that do and do not seem to have evolved in particular evolutionary contexts.

The first step in our critical examination is to understand what evolution does and does not mean in a Darwinian framework; as well as whether and how cognition can be defined and accurately assessed. We look at what aspects of behaviour are hardwired, and what is plastic. We understand that evolution pertains to genetic changes, and get a quick understanding of what genetics constitutes. We then learn about epigenetics, gene expression, how the framework of genes and their expression drives physiological development of an embryo, how the brain develops as a subset of the body from a genetic framework, and about the relative ridigity and plasticity of parts of the brain during development and in adulthood. We then visit various questions in evolutionary cognition, focussing on the historical debates between the people who began extending the framework of evolution to understand behaviour and cognition.

 

Learning Outcomes

The learning goals for this class are to primarily learn how to distinguish an evidence-based understanding of evolutionary cognition from what have been called “just-so” stories, which clog the public and even scientific realm.

 

Classes will be structured with lectures interspersed with discussions and student presentations. Students will take responsibility for presenting specific papers and sections of books to the rest of the class. This will be a reading and discussion-heavy course.

 

The main expectation of students is that they pay full attention in class, alerting the TF or me, through class discussions or by posting on discussion fora if there is anything they do not understand. Piazza posts are encouraged to be public, so that other students can benefit from reading responses to questions asked, although they can certainly be anonymous.

Grading Rubric

This class will have one assignment and one presentation per student in class, where you can chose a topic to research and critically analyse the literature on the issue and develop your thinking on the question. Students can choose between a presentation and assignment format for their third submission. Each submission, whether assignment or presentation, will count for 30% each of your final grade.

 

Your participation in class or even by email will count towards the remaining 10%. This means that attendance is in some sense graded. Also note that your participation during presentations carry more weight than participation in other classes. The breakdown of this 10% is: 2% sharing of all presentations and assignments on piazza, 2% attentive listening, 4% attendance, 2% general participation in class or outside class during the semester (note that participation is calculated relative to the maximum participation score).

Attendance Policy

Attendance: will be marked as a component of the participation grade. Missing class is a student’s loss and will have a marginal impact on the class participation grades. For students who miss class for unavoidable reasons, they can come to me during office hours for help.

title: QUALITATIVE RESEARCH METHODS
description:
Qualitative Research Methods [PSY-3082] [PSY-3082-1]

Faculty Name
Aniruddha Methi [aniruddha.methi_ug23@ashoka.edu.in] ,Rashmi Nair [rashmi.nair@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Unlike quantitative research methods that are aimed at hypothesis testing and generalization, qualitative methods aim to understand a phenomenon in a context-sensitive manner and help generate hypotheses. Here are just a handful of questions that you can answer using qualitative methods: How do Ashoka University students perceive their experiences in relation to Delhi University students? How are memories of collective violence in the past transmitted across generations? What was the psychological impact of COVID on migrant workers? How do employees in corporate organizations feel about their bosses? This course equips students with the theoretical as well as practical aspects of qualitative research in psychology. Furthermore, students will learn about communicating qualitative research.
 

Learning Outcomes

Course Objectives: By the end of the term, you will be able to:

  • Understand the theoretical assumptions underlying qualitative research and the different components of the qualitative research cycle.
  • Identify, conceptualize, and plan a qualitative research project including choosing appropriate sampling strategies.
  • Plan and undertake thematic analysis of qualitative data.
  • Communicate the results of a qualitative study in the form of a scientific poster.
  • Understand what makes for scientifically sound and high-quality qualitative work.
  • Critically examine your role in shaping the research process.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

All books and readings will be posted on Google Classroom. 

Required Book: Braun, V. and Clarke, V. (2013) Successful qualitative research: A practical guide for beginners. Sage Publications. 

Optional Book: Silverman, D. (2007) A Very Short, Fairly Interesting, Reasonably Cheap Book about Qualitative Research. Sage Publications.

Grading Rubric

I will use the rubric provided by Ashoka University.

 

 

Attendance Policy

 Attendance will be taken within the first five minutes of every class. I expect students to attend all lectures, workshops, and discussion sessions. The following rules will apply for absences:

  • Missing 5 classes: One grade cut on the final grade for the course

description:
Advanced Neuroscience [PSY-3011/ BIO-3114/ BIO-4114/ BIO-6114] [PSY-3011/ BIO-3114/ BIO-4114/ BIO-6114-1]

Faculty Name
Bittu R [bittu@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

In this class, we will put together a series of topics in neuroscience for further study. A rough set of topics is provided in the syllabus, but we can explore really any other system that people are interested in. Every week, one class will involve teaching, and the other will involve discussion and presentations. In the second class, students take turns contributing to the collective understanding of the field by presenting individually selected readings, based on your own interest.  Then we will collectively discuss advances in each field, relying on looking up fresh primary research papers together.

Learning Outcomes

The goal of this class is for students to explore various topics in neuroscience that give one a sense of the possible framework of computation through electrical signaling by wet, messy, living systems. The introduction to neuroscience course should have already given you all a sense of how single neurons perform basic computations of addition and subtraction and how elementary circuits might perform more complicated computations. We will explore how these multi neuron circuits work in this course not through textbook material or conventional teaching, but rather through reading primary scientific material.

Grading Rubric

Grading is equally divided between assignments and presentation - one assignment, one presentation, and one choice between an assignment and a presentation. 

 

Your participation in class or even by email will count towards the remaining 10%. In terms of class participation, questions in class will be counted, as will engaging  by email, etc. Your attendance is a part of your participation grade.

title: CONTENT ANALYSIS AND COMMUNICATION RESEARCH METHODS
description:
Content Analysis and Communication Research Methods [MS-3215/ PSY-3153] [MS-3215/ PSY-3153-1]

Faculty Name
Purnima Mehrotra [purnima.mehrotra@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Content Analysis and Audience Response: Understanding Behaviour Change through Communication How does one formulate the “right” questions? What are the ways and means of information retrieval, processing, and organization? How does one summarize and articulate the information or "research results" in a lucid manner? All of these are important questions that this course will help you address. Students of communication studies need to develop a strong understanding of and ability to use research methods as it is a practical and important skill that will be required in further studies, internships and future professional positions.

This course will provide an overview of research methods used in communication with a specific focus on content analysis. Content Analysis is the systematic and objective analysis of message characteristics and is one of the fastest growing methods used in communication research. It is a powerful tool because it enables one to examine a wide ranging set of social and cultural patterns in communication that are often subtle or difficult to detect through other means. While outlining commonly used communication research methods, this course will provide an overview of the potential and the challenges of conducting content analyses, as well as the specific procedures relevant to carrying out this type of research so that you will be able to design and execute such research independently.

Learning Outcomes

Students will understand the various methods employed in communication research. They will learn to analyze media messages, including audio/video, print, and visuals.Learn about sampling, validity and reliability, category construction, calculation of intercoder reliability,and analysis of data.
Each student will undertake a research project using this methodology.

description:

Faculty Name
Soumya Madabhushi [soumya.madabhushi@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course is designed to provide an introduction to psychotherapy skills. Students will be able to understand elements of ethical and effective counseling practice. They will be able to identify and use a variety of helping Skills at a beginner level with an appreciation of personal and sociocultural factors. The course also aims to enhance student understanding of self as a tool and increase self-awareness and self-reflective abilities. Students will practice helping skills with each other and attendance is mandatory and contributes to the course grade. Note that the course will involve discussing and working with emotionally charged content. Students should also be prepared to reflect on, and talk about (not mandated) some personal/emotional issues in class.

Learning Outcomes

At the completion of this course, students will be able to…

  • Identify helping skills, analyze their function, and evaluate their usefulness
  • Demonstrate a working knowledge of the Hill three-stage model of helping.
  • Use helping skills at a beginner level
  • Articulate ways their & others’ use of helping skills are influenced by personal and larger sociocultural characteristics

Note: Completion of this course does not qualify students to practice as counselors or therapists.

fullName: BIO-4029 / BIO-6029, RHYTHMS OF LIFE AND SLEEP, SOUGATA ROY, KRISHNA M
title: RHYTHMS OF LIFE AND SLEEP,
description:
Rhythms of Life and Sleep [BIO-4029/ BIO-6029/ PSY-3013] [BIO-4029/ BIO-6029/ PSY-3013-1]

Faculty Name
Krishna Venkata Melnattur [krishna.melnattur@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sougata Roy [sougata.roy@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview


Rhythms of Life

Rhythms ranging from milliseconds to a year are observed across all kingdom of life. We will learn about all rhythms with special emphasis on the 24 hour circadian rhythms. Living organisms adapt to the surrounding environment by coordinating different biological tasks with the 24 h rotation of the earth with the help of a cell-based clock, termed as the circadian clock. Circadian clock generates self-sustaining endogenous rhythms in physiology, behaviour and metabolism that have wide implications in eukaryotes and prokaryotes. This course will give a brief overview of how circadian clocks generate temporal rhythms and their significance in survival and adaptability of the organisms.

Sleep

Sleep is a brain state we enter into and exit from daily. Further, it is not just us humans who sleep - sleep is near ubiquitous among animals. Yet, sleep remains enigmatic. In this section, we will introduce the neuroscience of sleep. We will begin with a description of sleep phenomenology, go on to discuss the circuits and transmitters that regulate sleep,  talk about sleep disorders, and finally consider some ideas about the functions of sleep. We will draw on sleep literature in humans, small mammals, and crucially very many invertebrates that are known to sleep.
 

Learning Outcomes

Rhythms of Life

Understanding the fundamentals and mechanism of temporal rhytms of behaviour, physiology, biochemistry and metabolism from a single celled to multicellular organisms

Sleep

Understanding the mechanisms that regulate sleep as well as the functional consequences of sleep for brain and body function.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

This course is for UG who have completed Introduction to biology 2 or Introduction to biology 3 OR Biology M.Sc. OR PhD students.

Some printed material will be provided in the class. 

Some electronic reading materials will be provided in the class.

a) Class Participation (5 marks).   b) One  exam of (20 marks).  c) Class assignments (15 Marks). d) Presentation (10 Marks). The grading rubric will be different for M.Sc. and PhD students and will be discussed during the class.

title: PSYCHOTHERAPY AND THE PHILOSOPHY OF MIND
description:
Psychotherapy and the Philosophy of Mind [PHI-2430/ PSY-3166] [PHI-2430/ PSY-3166-1]

Faculty Name
Alexander Bruce Watson [alex.watson@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The course is primarily intended for those wanting to major in PsyPhi, but is open to anyone.  It will consider whether the ways of thinking characteristic of Philosophy of Mind can yield any fruit when applied to the topic of Psychotherapy, and whether the Psychotherapy literature is of use to any of the debates in the Philosophy of Mind.

We will start with Freud's case study of Elisabeth von R., who, it turns out, was in love with her sister's husband without knowing it.  How can one be in love with someone without knowing it?  This paradox led to Freud's distinctive map of the psyche with its division into conscious and unconscious parts.  A censor stands at the gateway dividing these two, deciding what it is safe to let pass from the unconscious to the conscious.  We will consider Sartre's critique of the coherence of this idea of the censor.

You will be introduced to some of the central debates in the Philosophy of Mind so that we can think about their application to psychotherapy.  If conversations with a psychotherapist can indeed result in significant changes in our mental life and our behaviour, does this imply mutual causation between the physical and the mental?  If so, is it more compatible with some positions than others in debates about the mind-body problem and free will?

Learning Outcomes

You will emerge from the course familiar with

  • central issues in the Philosophy of Mind
  • the theory and practice of several modalities within Psychotherapy: Psychodynamic, Humanistic (gestalt, person-centred), Existential

and having reflected on what light these two areas of enquiry can throw on each other

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The reading list is not yet finalized, but it will include readings by

Freud

Karen Horney

Frits Perls

Alice Miller

Brian Thorne and David Mearns

Carl Rogers and Rollo May

Anthony Storr

Irvin Yalom

Alexander Lowen

Jean-Paul Sartre

Peter Smith and O.R. Jones (The Philosophy of Mind: An Introduction)

 

Grading Rubric

Your final grade will be calculated from a combination of five scores. These will be weighted in the following way:

10% Presentation

27% Mid-length assignments

20% Engagement with the course through Perusall annotations

27% Final Essay

16% Quiz questions

title: MORAL PSYCHOLOGY
description:
Moral Psychology [PHI-2702/ PSY-3165] [PHI-2702/ PSY-3165-1]

Faculty Name
Tatyana Aleksandrovna Kostochka [tatyana.kostochka@ashoka.edu.in] ,Yash Agarwal [yash.agarwal_asp23@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

"The job of moral psychology is to tell us how, in acting, feeling, and thinking, we end up related to the right and the good, or the wrong and the bad."

- Nomy Arpaly and Timothy Schroder, In Praise of Desire, p. 1

The world is a messy place and we are messy parts of it. We rationalize our bad actions, act against our better judgment, and want things that we believe to be bad for ourselves and others. In this course, we will explore some aspects of our psychology that have an important relationship to morality—belief, desire, emotion, motivation, intention, and character. The topics are broken up into four rough categories: thinking, feeling, planning, and acting. As we try to get a grasp on these psychological matters, we will wrestle with the questions: “what we are morally responsible for?” and “when we are worthy of praise or blame?”

Further, students will understand the merits and challenges of using intersectionality when studying psychological issues.

  • unpack the ways in which interlocking systems of brahminism, colonialism, racism, sexism, ethnocentrism, ageism, and heterosexism shape people’s lives
  • apply intersectional perspectives to their everyday lives and in seemingly non-psychological contexts, such as mass media, popular culture, and their own education

title: COMMUNICATION THEORY AND BEHAVIORAL CHNGE
description:
Communication Theory and Behavioral Change [MS-3210/ PSY-3141/ VA-3020] [MS-3210/ PSY-3141/ VA-3020-1]

Faculty Name
Purnima Mehrotra [purnima.mehrotra@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

“There is nothing so practical as a good theory.”— Social psychologist Kurt Lewin


We live in an era in which the processes of content production and the patterns of media consumption are changing rapidly. Even the most  seasoned media professionals are struggling to determine what the media landscape of the future will look like and what business models can be
used to support it.  It is in times like these when theories of mass communication are particularly valuable.  The broadly explanatory concepts of theory help us understand some of the underlying ways in which humans respond to and share different types of information, and can help us make some informed predictions about what the future may hold. This course will introduce students to mass communication theory, and will focuses on theories of audience and effect. This class will provide you with an overview of some of the important theories in the field, and
will encourage you to think about how these apply to the real world and how they will inform your future work, perhaps, as a media professional.

This course is cross-listed with Psychology as the two disciplines are closely related. Some studies that are considered seminal in the field of communication were originally conducted by psychologists, e.g. works by Hovland, Bandura, Lasswell, Lewin, Festinger and Fishbein. The two disciplines continue to enrich and enhance each other such that there are many common publication platforms, partnerships among scholars, and common faculty across departments. In terms of the historical evolution of the two fields psychology is an older and more established discipline than communication, hence communication continues to draw on the more consolidated approaches of psychology.


 

 

 

Learning Outcomes

Learning Outcomes

Understand the historical development of Mass Communication theories and how they link with historically important social, political and technological developments in the field of communication

Develop an understanding of the most often used theories of mass communication and the ability to apply them in research and practice

Critically evaluate theories as applied to practical mass communication problems e.g. media portrayals of sex and violence

Understand how mass communication is a powerful tool of persuasion and how it has been and continues to be used across sectors - adverstising, politics, development etc.

 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Reading materials will be shared with students at the beginning of the semester either as a compendium for the entire semester or in batches arranged according to major theoretical traditions in communication theory.

Some easy reads that students might find useful:

A First Look at Communication Theory by EM Griffin

Mass Communication Theory by Dennis McQuail

Grading Rubric

Class participation:                                                                                                   15%
Brief written critique of selected readings/quiz/other weekly assignments:              20%
Presentations:                                                                                                          20%
Mid-term paper:                                                                                                        20%
Final paper:                                                                                                              25%

Attendance Policy

Students should not miss more than 2 class sessions as we will cover a lot of material in each session. Too many absences will impede your ability to follow, learn and absorb the material. For any absences, students are required to notify the instructor.

title: ELEMENTARY SANSKRIT - I
description:
Elementary Sanskrit - I [SAN-1001/ HIS-1101] [SAN-1001/ HIS-1101-1]

Faculty Name
Naresh Keerthi [naresh.keerthi@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Elementary Sanskrit I is the first of a set of three language courses meant to introduce the beginner to Sanskrit Grammar.  At the end of this intensive course, the student will have learnt about half of the major topics required to read and comprehend texts in Classical Sanskrit. We assume no prior knowledge on behalf of the student.

Learning Outcomes

At th end of this course, student will be able to read and understand simple Sanskrit sentences with the help of a dictionary.

This is the list of topics we will cover in this course –

the alphabet

phonology

parts of speech

overview of the verbal system

indicative mood, future

overview of the nominal system

case grammar

converbs (infinitives)

‘past’ participles

past imperfect

present potential mood

prepositions, preverbs

vowel gradation and sandhi

overview of compounds

poetics 1 –productive synonyms, Amarakoṣa

-a, -i, -u terminal stems

derivative nouns, abstract nouns

pronouns 1

syllabic metres – scansion

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

We will mostly follow the Devavāṇīpraveśikā by Robert and Sally Goldman. (2009/  New Delhi: Motilal Banarsidas) – chapters 1-8. Additional handouts and worksheets will be shared over the AMS.

There are no prerequisites for this course.

Attendance Policy

Grade breakdown

Class Participation 10%

Weekly assignments 20%

Midterm exam 1: 30%

Final Exam: 40%

title: INTERMEDIATE SANSKRIT 2
description:
Intermediate Sanskrit 2 [SAN-2002/ HIS-2802] [SAN-2002/ HIS-2802-1]

Faculty Name
Alexander Bruce Watson [alex.watson@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course is for those who have either done 2 or 3 semesters of Sanskrit already (i.e. those whose most recent Sanskrit course was either 'Elementary 2' or 'Intermediate 1').

We will start reading actual Classical Sanskrit.  First the Hitopadeśa and perhaps then the Bhagavad Gītā.  The actual texts will depend on what the students want.  Along the way we will consolidate grammar.

Learning Outcomes

Over the course of the semester your grammar will be consolidated and extended, and you will become gradually more confident reading actual classical Sanskrit.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

We will read from Lanman's Sanskrit reader.

Before each class students will prepare.  During class we will go around the room, each student reading one sentence and attempting to translate it.  We will then discuss it before passing on to the next student for the next sentence.

Final exam 60%

Attendance Policy

If you miss a class, the 2 exams will be harder for you, as the passage we translate in that class may come up in the exam.

title: THE DANCE OF SOUND: AN INTRODUCTION TO METRE AND POETICS IN SANSKRIT
description:
The Dance of Sound: An Introduction to Metre and Poetics in Sanskrit [SAN-2004] [SAN-2004-1]

Faculty Name
Nirajan Kafle [nirajan.kafle@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course will introduce students to metre and prosody (chandaś-śāstra) in Sanskrit.  Students will learn to recite some of the major Vedic and post-Vedic metres by reading from the original Sanskrit texts from different genres. During this course, students will develop the skill of reciting Sanskrit verses in different meters. We will also learn to identify the metres by scanning the verses on paper, and at the same time by cultivating an ear for the rhythmic patterns of each metre.

Using the same exemplar verses, we will acquaint ourselves with the poetic figures (alaṅkāra) and poetic conventions (kavisamaya) seen in Sanskrit and Prakrit belles lettres.

Learning Outcomes

Course Objectives

To become familiar with the major Sanskrit and Prakrit metres

To learn about major poetic figures and poetic conventions in Sanskrit literature.

To learn different styles of reciting verses in the major Sanskrit metres.

To recognize the Sanskrit metres upon listening or reading them.

To get acquainted with the vocabulary of chandaḥ-śāstra for the description of metrics.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Course Book - We will not follow any single textbook for this course. Relevant tets and audio resources will be uploaded to the AMS in time.

Prerequisites - The course presupposes a basic knowledge of the Devanagari alphabet.

Grading Rubric

There will be two written/oral examinations. A student has to get 60% in order to pass the course.

Class attendance and participation (30% marks)

Midterm exam (35% marks)

Final exam (35% marks)

Attendance Policy

Academic integrity is very important. Students should present/submit their original work. While citing other’s work, please provide references to the works consulted.

Students should come to class on time. You cannot absent yourself with same-day notice, except under very serious circumstances.

If students fail to come to the class, 5 marks will be reduced for each dropped class. If a student comes to the class after 10 minutes that is considered an absence.

title: THE GEOGRAPHY OF RELIGION IN THE SUBCONTINENT
description:
The Geography of Religion in the Subcontinent [SAN-3001] [SAN-3001-1]

Faculty Name
Nirajan Kafle [nirajan.kafle@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This is an introductory course on the landscape of religion in South Asia.  We will explore the broadest contours of India’s many diverse religious traditions, their antecedents, branches, practices and texts. Our approach will be historical, with thematic issues introduced to further our understanding. The student will be exposed to primary religious texts in translation. Particular emphasis will be placed on the local ‘little traditions’ that often lack a textual record, and are often under-represented in academic scholarship. This course is conceptualized as an introduction to classical South Asian culture, and thought, with religion as a frame.

Learning Outcomes

To get an extensive, broad overview of early and modern religions of South Asia.

To balance a critical and historical approach with openness and sensitivity to the systems under study.

To understand the imbrication of religion, culture and society in each case.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Fred W. Clothey (2006). Religion in India. A Historical Introduction by. Routledge: Taylor & Francis.

Further weekly readings will soon be uploaded to the AMS.

title: SOCIOLOGY AND THE MAKING OF CONCEPTS
description:
Sociology and the Making of Concepts [SOA-1101] [SOA-1101-1]

Faculty Name
Deepak Mehta [deepak.mehta@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

SOA 1101: SOCIOLOGY AND THE MAKING OF CONCEPTS

 

Rather than ask, ‘what is a concept?’ this course is concerned with showing how concepts are made in sociology and anthropology, how they are played out or performed in local contexts and the analytic dividend that is associated with such performances. Put simply, we will ask what is the work done by concepts and whether they enrich or impoverish our understanding of social relationships. In a second move, the course will pick up forms of inquiry, such as definitions and factual descriptions to show how concepts appear. Do they point us to some abstract essence, or are they central to how we live our everyday lives? In negotiating with the above and in consultation with students of the class the course will address any three the following questions.

How do we establish proof? What is the value of the archive and the library in arriving at verity.

Are there rules for the study of social facts?

How do we delimit the rationality of science and politics?

Are commodities bundles of social relatedness?

How are distinctions established in society, and what is the significance of hierarchy in establishing social privilege?

Is social power a relationship and what is its link to order and disorder?

Can the secular be separated from the sacred?

What is the force of visual images? Do they have any relationship to our sense of well-being?

fullName: SOA-2102, GIFT, COMMODITY AND THE EXCHANGE OF VALUES, MEKHALA KRISHNAMURTHY
title: GIFT, COMMODITY AND THE EXCHANGE OF VALUES,
description:
Gift, Commodity and the Exchange of Values [SOA-2102] [SOA-2102-1]

Faculty Name
Mekhala Krishnamurthy [mekhala.krishnamurthy@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

What kinds of things are gifts and commodities? What does their exchange tell us about the relations between persons and things, between things and things, and between different persons party to an exchange? What gives a thing a sense of value? Are there such things that are useful but that are not up for exchange? What kinds of debts are generated when gifts and commodities are exchanged? Does the clearing of a debt signal the end of a relationship? Is reciprocity a good thing after all? If being creditable is a respectable characteristic, why are creditors typically such villainous characters? Is being indebted a show of strength or a sign of weakness? What goes into making a price? What does it really mean for a thing to be priceless? If time is indeed money, is money also in some way a form or measure of time? 

This course is an intensive introduction to the anthropology of exchange through the circulation of gifts and commodities across diverse times and places. We will read a set of classical and contemporary texts that explore the complex processes and relations of gift and commodity exchange and consider the rich and seemingly endless debates that they generate for the discipline and beyond

fullName: SOA-2104-1, KIN, FRIENDS, AND ENEMIES, RITA BRARA MUKHOPADHYAY
title: KIN, FRIENDS, RITA BRARA MUKHOPADHYAY,
description:
Kin, Friends and Enemies [SOA-2104] [SOA-2104-1]

Faculty Name
Rita Brara Mukhopadhyay [rita.mukhopadhyay@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Why do we have a taboo on incest? Why do cousins marry in some cultures?  Do women have to leave their natal homes on marriage?  Why are children often named after their father’s lines? How do the contours of American kinship and marriage differ from practices in India? What do we mean by ‘blood’ relatives? Is kinship in the genes? How do these notions relate to new reproductive technologies?

Puzzle over these human conundrums with the classic and the contemporary in the field. As one of the subject’s most popular writers put it, ‘Kinship is to anthropology what logic is to philosophy or the nude is to art’. It structures human life.

title: DECODING GENETICALLY MODIFIED CROPS: THE GLOBAL POLITICS OF AGRICULTURE AND BIOTECHNOLOGY
description:
Decoding Genetically Modified Crops: The Global Politics of Agriculture and Biotechnology [ES-3411/ SOA-3502/ POL-3061/ BIO-3411] [ES-3411/ SOA-3502/ POL-3061/ BIO-3411-1]

Faculty Name
Aniket Pankaj Aga [aniket.aga@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Decoding genetically modified (GM) crops: The global politics of agriculture and biotechnology
Spring 2023
Tue/Thu - 8:30 am - 10:00 am

AC 01 LR 103

Course description

Genetically modified (GM) are the subject of fierce global controversies. Nearly every aspect about them is disputed – from their role in “feeding the world” and their impacts with respect to yield and environment to regulatory policies and peoples’ notions of choice and ethics. This course examines the GM debate by looking at the transformations of agriculture and agricultural sciences in the 20th century. It analyzes how private industry has sought profits from agriculture, and the consequent impacts on farming communities. This will help us grasp deeper issues that are often lost in heated anti/pro-GM arguments. Surveying controversies in India, the USA and other parts of the world, the course will demonstrate how the GM debate is shaped by the inter-related shifts in law, politics, and science. By way of examining the case of Bt cotton, Golden Rice, Bt brinjal among others, the course ultimately invites the question: Where do GM crops fit in the landscape of the burning issues faced by the average farmer, if at all?

More broadly, the questions we will consider in this class are, in fact, relevant to most technologies incident upon agriculture, and on the relationship between technology and society, in general. Our learnings from this course will carry over to a larger set of issues than GM crops alone.

This is a seminar course i.e. it is a discussion-oriented course that relies on close reading of research. This course will involve a good amount of reading. 

Learning Outcomes

Students will…

1. Study the relationship between agricultural sciences and GM crops.

2. Study the questions of public interest in different classes of GM crops, particularly insect-resistant crops, herbicide tolerant crops, and Golden Rice.

3. Engage with the complexities of regulatory design.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Pre-requisites: None

title: ANTHROPOLOGY'S METHODS
description:
Anthropology's Methods [SOA-3101] [SOA-3101-1]

Faculty Name
Andrew Alan Johnson [andrew.johnson@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

There are few disciplines that seem to be so deeply wedded to a method as anthropology is to something called fieldwork and to something related called ethnography. So much so that one often wonders if and to what extent anthropology is method? This course explores the relationships between anthropology and ethnography and those between question and method in the making of the discipline. Indeed, in some ways, the course could also have been named Anthropology's Questions. Here are some other questions we will ask: What might it mean to have an anthropological imagination or an ethnographic sensibility? How are they related? Where does the field of fieldwork begin and end and how does one find it? What is the relationship between a 'site' and 'sight' in constituting the field? How else does one sense the field? How long does it take to arrive at and exist in the everyday and how does one exit? How does one deal with questions of subjects and objects, subjectivity and objectivity, intimacy and scale, the actual and the virtual, power and privilege, anonymity and representation, originality and authenticity? How does one go about uncovering and establishing relationships in practice? What is the role of comparison in anthropology? What does it mean to move relationally and comparatively in conceptual and empirical terms? What are the different ways in which anthropologists approach 'the field' and 'the archive'? How does one go about conducting fieldwork and composing an ethnography? What are disciplinary codes and conventions, how are they established, when are they broken? In what ways might the limitations of anthropology's methods expand our imagination of its very possibilities?  Over the semester, this course will attempt to address these and other questions through close reading, discussion and debates on a range of anthropological texts and texts on anthropology and its methods. Students will also complete a series of methodological exercises and assignments, including crafting a short research proposal and paper.

title: THESIS WORKSHOP II
description:
Thesis Workshop II [SOA-4102] [SOA-4102-1]

Faculty Name
Kathryn Collins Hardy [kathryn.hardy@ashoka.edu.in] ;

title: UNDERSTANDING URBAN POVERTY
description:
Understanding Urban Poverty [MS-2811/ SOA-2507/ POL-2104] [MS-2811/ SOA-2507/ POL-2104-1]

Faculty Name
Neha Dixit [neha.dixit@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

MONDAY/ WEDNESDAY : 11:50 - 13:20 

More than 25 per cent of the urban population is below the poverty line. By 2030, urbanisation in India is projected to reach 50 per cent. This intensified complex, urban issues including land, water and sanitation. The course will focus on looking at socio-economic disparities in Urban India. Key teachings will be navigating geographical landscapes, government bureaucracies and hierarchies of resources and trauma in urban spaces.
Through lectures, readings, films, news reports and assessment of a wide range of issues like affordable housing, unequal distribution of resources-electricity, public spaces, unorganised workforce, gender gap and more importantly, a lack of representation and voice in framing of urban policies, students will be taught how to report and analyse urban poverty in an ethical, comprehensive and impactful manner.
