title: UNDERSTANDING DEVELOPMENT
description:
Understanding Development [SOA-3208/ POL-3080] [SOA-3208/ POL-3080-1]

Faculty Name
Ravindran S [ravindran.sriramachandran@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Our world is increasingly interconnected economically, politically, and culturally, yet it remains characterized by tremendous diversity in the standards of living observed between, among, and within countries. The gap between the global North and global South is particularly stark as evidenced by just a few distressing indicators: 1.4 billion people live on less than $1.25 a day; 1.1 billion people have inadequate access to water; 2.6 billion lack basic sanitation; 24,000 children die each day due to poverty.

This seminar examines some of the major theories, paradigms, perspectives, concepts and policies that, over the past 60 years, have attempted to explain, predict or otherwise effect change in the global South, including modernization and dependency theory, neoliberalism, human development, post-development, and feminist contributions to development. The course also surveys some contemporary perspectives on the discourse and practice of development, such as participatory development, the “good governance” agenda, and the “institutional turn.” This is a multidisciplinary social science course, drawing on “mainstream” and “critical” literature from development studies, geography, anthropology, and sociology. We should note at the outset that development is not static, and that it has long been impelled by both practical and theoretical concerns. It has also been and continues to be shaped by geopolitical interests and social scientific trends that are not immediately tied to development. Bearing this in mind, we shall seek to answer the following key questions this semester: What is development? How have our ideas about development, its causes, and its objectives changed over time? Why, after 60 years of development, are so many people still suffering from poverty, economic decline, ill health, political insecurity, repression, and powerlessness? Where should we focus our development efforts in the future?

Goals

This course is intended to survey the major debates that have occurred within development studies over the past 60 years. By the end of the semester, students should:

have a deep and broad interdisciplinary knowledge of development;

appreciate the range of alternative concepts and measures of development;

be able to think critically about the ways in which intellectuals engage and effect change in the global South through development discourses;

have a greater knowledge of the political, economic, social and cultural issues confronting former colonies at independence;

research.

Learning Outcomes

This course is intended to survey the major debates that have occurred within development studies over the past 60 years. By the end of the semester, students should:

have a deep and broad interdisciplinary knowledge of development;

appreciate the range of alternative concepts and measures of development;

be able to think critically about the ways in which intellectuals engage and effect change in the global South through development discourses;

have a greater knowledge of the political, economic, social and cultural issues confronting former colonies at independence;

research.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Syllabus Change Policy

This syllabus is only a guide for the course and is subject to change with advanced notice.

Course Requirements

Research Paper: 40%

Mid-Term Paper 20%

Participation and Attendance 20%

Research presentation at the end of term 10%

Seminar reading presentation with written summary 10%

Research Presentation:

Each student will present his/her independent research findings at the end of the term. When appropriate, the lectures are accompanied film clips The presentation should articulate the argument, situate the audience in the debates within the literature, and give relevant case evidence from research. 10-15 minutes, in a conference-style presentation.

Students must abide by the Student Academic Integrity Code as stated in the Ashoka University Undergraduate Handbook.

Teaching and Learning Methodologies:

The course is taught as a combination of lectures and class discussions. Students are expected to come to class having read the relevant text. Students may occasionally be required to discuss a series of study questions in groups.

Welcome to the course! We will devote our first meeting to laying the foundation for our subsequent conversations. We will begin by introducing ourselves to one another, reviewing the syllabus, and discussing the main themes of the course. In an effort to remind ourselves of what is at stake with respect to the success/failure of “development,” we will consider a brief article by Thomas Pogge (2005), in which he argues for the moral duty to address world poverty.

fullName: CHI-3003, CONFUCIANISM, FAMILY LINEAGE, AND LOCAL SOCIETY, DANIEL MURRAY
title: CONFUCIANISM, AND LOCAL SOCIETY,
description:
Confucianism, Family Lineage, and Local Society [CHI-3003/ SOA-3100/ HIS-3814] [CHI-3003/ SOA-3100/ HIS-3814-1]

Faculty Name
Daniel Murray [daniel.murray@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Course Overview

This course approaches Confucianism as a lived tradition in Chinese local society with an emphasis on the role of family lineages. Family lineages developed to be one of the pivotal institutions in organizing local society in late imperial China. These institutions were an important factor in state-society relations, property ownership, infrastructure projects, personal relations, and ritual practice. This course overviews major studies of the historical development of family lineages, its geographic diversity, and their continued existence today as well as their relation to issues of gender, ethnicity, religion, and kinship.

The first section gives a general overview of Confucian thought with an emphasis on its understanding of kinship and ritual. Section two moves onto historical anthropological studies of the development of family lineages, their related institutional structures (lineage halls) and rituals (ancestor veneration), and their connection to broader social, political, and economic life. Finally, we end the course with ethnographic studies of family lineages in the modern world to consider the impact of the nation-state, urbanization, changes in family dynamics, and transnational communication have had on the lineage.

Section 1: Kinship and Ritual in Confucian Thought and Imperial Power
This section of the course focuses on Confucian theories of kinship and ritual followed by an overview of the role of these ideas in the structuring of the state and society. The purpose of these theories was different than modern academic works as the aim was to influence how people acted rather than explain what they already were doing. However, they also present an indigenous understanding of these concepts and how the literati elite used them to analyze social issues.

Section 2: Historical Anthropology, Family Lineage, and Local Society
Historical anthropology emerged in China in response to largely ahistorical orientalist ethnographies of Chinese societies that saw the lineage structure as a monolith and largely drew on existing theories of lineage from European colonies in Africa as well as nationalist histories that presented a unified Chinese culture. In contrast to such studies, historical anthropologists combine fieldwork and local historical documents to analyze the diverse ways that family lineage developed throughout China. Historical anthropology emerged in China in response to largely ahistorical orientalist ethnographies of Chinese societies that saw the lineage structure as a monolith and largely drew on existing theories of lineage from European colonies in Africa as well as nationalist histories that presented a unified Chinese culture. In contrast to such studies, historical anthropologists combine fieldwork and local historical documents to analyze the diverse ways that family lineage developed throughout China.

Section 3: Ethnography, Lineage, and Modernity
The twentieth century saw the end of dynastic China and with it the bureaucracy staffed by scholar-officials trained in the Confucian tradition. Despite the numerous attacks on traditional culture and the land reform movement that stripped lineages of their land holdings in this period, many lineages throughout China continue to this day. This section focuses on ethnographic studies of how the family lineage has responded to many of the changing social, political, and geographic issues in this period.

title: MARKET ETHNOGRAPHIES
description:
Market Ethnographies: Persons, Places and Practices [SOA-3097/ SOA-6110] [SOA-3097/ SOA-6110-1]

Faculty Name
Mekhala Krishnamurthy [mekhala.krishnamurthy@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course will immerse itself in ethnographies of diverse market sites around the world to try to better locate and dislocate popular understandings of 'the market'. From village haats and bazaars to agricultural mandis and commodity futures, from Wall Street to e-bay and Amazon, anthropologists have deepened and expanded the imagination of their own stock-in-trade -- ethnography -- to explore a remarkable range of institutional relations, transactional forms and regulatory practices that help us grasp the life, labour and logistics of everyday exchange and trade. Through this course we begin to ask how might the anthropology of markets, as it comes to be worked out in classical and contemporary texts - inform, unsettle and reframe our engagement with the idea of the market and its presence in our lives? This elective is intended for advanced undergraduates interested in deepening their understanding of economic anthropology and exploring ethnographic fieldwork and writing on markets and economic life in diverse contexts.

title: RESEARCH METHODOLOGY AND ETHICS
description:
Research Methodology and Ethics [SOA-6105] [SOA-6105-1]

Faculty Name
Swargajyoti Gohain [swargajyoti.gohain@ashoka.edu.in] ;

fullName: SOA-2221, TRAVEL, TOURISM, PILGRIMAGE, SWARGAJYOTI GOHAIN
title: TRAVEL, TOURISM, PILGRIMAGE,
description:
Travel, Tourism, Pilgrimage [SOA-2221] [SOA-2221-1]

Faculty Name
Swargajyoti Gohain [swargajyoti.gohain@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course is framed around three broad questions or modules:

What is travel? Who travels and why? What makes travel possible?

I. What is travel? This module will explore the conceptual underpinnings of notions of travel, tourism and pilgrimage. From Victor and Edith Turner to Simon Coleman, from Dean MacCannell and Nelson Graburn to Noel Salazar, many have tried to approach tourism and pilgrimage as an anthropological subject. Travel is clearly a necessary part of a tradition of religious experience. Typically, defined as a journey, pilgrimage is thought to have transformative effects. Unlike permanent migration, it is assumed to be transient. But are all forms of transient travel or journeys pilgrimage? Then what is the difference between tourism and pilgrimage? Is pilgrimage religious tourism or tourism a secular pilgrimage? Is the pilgrim a figure of modernity and the tourist a figure of postmodernity, or is the divide between the two wholly false? As the lines between the two become increasingly blurred, and as tourists travel to attend sports events and music festivals, how do we, as anthropologists, theorise all this?

II. Who travels and why? This module will probe the motivations for travel, and the embodied and embedded practices of tourism and pilgrimage. Why do people travel? To find meaning, for self-expression, or as a form of leisure? What are the perceptions that impel and are produced by travel? We will explore how the tourist gaze, a notion given by John Urry, is shaped and manifested. Yet, not everyone is in a position to travel. How do we treat travel and tourism, which come with assumptions of privilege, differently from exile and forced movement? We will draw on anthropological literature as well as fiction, film, and travel memoirs to give students insights into this topic.

II. What makes travel possible? Here, we will look at the infrastructures of travel, tourism and pilgrimage. Wolfgang Schivelbusch’s classic work The Railway Journey is one example of a study of industrialized consciousness facilitated by railways, which in turn made possible travel imaginaries. As people now move to adventure and eco-tourism, or conversely, turn towards virtual pilgrimage events, how do we write about the infrastructures of travel?

title: SCIENCE STUDIES
description:
Science Studies [SOA-3094/ SOA-6106] [SOA-3094/ SOA-6106-1]

Faculty Name
Deepak Mehta [deepak.mehta@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

To study science in its relation to the social is to affirm that scientific and technological practices are central to how life is lived in contemporary times. This course introduces students to some of the most significant debates and concerns that tailor the intersection of science and the social. Beginning with classic accounts that situate the making of scientific communities, the course will navigate the following: science and politics; scientific disasters; science and development; alternative sciences.

Course cap: 30 but negotiable.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The readings will be a selection from the following types of texts.

  1. Ludwig Fleck: Genesis and Development of a Scientific Fact
  2. Thomas Kuhn: The Structure of Scientific Revolutions
  3. Dominique Lecourt: Proletarian Science: The Case of Lysenko
  4. Robert Proctor: Racial Hygiene: Medicine Under the Nazis
  5. Joe Masco: Nuclear Borderlands
  6. Case studies on the Bhopal gas disaster
  7. Adrianna Petryna: Life Exposed: Biological Citizenship After Chernobyl
  8. Jean-Luc Nancy: After Fukushima: The Equivalence of Catastrophes
  9. Case studies of science and development in South Asia
  10. Ashis Nandy: Alternative Science
  11. JPS Uberoi: Science and Culture

We will have mid-term and end-term examinations. The exact percentages of the tests will be decided in consultation with students of the class. All students are required to make seminar presentations from selected readings, for which they will be graded. Attendance is compulsory.

title: ANTHROPOLOGY OF MASS MEDIATION
description:
Anthropology of Mass Mediation [SOA-3095/ SOA-6107/ MS-3251] [SOA-3095/ SOA-6107/ MS-3251-1]

Faculty Name
Kathryn Collins Hardy [kathryn.hardy@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Mass mediation is sometimes seen as a destructive force, driving out "authentic culture" and homogenizing thought. Conversely, some recent opinions have seen mass mediation as a pure source of grassroots political expression. In this course, we will complicate both these extremes. We shall see how media technologies do not just transmit or allow access to "culture," but are themselves cultural practices. This course considers film, television, radio, and various online media forms to explore the social processes and practices of mass mediation. Using the tools of anthropology, cultural studies, and media studies, we will explore a diverse range of ideas, objects, and forms of sociality engendered by technological mediation, as well as the material practices and processes through which meaning moves.

title: RUIN
description:
Ruin [SOA-3096/ SOA-6108] [SOA-3096/ SOA-6108-1]

Faculty Name
Andrew Alan Johnson [andrew.johnson@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

We think about ruins as belonging to the past, but they do not. We make our homes on the bones of what came before. Ruins are that detritus – physical, conceptual, ideological - that stays with us into the present and, as they do so, bring together disparate points in time. They can be sources of melancholy, inspiration, wonder, and horror. They include both the ruined castles and temples that the word initially calls to mind as well as other elements: lingering toxins in the soil, racist legacies of colonialism, nationalistic points of collective sentiment, and the remnants of past cities bleeding through into the present-day urban landscape.

This course will examine ruins from an anthropological lens. We will address the construction and poetics of space and place, moments when former ways of being in or conceiving of space bleed into the present, and the legacies of empires long gone (or not-so-long gone).   

Students should come out of this class with an introduction to the relationship between space and place and a new appreciation for urban infrastructures and their legacies.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Suggested Readings:

Abu-El Haj, Nadia. 2001. Facts on the Ground

Bachelard, Gaston. 1994. The Poetics of Space

Holston, James. 1989. The Modernist City.

Johnson, Andrew Alan. 2014. Ghosts of the New City

Stoler, Ann. 2016. Duress.

Trouillot, Michel-Rolph. 2015 Silencing the Past 2nd edition.

Grading Rubric

Reading/Writing Assignments

Participation (10% of grade) You are expected to come to class having read the assigned readings and actively participate in class discussions. Failure to attend class will result in a grade penalty. A good participant is neither a wallflower nor a boor, he or she engages in the discussion, responds thoughtfully, and seeks to contribute to, not dominate the conversation. You can earn participation points by engaging in a constructive manner with the readings and with the comments of other students.

Précis (30% of grade): Each week that readings are assigned, you are expected to email me a one-page (appx 200 word) précis of one of the readings. This will summarize a particular point from the reading that you found compelling or wished to challenge. In addition, please provide one to two questions for discussion. These can be within the précis or separate. The précis are due Sunday night by midnight. No extensions will be given. Please copy the text of your précis into an email and send it to: andrewjohnson@princeton.edu .

Précis are graded on a simple scale:
3 – Shows clear understanding and engagement with the text. Brings a new angle or outside perspective. A clear sense of the student’s own voice.

2 – Understands and correctly summarizes a key point from the text.

1 – Confused, incorrect or incomplete understanding of the text. (But at least this student read).

0 – Did not turn in assignment.

Oral Presentation (10% of grade): There are two components to this grade. The first is a student-led presentation on one of the week’s readings. You will sign up for one such presentation on the first class day and become an expert on that reading. Then, in class, you will lead the discussion for appx. 30 minutes. Do note that you don’t need to lecture on the reading, rather, you will be the ‘hub’ of the discussion for that time.

The second component involves the week’s “activity”. On the first class day, you will sign up for one of the weeks featuring an activity, and on that week, you will give a presentation following the week’s instructions of about 20 minutes. Do note that not all weeks have activities. Please stick to the 10-minute time. You may have handouts or Powerpoint (or Prezi) classroom technology permitting, but do not simply read off of the presentation – treat the presentation as an opportunity to briefly teach the class, and try to be engaging. You do not need to hand in anything for the oral presentation.

Midterm Essay (20%) and Final Essay (30%): There are two long-form, take-home essays in this class. These will be assigned at the midterm and at the end of the course. These will be capped at 4,000 words and 6,000 words, maximum, respectively. We will discuss the grading rubric for these papers beforehand, but here I should note that an “A” paper should show both an in-depth understanding of at least some of the readings for class as well as your own original analysis.

These essays are to be sent as Word document attachments (or in a similar format) to andrew.johnson@ashoka.edu.in by 5PM on the day that they are due.

fullName: SOA-2223, NATIONALISM, ETHNICITY, VIOLENCE, RAVI SRIRAMACHANDRAN
title: NATIONALISM, ETHNICITY, VIOLENCE,
description:
Nationalism, Ethnicity, Violence [SOA-2223/ POL-2100/ MS-2291] [SOA-2223/ POL-2100/ MS-2291-1]

Faculty Name
Ravindran S [ravindran.sriramachandran@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Nationalism, Ethnicity, Violence

This course examines the historical origins and contemporary dynamics of ethnic politics in the developing world. We will explore different theoretical approaches to the study of ethnic conflict, as well as the impact of colonialism on ethnic identities, and the legacy of decolonization on nationalist movements in the developing world. Lastly, we will examine a number of post-independence challenges faced by multiethnic states through the use of case studies.

This course is designed to provide students with a broad overview of the major theories on the relationship between ethnicity and politics. We will attempt to address of number of questions in this literature. These include: To what extent is ethnic identity a causal factor or simply a label that is assigned to contemporary political violence? If ethnicity identity is a causal factor, is it compatible with predictive theories, and if so how can it be incorporated? Can we account for the origins and nature of ethnic identity, and if so, how? We will examine both theoretical and empirical studies and explore whether existing theoretical models adequately examine the issue at hand. The course is not designed to teach you a litany of facts about different conflicts that rage around the world. Rather, it is designed to give you an important set of intellectual tools with which you can think historically and critically and about the world around you.

 

Please note that this syllabus is tentative and subject to change as the semester progresses.

Learning Outcomes
  • Demonstrate knowledge of theories and methodologies that can facilitate the analysis and understanding of the concept of ethnicity and ethnic conflict.
  • Have a greater knowledge of the political, economic, social and cultural issues confronting former colonies at and after independence.
  • Synthesize and contextualize ideas and arguments from different sources.
  • Produce a research paper that displays critical thinking and analytical skills.
  • Use both primary and secondary data to conduct independent research.

fullName: SOA-2224, CASTE, COMMUNITY, COLONIALITY: POLITICAL RESPONSIBILITY TOWARDS THE OTHER, GOWHAR FAZILI
title: CASTE, COMMUNITY, COLONIALITY: POLITICAL RESPONSIBILITY TOWARDS THE OTHER,
description:
Caste, Community, Coloniality: Political Responsibility towards the Other [SOA-2224/ POL-2099] [SOA-2224/ POL-2099-1]

Faculty Name
Gowhar Fazili [gowhar.fazili@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

The language used by activist and scholars to capture power, privilege, violence, and injustice has for various reasons remained underdeveloped. This course introduces scholarship that seeks to expand this language so as to enable articulation of nuances that are otherwise lost. Critiquing the dominant colonial and postcolonial frameworks, it takes a fresh look at the imbrication of caste, community and coloniality in South Asia. Pushing beyond the usual impasse on the binaries of perpetration and victimhood, blame and guilt, culpability and innocence to concerns like epistemic injustice, collective responsibility, implicated subject and the pure concept of forgiveness, it explores problems like: how we come to inherit collective responsibility for acts of violence and injustice that may have preceded us or may not have committed directly, and yet on closer examination find ourselves variously implicated in. Apart from introducing new concepts, the course offers a reflection on contexts like Kashmir that make the intricacies, contradictions and overlaps manifest.

Learning Outcomes

Appreciate and explore:

  • how caste, community and coloniality came to be intertwined in South Asia.
  • how we come to assume a political self and construct the other.
  • the ways in which our selves are implicated in the lives of others.
  • the relationship between ethics and politics.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The following is an indicative reading list.  The actual readings are subject to change in accordance to the proceedings in the classroom.

Module 1: Constructions of the Self and the Other in Colonial South Asia

In this module we will familiarize ourselves with excerpts from a range of texts to help appreciate the struggle around self-definition in response to the colonial encounter in South Asia.

Phule, Jotirao Govindrao. 1883. The Cultivator's Whipchord and Gulamgiri

E.V.R. Periyar. “Untouchability: History of Vaikom Agitation” from the Collected Works of Periyar E.V.R.  Compiled by K. Veeramani

Ambedkar, B.R. What Way Emanicipation?” (1936)” pages 113 -145 and the Speech on the occasion of mass conversion on 15th October 1956. Pages 533-545. Collected Works Volume 17 Part III.

Iqbal, Mohammad.  Presidential Address, Allahabad Session 1930. 

Gandhi, M.K.  1925. My Experiments with Truth; and 1909. Hind Swaraj

Savarkar 1933.  Hindutva.  Who is a Hindu?

Hossain, Rokeya Sakhawat (1880 - 1932) Sultana's Dream.

Phule, Savitri Bai: https://feminisminindia.com/2021/01/03/savitribai-phule-literature-poems-feminist-history/ 

A reflection on Muivah’s interview with Karan Thapar “A Rebel’s Vision” in Ranabir Samaddar, 2010. Emergence of the Political Subject, New Delhi and London: Sage Publications,), Chapter 6, pp. 162-186.

Module 2: Re-conceptualizing Caste, Community and Coloniality: Towards a critique of postcolonialism

This module introduces short selections from a set of postcolonial texts concerning caste, community and coloniality and invites students to read them critically.

Srinivas, M.N. 1976. The remembered village. Delhi: Oxford University Press.

Nagaraj, D. R. 2011. The Flaming Feet and Other Essays: The Dalit Movement in India. Seagull Books.

Soundararajan, Thenmozhi. 2022. The Trauma of Caste.

Gidla, Sujata. 2017. An Elephant Among the Ants: Untouchable Family and the Making of Modern India. Farrar, Straus and Giroux.

Berg, Dag-Erik. 2020. Dynamics of caste and law: Dalits, oppression and constitutional democracy in India. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.

Ramaswamy, Gita. Land, Caste, Guns, Women: The Memoir of a Lapsed Revolutionary

Sarkar, Tanika.  2001. Hindu Wife, Hindu Nation: Community, Religion and Cultural

Nationalism, New Delhi, Permanent Black.

Zamindar, Vazira Fazila-Yacoobali. 2010. The Long Partition and the Making of Modern South Asia. Refugees, Boundaries, Histories. Columbia University Press.

Fanon, Frantz and Charles Lam Markmann. 1967 [1952]. Black Skin White Masks. New York: Grove Press.

Du Bois W. E. B. 1989. The Souls of Black Folk. New York N.Y. U.S.A: Penguin Books.

Suggested Readings:

Nandy, Ashis. 1983. The Intimate Enemy.

Chatterjee, Partha. 1993. The Nation and its Fragments

Dirks, Nicholas.  1992. Castes of Mind

Neil Lazarus (2002) The Politics of Postcolonial Modernism, The European

Legacy, 7:6, 771-782

Ahmad, Aijaz. “Orientalism and After: Ambivalence and Metropolitan Location the Work of

Edward Said.” In Theory: Classes, Nations, Literature. Oxford: Oxford University

Press, 1992. 159-220. Print.

Chibber Vivek. 2012. Postcolonial Theory and the Specter of Capital. London: Verso.

Spivak, Gayatri Chakravorty.  1999. A Critique of Postcolonial Reason: Toward a History of The Vanishing Present. Harvard University Press.

Dalit Activist Thenmozhi Soundararajan Takes on Caste https://www.harpersbazaar.com/culture/features/a42257504/dalit-activism/

Module 3: From Victimhood to Political Responsibility: The Questions of Ethics

This module introduces a range of thinkers who enable us to think beyond the impasse of competitive victimhood towards the assumption of political responsibility.

Seminar Special Volume:  Victimhood: a symposium on its politics in our times #727 March 2020.  https://www.india-seminar.com/2020/727.htm

Fricker, Miranda. 2007. Epistemic Injustice: Power and the Ethics of Knowing. OUP.

Forst, Rainer. .2018. Normativity and Power: Analyzing Social Orders of Justification

Arendt, Hannah. 1987. “Collective responsibility” In James William Bernauer (ed.), Amor Mundi: Explorations in the Faith and Thought of Hannah Arendt. Kluwer Academic Publishers.

Rothberg, Michael. 2019. The Implicated Subject Beyond Victims and Perpetrators. Stanford University Press

Ambedkar, B.R. The idea of Equality and Fraternity in the – Last Speech to the Constituent Assembly 1950.

Derrida, Jacques. 2001. “On Forgiveness” In On Cosmopolitanism and Forgiveness Pages 25-50.

Suggested Readings:

Mayaram, Shail. 2015.  Israel as a Gift of the Arabs. Yoda Press.

Module 4: The Pandit and the Muslim:

This module contextualizes the problem of caste, community and coloniality in Kashmir, it examines the current discursive impasse on the Pandit-Muslim question, the political factors that intervene—the questions of accession, Hindutva, removal Article 370 (See Noorani and Srinath Raghavan), and invites a reflection on its future.

The Past:  Historicising the Self and the Other in Kashmir

Rai, Mridu.  2004. Hindu Rulers Muslim Subjects: Islam, Rights, and the History of Kashmir

Zutshi, Chitralekha. 2003. Languages of Belonging: Islam, Regional Identity, and the Making of Kashmir

Bazaz. Prem Nath. 1954. Struggle for Freedom in Kashmir. New Delhi, Kashmir Publishing Company.

The Present:  Representations of the Self and the Other in contemporary Kashmir

We will read and watch relevant selections from some of the following Kashmiri self-statements:

Memoirs and Self representation: Basharat Peer, Farah Bashir, Rahul Pandita, Nisihita Trisal

Cinema: Haider, Shikara, Kashmir Files

Fiction: Akhtar Mohiuddin, Hari Krishna Kaul, Mirza Waheed, Siddhartha Gigoo

Documentary: Sanjay Kak, Abir Bazaz, Ajay Raina

The Future: Contextualizing Political Responsibility: The Future of Pandit-Muslim Relationship in Kashmir

See “Relating Otherwise: Curated Narratives”. Biography, Volume 43, Number 2, 2020, pp. 306-322.  University of Hawai'i Press.

Lecture/s and Open discussion/s.

Suggested Readings:

Madan. T.N.  1965. Family and Kinship: A Study of the Pandits of Rural Kashmir

Lawrence, Walter. 1895.  The Valley of Kashmir.

Grading Rubric

Evaluation Pattern:

You will be assessed on the following deliverables:

  • Regularity of attendance. (10%) 
  • Class participation: including a collaborative formal class presentation based on a prescribed reading The duration of the presentation must not exceed 20 minutes. (20%) 
  • An open book exam: You will be required to answer one question out of two using whatever resources you can muster within a day. (30%) 
  • Term paper: The paper must engage with a concept and a social situation relevant to the concerns of this course You will be required to submit a 600 word abstract towards the middle of the course on which you will receive feedback.  The completed paper must not exceed 3000 words. (40%) 
  • All submissions must be made in the google classroom.  You must follow a formal social science standard for citations and formatting for all your submissions.  Plagiarism (unacknowledged appropriation of someone’s ideas or words) in any form will be penalized.  
Attendance Policy

The regularity of attendance is a must for this course. Missing more than three classes will result in a grade cut.    

Attachment
Coloniality - Gowhar Fazili.docx

fullName: SOA-3098/ SOA-6112-1, THINKINGS: ASSEMBLAGES, NETWORKS, KINSHIPS, RITA BRARA MUKHOPADHYAY
title: NETWORKS, KINSHIPS, RITA BRARA MUKHOPADHYAY,
description:
Thinkings: Assemblages, Networks, Kinships [SOA-3098/ SOA-6112] [SOA-3098/ SOA-6112-1]

Faculty Name
Rita Brara Mukhopadhyay [rita.mukhopadhyay@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course will explore groundbreaking writings on assemblages, networks, and kinships that relate to contemporary currents in social anthropology/sociology. These three thinkings focus on relationships, connections, and processes that tie human beings, non-human life and the material world. We will draw on the works of Gilles Deleuze and Felix Guattari, Michel Foucault, Donna Haraway, Bruno Latour and Marilyn Strathern along with their interlocutors to shine a light on how we can add value to our ethnographic researches by working in elements and notions that kin, assemble, and network.

title: ANTHROPOLOGY OF DISASTER AND VULNERABILITY
description:
Anthropology of Disaster and Vulnerability [SOA-2222/ ES-2439] [SOA-2222/ ES-2439-1]

Faculty Name
Mitul Baruah [mitul.baruah@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Neil Smith famously said – “there’s no such thing as a natural disaster.” He was echoing a generation of environmental geographers and anthropologists. Over the past few decades, critical scholarship on disaster and vulnerability has grown significantly, drawing on, among others, frameworks of political economy and political ecology. At the same time, hazards and disasters have also become increasingly frequent and destructive across the planet. From mega events such as tsunamis, hurricanes, earthquakes, nuclear accidents and oil spills to slow-onset disasters like air pollution, desertification, epidemics, soil erosion and sea level rise, disaster has come to define the times that we live in. Climate change has made matters worse. The impact of a disaster is uneven, however; some people are much more vulnerable than others.

This course is aimed at providing students critical perspectives on disaster and vulnerability. We will begin with an overview of concepts such as risk, hazards, disaster, vulnerability, and resilience. Drawing on case studies from around the world, the course will then expose students to a variety of political and cultural questions concerning disaster and vulnerability. The students will learn about, among others, the role of the state and capital in the production of disaster and hazardscape; how vulnerability is a social calculus; ideas of climate coloniality and climate justice; how various societies in different historical moments have responded to calamity, offering insight into the complex relationships between societies and their natural environments; and how disaster management efforts can promote widespread resilience or increase the vulnerability of some populations, thereby further deepening societal inequities.

title: AGRARIAN WORLDS
description:
Agrarian Worlds: Land, Culture and Power [ES-3401/ SOA-3224/ SOA-6109] [ES-3401/ SOA-3224/ SOA-6109-1]

Faculty Name
Mitul Baruah [mitul.baruah@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

How has capitalism impacted the agrarian world? Have these impacts been homogenous across time and space? How have agrarian societies around the world responded to the capitalist and neoliberal forces? These are but some of the questions that this course will examine in trying to understand the modern transformations of the rural/agrarian world and the broader socio-political implications thereof. The course is theoretically rigorous and empirically grounded. It covers a wide range of issues, including the classical agrarian question, contemporary agrarian debates, green revolution and its legacies, the question(s) of food, land and water grabbing, farmer suicides in India, gender and agriculture, transnational peasant movements, and the recent farmers protest in India. This course will be run as a seminar, which means students will be expected to actively participate in class discussions. As part of the course, students will also get a chance to watch some iconic films on the agrarian worlds. Furthermore, there will be a few field visits for students to gain a firsthand exposure to certain aspects of the agradian world.

title: CITIES: ECOLOGY AND EQUITY
description:
Cities, Ecology and Equity [SOA-3207/ ES-3404/ SOA-6114] [SOA-3207/ ES-3404/ SOA-6114-1]

Faculty Name
Amita Baviskar [amita.baviskar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Since 2007, more people in the world live in urban than in rural areas. Between slums and smart cities, they inhabit a world of social conflict, ecological crisis, and contending visions of the future. As cities become even more central to social experience and aspiration, we need to understand their place in history and in the human imagination. This course looks at cities through three thematic lenses: accumulation, order, and identity. It studies cities in relation to the countryside, tracing flows of people and goods that create wealth and poverty. It examines the spatial politics of managing urban populations, from planning to informality. It analyses cities as places where cultural identities – parochial and progressive – are formed and defended. It introduces urban studies as a critical area of sociology and anthropology, and as an essential prerequisite for understanding environmental politics.

title: ECOLOGY AND UNREST
description:
Ecology and Unrest [ES-3406/ SOA-3503/ POL-3050] [ES-3406/ SOA-3503/ POL-3050-1]

Faculty Name
Aniket Pankaj Aga [aniket.aga@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Ecology and Unrest

Tue/Thu - 11:50 am - 1:20 pm

AC 02 TR 009

This is a seminar cum practicum course i.e. we will explore theoretical issues and empirical findings in class AND do small group research projects in the field, to test out our classroom discussions. About half the course will be related to designing a small, do-able research project and grappling with issues of research design and methods.

This course takes up the issue of political violence and explores their underpinnings to ecological politics and conflicts over what are labeled ‘natural resources’. Human lives and livelihoods are fundamentally embedded in cultural and ecological landscapes, and by implication, actors and institutions such as states, castes, political parties, social movements often (not always) have specific political and ecological bases. In this course, we will go over issues related to mining, forests, water, shifting and settled agriculture, race and caste, etc. and link these to insurgencies, agitations, political unrest and movements for self-determination. We will explore cases from India, South Asia, and other parts of the world.

Learning Outcomes

Course Objectives

Students will…

1. Understand the interplay of domination and hegemony in state-centered politics. 

2. Connect issues of natural resources with political actors such as states, parties and social movements.

3. Explore the ecological bases of some important social and political conflicts.

4. Embed familiar concepts of freedom, autonomy, and rights in cultural and ecological systems.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Pre-requisites: None

fullName: VA-3040/ PA-3800, CRAFTING IDENTITIES: ARTS, CRAFTS AND PERFORMATIVE PRACTICES FROM CENTRAL INDIA, PREETI BAHADUR RAMASWAMY
title: CRAFTING IDENTITIES: ARTS, CRAFTS AND PERFORMATIVE PRACTICES FROM CENTRAL INDIA, PREETI BAHADUR RAMASWAMY,
description:
Crafting Identities: Arts, Crafts and Performative Practices from Central India [VA-3040/ PA-3800/ SOA-3103] [VA-3040/ PA-3800/ SOA-3103-1]

Faculty Name
Preeti Bahadur Ramaswami [preeti.ramaswami@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course  seeks to enlarge the boundaries of art history as a discipline by focussing on art practices  of persons seen as belonging to marginalised communities. What are the forces that shape the lives and practices of individuals referred to in public discourse as craftsmen, or ‘folk ‘and ‘tribal’ artists in post -colonial India? How much agency do they have over their lives and practice and to what extent are they ‘manipulated’ by ‘outside’ mediations? And how do tradition and modernity parley with each other in the shaping of their work and careers? This course is designed to make students actively debate and engage with these issues and beyond, through case studies of practitioners of both material and performative practices from Central India. It  examines trajectories in artisanal and performative practices from the region of Madhya Pradesh and the recently created state of Chhattisgarh. 

The course will acquaint students with case histories of practitioners, from the ground,  to trace trajectories of transformation. Students will engage with questions of caste and community, agency, selfhood, and gender, to understand the shaping of art forms and their contexts. They will be led to look at  shifting contexts for the production  and reception of art practices, examining  the role of the state, museums and institutions, exhibitions and the market in creating binary categories of ‘art’ verses ‘craft’. A key component will be unravelling histories and modes of intervention following developmental or anthropological paradigms in the field.

Discussions will be largely based on films and video recordings from the ‘field’, interviews, exhibition catalogues and on- site visits to the crafts museum  and art galleries. 

Course Structure and modules

The course syllabus focuses on the following set of practices and forms from Central India. It follows developments in the lives of practitioners and their practice. 

Modules

‘Gond’ art

In 2001, the artist Jangarh Singh Shyam committed suicide at a Museum in Japan, unable to return home before  paintings that had been  commissioned by the Museum  were completed. He was a Gond Pradhan,  from an ‘adivasi' community in Central India, famously ‘discovered’ by the art world in 1981. This module charts his life and art through films, art works and publications and examines the role of played by art world interlocutors in shaping his life and career. Lectures will look at  ‘Gond art ‘ as  a tradition that was ‘invented’  in recent times, and look at individuals who followed Jangarh Singh Shaym to trace trajectories in their practice.  It will also look at  ‘primitivism’ as a phenomenon in 20th century modern art  to unpack ideologies that informed the discovery of ‘adivasi’ artists.  

Rajwar clay sculpture 

 Valorised as a woman sculptor whose art was born of loneliness, Sona Bai’s life changed completely after her discovery by teams from Bharat Bhavan, an art intitution based in  Bhopal. Her art which was made from local clay found in  Sarguja in Chhattisgarh  shaped into sculptures and screens, began to  adorn museums and exhibition spaces.   What did this shift from a domestic space  in the interiors of Chhattisgarh to sites of international exhibition do to her art and how much agency did she have in shaping her life or work? Which markets defined her work  as individualistic  art practice and which defined it as  craft born of women’s labour?  What happens when her work, which was domestic and therefore private,  enters a larger public sphere for staging ethnicities? Students will look at films, exhibition catalogues and in situ installations to understand her art and that of others who followed her. 

Gadhwa metal sculpture, Bastar. 

The module will  focus on the transformation of  metal sculptures from Bastar, from objects of ritual use to highly sought after objects in the art market.  Jaidev Baghel, metal sculptor from Bastar, was able to negotiate a space for himself across markets, moving between art worlds and sites for the marketing of  ‘crafts. Students will look at his work and that of the modernist sculptor Meera Mukherjee  who apprenticed under him to see how both practices changed through the interaction. They will also examine how the idea of the ‘folk’ feeds into ideas of authenticity and nationality. 

Between ethnography and anthropology 

How have ethnography and anthropology as disciplines shaped the work of largely urban based individuals and institutions to inform interventions in the field?  Students will look at the work of the anthropologist Verrier Elwin, artist and adminsitrator  J . Swaminathan, photographer Sunil Janah, culture activist Pupul Jaykar, artists Meera Mukherjee, Navjot Altaf to raise questions about ethics and intentionality. ‘

Performative practices

This module looks at  shifts in the performances of the Pandvani, (stories of the Pandavas recited in Chhattisgarh), and the Lorik Chanda , tracing the emergence of  ‘professional artists’ and the shifts from oral to textual sources of storytelling. What are emic understadigns of this shift ? Student will also looks at ‘Nacha’ a form of theatre that became popular in Chhattisgarh in the early years of the twentieth century, examining interventions by Habib Tanvir, well known modernist theatre director,  and the trope of  ‘indigenism’ in modernist art discourse.   

Subalternity in Chhattisgarh. 

This module will focus on practices that define subalternity in this region, and their resistance to the culture of upper caste communities.  Many of these are highly charged performative practices that have, so far,  also resisted being co- opted into mainstream culture. One of the most compelling of these are the Ramnamis, a community that perform  bhakti and resist upper caste practices by tattooing their bodies with the name of the divine. 

Discusssion themes include:  

  • the  performance of oral epics (Pandvani and Lorik Chanda), by stellar performers from this region and their adaptation by the modernist theatre director and activist Habeeb Tanvir.
  • the life and art of  Jangarh Singh Shyam, painter from Patangarh, Madhya Pradesh and the phenomenon of ‘Gond painting’.
  • performing identities of ‘artist ‘and ‘craftsperson’ in the lives and practice of modernist sculptor Meera Mukherjee and  Jaidev Baghel, metal sculptor from Bastar.  
  • the role of key museums and institutions in the ‘discovery’ of art forms and  the creation of  exhibition paradigms.(Bharat Bhavan, Crafts Museum, Tribal Museum) 
  • the role of interlocutors from art worlds, such as J.  Swaminathan, Bhasakar Kulkarni , Pupul Jaykar etc and their impact in transforming practices.   
  • seeking the indigenous in the ‘folk .
Learning Outcomes

this course will enable students to 

  • trace  shifts in art practices of marginalised constituencies in post- independence India. 
  • debate the binaries of ‘art’ and ‘craft ‘ as categories created within different social and institutional contexts. 
  • debate the nature  and extent of agency  exercised by creative persons from marginalised communities.

  • re imagine modes for alternative interventions in art practice. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Grading Rubric

End semester curatorial project: 20% of total grades. 

Attendance Policy

fullName: VA-3014, IN SITU: ARCHITECTURE, SCULPTURE AND PAINTING IN THE WESTERN HIMALAYAS, LATIKA GUPTA
title: IN SITU: ARCHITECTURE, SCULPTURE AND PAINTING IN THE WESTERN HIMALAYAS,
description:
In Situ: architecture, sculpture and painting in the Western Himalayas [VA-3014/ SOA-3104] [VA-3014/ SOA-3104-1]

Faculty Name
Latika Gupta [latika.gupta@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Level of the Course: 1000/2000/3000

Prerequisites: None

Course Description: 

This course is an introduction to the architecture, sculpture and paintings of Buddhist temples and monasteries in the Western Himalayas, with a focus on extant sites in Ladakh and Himachal Pradesh. We will study major sites of art historical and cultural importance, while tracing their roots and interconnections to developments in religion, iconography and aesthetics in Kashmir, Bihar and Tibet. 

The course focuses on studying monasteries and temples through their location, their usage, and changes in structure and style in response to religious and socio-political developments as well as changes in local ecological conditions. The artistic strategies employed, the material used in making paintings and sculptures will be explored in relation to their geographic, architectonic and spatial contexts as well as the ritual requirements of different schools of Buddhism in the region. Students will be familiarized with artistic styles from the late 9th century onwards and the major iconographic programmes and deities of the ‘Tibetan Buddhist’ pantheon.

Course Modules:

1. Himalayan Art: disciplinary formation and evolution

2. Introduction to basic concepts of Buddhism- major schools and developments in Buddhism in the Trans-Himalayas

3. Eastern India: the development of Vajrayana Buddhism in the great universities in Bihar

4. Early temple and stupa sites in the Kashmir valley: Architecture and in-situ sculpture in stone; wood and bronze sculpture- patrons, major deities, artistic styles and material

5. A brief history of the Western Himalayas: dynastic patrons, scholars, teachers and monks

6. Early sites in the Western Himalayas: 

- Mammoth rock cut sculptures: Mulbek, Kartse, Drass, Digar, Sani etc.

- Kinnaur, H.P: The stele of Yeshe ‘Od, Lotsawa Lakhang in Puh and Kanam villages, Buddhist temples in Ribba and Ropa, wooden sculptures in the temple of Rangrigtse in Charang village

- Tholing (Tibet) Nyarma (Ladakh) and Tabo (Spiti) complex of temples- a study of the architecture, iconographic programmes, sculpture and painting on site, the relationship between the iconic and the narrative in an architectonic context

7. Early sites in the Western Himalayas:

Alchi choskhor (Ladakh)- the development of the complex from the 11th- 13th centuries, architecture, sculpture and painting with a focus on style, iconography and narrative strategies 

8. Later Buddhist monasteries in Kinnaur, Spiti and Ladakh:

13th- 14th century onwards (Nako, Lhalung, Kye, Diskit, Thiksey etc.)

9. Paintings of textiles in Buddhist temples in the Western Himalayas

10. How are sites used: Sacred landscapes, spatial layout, ritual and material culture 

11. Sacred Objects: in situ and in museums

Learning Outcomes

By the end of this course, students:

  • Will be conversant with major Buddhist temples and monasteries in Ladakh and Himachal Pradesh.
  • Will have the ability to ‘read’ sites as architectonic spaces, and study the architecture, sculptures and paintings in relation to their usage.
  • Will be able to identify major deities of the 'Tibetan Buddhist' pantheon and identify stylistic features of early Buddhist art in the Himalayas.
  • Will be familiar with developments in the art of the region in conjunction with changes in religion and socio-political contexts of patronage.
  • Will be able to write concise art historical notes in the nature of museum catalogue entries. 
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Select/ Preliminary Reading List:

  • Brauen, Martin. The Mandala: Sacred Circle in Tibetan Buddhism. London: Serindia Publications, 1997.
  • Bue, Erberto F Lo and Bray, John, Art and Architecture in Ladakh: Cross Cultural Transmissions in the Himalayas and Karakoram, Brill Tibetan Studies Library, 2014.
  • Chandra, Yashaswini. “Art, Ritual and Belief at the Mrikula Devi Temple in Lahaul” in The Draw of the Hills, (Ed.) Latika Gupta, Marg Vol. 69 No.4, 2018
  • Davidson, Ronald M. Indian Esoteric Buddhism: A Social History of the Tantric Movement, Motilal Banarsidass Publishers, 2003.
  • Francke, A.H. A History of Western Tibet. Delhi: Pilgrim Books, 1999.
  • Goepper, Roger and Jaroslav Poncar. Alchi: Ladakh’s Hidden Buddhist Sanctuary. London: Serindia, 1996.
  • Handa O.C. Buddhist Monasteries in Himachal Pradesh. New Delhi: Indus Publishing Company, 1987.
  • Harrison, Peter. Fortress Monasteries of the Himalayas: Tibet, Ladakh, Nepal and Bhutan, Osprey Publishing, 2012.
  • Heller, Amy. “Tracing the Impact of Kashmiri Art in Guge and Ladakh, Eleventh to Thirteenth centuries” Inner and Central Asian Art and Archaeology II, New Research on Central Asian, Buddhist and Far Eastern Art and Archaeology, 2019.
  • Heller, Amy. Early Himalayan Art. Oxford: Ashmolean Museum, 2008.
  • Heller, Amy. Tibetan Art. Tracing the development of spiritual ideals and art in Tibet 600–2000 A.D. Milano: Jaca Book, 1999.
  • Heller, Amy and Giacomella Orofino (Eds.). Discoveries in Western Tibet and the Western Himalayas, Brill, 2007.
  • Khosla, Romi. Buddhist Monasteries in the Western Himalaya. Kathmandu: Ratna Pustak Bhandar, 1979.
  • Klimburg-Salter, Deborah E. Tabo- A Lamp for the Kingdom- Early Indo-Tibetan Buddhist Art in the Western Himalaya. Milan: Skira, 1997.
  • Klimburg-Salter, Deborah E. The Silk Route and the Diamond Path- Esoteric Art on the Trans-Himalayan Trade Route. UCLA Arts Council, 1982.
  • Konchog Lhadrepa, and Charlotte Davis. The Art of Awakening: A User’s Guide to Tibetan Buddhist Art and Practice. Boulder: Snow Lion Publications, 2017.
  • Linrothe, Rob (Ed.) Collecting Paradise. Buddhist Art of Kashmir and Its Legacies, edited by Rob Linrothe. New York & Evanston: Rubin Museum of Art, 2014.
  • Linrothe, Rob and Jeff Watt. Demonic Divine- Himalayan Art and Beyond. Rubin Museum of Art, NY, Chicago: Serindia Publications, 2004. 
  • Lo Bue, Erberto F. “The Newar Artists of the Nepal Valley: A Historical Account of Their Activities in Neighbouring Areas with Particular Reference to Tibet.” Oriental Art 31.3 (1985): 262–277.
  • Lo Bue, Erberto F. “Cultural Exchange and Social Interaction between Tibetans and Newars from the Seventh to the Twentieth Century.” International Folklore Review 6 (1988): 86–114.
  • Luczanits, Christian. “From Tabo to Alchi: Revisiting Early Western Himalayan Art”, Orientations 51, no. 5 (2020): 36-47.
  • Luczanits, Christian. “Revival and Renaissance in Tibetan Art: Imagining Kashmir and Nepal in the Fifteenth and Seventeenth Centuries”, European Bulletin of Himalayan Research 52, (2018): 93-131.
  • Luczanits, Christian. Buddhist Sculptures in Clay- Early Western Himalayan Art, Late 10th to early 13th centuries. Chicago: Serindia Publications, 2004. 
  • Meister, Michael. “Mountain Temples and Temple-Mountains: Masrur” Journal of the Society of Architectural Historians, Vol. 65. No. 1 (March 2006), 26-49.
  • Samuel, Geoffrey. Civilised Shamans: Buddhism in Tibetan Societies
  • Samuel, Geoffrey. The Origins of Yoga and Tantra: Indic Religions to the 13th century, Cambridge University Press, 2013.
  • Pal, Pratapaditya. Art from India, Nepal and Tibet, Philip Wilson Publishers Ltd., 2001.
  • Siudmak, John.  The Hindu-Buddhist Sculpture of Ancient Kashmir and its Influences. Brill, 2013.
  • Snellgrove, David L. The Cultural Heritage of Ladakh. Warminster: Aris & Phillips, 1977. 
  • Snellgrove, David L. Indo-Tibetan Buddhism. Indian Buddhists and their Tibetan Successors. London: Serindia, 1987.
  • Tucci, Giuseppe. Indo-Tibetica Series Vols. 1-7. Ed. Lokesh Chandra. New Delhi: Aditya Prakashan, 1988.
Grading Rubric

Students will be graded on the basis of active participation in class seminars and on written assignments.

  • Continuous assessment in classes/ Seminar Participation: 20%
  • Four art historical notes on chosen site/ sculpture/ painting (300 words each): 40%
  • End Semester essay (2000-2500 words including footnotes, bibliography): 40%
Attendance Policy

Three absences are permitted.

However, since grading will be based on continuous assessment through the semester, absences during seminars and presentations will result in a reduction in the overall grade.

title: BORDERLANDS: TOWARDS A SPATIAL HISTORY OF EMPIRE
description:
Borderlands: Towards a Spatial History of Empire [HIS-3516/ SOA-3514/ CHI-3203/ IR-3028] [HIS-3516/ SOA-3514/ CHI-3203/ IR-3028-1]

Faculty Name
Sayantani Mukherjee [sayantani.mukherjee@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

What is the violence of a line drawn upon a map? Or on a terrain? How are people produced by such mapping? What anxieties drive the imperial cartographic impulse? What pressures does terra nullis exert in situ? What do the bodies produced in mapped territories look like? What bodies exist in unmapped terrains? What is the relationship between wonder/amazement, and control/annihilation? Where do we locate ourselves as scholars reading these maps? What maps are visible when we visit the landscape? How are narratives produced against maps? How are histories made visible in terrain?

These questions will guide us as we traverse a theoretical terrain of writings on space and territory, and situate ourselves in specific historical moments of imperial mastery over space. We will cover a lot of ground temporally but our geographic focus will be South and East Asia. In this class we will develop skills in reading and understanding the genre of the academic monograph; in understanding how they relate to each other; and in analyzing the theoretical and methodological bases and trends of these works.

Learning Outcomes

Summarize academic monographs in South and East Asian studies and introduce salient points in notes and in speech.

Be able to draw connections between works to gain an overview of scholarly and historiographical debates.

Be able to trace theoretical or methodological trends across multiple empirical contexts.

Analyze and present in writing your interpretation of the role of space and place in a geographical region relevant to your work or interest.

Learn the skills of co-writing and co-presenting to gain a sense of how cooperative work can integrate intellectual property as well as collective clarity.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

You are not required to purchase any materials for this course. All readings will be provided in PDF via email.

Grading Rubric

Assessment & Assignments:

40% - Leading weekly discussion in class and participating in class discussions

60% - Carto-Paper (Optional Team Project)

Attendance, Participation and Discussion Etiquette :

I will not take attendance in each class meeting, however, participation in weekly class discussions is a mandatory part of your grade and is necessary for succeeding in the course. If you have circumstances that might affect attendance at a specific class meeting, please let me know ahead of time whenever possible. Flexibility is especially important since Covid is still with us. To protect your privacy, please do not describe any medical situations to me; just inform me that the situation exists and be prepared to provide a doctor’s note if requested.

 

Participation is part of your grade, and should be based on attentive reading, listening, and preparation. Participation can take many forms. Always keep an open mind and be respectful of your classmates and your instructor regardless of what you wish to say, or whether you agree with what has already been said. Being respectful also means that (1) if you have not completed a particular reading, please refrain from commenting on it (2) in the normal course of discussion, if you have just spoken, you should refrain from speaking again until others who wish to contribute have done so (3) contributions to discussion should be based on the readings, lectures, and discussion questions, and should aim to improve our collective understanding of them. In general, please avoid unstructured/unsupported reflections as well as topics that are beyond the scope of the course.

 

Class lead:

One student per week (both Tuesday and Thursday) will introduce the assigned readings for that week (~10 mins) and facilitate discussion for the rest of the class. Try to keep your presentation to under ten minutes, and use the time to provide a short summary of one or two of the assigned texts, and present to the class your own questions and ideas about the theme through the readings. This exercise will help you condense the readings to their core argument and thereby facilitate review before assignments are due. For this reason, it makes sense to approach every set of readings with a few basic questions: who is the author? What is his or her background? What kind of audience are they addressing? And what is the aim of the text? Is it a purely technical piece of writing or does it raise (or hide?) important political questions? These questions are very basic, but they will help you to structure your contribution to the class. If you would like to additionally discuss reading material or resources not on the reading list in your presentation, please feel free to discuss your ideas for the presentation with me beforehand. Following the week’s discussion, the class lead will collate all the notes for the assigned readings, to structure them into an annotated entry for each text we have read.

Carto-paper:

This assignment will be a 5500-6000 word (Times New Roman 12 pt. font, double-spaced, not including footnotes and bibliography) investigation of a single primary source relevant to the field of cartography, broadly construed: this can be a specific map, a surveyor’s field diary, an object history of a technical instrument, etc. Feel free to discuss your ideas or adjustments, if you prefer, for this project with me beforehand. You may also turn this into a collaborative project if you wish. Your carto-paper is due 11.59 pm May 14, by email to me. We will be discussing two drafts of your paper as a class. These two drafts are due on Monday 11.59 pm February 20 and April 3, by email. Following your submissions, we will intensively workshop everyone’s paper as a group. In these group discussions, you will be expected to have read your peers’ work (as you would when you will attend conferences, workshops, and panel discussions), and offer constructive feedback to help your peers make progress on their projects. Your participation in these discussions will count towards your final grade for the carto-paper.

These essays are an important way to develop your writing skills—particularly the formation of a clear and logical argument, the mobilization of evidence, and the quality of prose. Your essays are intended to help you build the specific skill of making a historical argument, and to that end they should be erudite, specific, supportable and argumentative—not an unstructured reflection, opinion, or summary. They must refer, when needed, to the readings with citations.

 

Late submissions will not be accepted. If you anticipate that for any reason you will be unable to make these deadlines, please email me at least 48 hours in advance for an extension.

 

Your essays must aim to illuminate the texts you have chosen to discuss, rather than simply critique them or identify the gaps in the knowledge of the authors. The effectiveness of your arguments will rest on your plausible articulation of positions and paradigms of thinking that you may be unfamiliar or even disagree with. Thus, both your essays and the feedback you offer your peers should attempt to first reconstruct the carefully considered and rigorously formulated thoughts and arguments of the authors you are reading, before seeking to push that comprehension in a new direction.

Attachment
Borderlands 2023 syllabus and weekly schedule.docx

fullName: VA-3018/MS-2239, ON PHOTOGRAPHY: HISTORIES, THEORIES, PRACTICE, SRAMAN MUKHERJEE AND RAKHI PESWANI
title: ON PHOTOGRAPHY: HISTORIES, THEORIES, PRACTICE, SRAMAN MUKHERJEE AND RAKHI PESWANI,
description:
On Photography: Histories, Theories, and Practices [VA-3018/ MS-2239/ SOA-3106] [VA-3018/ MS-2239/ SOA-3106-1]

Faculty Name
Rakhi Peswani [rakhi.peswani@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sraman Mukherjee [sraman.mukherjee@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course will bring together image making histories, concerns, theories and practices, based on photographic techniques and technologies. The course will comprehensively introduce
proto-photographic methods and re-trace those with modern and contemporary material as well as some nineteenth and twentieth century cultural reactions and theories of photographic
image-forms. Considering its interdisciplinary nature, the media of photography will be introduced and explored through its social and cultural histories, contemporary usage as well as creative possibilities, bringing in perspectives from Art History, Visual Culture as well as artistic practice of the form.

Detailed description: 

Instructors: Rakhi Peswani, Sraman Mukherjee

Class timing: Monday and Wednesday – 11:50 am -1:20pm  

Course Pre-requisites for students (if any) :Curiosity and interest in photography history or practices. Any VA practice courses whether elective or gateway, preferred. Media Studies students with an interest in still photography are encouraged to apply as well.

Details of Course Modules along with readings for every module:

Module 1: Proto-photography techniques and histories:

This module will emphasise the early techniques and technologies that led to the invention of the photographic camera as we know it.

Various histories of image making will be excavated to understand the concepts of photography.

This module will also delve into the interdisciplinary nature of photography, the relation of art and science, its quality of light sensitivity, differences in technique and  technology, and the  impact photography had in shaping global modernity.  

      Proto-photography and various techniques of image making:

Fading of a color or a surface due to light as reaction or creation of an image due to light sensitivity.

Camera Obscura

Camera Lucida

Proto-photographic methods and image making in oil painting- development of Single Point (Linear) Perspective.

Linear perspective and development of photography

Tableaux Vivant for painting- history painting, Caravaggio and baroque light.

Shroud of Turin and the ‘miraculous’ image form.

Readings:

Mike Ware- Proto Photography and the Shroud of Turin

Peter Galassi – Before Photography

Artists’ references:

Single Point Perspective-

Some paintings, drawings and images of Masaccio, Giotto, Durer, Raphael, Caravaggio,

Cyanotype and Daguerreotype:

Anna Atkins, Henry Talbot- Cyanotypes. Louise Daguerre.

             Practice exercise :

Practice Workshop - Making Cyanotype images.

1 day- 3 hours. VA studio.

Assignment 1, create 4-5 image forms using any one or two proto-photographic methods introduced in class. 

The assignment will be based on experimenting and producing images with the aid of tools that seemingly appear familiar or simplistic.

Use some or any of the methods as tools to create 4-5 images and reflect (write an essay) on the experience, technique the outcome of the images, especially considering what are the significant markers of making images in such ways? what kind of aesthetic attitude or aesthetic form does such a method entail? 

Alternate assignment  – Cyanotype workshop exploring photo-chemicals and sun exposures to create image forms.

(Considerations of Dark room, safe light, 2 D and 3D image forms, imagination and image creation. )

Module 2: Photography as Representation and as Reproduction

This module will explore early and mid 20th C photography, through its defiing features of reproduction and representation.

Both these tropes will be explored to understand how photographic images played a role in the political, social, cultural shaping of individuality, modernity, urbanism, and nationalism. 

Readings:

Walter Benjamin (1931) - Little History of Photography

Walter Benjamin (1936) – The Work of Art in the Age of Mechanical Reproduction

Artists References:

Louise Dagguere, Edward Muybridge, Henry talbot, Karl Blossfeldt, David Octavius Hill, Julia Margaret Cameron, Victor Hugo, Felix Nadar., August Sander, Man Ray, Laslo Moholy Nagy,  Sasha Stone, Henri Cartier Bresson, Eugene Atget, Raghu Rai,

Practice exercise :

Assignment 2: Making a Photo Essay-

Representation, Reproduction, Sequentiality and Narration 

Using some of the most basic aspects of photographic form, representation and reproduction, construct a sequential arrangement of photo images that shape a narrative of your choosing. 

Early Photography had its claim in indexicality- a 'true' 'impression' of an object or event that has existed in front of the camera lens. While photographic images stand for real/truth of an image, ie, 'this exists' in a moment in time, it is also a framing device; it is an apparatus that lends itself to re-presentation and reproduction of an image. 

While a still image captures the fleeting momentary aspect of a world we live in, it represents this moment in specific ways. It reproduces this moment, frames it and imbues it with the subjectivity of the photographer. 

It is this aspect of photography that this assignment explores, especially in relation to early photographic folios, albums and other incunabula as Walter Benjamin points out to us.

Note:  Sequentiality and Repetition could be utilised to hold certain directorial vision or poetic aspects to the narrative. Also you could utilise the inherent qualities of a photograph- that a photograph manages to capture a fleeting moment of a second (shutter speeds), as well as varying qualities of light (aperture);  it captures certain frames that human eye cannot capture, including a point of view where human eye may not be able to reach.) 

Module 3: Photography and Identities:

This module will address the complex lines of the real and the fictional in relation to photographic images. The two readings will address the forms and formations of identity and the political nature of representation, distribution and circulation of photographic images.

The module will emphasise on aspects of photography that spill into the amateur, the cinematic, and the everyday. Its ubiquitous aspects will be explored through various lenses.

The practice exercise will be a way for students to address the complex space of creating meanings and identities through photographs.

            Tableaux Vivant and Photography.   

Photography and Anthropology,

Archival Practices and Photography.

Artists References:

Hippolyte Bayard,  Marcel Duchamp, Homai Vyarawalla, Helmut Newton, N. Pushpamala, Cindy Sherman, Sheba Chachi, Annie Leibovitz, Robert Mapplethorpe, Jitish Kallat

Readings:

            Christopher Pinney  (1997) - Camera Indica          Chapter- Chamber of Dreams

            Susan Sontag   (1973)           On Photography          Chapter- On Melancholy

Practice exercise:

Assignment 3: Shifting from the premise of photography as that representing a reality, create a series of images that provide a convincing impression of a construction and framing of a tableau. Use lights, props, models, or any required additional elements to create a ‘subject’ of description through photography.

Bibliography of further readings

Additional reading:

Roland Barthes (1980)-  Camera Lucida- Reflections on Photography

Christopher Pinney (2004): Photos of the Gods : The Printed Image and Political Struggle in India

Susan Sontag (1977)-  On Photography

John Berger (1972) – Ways of Seeing

 Aileen Blaney and Chinar Shah (2018): Photography in India from archives to Contemporary Practice

Details of grading rubric

Cumulative grading through three assignments. 

Each assignment will have components of practice plus one written essay based on a verbal or image prompt (Time frame : 4 weeks for each assignment.)

Each assignment will have a historical and theoretical framework to generate creative and investigative processes in the assignment.

Each assignment will have modules of a written essay and a practice oriented work. The rubrics will be : 

40% practice
