fullName: CHI-3204, STONE, PAPER, BAMBOO, SILK: SINOPHONE TEXTUAL CULTURES, ELOISE WRIGHT
title: STONE, PAPER, BAMBOO, SILK: SINOPHONE TEXTUAL CULTURES,
description:
Stone, Paper, Bamboo, Silk: Sinophone Textual Cultures [HIS-3513/ CHI-3204/ VA-3027/ ENG-3413] [HIS-3513/ CHI-3204/ VA-3027/ ENG-3413-1]

Faculty Name
Eloise Wright [eloise.wright@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Today, when so much of our daily communication occurs via text or email, it can be difficult to imagine a world in which writing was the preserve of a tiny minority. Chinese characters are frequently cited as the oldest continuous written tradition, beginning over three thousand years ago, but in that time the physical form of the characters and the materials they were written on have transformed over and over again. We will consider what questions these problems raise for historians' use of textual sources by looking at writing as a social, material, and political act. What were the symbolic meanings attributed to writings that most people could not understand? What practical uses could writing serve? How did access to writing intersect with other social hierarchies, like gender and class? Beginning with the invention of writing in the Yellow River region, we will discuss problems such as: the relationship between speech and writing; changes in writing materials; writing for display and writing for use; censorship; Chinese characters in non-Chinese societies; and debates over script reform.

The written assessment for this class will build towards a final research paper on a topic of the students' choice.

title: STORYTELLING IN THE DIGITAL AGE
description:
Storytelling in the Digital Age [MS-3051/ CW-2051/ VA-2015] [MS-3051/ CW-2051/ VA-2015-1]

Faculty Name
Natasha Badhwar [natasha.badhwar@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This course will focus on the creative process of using digital technology as a medium and a tool of narrating personal histories. We will create podcasts and videos using apps and software, but more importantly our own talent and skill with scripting, drawing, interview, monologue, multimedia visualization, videography, design and editing. 


AIM: The aim of this course is two-fold. Students will experiment with form using multimedia tools to combine audio, images, and video clips to tell a story. They will learn to create digital stories that explain a concept, make an argument, reflect on a personal experience and retell a family or community history. 
Through workshops and targeted assignments, each student will be encouraged to craft personal narratives that delve into conflicts of identity and privilege and lead to a deeper understanding of one’s own location in the intersecting grid of socio-economic, cultural as well as political hierarchies that dominate the times we live in. 

 

 

 

Learning Outcomes

Through practical exercises, writing and collective brainstorming, students will get familiar with both form and content of digital storytelling. They will acquire multimedia skills as well as engage in critical thinking and analysis as they complete their final projects for this course.

title: INTRODUCTION TO AUDIO VIDEO PRODUCTION
description:
Introduction to Audio Visual Production [MS-1001/ VA-2014] [MS-1001/ VA-2014-1]

Faculty Name
A K Ranjit [ak.ranjit@ashoka.edu.in] ,Kiran Singh [kiran.singh_asp23@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

This is an introductory technical course on audio-visual media; students will learn to listen, watch and create audio-visual stories of their own. This includes an introduction to handling audio and video recording systems. From microphones to cameras, basic audio and video editing. The course would begin with a brief introduction of the various roles required to be taken up for the smooth running of a studio. We will cover camera handling and basic techniques to take good-quality videos. We learn about the kinds of different microphones and where and when to use which one. While learning audio and video, we will simultaneously begin basic editing to stitch together the shots and audio samples we take. Gradually we get into more nuanced editing techniques followed by studio lighting.

 

 

Learning Outcomes

Media Literacy on how to hear & watch media in the audio-visual format, separately and together.

- Comprehending basic camera operations.

-  Lighting Technique

- Basic Audio-Video Editing tools like Adobe Premiere, Adobe Audition

- Sound and Video recording

- Constructing an audio and audio-visual narrative from end to end

- Mastering fundamental elements of storytelling from scripting to logging, from production to preview.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The student has to think beyond the box with empirical planning of implementing it onscreen with time limits.

The students will have to submit three assignments throughout the semester. The First and Second assignments will be done in groups, and the Final assignment will be individual. The exact details of the assignment will be shared during the class.

title: COMMUNICATION THEORY AND BEHAVIORAL CHNGE
description:
Communication Theory and Behavioral Change [MS-3210/ PSY-3141/ VA-3020] [MS-3210/ PSY-3141/ VA-3020-1]

Faculty Name
Purnima Mehrotra [purnima.mehrotra@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

“There is nothing so practical as a good theory.”— Social psychologist Kurt Lewin


We live in an era in which the processes of content production and the patterns of media consumption are changing rapidly. Even the most  seasoned media professionals are struggling to determine what the media landscape of the future will look like and what business models can be
used to support it.  It is in times like these when theories of mass communication are particularly valuable.  The broadly explanatory concepts of theory help us understand some of the underlying ways in which humans respond to and share different types of information, and can help us make some informed predictions about what the future may hold. This course will introduce students to mass communication theory, and will focuses on theories of audience and effect. This class will provide you with an overview of some of the important theories in the field, and
will encourage you to think about how these apply to the real world and how they will inform your future work, perhaps, as a media professional.

This course is cross-listed with Psychology as the two disciplines are closely related. Some studies that are considered seminal in the field of communication were originally conducted by psychologists, e.g. works by Hovland, Bandura, Lasswell, Lewin, Festinger and Fishbein. The two disciplines continue to enrich and enhance each other such that there are many common publication platforms, partnerships among scholars, and common faculty across departments. In terms of the historical evolution of the two fields psychology is an older and more established discipline than communication, hence communication continues to draw on the more consolidated approaches of psychology.


 

 

 

Learning Outcomes

Learning Outcomes

Understand the historical development of Mass Communication theories and how they link with historically important social, political and technological developments in the field of communication

Develop an understanding of the most often used theories of mass communication and the ability to apply them in research and practice

Critically evaluate theories as applied to practical mass communication problems e.g. media portrayals of sex and violence

Understand how mass communication is a powerful tool of persuasion and how it has been and continues to be used across sectors - adverstising, politics, development etc.

 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Reading materials will be shared with students at the beginning of the semester either as a compendium for the entire semester or in batches arranged according to major theoretical traditions in communication theory.

Some easy reads that students might find useful:

A First Look at Communication Theory by EM Griffin

Mass Communication Theory by Dennis McQuail

Grading Rubric

Class participation:                                                                                                   15%
Brief written critique of selected readings/quiz/other weekly assignments:              20%
Presentations:                                                                                                          20%
Mid-term paper:                                                                                                        20%
Final paper:                                                                                                              25%

Attendance Policy

Students should not miss more than 2 class sessions as we will cover a lot of material in each session. Too many absences will impede your ability to follow, learn and absorb the material. For any absences, students are required to notify the instructor.

title: GENDER LENS REPORTING
description:
Gender Lens Reporting [MS-2115/ VA-2012] [MS-2115/ VA-2012-1]

Faculty Name
Neha Dixit [neha.dixit@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

MONDAY WEDNESDAY 15:00- 16:30  Neha Dixit

Patriarchal agendas still form the bedrock of public discourse. Media outlets refuse to treat marginalised genders as equal participants in the nation and its politics.  

Many news organisations believe that they are pulling their weight because they publish a few pieces that cater to gender – the odd inspirational business story, something about reproductive health, the occasional report of domestic or sexual assault, harassment, violence, government schemes or aid for the trans community. 

So, how can we begin to fix this problem? The answer is that we can apply something known as a gender lens. A gender lens is not a tangible object; it is a way of looking at things, a means to critically assess a wide range of social and political situations, to see how gender-inclusive or gender-sensitive they are.

It highlights the difference in interests for various genders– within the same household, state, country, or globally – and also shows how they interact.

 Simply put, it is like a pair of spectacles that correct the prevailing view of marginalised genders and their place in the world.

In this course, you will learn how across the global media, gender stereotypes are used to trivialise, objectify and sexualise. With the application of the gender lens, you will be provided with a viewfinder that filters all of that out and exposes the roots of inequality. It will help the students place the spotlight on the realities, needs and perceptions of all genders. 

With a few exceptions 'gender issues' are always seen as exclusive of the wider world of economics, politics, sport and current affairs. This class will study reportage on women, men, and LGBTQI issues from an intersectional perspective, as tempered by race, ethnicity, nationality, caste and class – as well as other factors such as religion, culture and ideology. Through, news reports, films, exercises, field trips, seminars, and discussions, the students will learn how to cover essential stories – be they of war, poverty, or crime – objectively and responsibly, by looking for the intersections of gender and these “bigger” issues. The students will be taught how to use these intersections to write ground reports, narrative pieces and profiles. 

Two field trips are included in this course

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Prerequisite:  Student should have done either the Media Studies Course - Introduction to Newswriting and Reporting

OR 

Any other Gender based course (offered by any department at Ashoka, in any of the semesters before this Spring semester. Please see list attached in AMS under Gender Lens Reporting Course details)

title: DECORATIVE ARTS: HISTORY AND AGENCY OF THE ORNAMENTAL
description:
Decorative Arts: History and Agency of the Ornamental [VA-3030] [VA-3030-1]

Faculty Name
Saumya Agarwal [saumya.agarwal@ashoka.edu.in] ;
Overview

Course Name: Decorative Arts: History and Agency of the Ornamental

Instructor: Saumya Agarwal

Level 1000/2000/3000 for Visual Arts

Course Code: VA-3030

Elective Course

Prerequisites: None

Course description:

The decorative arts, or applied arts as they were known in the nineteenth century, constitute a variety of visual and material artefacts whose primary purpose is display and an enhancement of aesthetic appeal of a space, another image, or object. Ranging from wall paintings; frames of other works of art; as well as prestige objects displayed in interior spaces, decorative art, is intended to elicit a range of emotional responses including facilitating attachment and inducing awe or pleasure. An important analytical approach to the decorative thus involves the study of affect and agency. Such an approach takes art analysis beyond semiotics and towards cognition. This course, by exploring the decorative in a variety of socio-historical contexts, seeks to interrogate and complicate the binary between high and decorative art while underlining the different analytical approach required to understand the peculiarities of the decorative. Even as divisions between high and decorative art, or fine and applied arts, exist in art historical analysis, often objects and images themselves cross these boundaries. Many art objects are simultaneously decorative or become decorative objects as their context and use shifts. For instance, when Mughal miniature art, meant to be viewed in albums (muraqqa), is used to decorate the ceiling of an audience room in the Schönbrunn Palace in Vienna in the 18th century its modes of viewing and meaning making change. Similarly, when painters in Madhubani in Bihar start painting ritual art on paper thereby creating portable and marketable objects of display, there is a shift in motifs, content and form. This course will thus situate and explore the category of the decorative, and its agency, in a range of socio-historical contexts.

How do wall paintings decorating houses in Rajasthan facilitate placemaking for a peripatetic merchant community? How was the category of applied arts used to construct the colony during the world exhibitions of the nineteenth century? How do contemporary artists negotiate the art market and the demand for works of art in the heavily curated space of the elite ‘drawing room’? How do decorative margins or hashiyas constitute or even subvert the meaning of a Mughal miniature? How do ideas of ‘aesthetics’ and ‘taste’ shape the decorative? What is the nature of the resistance that geometrical patterns pose to formal analysis and how does one approach the apotropaic and ritual aspects of the decorative? These are some of the questions that this course seeks to address while engaging with aesthetic theories from a variety of cultural contexts to understand the agency of the decorative from a transcultural perspective.

An important element of this course will involve practical engagement with the decorative through field visits to Lodhi Art District to experience wall murals in the city. Other field visits include a trip to the National Crafts Museum, as well as the studio of a contemporary artist. An extensive exploration of the painted towns of Shekhawati, through the photographic collection of the instructor, will also be part of the course. An innovative assignment will involve students engaging with the decorative in their immediate environment of the campus and the home.

 

Course Modules:

The Ontology of the Decorative:

The course begins with exploring the very nature of the decorative. This involves approaching it through the heuristic lens of cognition and the agency of art, based primarily on works by EH Gombrich (1979) and Alfred Gell (1998). Such an approach shifts the focus away from an interpretation of the semiotics of images and hierarchies of aesthetic appreciation to an analysis of affect, agency and psychological impact of the decorative on the observer. This will be discussed through concepts linked to cognitive anthropology (Severi 2004); agency of art objects (Gell 1998); and corpothetics (Pinney 2004).

There will also be an emphasis on understanding surfaces (Wigley 1995), as well as a brief segue into an exploration of the affective role of colour both from a philosophical and historical context (Taussig 2006; Eaton 2017).

The Decorative in the European Context:

This module will explore the category of the decorative through a range of historical contexts. We will first trace the emergence of the category of the ‘decorative arts’ or ‘applied arts’ in the European context. This will involve brief overviews of art movements associated with the ornamental, such as Baroque to Art Nouveau and Art Deco; covering, thus, a time period from the seventeenth century to the early twentieth century. A particular emphasis will be placed on exploring the links between applied arts and industrialization. In the exploration of Art Deco, in particular, interocularity between modes of depiction like cinema and decorative arts will be used to explore the aspect of gender.

The Decorative in the Colonial Context:

The focus on applied arts will allow the discussions to segue into an engagement with the arts of the colonies as ‘craft’/ applied arts, particularly as linked to world exhibitions that started in the middle of the nineteenth century (The Great Exhibition of 1851). We will also study more indigenous versions of the exhibition format, for instance, the Jaipur Exhibition of 1883, which was also titled “The Exhibition of Industrial and Decorative Arts”. This will allow for an exploration of the category of the decorative as it emerged in the nineteenth century with its links to setting up of art schools, commodification of the orient and emergence of the category of ‘craft’. This will provide an insight into early musealization practices, while exploring the reification of the division between high and decorative art. This module though will not only discuss how the ‘colony’ was consumed, but the multiple ways in which non-western societies consumed other ‘cultures’ through the framework of the decorative.

Beyond the Binaries: The Decorative in a Global Context:

This module places an exploration of the decorative in a more global context which would include decorative arts from Japan, Korea and South America. This will shift the binaries of locating historical explorations within the dichotomies of the colony and metropole thus allowing the students a wider perspective into the decorative arts.

The Social Life of Things: Metamorphosis of Art Objects

After exploring the decorative in a variety of historical contexts, this module will explore the change in meaning of objects and images as they travel from one cultural context to another. ‘Culture’ here would be approached through a range of spatial and temporal scales between boundaries of nations but also boundaries of the rural and urban. This would thus include mobility of images in instances such as when the pages from Mughal albums (muraqqa) were displayed in the millionenzimmer at the Schönbrunn Palace at Vienna in the eighteenth century. It would also include an exploration of instances when art from a ritual context, for instance the wall art of Madhubani, is transferred to a medium like paper and sold in urban spaces as decorative pieces. The metamorphosis of a range of images and objects, as they turn into commodities, decorative or fine art will be explored.

Intransigent Form of the Decorative? Non-figurative and the geometric in the ornamental:

With a focus on Islamic arts ranging from painted scrolls to architectural elements like muqarnas, this module will explore the formal aspect of the ornamental by focusing on the relationship between non-figurative and the decorative, for instance. This would also include exploring the role of the geometric in ornamentation, and the analytical framework required to approach the non-figurative through art-historical analysis.

Placemaking through the Decorative

As Alfred Gell has highlighted, the decorative is agentive because it facilitates a sense of attachment. Given this premise, this module will explore the nature and role of the decorative particularly in the context of public spaces. This would include an exploration of nineteenth and twentieth century wall paintings decorating buildings in Rajasthan (Shekhawati) as acts of place making by a peripatetic merchant community. This would also include an exploration of public art and graffiti in urban spaces. This module will thus explore the complex links between architecture; decorative art and perception as linked to ‘distracted’ modes of viewing. Since the onus on this module will be on the ‘affective’ potential of art, this will be further explored though concepts of reception theory like rasa and bhava.

Decorative Art in Contemporary Art Practices: Ideas of Taste

In this module we will explore the ostensible divide between ‘fine’ and ‘decorative’ arts through the various transformations that works of art undergo while negotiating the contemporary art market. The categories of ‘fine’ and ‘decorative’ art will be historicised while also being studied through the negotiations that contemporary artists, in the context of South Asia, have to make between demands of the art market, museums, as well as decorative/design pieces for the interiors of a private home, office or public space. The theoretical concepts of taste and aesthetics will guide this study into contemporary art and curatorial practices. An important element would be a visit to the studio space of a practising contemporary artist.

From the Margins: The Subversive Potential of the Decorative:

While an enquiry into the decorative has always been on the margins of art historical research, this module explores how the marginality of the ‘ornamental’ itself gives it immense subversive potential. This would include an exploration of hashiyas (margins) in illustrated Mughal manuscripts that have the potential to subvert the meaning of the main image as well as the text. This would also be explored through Buddhist relief sculpture, as well as through the “rhetoric of the frame” in a range of images and art objects. The decorative margins will also be explored from the purview of artistic practices, since often the decorative elements of a work were executed by individuals occupying a space of subalternity, thus becoming particularly compelling as spaces of expression that tend to be overlooked.

Learning Outcomes

Learning Outcomes:

Develop an understanding of visual culture beyond the traditional scope of art historical analysis.

Understand the historical developments which led to the reification of categories such as fine and decorative arts.

Develop analytical skills to engage with objects from a variety of contexts through a transcultural approach while learning about the histories of art in a range of socio-cultural contexts.

Becoming more familiar with inter-disciplinary enquiry by engaging with histories of art, visual culture, cognitive anthropology and sociology of aesthetic hierarchies.

Engagement with lived environments through the lens of cognition and agency of visual elements.

Introduction to contemporary art and curatorial practices.

Practise in writing research pieces on topics of art history and visual culture.

Grading Rubric

Grading Rubric

This course follows a pattern of continuous assessment and grading through the entire semester including active class participation and image analysis, and mid semester and end semester evaluations. The assessment and grading criterion are as follows:

1. Students will be assessed on basis on their active engagement with course contents during classes and after class office hours which will carry ten percent (10%) of the total course grades.

2. An art historical note (within a word limit of 600 to 700 words) on an image, object, site or theoretical concept will carry thirty percent (30%) of the total course grades.

3. The mid semester assessment will comprise of a class presentation based on any one image or theoretical concept chosen by the student in discussion with the instructor. The mid semester evaluation will carry twenty percent (20%) of the total course grades.

4. For the end semester evaluation we will write an essay between 2000 and 2500 words (including footnotes and bibliography). The topic of the end semester assessment has to be chosen by the student from a range of verbal text and visual image prompts provided by the course instructor. The end semester assessment will carry forty percent (40%) of the total course grades.

5. All submissions including field reports, mid semester and end semester papers have to be made electronically.

6. Plagiarism (intended or unintended) constitutes the most serious academic offence. Any act of plagiarism will be reported to the Academic Integrity Committee of the University and will attract punitive measures from grade cuts to failing the course. The first detection of plagiarism in any paper will result in grade cuts and reporting to the AIC. For repeat offense, students will be allotted a Fail grade for the entire course. Please go through the Academic Integrity document of Ashoka University to check what constitutes plagiarism and other forms of academic dishonesty. Specific citation styles for texts and images will be addressed by specific course instructors.

Attendance Policy

Attendance Policy

Three undocumented absences are permitted for the entire semester.
